column10:
I've started playing in NMS while it still had mixed reviews, and seeing how far Hello Games have come makes me very happy. So many new things, new features, upgrades of old parts, expansions, improvements. You can see that developers care for their game, and I hope there will be more and more updates, because when you think "well, there's no possible new things to add" - HG will drop something that you never expect but still very pleased to see and experience. 
I still think that NMS is not for everyone, esp. if you're not a fan of a little bit of grind, but give this game a try, esp. when it goes on free weekends! I thought I'd never like it, and here I am now, with 300+ hrs of gameplay and not planning to stop. 
Hell, this game was a reason why I bought new laptop, because old one was so clunky to boot it up, and I really-really wanted to spend more time playing NMS. It's kinda addictive once you got into it. 

Price may seem a bit overwhelming, but so many years of new added cool content for free, not in dozens of separate dlc packs, are totally worth it. And I  am not seeing HG stopping on what they have acheived.

This game from what it was to what it is today is like night and day, tons of content to plough through, game does it right with the side content, you can play for hours and still not touch the main quest line after getting your ship working again.

This game has so much time you can sink into it and youll still not really see it all.

If youre on the fence, just know this is a wiki game, there are also sneaky unethical ways to speed things up if you arent too patient. This game is worth it at full price and honestly is worth its weight in diamonds on a sale.

Easily the best game I've ever played. Consistent updates always keep the game fresh if it ever gets boring. It's essentially space GTA, without some of the more "M" rated features. The expeditions can make you feel accomplished and give you exclusive rewards if you want limited-time items and don't enjoy other features as much as this. The VR headset support makes this game a lot scarier.  If you want a different type of horror in virtual reality and a game you will want to play on PC too, this is definitely the game for you. While it's centered around exploration, a feature I do enjoy, you can do much, much more, ranging from becoming friendly with every extra-terrestrial race to becoming the literal space mafia. If you like building or architecture, you might like this, too. You have the ability to construct amazing bases and decorate them. The developers have turned this game from a disappointing lump of code into a masterpiece with millions of planets. You will always have enough to explore. There are 250+ galaxies, each with 1,000,000+ solar systems, each system having 1-6 planets or moons, and in total, there are a little over 15 QUINTILLION planets. So, all in all, this game can be very fun for many different types of people.

Updating my review again after coming back to see if anything's improved with the dogfighting -- NOPE.

Your enemies will still ignore the laws of physics and instantly do 180 turns and joust at you...to say nothing of their ridiculously tanky, fast recharging shields and nerfed weapons on your part.  If you don't value your time, you can trivialize fights anyway now by just backpedaling while they all line up in your sights, ironically cheesing the supposedly "improved" dogfighting AI.

Dogfights were one of my favorite parts of the game, and they used to be fun and dynamic -- maybe at times trivial and easy -- but never an annoying chore, but guess what they are now?

For someone who bought NMS recently, ignore this review. Play the game and have fun.

I share the opinion of those who played the game for a very long time. The developer destroyed hundreds of hours of work and collections and achievements and explorations. Everything lost.

In addition, you have to start a new separated game, for every new feature (Expeditions). Thumbs down until they merge everything together?

Is it worth playing? I play it a lot, every expedition I jump in again.
There's a lot of content but there are also problems.
Like the terrible UI, the quest log has a weird delay, there's button holding all the time, time gating (multiple 24hs with void egg) Quest design is kinda meh. Lack of proper mapping in a space game, getiing back to a place with no base is tough.
Wonky combat and lots of RNG and grinding.
But there's good stuff. Base building, customization. Hunting for a perfect paradise planer unspoiled by other players with fauna, flora and pretty coloring. Naming stuff. Hunting for pretty ships. Hunting for cool animals.
Incremental efforts, breaking the game system for lots of credits. Upgrading your gear, hunting for rare items. 
A ton of content. Build a mech, raid a space hulk, smuggle cargo, help a settlement.
It annoys me a lot but I keep coming back.
it's so addictive, no cap

this game is a downright wonderful space exploration-themed sandbox. im especially in love with the terrain manipulation (think of it like hd minecraft) and base construction. each planet is uniquely beautiful, and the experience of exploring them for yourself and claiming one as a home, where nobody else has touched, is a magnificent experience that puts it above other exploration sandbox games.

Maybe this will put it into perspective:

I bought a hunting game that was on sale for $4.
The game is usually $40
The game is 70GB

I  bought this game on sale for $30
the game is usually $60.
This game is 15GB

Needless to say, I am lightyears happier with this game, not to say that hunting and space exploration are comparable, but i spent way more on this game and am a million times happier. It takes a lot to have a game worth $4 be disappointing, but it doesnt take much for a $30 game to be disappointing. This game is incredible. I cannot recommend it enough.
the possibilities are endless!! and the updates are great!!

Do not buy. Straight up do not buy.

I caved in after 8 years of laughing and my God, I would've been better off saving my money. Not only is the game boring with repetitive missions and the exact two types of space stations (normal and pirate base) in every inhabited solar system, but the way how things like game mechanics, from missions to just trying to buying or selling equipment, are handled and the bugs are just unacceptable.

For starters, the very start of the game is just a slog of a tutorial that has you run on a planet for 30 minutes. Alright fair enough, a slow introduction and time to admire the world. Then you get your first ship off the ground and you think you're good to go. lmao nope. The game then proceeds to spam tutorials, mission and build instructions left and right. Okay, so you suddenly have a settlement you absolutely didn't even want but the game doesn't give you an option to decline and be done with the quest. What's that? You want another star ship? Alright then, first you just have to cough up a few million Units (one of the currencies in the game). You scrape enough money for some ship, [i]any[/i] ship, but it's not enough. Don't worry, you can trade in your old ship to get a new one! So then you find one that has more space than your old ship and you go for it because you're just begging for more inventory space. That's cool, just remember to empty out your cargo and your upgrades, otherwise you straight up lose all of them!

Skip forwards by about 20 hours, you finally figure out that you can scavenge some ship from wrecks if you're lucky. You pile up a few of them, fix them up enough so that they can fly and you wanna sell them. You sell ships by taking them to a space station and salvaging them, which actually gives you a pile of items which you have to sell. Fair enough. Wanna sell another one but [b]not[/b] the ship the game decided to default on? Okay, just walk to the other side of the hangar to use a portal, teleport to your base, call in the ship you want to sell, go back through the portal to the space station and back to the salvaging station. That's gonna take you about two minutes and two loading screens and that's as efficient as you're gonna be when "selling" starships. Because you can't change your ship while in a space station and there's no menu to select which ship you want to fiddle with. This is the kind of hoop-jumping you'll have to deal with.

By this point, you will have learned a few key facts about this game, including but not limited to:

-exploring planets becomes an annoying repetitive chore after 15 planets (especially if you try to truly 100% a planet, which will then require you to scan ever single rock and leaf while not highlighting anything un-scanned besides animals),

-space battles are always the same nausea-inducing garbage: the enemy rushes and flies by you, does some fancy maneuvers and if you use target lock-on, your ship will spend about 2/3 of your life just spinning around trying to even see the target, during which they tend have turned around and come at you again, repeating the process,

-trading becomes a game of buying goods from a shop of a space station, jumping through a portal from that station to another, selling the goods from the first station, buying the new goods the locals are selling, repeat,

-finding any sort of upgrade to anything is just luck, because there are no ship shops, starships must be bought or traded for in stations and platforms or scavenged, and you're just buying pigs in bags when you try to shop for weapon and equipment upgrades, as the stats are not shown until you have them installed,

-the largest amount of population you'll see in the galaxy is in space stations, the best the rest of the universe has to offer are trade platforms on planets, the next best thing you'll get are outposts that populate up to two NPCs so the universe is still quite barren,

-you're not allowed to be neat because there is no sorting or searching of any kind: no inventory sorting, no searching for something specific in the Catalogue (basically an index of all the knowledge you've discovered, from crafting recipes to trade items and from animals to solar systems), none of that. the best you can do is go through your caches and just throw anything anywhere and hope to Gabe you spot what you need when the need arises and

-you will come across some obscure limitations like not being able to build a house in the settlement that was forced upon you. Just to name a few things.

Even during the event where I got to play the game for free, a mission required you to fly through a black hole. Easy enough, right up until the black hole didn't work. Saw about a dozen people having the same problem with the same hole. But fear not, apparently it caught up to me for some unknown reason not 15 minutes ago as of writing this review. Made my way to the center of the galaxy, ~3,000 light years away on the closest solar system I was able to get to, decided to go check the Anomaly (a big-ass space station you can just call in because reasons), tried to fly back outside, WHOOPS, the game decided that I actually wanted to warp [b]700,000 LIGHT YEARS AWAY TO A SECTOR I LEFT THREE HOURS AGO![/b]

This is straight up atrocious. Once I'm done with this pile of junk, I'll happily continue laughing at this game and people who support it.
This game is great

I can hardly believe how far this game has come since its release - and it is still being given large, quality updates on a somewhat regular basis, including a fully implemented VR mode that can be played alongside non-VR players (although even a high-end GPU will struggle to maintain 90+ FPS at anything above medium (i.e. 'enhanced') settings).

Whether No Man's Sky was worth the price a few years ago is debatable, but $60 is certainly a more reasonable asking price now, considering all of the additional stuff the developers have managed to shove into the game - even more so on sale.

I've been playing this game on the Xbox for years now. I have not enjoyed a game more since the old days of Quake, and Unreal Tournament. Updates are free, and massive in size and scope.

No Man's Sky isn't just a game; it's a testament to the power of redemption and the unyielding spirit of game development. After a turbulent launch, Hello Games has transformed this once controversial title into an interstellar masterpiece that continues to evolve with every update. With over 1500 hours invested, I can confidently say that No Man's Sky has become my virtual home away from home, a boundless universe brimming with endless possibilities and uncharted wonders.

From the moment you step foot onto your first procedurally generated planet, you're enveloped in a sense of awe and wonder that never ceases to diminish. Each celestial body you encounter is a unique tapestry of landscapes, flora, and fauna, waiting to be explored and cataloged. Whether you're scaling towering mountains, delving into the depths of ancient ruins, or engaging in dogfights amidst asteroid fields, every moment feels like a grand adventure waiting to unfold.

But what truly sets No Man's Sky apart is its commitment to continuous improvement. Hello Games has tirelessly listened to feedback from the community and has consistently delivered updates that not only address existing issues but also introduce groundbreaking features that push the boundaries of the gaming experience. From the expansive multiplayer overhaul of Beyond to the ambitious living ship update of Desolation, each new iteration feels like a love letter to the dedicated fanbase that has stood by the game since its inception.

Moreover, the sense of community fostered within No Man's Sky is unparalleled. Whether you're embarking on epic expeditions with friends or stumbling upon the intricate bases of fellow travelers, the game seamlessly weaves together the shared experiences of players from around the globe. It's this sense of camaraderie that transforms No Man's Sky from a solitary journey into a collaborative odyssey that transcends the confines of the digital realm.

As I reflect on my hours spent traversing the cosmos, I'm filled with gratitude for the incredible journey that No Man's Sky has provided. It's a testament to the resilience of both the developers and the community, proving that even the most turbulent of launches can lead to greatness. So if you're seeking a game that promises boundless exploration, limitless adventure, and a universe teeming with possibility, look no further than No Man's Sky. Strap in, fellow travelers, for the stars await, and the journey has only just begun.

Played NMS in 2018 and had no performance issues, reinstalled it recently and was met by regular stuttering with CPU utilization spiking from 60% to ~90%. Tried every method i could find: updating drivers, modifing settings file (and setting it to read-only), switching processor scheduling to "Background services", turning off V-sync and lowering graphics settings to "Standard". Still experiencing stuttering at random moments, usually while looking at something in the distance or interacting with creatures.
Have seen people with more modern and powerful PCs complain about similar stuttering, so i don't think it is my computer's lack of power.

15 billion different-looking plants, animals, resources. All of them are harvested for maybe like  20 or 30 different elements. You've heard it a bunch of times: a thousand miles wide and 2 inches deep.

The game is honestly worth the money though because it entertained me for a good 30 hours. After that I realized how shallow the game is. Couple that with the fact that multiplayer is fake. You are ALL ALONE in the universe with one tiny hub where you actually see other players.

Overall:

* Great game, with the potential for states of mind from dogfighting to meditative
* The weather effects are great, and add a lot of *cough* atmosphere
* Great in VR - but with significant caveats that may be improved in future updates
* In VR, the UI panels also modelled as in-world objects, which is exactly the right way to do things
* The HUD, interestingly, doesn't move with your head, which turns out to be a good thing, because it gives you a point of reference into your physical world, and tends to keep you from winding your VR cables around the post of your rotating chair...   This would be nice to be a toggle for the 7 of you who might have a full wireless rig.
* While the game has lots of bugs, it also resolutely autosaves every time you exit your starship

I like the game a LOT, so keep that in mind while I complain below.  I'm playing in VR on the Valve Index

Things that could be better:

* Repetitious in some respects, starbases and buildings for common encounters need more randomization
* No option to skip the delay in NPC speech - I can't believe devs still think waiting word by word should be mandatory
* EPICALLY unrealistic flight physics. Seriously, the fastest way to a planet is straight down.  And if I'm trying to slowly circle an object on the ground, why does my ship end up 45 degree nose down crawl?  And, obviously, in dogfights it doesn't let you fly past the enemy, pivot and fire in the direction you're moving away from, even though that's how things work in space -- that being said, slow flight near to ground is nice, and has an esthetically pleasing smoothness when turning
* Hitting an object with your spacecraft often makes it go into full reverse and instantly hit something else... rinse, repeat, die
* Is space really orange some of the time?  You get a pass for steller cloud material, but just a blanket color other than black is nuts and makes me think my video driver is malfunctioning...
* Default controller map omits key abilities, especially being able to select color on items during construction, and to cycle through items during construction without going back to the build menu
* Can't even fiddle with my inventory while in a teleporter, so that time is essentially just wasted (sure, it still beats walking, but...)
* When in tornadic environments in a closed room, the winds will still lift you, move you around the room, and sometimes glitch you out of the room (at a corner?)... .then you're 100u up in the air trying to teleport-to-spot = ground, or brake your fall with the jetpack, etc.   One SHOULD be able to build a room wherein you're safe from hazardous wind conditions
* Fundamentally 2D control concept around positioning items you're building, even though just moving your hand out or in could have been used to control how far away the object would be

Things that really HAVE to get better:

* Default starship flight controls in (my) VR are the worst I've seen, ever, including issues with disabling themselves without warning, precession in the joystick [2024: better now]  controls that require literally throwing up your hands to detach from them [2023: deep in the steam controller bindings, there's a way to switch between contact and pressure for the Grip actuation] and then trying to reëstablish joystick mode while getting shot to bits in dogfights, and it's terrible choice to make squeezing toggle flight mode
* When using the teleport-to-target-spot model to move around, in many cases being able to just say "go there" by any means is good - however, the blue target circle does NOTHING to help you find the one tiny spot you can move to, which is especially maddening when trying to climb things.  It's also blocked by line of sight objects like furniture, which makes no sense

And bugs can be amazing...

* Falling to my death in lime-yellow shadow worlds while using teleporters
* Getting shunted on top of internal structures in space stations when a door closes on me (among other things) and having to try to find a place to glitch back into a room
* Falling to my death because the structures hadn't loaded yet after popping out of a teleporter
* Occasionally being on the wrong side of UI elements when opening/interacting with things
* UI elements being rotated with the frame of reference of the interaction object instead of being in my FoR (especially for chests on steep hillsides)
* Being able to build rooms in the freighter too close to the front of the ship, where only the aft half of them can be used because of some weird invisible wall

What the game needs in some future expansion

* I really love the idea of being able to build your own ship from parts bolted together like the buildings - and ESPECIALLY pillaged from other ships (so you can combine their styles in yours) - although given the flight physics being garbage I'm troubled by how the thrusters on such a lovely, Frankensteinian abomination might be completely nonsensical.  I want a gun in the BACK of my fighter, dammit.  I'd also like the outer parts of the ship to protect the inner parts, so that armor and shields, and the location of more expendable ship systems, would matter.  I'd like to be able to delegate flying/shooting/repair to crew members while I go do the thinks I enjoy more.  Finding a good pilot, gunner, etc, or developing his skills could be an interesting subplot. I'm not sure how the developers would really handle this since it looks like the freighters are modelled as locations, not ships.
* While scanning everything does earn some units and nanites (indirectly), it should have some impact on what a player can DO as well.  Scanning minerals should occasionally teach you how to make some new related compound.  Scanning beasts should perhaps lead to an ability to genetically engineer pets.  Scanning plants should occasionally grant you some new farmable plant to use.
* The logs should automatically memorize more things for you, particulary stargate coördinates for a planet where you find one, and (if inter-market trading is supposed to be thing) the going prices for goods in the buy-o-bots in each system.
* The settlement concept sounds like the beginning of some kind of civilization-building, which could be fascinating, and I'd love to interconnect them with teleporters between systems and have them make units for me while I try to figure out how to equip them for survival and profit.  I'm not asking for Dwarven Fortress here - their fortresses die far too easily - or just the cats all die mysteriously...

Smaller things that would be useful

* Tents.  Some small shelter, probably specific to a certain environment, that you can carry with you and deploy even while on someone else's base during a storm, but that fall apart when you leave.
* Devices to teleport to your nearest base, or your ship.  Should require a resource as fuel, possibly scaled by distance.
* It would be useful to be able to define a prefab - something like snapshotting a base using your base computer (omitted) as the origin, so that later you can just tell it to build *that* (and see the sum of all the parts it'll need, which you still have to have on you somehow).  If you can define several, a player could use them as building blocks for larger structures.  This gets more interesting when using repeated structures to build farms and so on, or (see the settlement stuff above) housing for your citizens.

If theres one thing this game does perfectly its atmosphere. Its just so easy to get lost in the sauce over something that just looks amazing, be it the planets, landscapes, or that shiny new starship you just found. I often find myself flying around planets just vibing with no particular purpose.
The gameplay starts off slow, with much to learn about how to get the things you will need to progress. It eventually ramps up into a full set age of exploration, with new objectives bringing new systems and new adventure, and with an unlimited number of them. Every system, every planet, every plant, animal, multitool, starship, point of interest, all of it holds itself to a healthy degree of variations which makes everything look different and unique.
The systems in place are pretty good to, combat, at least in single player is pretty fluid, where upgrades and equipment matter, but skill can make up for any lack thereof, and theres usually a way out with minimal penalty even for death. 
No Mans Sky has come a long way since its original release and is continuing to get consistent content updates that always add something new to discover.

[list]
[*]5 types of alliens (korvax, gek, vykeen, travellers and autophage)

[*]3.75 types of a space stations (regular, anomaly, atlas, the half being outlaws and quarter being abandoned)

[*]8 types of starships (shuttle, fighter, hauler, explorer, exotic, interceptor, solar and living ship)

[*]7 models for freighters (differ only in exterior)

[*]11 types of planets (lush, barren, scorched, frozen, toxic, radioactive, dead, marsh, volcanic, waterworld, dissident) - all being generated from the same formula, so they feel very similar

[*]8 types of weapons (boltcaster, blaze javelin, pulse spitter, scatter blaster, neutron cannon, plasma launcher, geology cannon, paralysis mortar)
[/list]

The list goes on and on. Switching colors, textures and minor model parts doesn't affect the gameplay. It's all fake, dummy, etc. The website of NMS states that it's an infinite universe. But it's not, it's just 11 planets scattered and shuffled in a way to confuse people.

A direct example of this would be calling the [b]barren[/b] planet type with different names in the game, e.g.: [i]desert, rocky, bleak, parched, abandoned, dusty, desolate[/i], etc. just so that you would hope it's something new. This applies to all planet types, they have multiple alternate names to confuse people, as there is no other value in these alternate names.

The storms on the planets are another example of faking, as they don't affect anything in the environment, there is no wind, animals wander the same way as before the storm, ignoring it, etc. A storm on a planet is just a full-screen post-processing effect (blur, color overlay, displacement, etc) with some imaginary "hazards" that drain your suit.

Additionally there are no charaters in the game, just dummy models that can't speak, all dialogue is written, no voice overs at all.

Nice music though.
It's the best game for someone who wants to explore and take his/her time to just take it a step by step.

Unfortunately, this game DOES NOT run on average laptops.

Most of my playtime is on other consoles, such as Xbox and Playstation.

I've heard people complain that things feel repetitive, and to be fair, it kind of is, but the thing is, everything is just distinct enough to still give a feeling of wonder. Especially when you find an anomalous planet, there are various types, and even when you come across a variant you've seen before, you still think "huh, neat." and appreciate the rare find.

The thing that mostly sells this game to me though is base building. I played Subnautica much more than I have NMS, and loved the building system, but I always felt restricted with my base building being pretty much restricted to just underwater. NMS scratched that itch by letting me build similar structures AND MORE in all kinds of different environments. Whether it be underwater research bases like I made in Subnautica, a sci-fi village on a desert world like that one from Star Wars, and even building space cities with the FUCKING AWESOME freighter building system. You want to build a custom cyber city? With a little practice and a freighter, just enter creative mode and watch your dreams come true! I sometimes spend a week hyperfixating on one base, then spend the next week just gawking at it and having self roleplays as I interact with the random NPCs walking around, making up a story. Great times.

The ONLY real complaint I have about this game:

Legacy cosmetics.

Unfortunately, this game DOES use a FOMO (fear of missing out) system with it's events, most of which I missed sadly. Some of them are really cool too, and I hope they bring them back in some way. I just have an awful schedule with the intervals I play the game at. I take a break from it for a few weeks, come back and find out I missed an event or the event ends really really soon. I've just made a deal with myself to just not participate in events to avoid getting envious about it.

Aside from that small tragedy, this game is really fun, has a neat story that's pretty much optional, especially in creative, and I can't see myself permanently putting it down for a long time from now.

And don't worry, for you bloodthirsty players, there is an outlaw faction, and epic space battles not too disimilar to Star Wars. You fly through ship trenches and blow shit up, pull maneuvers on bogeys and obliterate them when you get the upper hand, and watch as the cowards warp away as you go and collect the rather valuable drops from broken ships.

I personally don't have much experience with the outlaw faction, but sometimes I will make a save just for the purpose of being a lone pirate, cracking freighters open, assaulting random ships, there's something for everyone.

9/10 game, been around since the start. I'm happy to have seen it grow.
Very cool game would recommend for people that are really bored. every time you seem bored of the game you can still find something to do. and even the small things like grinding are fun.

This game is VERY engaging, for me any ways. Lots to do. So much to learn. Do not let early combat turn you off. It does get better. 

My only real problem with the game, well a couple. Is direction. Not knowing upgrading Exosuits or ships, you can choose inventory or a Tech Slot upgrade. Even though they are labeled as "Inventory Upgrades".

Space combat. Well, in general ships are missing the hover option. Hover up and down. Can not reverse when on planets? But can in space. Auto Locking is nice, but. Good for toggling to get on targets. When you get better weapons it really will not matter since you will down them stupid fast. Elite Dangerous spoiled my space combat skills.

The planets are amazing to wonder around. Right now my thing is running around in crazy storms gathering storm crystals for currency. And as in any game,there will  always be something that will tick you off. Then later slap yourself. Just be patient. Research if lost.

I was one of the people who bought into all of the hype back when it was released and was massively disappointed. Didn't pick it back up for years. And while it's still not the ~brilliant evolution/universe simulator we were promised, I actually think No Man's Sky is a great game now. The graphics are gorgeous, there's lots to do, and the devs have done nothing but put care into the game since launch. It still has some level of jank to it - multiples of aliens spawning into space stations, some weird camera angles - but overall, I really enjoy it now.

If you like Subnautica,  this is better,  it's Subnautica in space with a procedurally generated massive universe and incredible replayability.   It's a fun massive game,  I just got into Expeditions, it is a really cool idea once you figure out what it is.  You get all kinds of excellent loot for playing Expeditions and completing milestones.   The loot just rains down on you.   An Expedition can last up to 4 weeks but when it ends you get to keep all the loot and unlocks you earned on your regular save when you return to the game you were playing before you switched over to the expedition.  

I actually got a ship when the Expedition started,  a cool ship that I liked better than the ship I had in the normal mode of the game I was playing.  

When I first starting playing this game I really didn't understand where it was going,  after watching a youtube video this one dude mentioned that it was like Subnautica and  it clicked,  yeah,  it is,  only in space and massive in scope by comparison.   Way much more to do.  Subnautica is a pretty darn big game but this thing is an entire universe.  It's a great game,  it's relaxing if that's what you want or it can be action if you like that,  or anything in between.

It's a huge Sci Fi Sandbox.  Unlike Subnautica,  you can play multiplayer as well.   IF that's your thing.

I decided on a whim to read and update my review since it's 2024 now! it's been SIX YEARS since I last updated my review, and to be honest, not much has changed that I know of. With the relevancy of the review, I mean, not the game. The game is crazy different, they never stopped adding more stuff and I haven't played it in awhile but I am aware of it from a distance. I'm looking forward to playing it again soon, I seen they added a new freighter or smthn smthn. I don't know if any of my specific complaints have been directly addressed but the hole filling in my base was sort of a very specific event, iirc it only happened like twice idk. I Don't think it was that big of a deal. It's been long enough that unfortunately I hardly remember the terrible launch in 2016, that was a lifetime ago, and I'm looking forward to their next game, Light no Fire? or something? I say it's unfortunate because I despise the live service model. I feel like it has ruined the video game industry as a whole.. or.. not the model itself, sorry, but it's provided an avenue for greedy profiteers to go down, which has made most of video gaming as a trend and culture kind of lame. I'm glad it works when it works but it hardly ever works, yk? Even MineCraft has fallen imo, so like.. IDK. NMS right now is the only 'live service' game (at least by technicality I think) that I feel like is on the right path to die peacefully. MC being my idea of the poster child of the live service formula had the Microsoft drama which was a rollercoaster for a time but it's pretty cemented to me that it was the ultimate downfall yk yk yk. I'm definitely not part of the popular crowd at least fiscally speaking, but I preferred the experience of the game back in Beta. Sorry, this review is about NMS but like.. yeah, good job Hello Games, keep it up, the game is undoubtedly worth the money now I don't even have any hesitations to be fair. Full price? I don't even know how to describe what kind of game it is.. it's pretty chill, I think relaxing, provides opportunity to grind, doesn't really force you to do that though.. all I'd say is that at least in my experience, it's not a combat sim, so don't get it if that's all you're after xD

I wasted a lot of text rambling about live service crap, haha, I doubt this review will mean anything to anyone so I'm alright with that. I've bought the game a few times for friends as well, so at the very least, I do recommend this game and believe it is worth the money. 
This is biased in hindsight, and I know there was a long time early on where it didn't feel that way and it felt like a waste of money.. but at this point in time, I'm glad the game is in my library, and while I'll never preorder a game again (I hadn't thought about that in awhile, but I genuinely haven't preordered a game since NMS, wow, preordering feels like some crazy fad from the 2010s now, wild) I do think NMS has made up for its previous failings. They got dune worms now :>

Oi, this game is alright. I'm struggling to figure out just how much game there is now D; so much stuff, that sometimes it feels bugged when things don't work, only for me to find out I just didn't do what I was supposed to because I wasn't paying attention to all the scattered little details. mind you, there are still a lot of bugs, like when the auto miners start grabbing copper from a uranium deposit and I can't fix it so in the end I ragequit and delete the base.. or when your base that was made in a hole you dug is spontaneously buried as the hole is erased as if you never made it :(
needless to say some things can be upsetting, but overall, the game is pretty, the game is relaxing, enjoyable, there's so much to do at any given moment that I never feel directionless, and I think it's worth the $30 it's for during the holiday sale as I write this. maaayyyybbbeee I still feel like $60 is a bit much... just maybe.. I still think it's great. Even though the launch was shit, and I wanted to find giant dune worms and hang out with friends and was very rightfully upset about that when the game was released, I think Hello Games is going in the right direction. They may never erase the stain that this game was initially, but they're trying, and as I see it, they're succeeding, slowly but surely. 

MATTER OF FACT, there are a lot of things I wish I could see in the game that I think would make it even more fun (for me xD )
like the ability to have an autopilot mode on your starship, so that you can maybe let the A.I. fight ships (maybe have it be a tech you can find and install or even upgrade)
or tag friend's ships and follow them in formation, because.. honestly when you're trying to follow friends without having them tell you exactly when they intend to slow down or where they're already going, it's actually really hard to follow when exploring, and if it was a tight enough formation, you could get a really nice view of their ships in flight, maybe a reason to show off your fancy ships ;b
Or maybe a trading system betwen players! unless that's already a thing, I have no idea

THIS GAME IS INCOMPLETE, EVEN WITHOUT ALL THE LIES AND FALSE PROMISES, IT IS INCOMPLETE. 
Repetetive, Grindy, and Monotonous. There is no varying experience in this game, and WITH all the LIES and FALSE PROMISES it's nothing but a dissapointment. This game is basically just another StarForge that skipped early access and costs way more.




Even without expecting anything this game was promised to have and playing the game with an open mind, it's ridiculously boring and grindy. If making a game is like composing a piece of music on a keyboard, and the procedurally generated world is supposed to be "all" the different music you can make with a certain number of keys, No Man's Sky has a ridiculously tiny keyboard. Everything looks the same, everything feels the same, there's no progression or actual drive to explore more than like, two planets. This feels like a very, very, very incomplete game, and i sincerely hope that the modding community for this game fixes this for me. I have no faith in the gaming industry anymore. I stopped trusting early access because of code][atch and StarForge, but now this crap happens and I can't trust even large games being officially released on console, too. I don't think I'm going to do much pre-ordering from now on. No Man's Sky is even worse if you came in because of all the false promises, like I did. I'm incredibly upset about this game, and in my bias review, I hope this game crashes and burns, but from an open minded and impartial point of view, if you see five minutes of No Man's Sky gameplay and think 'hey, I would love to do that forever' <-- but you want to pay $60 for it, this is the game for you, congrats, your life is complete now. It literally never gets any better than that.

I guarantee that you will never get bored of this game. This is the kind of game that has no real end- you just keep getting better and better at it. When you start out, you struggle to get enough sodium and oxygen to sustain yourself. A little later, you get past that and start building a base, and then you struggle to get enough carbon or ferrite to get what you want. Then, once you have large stores of all the common materials, you start worrying about things like Gold, Chromatic Metal, and Tritium. And so on. Eventually, you just can't ever be bored, because there's so much to do- you eventually have to start making lists of tasks for yourself. Here's an example of a list you might have:
Okay. I start in my main base. I can
-Manage my settlement to improve productivity and ensure debt payment.
-Visit the Space anomaly and get that upgrade I want
-Look for Artemis some more
-Find the Atlas
-Look for more tech buried in my base computer
-Improve my base power production
-Send my frigate team on another mission
-Get a few tasks from the mission board on Keblok-Allus Station Beta
-Search for Exosuit Upgrades with my Drop Pod Detector in my Exocraft
-Pick a fight with some Sentinels
-Just chill.
So if I choose to get some money and reputation off the mission board, I might find some missions that require me to go to another system and analyze underwater minerals. But I'm out of Hyperdrive power, so I'll have to make some more antimatter, and for that I'll need chromatic metal, but I can't make that without copper, so I'll have to go copper-farming on Kerichus UO5. Once I've fueled my hyperdrive, I remember that I'll have to build the Nautilon, a submarine Exocraft, which I've been putting off because that weird crystal is hard to find, so I'll have to go looking for it, but since it can only be found underwater in the first place, I'll have to visit Mariar to dive in and get some, but for that I'll have to make sure I have an Auxillary Oxygen upgrade to make sure I can't drown, but to buy that, I'll need Nanites, and for that I'll have to-

You get the picture?
This game is worth its price, because it's so BIG. And besides that, Hello Games is still releasing free updates for it all the time. There have been more than nine major updates since I got it, and I don't think the price has risen once. On top of all this, the game only takes up 20 Gigabytes or so, and absolutely everything is procedurally generated- Terrain, outposts, Space Stations, Wildlife anatomy, even starship architecture and Sentinel makeup.

There's a reason this game is in my favorites.

Is there an award for most improved game? If not, there should be. I'm an OG player who gave it up at first. I recently picked it back up, and MY GOD. It's so fun. The details they put into this are lovely as well. The planets really do rotate if you look close enough from the ground at night. You can just roam around and explore countless (and I mean literally countless, there are 18 quintillion-ish planets) planets of all different types, or if you like more of an objective based play, there's that too. The space anomaly is super cool, too. They added in sandbox mode, essentially. You can fully customize your experience. Think Minecraft creative mode. You can turn combat, crafting, fuel cost, and so much other stuff off so you can literally just explore the whole game if you really wanted. I like the storyline a lot, but what captivates me is the infinite galaxies to explore thing. Some of these planets are wicked cool. Sometimes it can get repetitive when you warp and keep finding the same galaxies, but when you think about how many planets there are in the game, I mean..there are only so many planet types lmao All in all, with all of the updates, its a solid 100/10 for me.

This game seems very good really. There actually are a lot of good things.
But then there are a few very annoying things that ruin the game.

Like, lastly I was refining stuff, and warping around, and at some point everything in my refiners were lost. Resources basically disappeared.

Lastly I built a base, mainly for radon.
Today I login to collect what should have been a big harvest, and my base wasn't there. Building disappeared...

Okay I built the base back, and then decided to put all my industry into my freighter. I built a real nice industry for me, ran some tasks and stuff.
Was working so I let the game run on my PC while in the freighter.
I get back 2hrs later was disconnected, connected back to the anomaly, and when back on my ship everything I did disappeared and I was back in time like 4h ago.

So yes the game seems like it could be fun.
But right now, and after 6 years of dev, it's so bugged that it is scary.
And I would clearly not recommend that frustration to anyone.
Especially since, obviously, those bugs won't be fixed anytime soon.

EDIT : 6 years later I have nothing to change to my review. Main bugs are still not fixed and probably never will. Don't buy this game.

Amazing game, always update it and continue adding new things to do, company always listens to players and truly makes a game for people to just have fun, nexus mods also offers some unique game play options.

NMS had a rough start, not meeting any of its promises on launch. A lot of people were upset, there were tons of returns and even a lawsuit if I recall. But all of that is in the past, and the developers and staff of Hello Games more than made up for their initial failures, because they never stopped improving. And unlike many other developers (:cough: Paradox :cough:) they did it for free. They didnt release a DLC for $20 to enable multiplayer, they just fixed it. They didnt ask for subscription fees to enable fleets, they just did it. Hello Games have demonstrated what it means to be a true developer and earned the respect of players. I for one will give them the benefit of the doubt for all of their titles moving forward. Respect.

Great game, but there are BIG problems.
The game loads way too slow, please fix this immediately. Loading times should not be more than 2-3 minutes, but this game takes 5-10 minutes to load, especially on less powerful platforms.
The game keeps lagging, please fix this immediately.
There is not a manual save button anywhere I can find.
Also, I want the option to reject a living ship I don't like and find another one at the end of the starbirth mission, and I want the option to "scrap" living ships for 1 void egg.
The free purchases setting should also apply to quicksilver purchases.
The profanity filter is broken, please fix this urgently or remove this altogether.
The player freighter's portal network is restricted from outlaw systems, unlike player bases. This should be fixed immediately, since the player's freighter should be treated as the player's base, unlike a regular space station. Also, The size of capital freighters should scale with class. C and B class should be small, B and A class for medium, and A and S class for large. Not only that, but the building area of the freighter remains unaffected by color customization. This should be fixed immediately. Also, there should be uniform color customizations for bases, settlements, and freighters. Freighters should also be upgradable. 
Ship customization is a much-needed feature in No Man's Sky, so if you could find a way to implement this into the game, that would be great. For example, there should be an option to recolor, salvage, and install  ship parts into your ship.
I also couldn't recolor or delete communication stations. Also, I can't put a save beacon or any other portable module because of "No edit permission". I also want to recolor the Exo Mech Hardframe Sentinel upgrades to any color. The inside walls for the cuboid rooms should be recolorable, and there should be a colored roof panel.
Also, the anomaly nexus missions cannot be saved. So even if you are 99.99% complete and the game crashes, you have to start over from the beginning and the progress is wasted. The mission could be lost, so you could lose the opportunity entirely. This makes it very hard to earn Quicksilver, an important in-game currency. 
It could be nice if you could find a way for me to get rewards from previous expeditions. I don't like the idea of cool stuff being lost forever. Maybe all expeditions could become available when a new expedition releases instead of that new expedition?
And most of all, the storyline and lore could be an expanded into a entire universe of ancient civilizations instead of some creepy files from a horror show. This could give No Man's Sky some much-needed depth.
Summary: 9.5/10 This game is good, gameplay is awesome, but keeps lagging and crashing.

This game is the definition of open world. You can do so many things in this game. You can run around on planets with no limits of what you can and can't do. You can fly to wherever your heart desires. It's a really unique kind of game play that I've never seen before. But I do have a few problems with it, and that's resources. These problems are probably because I have an RTX 3050- which sucks. The loading screen with all the stars that you pass by uses WAY too many resources, having to render all of those systems or stars at the minimum uses a lot of resources. And that's really it. But if you also suffer from low frames and have an RTX graphics card, here's a tip for you. Go to options, then graphics, turn the graphics preset to standard, then turn on DLSS in anti aliasing, turn it to quality, and your frames should be much better. All in all, I do recommend this game.

This is hands down the most fleshed out space game we have to date, whether or not that was the case on release is a different story. 

You have the freedom to manage a village and weigh in on political issues or town decisions, become a farmer, pirate, build a base in a cave or just fly around with your recruited squadron to fight pirates. When warping between galaxies you can encounter random events which result in a choice to defend random freighters in large scale battles or help the pirates secure the loot. 
The possibilities are endless when charting hundreds of galaxies with procedural generated planets, making every planetary landing feel unique. 

ᴍᴜʟᴛɪᴘʟᴀʏᴇʀ: Best described as coexisting with others without any real intent. There is a community hub that can be spawned by all players at any time which allows players from Xbox, PS, PC to meet and start missions together via "The Anomaly". 
This hub carries crafting benches and general necessities for players like, vendors, upgrade stations and an intergalactic portal. 

This game is incredible and deserve every second of praise it receives. Plays extremely well on Steam Deck as well as VR (on a 1660 ti). 

𝗟𝗼𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗺: The continued for support for this game is phenomenal, free updates including more content and mechanics with Explanation Modes being released every few months with exclusive content and cosmetics. 

As of 2/15/24 there has been a total of 12 expeditions with a new one releasing today with a free weekend to boot and up to 25 free updates.

NMS is a fantastic game to start out and explore, with tons of avenues to play and experience the billions of worlds generated all at your own pace. The big problem is that it suffers from the same flaw many games with such an increasingly wide scope experience, a lack of proper depth and feeling of shallow-ness once you're maybe 30 or so hours in. 
TL;DR It's definitely worth the price for a first-timer, but it dries out very quickly. Every new system added feels very much stapled-on to the last without any proper connection or unity.

Billions of customization options between ships, freighters & tools ultimately feel kind of meaningless when you have zero ability to actually choose any of the customizations aside from base upgrades. Like the shape of your ship but hate the color? Just go explore for a dozen more hours and you MIGHT find one in a better color! Love the shape and color of a freighter but it's not an S-rank? Go spend a few dozen hours resetting your game to re-roll the ship and again since there's no way to upgrade your capital ship's class!
Community resources like the Coordinate Exchange help, but only when someone has actually, by complete chance, found what you want. There are MANY colors or shapes of ships that are still missing aside from the S-tier exotic ships, which only come in a few colors (White, Black, Red, Blue, Yellow, Orange). This also extends to the planets too. Even with billions of procedurally generated worlds they all get separated into about 7-ish types with only small visual changes between them (Hot, Cold, Acidic, Nuclear, Barren, Paradise, Exotic, etc).

Combat aside from the most recent Pirate Dreadnought update feels very shallow and clunky as well, with only sentinels having any range and hostile fauna fighting their AI pathing over the randomly generated geography more than they do you. Most fights consist of moving a grand total of one foot side-to-side and holding down the fire button. Ship-to-ship dogfighting is fairly clunky as well, with most enemy ships randomly changing velocity and vector to either stay within of out of your field of view very artificially. The maneuvering of the ships is fairly basic as well, with the ships only being able to land in VERY specific circumstances and automatically dodging most any even semi-lethal collision. It feels very much like the game is holding back any true freedom of control or even consequence. If you try to slam into a planet or mountain your ship will all of a sudden veer off to the side to avoid it.

The game's big saving grace is the base-building, which is only held back by a few large flaws as opposed to the fundamental ones the world and combat are. You can build some amazing bases anywhere you want (within atmosphere) or on your very own freighter. The biggest issue is that there's no proper system of lighting and depending on how long ago the parts were developed, they may not connect properly to the rest of your base if at all.
The lighting is the largest issue in that light appears to be mostly simulated in bloom rather than actually lighting up the environment. Most often you get non-prebuilt-parts bases looking like a neon sign hellscape where the rooms are dark but every lightsource has more corona than a binary star system. Some of the later developed base parts, like the ones made for the capital ships, have their own built-in lighting, but anything using the standard walls, floors and roofs from the Settlements update are severely lacking in properly-functioning options.

Exploration should be the main draw of the game, but that's unfortunately lacking as well. Each planet functions as its own biome, meaning that once you're on-world there's likely little to no variety anywhere you look. Even using the ship scanners rarely ever comes up with anything of interest and the scanners on your visor, exocraft and ship all have different uses that are all missing from each other. The most infuriating are the exocraft, which often have scenarios where you have to drive 30 seconds, get out, look around with your visor for the objective direction (since the tracker doesn't show a marker, just a vague direction), then get back in and drive for another 30 seconds before having to get out again and check your visor direction. Because god forbid you have access to your helmet visor info in a vehicle or ship! It just feels incredibly disconnected.

There is a special place in my heart for this game. Not for everyone, definitely. But the nice thing is - understanding that it's not for you comes pretty quickly. And if you stay, there is a huge little world, just waiting for you.

TY Hello! Games for sticking to your word. I won't instantly write off your future works but I definitely will not trust what your company says until I see it for myself.

UPDATE: 300 hours at time of original review. I now have 2000+. I love this game, I still load it up every few days to make a little progression. All of the updates are what keep me coming back and now Expeditions give me a reason to start over... and over... and over again! Each update brings bugs, sure, but they work pretty quickly to fix.

UPDATE: The Omega update has caused me 3 hard crashes when no other games give me problems. Tried the usual troubleshooting and downloaded the game all over again, no luck. I will avoid this game for a few more updates before attempting the revamped Atlas path. Until then, back to thumbs down. The bugs are TOO MUCH
This was a great time in 2021/2022 and I'm stoked to get back into it with all the new content. Highly recommend <3

Whether it's basebuilding, talking to aliens, exploration, gunplay, dogfights or what have you that you may want out of a sci-fi video game, this game does it all bloody well.
It has something for everyone in terms of it's gameplay loop and tends to let you run free in your own way. Take more pleasure in building up a giant base and selling off resources to buy what you need?
Easily doable.
Don't want to build a base and would rather go around shooting robots, aliens and maybe indulging in some piracy?
Start blasting away, there's lots to shoot.
Don't want to do any of that and just want to explore ancient sites, find relics or maybe partake in some wildlife photography?
Viable playstyle too.

It's a game that let's you play your way, explore your way, or not even explore at all.
If you like space, you'll like this game.

I can't imagine a conversation where I don't recommend No Man's Sky. Maybe to someone that has no interest in video games, but even then I'm still explaining the spiritual experience that this game is. It's like when a pothead tells you that everyone should try weed at least once in their life. Everyone should try video games, and No Man's Sky is the perfect game for any and everyone to try as their first. It's casual enough for your 80 year old grandma to pick up and play for five minutes, and deep enough for the most dedicated no-lifer to get hundreds of hours out of. It is a truly special experience that I feel privileged to be able to experience.

“Look again at that dot. That's here. That's home. That's us. On it everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every "superstar," every "supreme leader," every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there-on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.

The Earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena. Think of the endless cruelties visited by the inhabitants of one corner of this pixel on the scarcely distinguishable inhabitants of some other corner, how frequent their misunderstandings, how eager they are to kill one another, how fervent their hatreds. Think of the rivers of blood spilled by all those generals and emperors so that, in glory and triumph, they could become the momentary masters of a fraction of a dot.

Our posturings, our imagined self-importance, the delusion that we have some privileged position in the Universe, are challenged by this point of pale light. Our planet is a lonely speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. In our obscurity, in all this vastness, there is no hint that help will come from elsewhere to save us from ourselves.

The Earth is the only world known so far to harbor life. There is nowhere else, at least in the near future, to which our species could migrate. Visit, yes. Settle, not yet. Like it or not, for the moment the Earth is where we make our stand.

It has been said that astronomy is a humbling and character-building experience. There is perhaps no better demonstration of the folly of human conceits than this distant image of our tiny world. To me, it underscores our responsibility to deal more kindly with one another, and to preserve and cherish the pale blue dot, the only home we've ever known.”

― Carl Sagan, Pale Blue Dot: A Vision of the Human Future in Space

No Man's Sky has seriously come a long way since launch, and I gotta say, it's now a blast to play! If you're into exploring endless galaxies, discovering weird and wonderful planets, and just getting lost in a massive universe, this game is totally for you. The updates have turned it into a whole new beast - with base building, space trading, and even running into other players out in the vast nothingness. Graphics? Gorgeous. Gameplay? Super chill and engaging. Whether you're a solo adventurer or looking to team up with friends, there's always something new to see and do. Honestly, if you've been sleeping on this game, it's time to wake up and dive in. No Man's Sky is legit a space odyssey worth taking. 🚀🌌

Of course the game is now good and the team has made an amazing work. But don't get fooled, it is still  a huge grindfest to cover most of the repetivity of the environment and lore. Basically they cover the fact that there isnt much deep lore after the first few days by filling the game to the grim with collectible hard to get stuff and skins. But worth of all since a few years now it is has a lot of time limited seasonal content, you missed it you don't get it. Personally I dismiss any game that I paied the same price than anyone else and cannot play because I am not available at certain dates or seasons. So yes my negative review does not reflect a game that is bad at the core. You can still buy it and have fun for a while. But long term there have been choices to cover poor mechanical gameplay, lack of deep simulation with artifices and time locked content. That is just a bad choice in my opinion.

Good base building open world game, but the best part of the game is autosave. If you don't like the way your last interaction with a monolith went? Reload at your last autosave and that will be the last time you got out of your spaceship, or saved at a waypoint. Quest game mechanics occasionally break so saving often isn't a bad idea: the new base building on freighters? A WIN for sure.

Alternate game start option? HIGHLY recommended, great alternative way to ease old players painlessly back into the game and eliminate a lot of the grind. Excellent expedition.

No Man's Sky has been both absolutely disappointing and glorious games I have ever played. Hello Games promised something they were unable to initially deliver, however they have also put much effort and content into taking this game above and beyond what was expected. I love the vastness and feeling alone in the universe that you get as you explore systems. If you don't want to be alone you can easily jump in with friends or other members of the No Man's Sky community. The real icing on the cake of this game is that when faced with a problem most game developers seem to intentionally create - releasing an unfinished game - they resort to paid content and essentially make you pay them to deliver a finished game. Hello Games saw that they disappointed the community and made it right by not requiring a SINGLE DIME to deliver more content AND they KEEP delivering content even though they have made good on initial promises of a vast universe of exploration that you can play with friends. I keep coming back to No Man's Sky and continue to enjoy new content as it's released. Hello Games has set the standard for righting wrongs and I challenge every other game developer to follow their example.
:P

also it isn't starfield, that alone should make you give it a shot.

In this dark age of video games, where almost no games are made with pure passion anymore and only intended to fuel the ever-growing corporate greed, No man's sky is a shining beacon of passion and love. 
Hello Games is one of the names at the very top of my favourite devs in Video games, and that even though I barely play it nowadays, simply because they understand the simple yet sacred transaction between developers and gamers, that has been ruined by in game transactions and battle-passes and deluxe/preorder editions and etc.:
It's buying passion to experience passion, and that at a fair and affordable price (the game is almost constantly on sale too).
Because, and take notes Bethesda, Ubisoft, EA and all you other companies that have gotten way too big the way you treat gamers, and honestly most of you should finally die off for the good of the industry:

I don't want to buy games for the title ex. Elder scrolls
I don't want to buy games for the great memories I've had with their predecessors. ex. mass effect
I don't want to buy games for the hook, the timed rewards from season-passes and the locked rewards of preorders/deluxe editions. ex. Rainbow six
I don't want to buy games because they are like the other big hits ex warzone

I want to buy games that draw me in with their own take, their own style, their own feeling.
I want to buy games that surprise me with their own little neat things that dont play a major role, but are rather contributing to the overall feeling of the game.
I want to buy games where I can literally feel the passion that has been poured into it.
I want to buy games that are made for me to enjoy, and not made so I have to abuse my wallet.

Remember when Video games were made to be enjoyed and shared, for nothing but entertainments sake, where nerds showed other nerds how great and fun the world they created is and that the one and only priority was user experience, not user tolerance?

I want that, and only that.

I really want to give this a positive review especially with the amount of work the devs are putting in following it's rocky start. But, the game just doesn't have any depth. Sean and Hello Games are the gold standard of how to support your game.
Can't wait to see how they handle the new game they have in the pipeline.
Nothing but love for these guys.
NMS is now the best space sandbox you can have, solo or with the homies. Expeditions are always a fun time and give you incredible rewards to use on your other save files. Not to mention you constantly get Twitch drops that are actually worth claiming as well.
There's so much ways to play whether it be creative with unlimited resources, extreme survival or Permadeath, a chill mode, or you can just customize your difficulty the way you like it.
The one thing you will see eventually is that planets and creatures can get quite repetitive as there is a visible line through all this but it makes it all the more rewarding when you explore and find unique planets, systems and creatures.
The lore also got insanely interesting over the years.
If you're looking for a space game where you make your own experience, this is for you.
If you're looking for a streamlined single player experience, this probably isnt' for you.
Give it a shot either way cause they deserve it.

If you want to experience a simulation of diverse planets over a quintillion numbers spread across hundreds of galaxies -- before deciding of living to Mars -- play this game! I guarantee you, it'll take you beyond what you can imagine.

If exploring is your thing, then look no further. Trillions of procedurally generated planets you van visit, but otherwise ignore and just explore the ones within reach! Base building mechanics are excellent, easy to throw up vast sprawling bases with hundreds of elements and decorations to unlock. more ship types and designs then you could possibly ever want. 

 The real joy comes from the exploring, discovering, building, upgrading, and managing your fleet. Didnt I mention that already? You can own a massive freighter (which you can also build a base in) and up to 30 frigates to send on missions gather units and resources for you.

Not only that...... but free (yes free) major updates every few months which continually add new stuff to the game.

Just endless fun.

This beats any other space-based rpg hands dowm, better than Elite Dangerous, Starfield, Space Engineers....you name it, this is the best!

Well,  after years of having steam, I am finally giving my first review.  I often swap from game to game to game, removing games from my PC and downloading another from my library, but I can say for a fact that this game has never been removed and re downloaded.  Though I have had large gaps in between times I have played, I always come back to check out the features they add with each new update.  From a game with little to stand on, to a game with so much to do and always updating and expanding and changing.  Hello Games turned a complete disaster into an apology, then into one of the best games I've ever followed and continued to play.  

The game is free for at least a while now, so if you have the opportunity and enjoy exploring, trading, discovery, epic scenes, space battles, finding an amazing vista for your next wallpaper or to find ridiculous looking animals to ride around on a planet that literally rains acid all the time, this is for you.  I can tell you that this game is for me.

No Man's Sky could be used as the blueprint for a lot of things.
How to revive a game that was on the ropes,
How to create a fun procedural experience,
How to let the player decide how they want to have their fun,
and much, much more.
With every update, Hello Games proves time and time that they are committed to giving their player base an expansive and wondrous experience, and while this game isn't perfect, it does have a little something for everyone. It can be as casual or as intense as you desire, the procedural generation is decently varied, and the options of systems you have to toy around with are enough to let you pick a path (or multiple) and lean into it. I'll admit that not many of said paths are super fleshed out, but it's amazing nonetheless that I can manage a freighter, own a settlement, convene with a space god, be a pirate, be a trader, build my own profitable base, and more!
This game has loads to offer, and is on sale for half price just about every other week. For that, this game deserves the success it's earned, and i'm excited to see what the team has in store for us next, both in No Man's Sky, and soon Light No Fire.

I will start by saying i love this game. I had so much fun with it, and played almost 200 hours on a single play through.

But I would not recommend that anybody play the game. The game is incredibly shallow. There are a billion things to do but none of them have any meaning or reasons to do them besides avoiding boredom. You are kind of just doing things. No real goals or objectives. No lasting effects. Nothing worth doing but by god I did it all. The whole game feels like you are grinding to get somewhere, and then you realize there inst any where to get.

You work your ass off to get the coolest capital ship, and you cant do anything with it. It doesn't give you anything more than a frigate would. besides storage what do you need it for?

Exocraft? none of them offer anything, for the most part they are actually slower than on foot, and have weaker weapons. If my mech isn't fast or heavily armed then what is the point?

The last time I played they added small villages of robots. Cool, what do they do? Oh they do nothing.

What about settlements? Yep, there is definitely a settlement here, and it really doesn't do much.

The devs keep adding new features but they go nowhere. Everything they add is separate from everything already in the game so you really just have a bunch of mini games in an unfinished base game.

The main drive to the game is exploration but there isn't shit to explore. The same few planets over and over (which by the way everything on the planets looks the same, so more like a couple locations that have really large repeating maps)

yet again, i really enjoy the game, but would NEVER in a million years recommend it to a friend.

(btw if you want an in-depth space sim with plenty of meaningful activities, interesting npcs and quest-lines check out X4. VERY different game but i thought id still mention it)

Why yes I would recommend this game to anyone. For a first experience, this game scratches that "goes on forever and I can explore forever" itch that some have. Sure it can be repetitive, but who isn't currently playing a grind simulator since Games As a Service started getting more prevalent. 

Aside from that, I have massive respect for the team continuing to work on this title and continually push out regular large scale updates over the years after the initial flop(And boy that flop was in fact large). Not many devs care for their work like this and even fewer stand behind that commitment they make to provide something they said it would be (We are all looking at you 'The Day Before')
