I've 'finished' this game multiple times. Done the story, did all the upgrades, the side stories. I participated in expeditions, did all the combat, did all the side content (multiple times). I've also owned NMS since its release date, refusing to refund it out of sheer hope the game got better.

Then why do I not recommend the game?

[b]TL;DR:[/b] as many others have said, the game is simply a shallow experience. It constantly feels like it [i]could be more[/i] and it [i]has so much potential[/i] but then constantly falls flat when looking for that experience.

[b][i]Update 15th Feb 2024 (Omega update)[/i][/b]: My review still stands fully. HG has done no changes to deepen the mechanics of this game or change the procedural generation at all. Seeing as how they announced their new game, Light No Fire, it's quite obvious they lack the resources to make big sweeping changes to NMS. This is not likely to ever change, the trajectory seems to be focused on new Expeditions and some gameplay tweaks.

I'm basing my review off of the full, $60 price tag. To spare you some time, I would never recommend getting this game at full-price. They often do discounts, so the price might as well be $30 or less, at which it becomes more worth it to purchase this game.

There are a lot of good things to say about this game. The absolute best parts of which you will experience in your first few hours playing. There are just [i]so many things to do[/i] at the start. On top of that, all of it is.. an almost magical experience. The planetary environments look really cool, there is a solid plot line and introduction experience to follow, and I will never forget the first time I got into my space ship and flew off into the sky. To spare you the full explanation, simply look at the other positive reviews and recommendations, they will explain all that.

The problems arise when you take [i]any[/i] deeper look into this game. It's a very surface-level experience. Let me go through it point by point:

The planets and universe:
When first experienced, they're cool. There is variation, different types of planets, different resources per planet, different creatures per planet, and different kinds of planets depending on the system you're in.
The problem is there is no depth here. There are no different biomes, so the entire planet looks the same. There is no depth to temperature variation, geographical generation variation, creature variation, etc. This is the same at all points wherever you are located on the planet. You'd think maybe poles, the axis on which the planet rotates, the distance to the parent star(s) or even an equator would matter. It doesn't. After a while you realize that there is a limited number of planetary types, all of them functioning and looking exactly the same. This 'limitless' universe is only limitless in size, not in experiences.

Expeditions:
So I have an idea what Hello Games was thinking when releasing these. There are other games which do 'seasons' as a way to increase sales and generate hype for their games, which also creates a lot of player interest in spikes. Players will come back to play seasons even if they've finished the game previously. It creates replayability.
The issue with expeditions is that I don't think it works at all for this game. The game already lacks content and now it's just being released on a time schedule and then its [b]gone[/b]. On top of this creating FOMO (fear of missing out) for the playerbase, the design of expeditions just suck in general. In my opinion, they're just not big enough to warrant a completely new playthrough of the game, but not small enough to ignore if you're a fan of the game. I think it just becomes a slog, and having the option to pick and choose or do expeditions in your main save would be so much better.

Side content:
I have huge gripes with side content in this game. It is often released nearly unplayable or at the very least buggy as hell. And although most of the bugs get squashed in the weeks after release, there are some that remain forever.
On top of that, all of the side content in this game is extremely shallow.
Outlaws added piracy, but it feels half-baked. Sentinel made combat go from almost non-existent to somewhat challenging for a bit, until it's completely irrelevant and easy when you get a few upgrades. Don't get me started on Frontiers, which added settlements, which is a half-baked mobile-like system (think clash of clans) where you feed resources to a location with a few buildings (which is time gated), make it slightly bigger, and get a small selection of random events every once in a while.
Every single piece of side content that was added to this game since release is shallow, half worked out and has only like an hour-ish of unique gameplay experiences at most.

Game stability:
So it's quite obvious the way Hello Games is earning money with this game is by re-releasing it for full price on other platforms.
The massive issue with this is that it comes at a price. Every single major update to this game completely breaks it for at least one platform, and these breaking changes often don't get fixed within weeks, or even at all! You could, right now, buy this game for the full 60$ on a console device and risk not being able to play the game due to gamebreaking bugs and crashes, which risk never being fixed.

Communication:
HG and Sean Murray have not changed their method of communicating since... Next (1.5) or so? They will refuse to openly update the community or talk about anything wrong with the game. There have been thousands of complaints about stability on certain platforms (see above) and not a single word from the team. The game sometimes has massive update delays after patches on certain consoles, and there will not be an update from the team. Their communication strategy has been the same: post community-shared images of the game, tease (hype) and announce updates. That's it.

The story:
The story in this game is interesting and it brings up some fascinating philosophical elements, as well as promoting adventure. I think it's pretty typical for good indie-game storytelling, but stops at that. The visual elements are boring (it's just text). No cutscenes (in or out of game), voice acting, interesting animations. It kind of detracts a little from the feeling and takes you out of the game. But I do understand this is ultimately an indie game and the selling point isn't meant to be the main storyline.

The future and my final thoughts:
I've had a vision of this game since it released as 1.0. No Man's Sky is described as a game of exploration and survival, in an infinitely generated universe. The way you explore and survive as a single player in this universe has barely changed since Next (1.5) and has mainly only visually been impacted (Origins/Prisms updates). The game has gone years now without any changes to how you explore, and no impactful changes to the core principles that represent this game. I've read the patch notes of every single update since release waiting for some sort of depth to the mechanics of this game, some sort of extra variation, some extra variables that make exploration interesting beyond the first few hours of playing this game. But nothing. All this game is getting is shallow side content, FOMO expeditions, some visual upgrades and updates to base building.
The description of this game and the original vision at this point is basically a lie. This game is a shallow procedurally-generated sandbox, with repetitive vistas that you can experience over and over in slightly different ways, while you interact with shallow side activities and some base building that get old after a few hours.
Now we all hope HG some day changes this trajectory.

Hello games was once a mobile game company that worked on the Joe Danger series. That's what they did before NMS.
I want that to sink in for everyone here. Anyone reading this or thinking about the game. Anyone skeptical about it because of its shaky launch.

Their studio also flooded before release, they were pressured by investors to reveal more features that just weren't ready, and while I have nothing for sympathy for them it's still a dark stain that will likely follow them forever.
Then they worked to fixed it. No mtx, no paid subs or battle passes. Just taking the money from the sales and using it to put it back into the game.

Has it paid off for them? No - objectively not. They would have been far better off just taking the money and running.
Has it paid off for *us*? Yes. Even if the game is buggy in more than a few spots, even if things aren't perfect and the gameplay isn't for everyone. Those people who had hope for this game are vindicated because at the end of the day we got a cool space exploring game with a unique story and plenty of sand in that sandbox to mess around with.

I give it a glowing 6/10. i can't rate it any higher in good faith because of some of the optimization issues and occasional bugs that still haunt this game even to this day. but it is easily the best 6/10 game i've ever played and I'll more than likely continue to play.

BEST GAME I HAVE EVER PLAYED!! I love exploring new systems and making new discoveries in this endless universe that is No Man's Sky!

I am a fan of multiplayer co-op and third-person perspectives in games and am happy with the expansive and flexible game play style of No Man's Sky. 

I love the feeling of limitless exploration and seeing so many ways to play the game. It is both enjoyable and extremely satisfying to survey, identify, share, and explore such a beautiful panorama of planets and their wildlife. 

No Man's Sky uses a community approach for multiplayer play, and it took two days for me to realize it. We found it easier for everyone to progress on the missions after we entered the same multiplayer game, built our starting bases, and shared access to them, and then re-entered our saved game without being in a party using the left game option instead of multiplayer. 

The multiplayer game instances save on the left and setting a name to our saved game made it easier to re-enter together.

Finding the mission objectives and completing them was much faster outside of a party. In a party, one person completed the early missions fast while the party kept the mission selected, but did not find it easy to progress. Visited locations seemed to be missing the objectives.

Realizing it, we entered the same saved game together, but without selecting multiplayer. We did not form into a party and our mission growth skyrocketed. *pun intended*

This gave us flexibility, a feeling of community and connection as we share the teleporters at our bases, but also the freedom to advance in missions and obtain the items we needed. It also made it easier to get a freighter for each player.  We are using the friends only setting because we like to form into close knit communities.

The benefit was our ease in sharing resources, like the base storage with the friends only setting active.
I love the space battles and developing a reputation protecting the mining fleets.

It is easier for friends to get their own freighters out of a party.

You need to be in a party for your friend to visit your freighter. Otherwise, your friend sees a copy in their own instance. This is not a problem as you can join and exit party, making the game feel flexible and expansive.

New players may need an updated starter guide for multiplayer play as beginning the game and progressing was a little mysterious in a party. Despite my slow beginning, the extra days spent in exploration and mining paid off and I found new missions and advanced fast, making it an exciting game of discovery.

We love it! Highly recommended for the adventurous player who loves a good mystery.

Every since I was a kid being fascinated with astronomy. I always dreamed of a game where I was able to explore not just space but to visit near limitless planets almost seamlessly. Lo and behold No Man Sky was that answer. During it's first announcement, I was part of the crowd that was heavily anticipating this games arrival. So much so that I even pre-order it. Sadly, once I gotten the game, that anticipation left me in utter devastation at the sight of the game for not even delivering half of it's promises. This is one of the very few games that nearly broke my trust in the gaming industry as a whole but unlike most...

I was always the sort to play the waiting game to see how things pan out and wait I did, as time passed by I witness not only the greatest comeback for a game but for a gaming stuido to earn back the trust from many of it's false-promised fans but millions of new fans in the process. To not only fall back and deliver what was promised but to go an extra literal mile and include so much additional content and game-core altering mechanics. Even to this day, the mad-mens are still continuing push out updates for No Man Sky. To which makes this all even crazier, IT'S ALL BEEN FREE! 

I'm truly glad this was one of the many games that playing the waiting game was worth it. The dream became a reality.
Wish this was real life.

This game has come a long way from its humble beginnings. If you haven't already, pick this one up. It is hours upon hours of enjoyment if you like exploration, building, and sci-fi.

NMS is amazing again. Everything is better. Lots of things have been fixed. 
Weapon targetting is better, both on foot and in ship. It feels less like randomly shooting in a general direction and more like having a dogfight.
Visuals seem to have generally improved across the entire game.
Seems like ship-base building has been reduced to functions that it would make sense for the flagship to have, which IMO is a good change, along with (OMG TY) a teleport pad in the bridge that connects to teleport pads in the hangar, in case you happen to have, y'know, accidentally deleted the stairway leading from the bridge to the hangar, while you were on the bridge, and THEN saved your game, leaving you hopelessly stranded on the bridge of your own flagship until an update finally comes out that lets you teleport to the hangar.... not that i'm speaking from personal experience or anything. XD

i haven't really delved back into the base building yet, but so far, the ship stuff and planet exploration stuff is better. Planets seem to have more geological variety now. Terrain seems more resistant to bugs while manipulating than previous iterations. Fauna and flora have more variety, there are new and cool ships to acquire, and i haven't yet run into the bug where you run sideways in the Anomaly.

I did notice my flagship bugged out after a combat, wouldn't leave combat alert status and kept firing at an unseen target while its hangar remained inaccessible. Fortunately, the game now has a feature that lets you dismiss your flagship, and resummoning the flagship seems to fix the bug.

Overall, an experience that has been generally awesome.
Very fun and grindy game always has something for you to do.

Specs:

[/list]

Now, with the review:

The game is absolutely stunning. Everything you look at, no matter what you are looking at in the game, is always visually appealing to the eye. I have visited 10 planets as of this review and I can say with certainty that No two planets have me me say "this one looks like X planet" because they all have their differences.

The creatures, however, do have more similarities than differences but I have yet to come across many creatures with distinguished features. Maybe the more planets I visit the more diverse the creatures become?

This game is a repetitive game (sort of like destiny minus the combat) ONLY if you aim to get to the centre of the galaxy
[olist]
[*]You gather resources
[*]You trade resources to gain currency
[*]You purchase items from the galactic network/traders
[*]get warp fuel
[*]Go to a new system
[/olist]
And repeat.

Now, if you could care less about the overarching goal of getting to the centre and just want to explore planets and play at your own pace, the repetitiveness would be as infrequent.

Overall, I enjoy this game and I would most definitely recommend it [b] BUT NOT AT THE AAA $60 PRICE IT IS CURRENTLY AT. [/b]This game would be an absolute must have at $30/$40 but right now it doesn't have enough content to justify the $60 purchase [i] (oh the irony) [/i]

Maybe later on when there are added updates to the game (which the developers have said themselves on their website that more updates/patches will be planned) then [u] MAYBE [/u] I would be able to see this game be justified at the price it currently is.

This game is an incredible mix of genius and failure.
One reason for the failure is that it tries to be so many things. It tries to be a resource management game, a mining/crafting game, a shoot-em-up, a dogfighting game, an exploration game, a building construction game, an epic and a sandbox. Inevitably, it ends up doing some of those things better than others and (arguably) none of them brilliantly. But many of them are done well, and that does make for varied gameplay that stays interesting for hundreds of hours if you're so inclined.
The procedural generation is also a huge strength and weakness at the same time. It allows for effectively infinite planets, but it means that, deep down, all the planets and the challenges they offer, their wildlife, landscapes and structures end up being too similar (but again, only after dozens or hundreds of hours). If you're "creating" a planet which only one player will ever visit in the lifetime of the game, it doesn't make any sense to make it in any way special.
Then there's the story element. To a large degree, this is an extended tutorial to encourage you to make use of all the features they've built in, and again it does that well, but (for me) it lacks any real emotional depth or connection to the characters.
In the end, it's best as an exploration sandbox. You can set yourself goals to achieve certain milestones in certain ways, and this is supported by an options menu with a good deal of customisation regarding difficulty and resource availability. The periodic community expeditions also provide a refreshing challenge: they make it possible for HG to curate a more original and varied experience, and they create a shared experience to discuss and compare notes with your friends, as well as letting you win some unique collectables.
I obviously recommend it, it's cost me barely a penny per playing hour by now and that's amazing value, it's presented me enough challenges and victories to justify its purchase, for sure. But I don't *cherish* it the way I do some much shorter, much more limited gaming experiences which had stories and characters that actually tugged at my heartstrings.
But I'll definitely be back for Light No Fire.

Obviously Hello Games deserves credit for the work they've put into this game since its disastrous launch. Unfortunately, the core gameplay loop has not changed and remains highly repetitive and tedious. 

Almost every single objective is to  go from point A to point B, perform some action, then return. This would be fine if the journey actually involved some challenge or intrigue, but for normal game modes, this is mind-numbingly dull. All obstacles, either planet side or in space can be trivially overcome. Ship out of fuel? Blast some comets that always spawns 20 metres away. Life support low? Oh how convenient there's the same oxygen rich planet that grows on Every. Single. One. of the 18 quintillion planets.

What's worse is that content updates have now become focused on "expeditions", which is basically the process described above but for TIME LIMITED rewards. That's right. You better grind away otherwise you're never seeing that content again. Sure there is multiplayer but any kind of meaningful interaction rarely occurs because everyone is trying to walk/fly/swim to the next marker point slightly faster than everybody else, since that's the only challenge this game poses. 

In conclusion, I believe this game is targeted to a somewhat niche group of people who enjoys very slow paced game play. I applaud Hello Games' effort to improve this game over time. However, for me and many others who are looking for a meaningful space sim and exploration experience, No Man's Sky fits the bill very poorly.

Let me just get out the way, I don't like that it went the "live service" route but it barely impacts the offline experience other than in the anomaly, the inability to talk to iteration: Helios for vital early-game nanites, or earn quicksilver while offline. 

The best explanation for this game if I had to summarize it in three words would be Fun, Shallow, and Soft. It's fun because 65 hrs in and I've basically finished the game (S Grade Gear) but still have lots to tune into, return to, and explore even if I've done almost all the achievements. Much of the games depth is in the writing and alien encounters but there is a ton of hidden content to discover as long as you avoid online spoilers.

It's shallow like the not-so-deep end of the pool which makes it a great casual experience even in permanent death difficulty. You never truly get past the early game which I think adds high value to the time you spend building as there is a lot of functionality to base building. I really wish you could remove the Mining Laser from some multi-tools since it gets in the way if you like using one multi-tool for exploring and another for combat.

It's soft difficulty is the only thing I think makes this a sleepy game, but not a bad one; The best metaphor I can use to compare the challenge of this game is it is like punching a bean-bag with the force of punching-bag. It lacks end game Field-Bosses or Challenge. Sentinels are a great hint to the difficulty missing with Alien Encounters. It would be nice if you could get special faction related rewards.

I am Autistic, I write this because my review will be influenced by my perceptions etc.  Some may find this helpful to know when looking at my review.

I play SSF (solo Self-Found) only now.

My main issue when I played multi-player is that, if your no quick enough during the Expeditions, it can be very hard to find an ideal place to build a base on the planets where you need a base for ease of travel or resource mining. Some expeditions I have had to skip because of this, so I stopped playing them, 3 years ago... 

BUGS = the are many long standing bugs in this game that have been in the game for years, the developers are aware but either don't seem to care or cannot fix them... either / or they still exist.  There are too many to list here.

There is one bug / issue that I want to mention.  There is a way to get unlimited resources.  this bug / exploit has been in the game for several years and once you find out how to do, it kind of ruins the game OR you can just ignore and spend too many hours grinding for various rare resources.

Issues = 
Bright Lights / Flashes = these in the game in plentiful supply. there is no way to turn these off so if your sensitive to these, be aware. you may need to change your monitor settings.
Sound = very limited control over how much of what sound you can hear.  For example, I cannot handle the sound of the jet-pack, but I cant turn this specific sound down / off
When you get to mine various resources/gases, you can only build a certain number of storage containers for it, which means you have to collect every day, or "lose" out on auto-generated resources.
Some Resource are required in great quantity but are very rare, which means you have to spend 4 hours farming to get enough of it for one days worth of missions...(see above)
Ships = when you find a new ship but do not want to take it as your main ship, the game does not want you that you will lose the position of your main ship.  make sure your main ship is right next to you BEFORE you swap. 
Vehicles = you very limited upgrades the various vehicles, eventually, all of the vehicles end up with the exact same upgrades because there are so few and you cannot expand the inventory (unlike your own and your ships)
You only get one save per game file.  you cannot "save as"
New saves games go to the TOP be careful when deleting, I lost a 350+ hour because of this. you cannot retrieve delete data.!

All The Good =
Solo Play, friends only play, or open multiplayer play.
Regular free major content updates
No P2W
the options for building is awesome, and once you unlock all of the things to build (available by grinding in game currency) you can build truly magnificent massive structures.  my current save is about 400 hours, 150 hrs of that is just building bigger / better bases. oops ;)
great custom building for ships, weapons and freighters.
You can either have your main base on a planet OR have it one a Freighter, or both :)
Unlimited exploration. (this could also be a bad thing, depending on your personal preference)

Overall I love this game, the only really bad thing about it is the long-standing bugs and unlimited resources bug / exploit.

No Man's Sky has come a long way since its controversial 2016 launch. What was once an empty, repetitive exploration experience lacking promised features is now one of the most ambitious gaming worlds.

I very much look forward to playing their next project 'Light No Fire' when it releases!
This game is so good that I can play for hours straight!

No Man's Sky (NMS), developed by Hello Games, stands out as a monumental achievement in video games, providing players with an almost infinite universe to explore. The game has evolved significantly through continuous updates since its launch, improving and expanding its features comprehensively.

Gameplay in NMS is unique, centered around exploration, survival, trading, and combat across procedurally generated galaxies. The game delivers an unprecedented sense of scale, with over 18 quintillion planets each hosting unique flora, fauna, and landscapes. Players engage in discovering new species, mining resources, space or ground combat, and interacting with alien races. The introduction of base building, underwater exploration, and land vehicles in updates has enriched gameplay, allowing deeper personalization of the journey.

The graphics and sound design of NMS are remarkable. The vibrant color palette and art style evoke classic science fiction, creating a sense of wonder. Procedural generation ensures each planet offers a new visual and auditory experience, complemented by an ambient soundtrack by 65daysofstatic, which enhances the immersive exploration.

Hello Games has shown a strong commitment to improving NMS through numerous free updates, including Foundation, Beyond, Origins, and Frontiers. These updates have expanded features, introduced multiplayer, enhanced base building, added new story content, and increased planet diversity, revitalizing the game and its community.

The NMS community has been crucial to the game's evolution, sharing discoveries, organizing events, and contributing to a knowledge database. Multiplayer allows exploration together, trading, combat, and building communities on distant worlds. Hello Games supports this community spirit with in-game events and challenges.

Despite a controversial launch, NMS has become a success story of redemption in the gaming industry, showcasing the importance of developer-community engagement and the evolution potential post-launch.

NMS is more than a game; it's a vast universe offering endless exploration and adventure possibilities. Its transformation over the years highlights Hello Games' dedication to their vision and players. With exploration, survival, and community at its core, NMS exemplifies the potential of video games to provide not only entertainment but also deeply personal and evolving experiences. Whether charting unknown planets or building bases with friends, NMS offers a universe of possibilities waiting to be discovered.
It got better.

Sit back, grab a drink and chill while you:
- Explore solar systems no one has gone to before
- Build and decorate bases
- Find your favorite ships
- Rescue your capital freighter (mobile space base)
- Upgrade your suit, weapons, ships
- Tame unique pets and companions to follow you
- Jump to other galaxies
- Make the difficulty as easy or hard as you like; Creative to Survival to Permadeath
- Manage a Settlement to govern as you see fit and reap the rewards

So, what a game. Honestly this is a gem in it's own right. However, it has some very clear issues that prevent me from seeing this out to 500+ hours. 

The worlds, and systems are beautiful. Flying around to different systems to see the make up of planets really has it's charm. During my adventure's I came across "rare" base decorations you could pick up from planets for placement in your base. This small addition adds to the exploration experience and should show what you can find. 

The factions/races are well thought out and fun to interact with. Each with their own specialties in markets and technology. However, it would be nice to see more races or unique interactions. It does boil down to the same things being repeated. 

Combat leaves plenty to be desired, but the game is not punishing enough to harm you for it.  Plenty of upgrades and directions to take your multi-tool or star fighter. Again these end up being limited in the end. Star fighting is satisfying but could do with a bit more "realism", in the sense of I want more ability and control to dog fight enemies, locking on and shooting has its limits. 

I could go into more depth with many of the systems in game. At the end of the day it has an endless mid game. Everything you collect or gather is upgrading and min maxing the gear that mostly serves it duty. However, you're not going to encounter any boss, or raid like challenge in the game. Sure, there are a couple of cool events, but again not enough challenge to warrant the min maxing of gear. Example, S-class solar ship with half the dps of my fighter took out a pretty large ship with a few shield recharges. 

Now, the biggest negative. I got this game to play with a couple of buddies on the side of our fps gaming. We all started out playing together find, but as time went on we no longer could join each other. It was as if our characters were invalid to load into our friend lobby with. The selection option was grayed. This was not the only issue, as we encountered different weather in the same location on a planet. It was clear this was a "multiplayer" game. 

In the end we spent hours trying to work around the issue to play together. The problem was, as I stated to my buddies "to what end anyway, what we can do and experience together is highly limited". With no end game raids or bosses, and the only direct multiplayer experience being Nexus events. The lack of server side weather or experiences and more. Multiplayer is not really a viable option. 

I would even go so far as to say, with no in game invite system, no way to meet up outside of a group at the nexus, inconsistent joining sessions, and lack of server side events. This game should not be advertising as a multi-player experience at all.

No man's sky is a no for me. 
I won't "finish" the game and may never come back to it (unless there are significant improvements). 
Like its own pitch, it's an illusion. 
Even with mods (and I've installed a lot of them to expand weapons, ships, and biomes types after a first "meh" impression), you have seen all of it in ten hours. 
No, mixing a triceratops head with a chicken body and wolf legs, then on another planet a triceratops body with chicken legs and wolf head, all of them being the same brown-green colors (despite earth's real fauna being extremely colored) is NOT a mark of creativity nor imagination. 
A lot of different words to describe the same worlds that differ only by the type of head the common local brown-green cow wears.
NMS is the embodiment of "quantity over quality" proverb. Story is bad. Characters are bad and shallow. Everything is repetitive to death. Everything is made to make you loose time and unecessarily multiply the numbers of clicks and small waiting times needed to get something done. Even after having installed numerous QoL mods I still had this feeling. 
It can only amaze people that are locked since childhood in a concrete filled city. Go to your nearby forest, try to observe calmly the plants, the insects on and in the soil, the flowers, and you'll see what diversity means. 
Not my Sky.

I originally reviewed this game in April 2020 after playing on release and going back to it. Back then I felt as though it was finally as good as what they promised in launch, saying
"It's alright, great improvement on what it was at release." Now though after being on and off for the past near enough 4 years I can confidently say it's practically a different game, the Live Service has been phenomenal with most just being cool updates that add some features, and a few being as big as expansion for certain games, all free of charge to just make the game better. It is well worth the price, and is honestly more worth it than most AAA Titles that release nowadays, if you like exploration and survival then you'll love this and it's hard to really run out of content at this point. I'm almost 200 hours in and have still only done about 4 hours of the actual story, spending the rest of my time learning about and the languages of the other races to help make traversing the Galaxy seem that much more friendly. I highly recommend this to anyone who is uncertain of getting it, and I hope it continues to grow, and that Light No Fire is just as good, if not even better than it on release. Hello Games truly have redeemed themselves with this game, and I disagree with anyone who still has a stigma towards them 

Also Sean's Tweets are cryptic af, WHY?!?

After 200 hours I came to the conclusion that this game could have been so much better with good Base Sync and overhauled Base Building.

Fun game, I zoned out while playing more than a few times due to the - VERY - colorful atmospheres and relaxing views. Not a bad way to kill time. Inventory management has gotten much better with updates but it can still sometimes be a chore. The base building aspect shines since there's a bunch of environmental hazards on planets, so constructing a functioning base is not only good for your longevity but also adds in a bit of customization akin to minecraft. Character controls are smooth, so are the starship flight operations and ground vehicles/submersibles. Also must mention how the seamless movement from orbit to planet and vice versa makes such a significant difference compared to a jarring loading screen. This is something I never thought I needed so much in my space exploration games since it stops immersion from being regularly shattered by a wrecking ball. 

However this is not a very deep or story-heavy game. It's technically there if you want, but most of the time you'll be cruising around with your ship or jetpack trying to gather resources and build. Still, I can't fault the game for seeking to improve itself after all these years with regular updates and fixes. That's something I think counts for something considering the abysmal launch way back yonder. Pick it up, sit back, relax and enjoy.

When this game came out, my disappointment was immeasurable, and my day was ruined. But they recovered the bag and have not fumbled it since! Every update has added something that enhances the quality of life for players and makes the game more in-depth, fun, and worth coming back to. 

I play on a taped together craptop, but it runs fine for my specs. If you have a decent PC, it'll look great and you'll probably get >60fps at least. 

The only hang-up I have about this game is the progression in Survival mode being a little bit repetitive at times. I'll want to progress the story (which is very well written btw), but first you have to fly your ship to your local station, buy some Microprocessors, Salt, and Uranium-235 to complete the crafting blueprint for a suspiciously salty Nuclear Bomb that can also probably run Doom on its Samsung smart-fridge display. Then once you've talked to the person you wanted to, you have to do it all again. However, without that gameplay loop, it really wouldn't feel like you earn anything. Also, running errands in this game is just jaw-droppingly beautiful. It doesn't matter if you're orbiting Planet Piss, the sun's light will bounce off the surface of the oceans and give you a golden shower of glorious light on the bridge of your Star Freighter.

TL;DR: This game is very fun, but sometimes doing questline type stuff can be a little tedious. But it's not like you're required to do any of that. Plus, there's also a creative mode if you feel like just exploring and getting everything for free. Also the game is visually stunning.

This game had a rough start and features were announced that were not implemented right away.  I loved the initial concept of the game and followed its development.  When it dropped I wanted to buy it but I waited, and I'm glad I did.  It was a shadow of the game it was supposed to be and the community was not happy.  When it was on sale I took the chance to see if it was as bad as the haters were saying and to my surprise I loved the game the way it was at the time.  Many years later and 800+ hours and it's one of the best space games I've had the pleasure of playing, up there with Privateer, Tachyon and Freelancer.  No Man's Sky doesn't have the story element that those games mentioned have, but an infinite universe with all the things you can do in it makes it an engaging game.  Hello Games continues to support it and make it better.  This is definitely a game to add to your collection if you love space, exploring and beautiful environments and vistas...there may even be a bit of adventure and danger!

I was a little late to this game - I bought it right after outlaws came out - post “the game’s good now” resurgence. I have been following it for a while, however, and I can say that now it’s worth every penny you pay. I was initially drawn in by the style - reminiscent of the covers of classic sci-fi novels. Without getting too much into spoilers, the game very much feels like a story that comes from that same era - if you’re like me, the game’s already for you. 

As of this review, my playtime (100ish hours) is what you’d expect for a single player run to the endgame. However, one of the special things about this game is that it never really ends - I’m going to have a lot of fun yet with that first save file. 

No Man’s Sky  is “quick detour: the game”  - And I love it for that. I set out to assemble a submarine, and I ended up diving deep into a horrifying derelict freighter. It’s the most authentic exploration game I’ve ever played, and Hello Games remains dedicated to making that experience even better. 

I’ll admit, it has its flaws… for starters, the tutorial section is pretty long-winded if you don’t know what you’re doing. uncovering the story’s mystery and the experience of a new game is what kept me going, but for others it might be a problem. Multiplayer is also kept locked until it’s over, so if you want to play with friends quickly it might put a kink in things, depending on how quickly you can guide them through it. And though the game is constantly updated, it can get a little repetitive if you’re not hunting for the perfect equipment. 

The game is also very open - it can be a chill exploration game, but it also has aspects which can fit most palettes - combat, a little bit of horror, trading (albeit limited), messing around with friends, building a base or settlement, you name it. 

Anyway, very good game. would recommend, had a lot of fun.

100+ hours into this game and I’m addicted. Some thing get really repetitive but take the game for what it is, a massive world for you to explore. Don’t rush it, just enjoy. Hell I don’t even have a base yet, but I really enjoyed getting a living ship. I believe I can do another 100 hours before I consider getting bored. I call that a succes. 9/10 worth the money. If they add actual battle with a real purpose I’d give it 10/10.

There is so much variety of stuff to do.  I feel like if you took 5 different players, they could all be playing the game fairly differently.  One player could be an upstanding citizen loved by all races, another could be a lowly pirate skulking around the outlaw systems.  One could be a wealthy merchant buying his way out of combat situations, another could be mining and resource gathering but shooting her way out of any tight spots.  One might be farming, another mining- another doing neither of those things.

You can follow the main missions if you like, or play side missions, or just explore the galaxy.  Maybe you want to maintain a fleet of frigates to help you earn wealth?  Maybe that just sounds like a hassle.  Do or do not, it's your choice.

The first time I played No Man's Sky it was really suffering from lack of content, bugs and performance issues. Over the years though Hello Games have added much needed content, graphical enhancements and they fixed most of the issues that plagued the early days.

 The views as you're flying around and looking upon planets in your starship is breathtaking. Music is so good and I'm constantly impressed with new tunes popping up. As for aspects that need to be improved I really wish there was more of a sense of progression and in depth quests. More geographical/environmental variety in the planets like different biomes, craters, crevasses, sand, mountain ranges, plains, ocean waves etc. Gas giants, heavy gravity, intense pressure, brown dwarfs, neutron stars... The game needs more in terms of aliens and npc stories with intrigue, character development and suspense. Crafting legendary gear and more customisation would be really nice. When you get to mid to late game there is not much to do with all your mats and money. They really could do much more with this title and it would make this game incredible. I've definitely gotten my money's worth and props to Hello Games for still keeping up on it and the expeditions they introduce occasionally. 8/10

* Update Feb 2024
I continue to play and enjoy NMS every time they release a new expedition.  If you are a new player, there is a ton of content to experience and explore from past expeditions that have released new content into the game.  Definitely worth the money, as the game gives you everything that Starfield should have but failed to deliver on.  

I have about 500h on PS4 and PS5 in addition to ~80h on PC.  The best part about this game are the Expeditions, I would have given up NMS if not for the expeditions, so if you haven't been doing those, you have been missing out.  They provide a fresh way to play the game outside of the normal mechanics.  NMS is lots of fun until you hit max level (fully upgraded Exo, S class ships, Freighter, etc.) and then there isn't really much to do.  The missions aren't really meaningful, the base building is fine, but if you really try to go all out, you will start having crashes.  The game has a lot of potential still in it.  I had hoped that the settlements expansion would be deeper but it was mostly wasted potential.  I would have liked to see a settlement system like Fallout 4 where you have fully realized individual settlers who have quests and will reward you and improve and change individually as you help them out.  Settlements as they are are extremely limited and generic with little benefit and not much to do other than kill a few sentinels now and then.

Graphics:
The graphics on NMS are great, the lush planets at night, the caves, they all look amazing.

Music: 
The music in NMS is just about right.  It hits when it should but is not overbearing when it shouldn't be.

Base Building:
The base building is great, my only complaint is lag and crashes if you make your base too big.

Story:
The original story of the game is pretentious nonsense and honestly, with the framework that they have for the Expeditions, they should just completely retcon the original story and make it more meaningful.  I get the whole procedurally generated intent, but the reality is that its fine for terrain, rocks and plants, but it leaves a lot to be desired for story and interactions.  NMS would be much better served to do an expansion that wipes out the original story and gives us a really good, hard core science fiction story, maybe add a few more new humanoid races with capitol cities.  As it stands, the universe feels really empty and impersonal at max level.  All that procedurally generated content is a mile wide and an inch deep.  

Persistent bugs:
Oxygen and mineral generators losing inventory, freighter extractors and refiners losing inventory

Edit:

I returned after a few years, and really enjoyed myself. The only thing that stopped me from playing was the fact that there was no way to mark one's map. That made it impossible for me to return to bases I had created on other planets, (a huge developer oversight). I've been told this feature has been added, but I cannot confirm, as I have not returned. I wanted to rewrite my review, because the game has improved so much, my original review no longer reflected the enjoyment inherent in the game. I sometimes think I'll return and see if they allow one to mark their galaxy map.

After playing this game for a month I've decided to turn it off and walk away. I thought after 7 years of updates and development I would give No Man's Sky a try. I read a lot of reviews about the game being glitchy. So I was prepared for some issues. Found a Paradise plant after 1 month of game play and finding all 16 glyphs. Decided to claim a piece of land next to a lake and build my dream base. Because the base was next to water and an energy source everything was perfect. Unlimited energy and an underwater base below my home. I was so happy. 

Logged into No Mas Sky today and all of the base, that took me hour to to carve out of cave wall, is encased in rock. 10 levels. All of it encased. I tried to carve it out with the multi tool. It was an impossible task. Everything I mined would return just a few seconds later ... my base was destroyed .... due to a glitch ... gone.

I went to the forums to ding this glitch has existed for some time.
I do not recommend it and you best set a timer for 2 hours or you will never get a refund if it doesn't work for you.

So far so good! I think I will enjoy it more once I get a little more proficient at tile placement and quick keys to navigate around. I like the technical aspect to the game but I do hope there is more. Something tells me there is. I obviously am new to NMS but I def recommend! The music, the atmosphere, the visuals, its amazing!

Outstanding game!  There are so many things you can do and I'm still only at the beginning phases of the game.  You can explore planets, land on planets, mine resources,  trade,  fight sentinels, fight ships and pirates, build colony bases and freighters. I played on normal just to get the hang of the game, then I started a new game on survival and I am having a blast.  You can upgrade your mining / fighting gun, your ship, your exo-suit.
You grow relations with other aliens to try and befriend them.   You can hunt for abandoned ships and repair them and keep them, or you can scrap them for big loot.  The list goes on and on.  I'm glad I tried this game!

I have been playing this game for many year now and I am absolutely hooked. The game offers infinite exploration of a vast and diverse universe, where you can discover new planets, creatures, resources, and mysteries. You can also build your own base on any planet you like, and customize it to your liking. The game has a beautiful UX/UI that is intuitive and easy to use, and the graphics are stunning and immersive. The game is also very fun and engaging, with plenty of quests, challenges, and rewards to keep you motivated. But what I love the most about this game is the community. The game has a multiplayer mode where you can join other players in exploring, building, trading, and cooperating. The community is very friendly, helpful, and supportive, and I have made some great friends along the way. This game is a masterpiece of creativity, innovation, and entertainment, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves adventure, discovery, and socializing.

Pro:
- The game is beautiful. The different Nebulae, the planets, the suns and overall visuals are superb. Really gives the exploring/immersion feeling a good boost. 
- Diversity is where the game truly shines. Sure, the pool from which the procedural generation picks is limited, but the combinations and overall spread of the different things you can find and catalog is superb. Collect ships, companions, freighters and invest hundreds of hours to fit and max them, fly them in adventures and see the galaxy.
- Good exploration sim.
- A lot of stuff to do with a scope in mind and completion goals. 
- Superb base designs. 
- Huge game, you will find places to call "home" and they will be beautiful.
- Music or should I say atmosphere is awesome. One of the best parts for me. 
- Great content with pirate dreads and alien like derelict explorations. Good immersion and feeling. 
- More ship slots! More freighters needed! I want to own a space armada please!

Cons: (this will hurt but every point here felt like a slap over the head when I played).
- The name of the game is Grind. Not because you have to slave away to have anything, but because you have to do the same thing tens/hundreds of times to reach the wanted result.
- The Click Hell! Want to skip over the same conversation 300th time? Click 20 times to fast force every sentence that slowly displays in the convo window. Alternatively, you will be taken out of vendor menu's so you have to reclick everything to get back, even thou you weren't finished! Click click click to skip everything, EXCEPT the entire conversation. Open again a lore journal by mistake? Start clicking to skip each sentence again. 30 clicks, done..Oh...another journal over there! Why the Hell are you being taken out of npc convo menus after each option you chose!?
- The difficulty is trivial. Even in the endgame content, there is no real danger. You get awesome ships armed to the teeth, a personal fleet, full rack of weapons, and you blast through derelict freighters with only an upgraded mining beam. 
- Horrible mechanic for scanning everlasting energy/resource nodes. In order to get the S-tier ones, you have to drive like a cretin in the same direction and scan. Hours upon hours of samey landscape where you just push a button to see if any RNG generated S-tier nodes are around you. WRONG! You have to spice up this torment by dismounting your vehicle hundreds of times because you cannot use the scanner while driving! It makes no sense! Why can't you use the scanner while flying/driving? 
- You can't change ship on station, you can't change the order of the ship you are being given after a scrap/sale. So get ready to teleport/fly around no one knows how many times because you are just not allowed on stations where you actually need to. 
- Map Cancer. The map is simply cancer. You want to set a waypoint? Hah! You see the road map only on locked view. Want to plan a trip? Get out in space, is the only place you can access the map! Besides this, the 3d map is so bad. Background colors change, systems overlap, you can't plot a course to a system you haven't visited, filter is simplistic, and you can't spin a 3d map. Good luck trying to pinpoint a system if you don't aim it perfectly with the center of your screen. Good luck trying to get anything to display unless you center it perfectly while flying.
- The Bugs. OMG, it's been 8 years already and still annoying bugs. 
  - terrain regrowing over your base.
  - falling through terrain and map
  - base registering screws the snap on base modules. All you can do is erase the entire base to make the modules snap and register the location on the same spot again, otherwise the game will not see your base as actually there, hence things won't snap anymore.
  - missions not registering progression. 
  - missions that ask impossible to achieve requirements (scan 12 flowers on a planet with no flowers)
  - things that display for me, do not display for my friends in multiplayer
  - resetting encounters with invisible enemies, etc
My gf quit on the game when all her inventory vanished during a Nexus mission losing rare items and tens of hours of progress getting them. 
- Multiplayer is NOT multiplayer. Sure, you can do missions with a friend, and battle sentinels or be a pirate (if you are lucky to see the same things on screen), but the multiplayer part (the reason why I bought the game with my gf) is not really there. Missions are trivial even on single player, so another person in your team just makes the ordeal go faster. Unless the game bugs and you get different requirements for the same mission :)) You can't use the same base unless the owner is online and ON SITE. You can't share the storage, you can't trade ships and "unboxed" modules (why???), You can't even build a shared base in the same spot. And while this is great for PVE and getting rid of thieves/griefers, it kills the coop game play and I feel scammed. 
- PVP is trivial and basically non existent. The NMS community is a hippie commune. The game itself is risk averse. There is no risk, no sweat, little skill involved and no punishment for failure on Normal. Hell, you only get tricked into pvp if you don't un-check a box. Even the predatory animals are slow! 
- I didn't care for the writing or the story. It's allover the place and the quests are 99% fetch quests. The mission UI is a mess also. Deselecting your missions when you enter ship, not giving clear checkpoints and making you resort to the messy galaxy map (accessible only while in space). But it's not why I played the game to begin with. The worst part is even if there is a large diversity of missions, their only goal is grind. Progressions IS GRIND. And they are RANDOM. You can't even grind what you need as a dedicated goal. Maybe this game session no missions with the rewards you need will spawn! Progression is therefore locked behind RNG, and that's a middle finger if you value your time. So get ready to check reddit for fastest ways to get through that grind faster! 
- the bases looks beautiful, and I've seen some incredible builds. Really jaw dropping material. The bad part, is that more than 50% of all the modules you can build in your base, are cosmetic only. There's no point going the extra mile. Some basic rooms/greenhouses/utilities and you are set for the rest of the game and fully outfitted. 
- The goal of many venues of game play mechanics is to give you money. Top tier farms for top tier minerals, rare plantations and expeditions providing with the rarest items, all have one utility - money. You can build entire bases by buying the materials off market, and it will barely make a dent in your wallet. And once you have everything you need and enough money, there's almost nothing to do in the game except grind for stuff you can't mine/build/buy. 
- cannot enjoy past expeditions and rewards given before I started :( 
- you can name everything, from systems to rocks...but they won't really show for you or others in space. The game forgets mapped planets and named systems. 

The game is extensive, but repetitive to braindead levels. The sandbox element is the saving grace. There are some incredible devs that managed to turn around a global scam and a global laughing stock of a game, and some designers/writers that should never touch a game again. The level of wasted potential in this game is staggering. It could have been one of the best games of the decade with all the things you could have done in it, instead, it's just a grindy "what could have been" with 0 replay value after a thorough game play. Respect for free dlc's, but the multiplayer aspect killed the main selling point for me. Buy it, but buy it on a sale.

Excellent game

When NMS was released back in 2016, it was a mile wide and a inch deep.  Today, it's a mile wide and like, maybe a couple of feet deep.   Enough to soak yourself and float around on your back, pleasant enough.  But no diving, not deep enough to practice your breast stroke or anything.  

By that I mean, there are plenty of systems in place to mess around with.  Lots of 'stuff' to do; you can build a base, explore planets, work towards getting the submarine to explore underwater, do missions, etc.  Most of this stuff involves finding and collecting money, resources, 'nanites' (secondary money), 'Salvaged Data' (third type of money) to spend on upgrades at the Anomaly bazaar.  It's all fun enough and although it's fairly grindy I enjoy it pretty well.

But, I wish there was more to it.  Especially with the great planet generating system the game has, I wish it had a real economy.  Last I checked (which was awhile ago, I could be wrong so I'll leave comments open for corrections) the economy was fake, ie you can sell a whole cache of some widget to a station and the price for it will crash in that system, but it will only stay that way until you warp a few systems away and back and then it will reset.  I wish it was possible to really set something up, like finding a mega-vein of an element and setting up a mining operation, sending the ore to a 
personal factory space station to make widgets, etc.  Maybe find a planet with particularly tasty animals and make a factory farm.  When I bring this up on NMS forums most players seem to think it would detract from what the game's point 'aught' to be, exploration.  Maybe that's correct, I leave it up to you to decide. 

On a side note the game runs great on my Steam Deck.  I avoided installing it there because I figured it would be a slideshow or look terrible, but it mostly runs smoothly and looks pretty good.  Lots of ugly pop-in, but that's true on most desktop PCs with this game too.  And so far I've only noticed a lot of slowdown in the Anomaly hub, where there's lots of other players doting around.  But it doesn't become unplayable and there's no combat or anything in that area anyway.  I haven't played any multiplayer besides the hub so I don't know how well it would run then.

It also plays very well in VR, and looks and runs well on my setup (Valve Index, RTX 3080 12 gig, 32 gigs RAM and Ryzen7 5800x3d)

Experiencing 'No Man's Sky' in VR is like discovering an entirely new game. While I've always enjoyed playing it on a monitor, the transition to VR, specifically using the Varjo Aero headset and Valve Index Controllers, has transformed my gameplay experience profoundly.

In this brief review, I want to focus not on the technical aspects, but on the unique emotional journey VR offers. This became particularly apparent in the shift in my playstyle, which I noticed was not a conscious decision.

Immersed in VR, my exploration of the game's universe has slowed down significantly. I find myself savoring every detail of each new planet I encounter. Currently, I am on a paradise world, which undoubtedly enhances this experience. The slower pace in VR contrasts sharply with my monitor gameplay, where I was more driven by technical progression and the thrill of advancement. In VR, my joy springs from the immersive visuals and the sensation of truly being present in these stunningly crafted environments, surrounded by exotic flora and fauna.

It's this shift from a focus on progression to a deeper appreciation of the virtual world around me that makes 'No Man's Sky' in VR a distinctly different, and profoundly more emotional, experience.

No Man's Sky, Hello Games tarafından geliştirilen ve 2016 yılında piyasaya sürülen bir açık dünya keşif oyunudur. Oyunculara milyonlarca gezegeni keşfetme, hayvanları gözlemleme ve ticaret yapma fırsatı sunar. İşte No Man's Sky'ın dikkat çeken özellikleri ve olumlu incelemesi:

1. Evrenin Sonsuz Derinliği:
No Man's Sky, milyonlarca gezegen ve güneş sistemlerinden oluşan devasa bir evren sunar. Her bir gezegen, benzersiz iklimler, bitki örtüsü ve fauna ile karakterize edilmiştir.

2. Keşif ve Hayatta Kalma:
Oyun, keşif ve hayatta kalma temalarını birleştirir. Oyuncular, farklı gezegenlerde kaynakları toplar, yaratıkları inceler ve kendi hayatta kalma stratejilerini oluştururlar.

3. Procedural Oluşturma Teknolojisi:
Oyun, procedural oluşturma teknolojisini kullanarak her gezegeni ve varlığı rastgele oluşturur. Bu, oyunculara sürekli olarak yeni ve benzersiz deneyimler sunar.

4. Uzay Ticareti ve Keşif:
Oyuncular, uzay gemileriyle ticaret yapabilir, farklı güneş sistemlerini keşfedebilir ve uzay istasyonlarında diğer gezginlerle etkileşimde bulunabilir. Ticaret ve keşif, oyunun temel unsurlarını oluşturur.

5. Grafiksel Güncellemeler ve Görsel Estetik:
Oyun, zaman içinde grafiksel güncellemelerle geliştirilmiş ve görsel açıdan etkileyici bir atmosfer sunmaktadır. Renk paleti ve detaylar, oyunculara görsel bir şölen sunar.

6. Derin Hikaye ve Yenilikler:
Oyun, zaman içinde derinleşen bir hikaye sunmuş ve bir dizi güncelleme ile yeni özellikler eklemiştir. Bu, oyunculara uzun vadeli bir oyun deneyimi sunar.

7. Topluluk Katılımı ve İletişim:
Hello Games, topluluğu dinleyerek ve geri bildirimleri dikkate alarak oyunu sürekli olarak günceller. Bu, oyunun gelişmesini ve topluluk ile etkileşimi sağlar.

Sonuç:
No Man's Sky, başlangıcında eleştirilere maruz kalsa da, sürekli gelişen ve genişleyen bir evren sunan etkileyici bir açık dünya oyunu haline geldi. Sonsuz keşif, ticaret ve hayatta kalma temasını birleştiren bu oyun, bilim kurgu severlere eşsiz bir deneyim sunuyor. Oyunun sürekli güncellenmesi ve topluluk katılımı, No Man's Sky'ı uzun vadeli bir oyun deneyimi haline getiriyor.



No Man's Sky, developed by Hello Games and initially released in 2016, is an open-world exploration game. It allows players to explore millions of planets, observe creatures, and engage in trading. Here is the notable features and positive review of No Man's Sky:

1. Infinite Depth of the Universe:
No Man's Sky presents a vast universe comprising millions of planets and solar systems. Each planet is characterized by unique climates, vegetation, and fauna.

2. Exploration and Survival:
The game combines themes of exploration and survival. Players gather resources on different planets, study creatures, and create their own survival strategies.

3. Procedural Generation Technology:
Using procedural generation technology, the game randomly generates each planet and entity. This provides players with continuously new and unique experiences.

4. Space Trading and Exploration:
Players can engage in trading with space ships, explore different solar systems, and interact with other travelers in space stations. Trading and exploration form the core elements of the game.

5. Graphical Updates and Visual Aesthetics:
The game has been enhanced over time with graphical updates, offering visually stunning atmospheres. The color palette and details provide players with a visual spectacle.

6. Deep Storyline and Innovations:
Over time, the game has introduced a deepening storyline and various innovations through updates. This offers players a long-term gaming experience.

7. Community Engagement and Communication:
Hello Games continually updates the game by listening to the community and considering feedback. This ensures the game's ongoing development and interaction with the player community.

Conclusion:
No Man's Sky, despite facing criticism initially, has evolved into an impressive open-world game that offers a continuously expanding and developing universe. Combining themes of endless exploration, trading, and survival, this game provides a unique experience for sci-fi enthusiasts. The continuous updates and community engagement make No Man's Sky a long-term gaming experience.

It took me awhile to seriously get into this game. I've had it since day 1 and even played 30 hours on and off or so. Just something kept nagging at me about playing this game and playing it in perma death mode recently which is what I choose to do. I'm glad I did. I can't even really call it a game because the difficulty is just simple and while I usually gravitate more towards more difficult or sweaty PvP games, but this game is simply put down as pure art for me. 

It's one of the few games I spent time just doing photo mode stuff. It's a game where I actually enjoyed exploring and build (I'm not much of the building type either). I usually don't get too engaged in survival games anymore but something about this game made me want to discover things in this vast and endless universe. 

So if you're in the mood for something where you can do pretty much anything from combat, pirating, farming, discovering/exploring, base building, doing multiplayer missions with strangers or timed expedition events, etc etc then give this game a go. 

The story is also very thought provoking and extremely meta to the game's development if you knew anything about the game when it launched. These guys really stepped it up. The combat is the only real weak point in this game, everything else is pretty amazing. This experience really made No Man's Sky on the top of my fav games. I'm only 76 hours total right now and I have barely scratched the surface.

Played for a long while over on GamePass until I decided to buy it on Steam in December. NMS has come a long way, whilst still not perfect, it's a damn fine game.
102 hours in and, given it's up to you what you do, I'm now just building a planetary base after using my freighter till now. The game is obviously huge, lots to do, to explore....ok...ok...some elements of the game are not too "deep" but the frequency and quality of updates keeps me going. 
Exploration is fantastic, some of the vehicles are too, base-building, and just pottering about....all good. My only real gripe, and this is imo, I'd love to see a greater variation of quests from the stations... it gets a bit samey if this is how you wish to play. I do the missions, a lot, so I probably feel the pain of only a handful of choices. 
Can't wait for the station updates, hopefully this will be February.
For those that haven't played NMS - do - just approach it with an open world mind.... this is not a game for the linear player.

There is no reason at this point and time not to play NMS if you are into the kind of game that it is. They have long since made up for their mistakes at launch, and have continued to support the game well past the point anyone could reasonably expect them to, FOR FREE. I was originally extremely upset by the release condition of the game after we were told so many things about the game that were not there on launch, but that argument has long since become a non issue. 

Play it, it's a great time. Also very fun in VR, provided your computer can handle it. It's rare to see a company not only make due on the things they say, but go far beyond any and all expectations. Definitely made me eat my former words. Which is why I happily, HAPPILY update this review to be a resounding yes. Check it out. There's more space in here than actual space.

[Edited several more months later:  It took way longer than reasonable, but most of the issues listed below have either been fixed or occur less often at this point, so changing my recommendation to "yes" for the moment.]

[Edited Two months later:  No progress on any of this stuff, the Mac version is still so broken you're unlikely to get more than an hour or two of play in before something breaks irretrievably.  Still have never managed to enter a derelict (_all_ of them are broken), can't rescue my colony any more because I can't land on the plant, teleportation/warps fail to complete about one time in three, etc.    There has been one tiny update that didn't even mention, much less fix, any of the major issues.]

Waited over a year after the announcement for this to come out for Mac.   When it does, it's effectively unplayable.   Planets randomly fail to "resolve," remaining fuzzy clumps all the way to the ground and preventing landing.   Derelict freighter doors go into "additional security required" scans permanently, preventing you from entering.   Models sometimes take so long to draw (on an M1 Max with 64 GB RAM!) that you can be halfway though a building or hill before it appears.   Ships suddenly deciding entire planet surfaces are "landing area not clear," even when they ARE clear.

I'm hoping they get it under control again; the Mac needs some upscale games, but right now its either wait or go back to playing it on the PC.

When I first heard of this game in 2020 , I thought of it as any other space explorer (even though it said "every spec of light is a star to explore"). After playing for about 1 year (80+ hours worth), I felt how wrong I was.

Yes, I didn't play this from day 1, but I started before the Frontiers update. I was so indulged in this game that I forgot my laptop was overheating (over 90 °C). But, I was glad that I played and got this game. After I saw it on steam for sale, I bought it immediately. Before that, I played on Xbox Game Pass PC.

This game definitely has beautiful procedurally generated planets, flora & fauna. You will be anxious about what planets will in my next visiting system. Story wise, game is just great. With Endurance update released a week ago,  I will definitely recommend going for this game. Even the original price is worth it.

But, with all those beautiful graphics, planets, music etc, there is definitely bugs and glitches which can get annoying sometimes. The only glitch I ever faced was when mining for deposits that show there are resources left to mine when scanned through scanner even though I have mined them completely.

Overall, I give 8.5/10 for this game. All for giving the free updates, expeditions and an infinite universe (literally) to explore on our own pace. Thank you, Hello Games. looking forward to 'Polestar' expedition. :)
Other than a few UI issues, it's everything I wanted it to be when it first came out, and more.

No Man's Sky has improved significantly in almost every way since launch, and I don't have any issues with the way this was done, what exactly was added, or any of the minute details involved. Credit where credit is due for that. I've seen plenty of games become shadows of their former selves, but never have I seen a game come up as much as this one. 

The problem I have, and I don't think I'm alone in this, is that everything still feels obfuscated. There's more to do than ever but figuring out HOW to do something is the problem. I'm the type that doesn't enjoy wandering and discovering slowly, I like being goal oriented and I get bored without both short term and long term objectives and interplay between them. 

No Man's Sky certainly has that, but the layering of each system that exists feels wrong. Every part feels independent of the other. As I said, I like everything they've added and have no complaints with each individual part, it's the whole machine that fits together wonky. 

As such, I'm never confident in what I'm doing or where it's going, I always feel like I need a guide to tell me what the end point of each system is. It just doesn't come together organically into something that feels like a cohesive experience. Each thing you can do stands out from the other things. On paper, that SHOULD be good, it should feel rewarding and interesting and give players that sense of discovery and awe that clearly was part of their design philosophy. But for me, it just doesn't. It doesn't click, there's no aha moment, I never feel like I understand what exactly I'm doing. 

It feels like I'm playing a game inside a game, or in a dream. Like there's another layer, a thin veil over the whole experience that I can never quite punch through. I do enjoy the individual parts for what they are, but the experience as a whole always gives me that sensation. 

I only recommend this game if you're NOT like me. But if any of this resonates with you then you might feel the same way about No Man's Sky that I do, and not enjoy it.

Well, this is a sad truth. Let me start off by saying. No Mans Sky at heart is a simple Survival Exploration game. That is all, do not go looking for much more. Ontop of that, all features in-game are only half baked ideas that arent fully fleshed out. 

If Exploration is your thing and you just want a game that lets you explore to your hearts content then this game is for you, i still dont recommend this at full price. Id say no more than $30 USD. 

The game does have good points. Its fun finding new planets, some are usally similar to others but unique enough to be fun to explore for some time. The views are amazing. The game was made for you to sit back, get a cup of your favorite drink, put on some music, and just cruise. Take this game too seriously and you will hit the wall of disappointment fast. 

The game does not have a story, and for what little story it attempts to have, it is very unsatisfying and a failed attempt at being philosophical. Sean Murray is no Plato, hes not even your community college philosophy teacher good. 

But heres the problem now. What else could i say about this game? Space combat, half baked, mining, half baked, UI, half baked, story, raw.....This is a walking simulator. You'v just been punked, Sean Murray is actually Ashton Kutcher.
Im not saying its a bad game, im just saying its not worthy of its spot, a little mean to say, but it didnt need sony, it didnt need IGN interviews, it needed just its simple design and a greenlight. Would have had a lot less hate if thats the way it went, but nope, they wanted it all, and they got it all, all the hype and all the hate. Their fault. 

All i can leave you with is the suggestion to go watch: WoWCrendor's 2 minute review of No Mans Sky. 
Because in all reality, this game doesnt need more than 2 minutes to review. 

All in all, No Mans Sky is a good Early-Access game for $25 USD.........oh wait its not an E.A $25 game.

10 hours in.
First hour was the same as hour 2-9-  All you do is collect the resources till you can buy/make enough fuel to warp to the next solar system, and repeat.
Exploring around the planets is fun and all, but around hour 9 I ended up finding enough blueprints that I could craft the fuel to warp using basic materials I could either buy from the galactic trade, which is floating around every solar system- Or if I wanted to be cheap I could simply mine asteroids for a few minutes then craft the fuel.

At that point I saw no reason to ever set foot on a planet, so it just became- Warp to solar system, make fuel, warp to solar system, etc..

That's about the point I went ahead and applied for a refund.

The game is a really nice work of art, its really well coded, it didn't crash once, and for the most part ran at 25-30 FPS, so playable at min settings.. But as a game, doing the same thing over and over, making slight improvements to fairly useless ship/inventory/guns, like, why? 

 There is no carrot here, no reward, just keep going to the middle of the map, and about the whole "quintillions of planets", the game has an optimal path for you to follow, and I can't see any reason I'd ever leave the path, and considering I'm only one person, I can't see what real difference it would make if everyone was on the same exact path, with people never meant to be able to ever cross paths, why not just make it purely single player, with everyone doing the exact same path, like in theory we wouldn't even tell the difference unless we watched someone elses gameplay- Without a multiplayer the only point of a different planet layout is replayability, and I can't see any reason I'd ever reset this game after putting in the effort of leveling it up etc, like there is no real different paths, its all about making cash and upgrades.

Maybe in a few years after they add some actual gameplay and not just eye candy it could be awesome, but by then something else pretty would come along, lets be real.

I'd reccomend watching someone stream that already has made it to the middle of the first galaxy AT LEAST, so you have some idea of how repetitive/samey/pointless the gameplay is, and if you really think that's enough to keep your attention, buy it.


Edit: Ok so they added a lot of content.. But I still give it a negative, because I logged into my old 63 hour save and I can turn off damage, free craft anything, etc???? They just ruined my save file.

Was suspicious of the game since day one. Got it for christmas '23. I've logged over 175hrs since then and I honestly still like the game; all though I can't shake the "look over your shoulder" feeling wondering how much longer I will want to keep putting in hours before the abundance of things to do becomes becomes too bland and mundane to really want to play anymore. But so far nothing has gotten old or become too repetitive or predictable. Somethings are repetitive - you'll see, but the environment is always changing and surprising and that's what I was hoping for, You can play for 20 minutes or you can play for 3hrs... that's not something many games can do and be enjoyable no matter how much time you put in. I have just started farming, and portal jumping, I have a decent frigate fleet, settlement, all exocrafts (I think), on-world and freighter bases. And yet there's still so much I want to do that I know will take hours upon hours yet I don't care, I still want to play. Great game... so far!
Certainly heading in the right direction since the initial release, good job devs, I'm hooked!
