I really enjoy this game, from the main story to the nexus events, this game is quite fun. They do little seasonal things they call expiditions, which allow you to get limited time items for your account. I wish you could get multiple expidition awards on one character, but you need to start a new character for each one. 

You can roam the universe, charting new solar systems, scanning wildlife on planets, scanning rocks and minerals, build bases, be a wandering merchant, be a pirate, you can participate in faction quests, you can go around learning alien languages, you can start a town, and provide a nice place to live for the aliens of the galaxy. You can buy a capital ship, and hire workers to go and start a trade empire for you, or a research task force, and get nice rewards from them. Find an abandoned ship floating on the edge of a solar system, and get rare rewards from it. Find a temple on a planet and excavate, declare war on a bunch of flying robots, and kill enough that a 5 story high robot spawns in and tries its best to end your existence. Kill it, and steal its brain. Use it to make yourself stronger. My point is, there is so much stuff to do in this game. It's well thought out, well executed, and easily one of the best games released in a very long time. Please spend your money here, the devs deserve it.

Personally, I'd like to see some changes made to this game in the settlement category. The cities you can make focus on producing resources for you (selected at random when the settlement is generated), and I'd like it to have options to grow into a functioning city with a populace instead of just being a little factory.

I want to be able to build housing, and schools, and medical centers, and make a real city. procedural generated, still, but just something more. 

This game is really good about being a universe of it's own, with a wide variety of game play options. I'd like to see some love given to the settlements.

I recently picked this up again after a few years and was pleased to see updates allowing settings tweaks for casual, I-just-want-to-build-stuff players like myself who dont want the stress of "surviving" but just want to harvest/collect/research/build and enjoy the missions.     On PC the controls take a bit of getting used to as its really built for console, but this is not insurmountable.

Like many I had very high hopes for this game with its release. I held off on buying it because of the horrible reviews, and got excited when reviews improved with the updates. Well IMHO it's still brutal. Disclaimer, I couldn't stomach getting past the tutorial. Maybe it gets better? I have summed up my game experience below.

Hello, you're stranded in space. Go get this material. Before you can harvest that material you need to repair your harvest tool. In order to do that, please run 800um over there to get that material. OK, repair tool. Now run back and gather that material. Oh, before you can find that material we need to craft a scanner, please run over that way and look for material to gather to build a scanner. OK, before we can build the scanner, please gather material to make a portable refinery. That material is on another planet, which requires we fix your ship, which requires another 45 different types of materials to be gathers. Opps, your gathering tool needs to be recharged, please gather material for that. Oh, your inventory is full? Drop something, and be very careful what it is, because your ship is out of fuel, and you will need to gather material to get to the place where you need to gather material to fix your material gathering tool. 

Nope. Don't get me wrong, I don't mind grinding out in survival games, but this game is over the top in mind numbing, near zero progress, just gather to stay alive style gaming.

Still feels empty.. I guess it's the lack of simulated intelligence.. A few dumb NPC's in outposts here and there doesn't cut it.. When the game's got cities and a little story beyond a startup quest to get you going, it'll feel like it's got some meat on its skeleton. Until then, it's just expanded skeleton.. What's that saying.. Wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle?
i quite enjoy this funny little space game

This game's developers are amazing, truly have I never seen such determination from game devs. They could have left this game, took the money and run. They didn't. They released tons of free content and continue to expand and improve this game. No Man's Sky might not have the absolute best graphics, or sound, or animations, but remember that not everyone has millions of dollars in budget. What's most important in a game isn't how much money you put into it, it's the heart and soul put into the gameplay. 
    No Man's Sky is an excellent game in that regard. I cannot express how much this game means to me. The sense of excitement and wonder at discovering strange planets and the feeling of seamlessly flying out of a planet's atmosphere for the first time. I still remember that moment. All I could think was, "wow". No Man's Sky isn't for everyone though. Please do your research before buying this game because I hate seeing people purchase games and hate them and demand refunds. All in all, I will continue to play this game wherever it goes. Thanks for reading this review and I hope that you too enjoy the vast universe of No Man's Sky.

I am a 76 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing. I am a single father to my Son, who is 28 now. My son found this game at my house, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 276 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his work buddies or just watching tutorial videos. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. Loaded into the game world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

No Man's Sky is a testament to how games can evolve and flourish over time. What we have now is a universe of endless fun, a game that appeals to both newcomers and veterans alike. The progression system is brilliantly crafted, allowing players to feel a genuine sense of accomplishment as they journey through the cosmos.

The game's world is vast and diverse, offering something new and exciting around every corner. Whether it's discovering uncharted planets, trading with alien species, or engaging in space combat, the game keeps you engaged with its variety. The sense of wonder and discovery is palpable, making every gaming session unique.

What truly sets No Man's Sky apart now is its accessibility. The new additions and updates have transformed the game into an experience that is welcoming for new players while still offering depth and challenges for the seasoned explorers. The developers have listened to the community and have continuously improved and expanded the game, making it a shining example of what dedication and passion can achieve in the gaming world.

In conclusion, No Man's Sky now stands as a remarkable achievement in gaming. With its endless fun, excellent progression system, and a universe that keeps expanding, this game is a must-play for anyone who dreams of exploring the stars. It's more than a game; it's an ever-evolving adventure that welcomes everyone with open arms.

No Man's Sky stands as a testament to the power of redemption in gaming history. Hello Games has orchestrated one of the most remarkable comebacks in the industry, transforming a once-criticized title into a shining example of dedication and innovation. The game's initial release left many disappointed, but the ongoing commitment to improvement and a series of major updates have turned the tables.

The vast and procedurally generated universe of No Man's Sky is now a playground of endless exploration, offering a sense of awe and discovery that was initially promised. The addition of multiplayer, base building, and a myriad of new features has breathed life into the game, fostering a sense of community among players. The visuals are stunning, with diverse planets, flora, and fauna creating an immersive and captivating experience.

No Man's Sky's comeback story is a lesson in resilience and the potential for redemption in the gaming industry. It has evolved into a title that not only fulfills its promises but surpasses expectations, providing players with a vast and ever-expanding universe to explore and enjoy. This redemption arc is a shining example of how a dedicated development team can turn criticism into triumph.

I decided to try out No Man's Sky because I found the idea of actually playing it instead of Todd Howard's latest scam, that was about a similar idea of space exploration, to be pretty amusing. I also happened to be craving a specific type of casual exploration game that I just wasn't getting from many other popular games of the genre. I wanted a game where I didn't have to try so hard and I could make my own pace. My steam hours says I'm at about 150 hours but my actual save is only 100 and those hundred hours were mainly acquired in just the past couple of weekends that I had off from the day job. I've had to think on it to put into words why i was so addicted to this game, just know that i've gone in mostly blind; all I've known before hand was its trailers and the reception it had during its original launch....

It would be easier to point out what I didn't like about it first; mainly the writing. The "story" of No Man's Sky is, most of the time, pretty serviceable and occasionally thought-provoking; but is also quite amateurish in a few others, in such a way that damage the setting and make it appear shallower than it could have been. To go into detail would be spoilers so, to be short, it seems clear that the devs have a favorite race in the game (the Korvax) and the player character's dialogue is written to be a bit presumptive in certain untasteful ways during certain sections of The Artemis Path questline and a few other spots. 
My other main critic is the UI. There doesn't really seem to be an auto-sort of any kind and in fact, inventory management IS a primary gameplay mechanic. To be honest, having to manually sort and arrange the inventory, one tile at a time, is one of the aspects that kept me most addicted to this game; although that is clearly tedious and will put off some people. Your mileage may vary :^)

There is a lot I could say about what I like about it. To just say that it is "comfy" somehow doesn't feel like enough; it is a visually pretty game and, to my surprise, the soundtrack is very heavily Post-Rock, which is a genre I love, and is a big part of NMS having such a strong, and immersive atmosphere. All the content the devs have added over the years has added a significant amount of value to the experience, on top of the addicting gameplay. I loved taming creatures and showing them to other players in the game's online. 

Speaking of the game's online, in my experience, there are somewhat few english speakers but there are a good handful of players who were happy to give some free things. I rarely ever got to play Nexus missions with other players which i was a bit sad about, so I cannot recommend NMS if you are seeking a highly active online experience, much less in a language you can understand. 
This is ironic because learning alien languages is a secondary gameplay mechanic of No Man's Sky.

TL;DR I liked No Man's Sky a lot as a casual space exploration game, where you can even land on a planet from outer-space without a load screen.

[b]UPDATE: [/b] Holy balls, did Hello Games redeem themselves. Well done.

Put aside all of the hype and misleading statements from the developers and marketers behind No Man's Sky over the last three years and just focus on the actual game, for a moment.

[h1]What No Man's Sky Has Going For It[/h1]
The math. As an exercise in procedural world generation, it is fantastic. A universe of 18,000,000,000,000,000,000 planets, all procedurally generated by a bunch of math that all fits in a two gigabyte download is rather fantastic.


[h1]What Drag's No Man's Sky Down[/h1]

The user interface is terrible. Every time you change a setting or option, you have to restart the program. Every time you want to select a menu item, you have to hold a button and wait for a progress bar to fill up. That's right, want to click "confirm"? Simply clicking it isn't enough. Click and hold for a couple seconds, instead. It's clearly an interface designed for the console and a controller that was poorly ported.

After you have visited three planets and a space station, you have essentially seen everything the game has to offer. They are all minor iterations on each other. 

There are only a few types of things to find on each planet, you'll start to see the same plants and animals (but a different color, perhaps) on every planet. 

Every planet will have generally the same resources (at least minimal necessities).

The only gameplay element is really inventory management, which is poor. You can't even see what things you can craft unless you have a free spot to craft it in and you can't rearrange your inventory unless you have at least one free spot to use as a "middle man" as you move things about.

The first couple of planets are exciting. Such variety! It's amazing! But by the third, you realize the trick.

And then you start to realize even more of the flaws.

Every planet has the same gravity.

Every planet has plant and animal life on it.

Every planet has minerals on it.

Every planet has some  monoliths and stations on it where you collect essentially the same things.

It isn't even that pretty. It's kind of grimy looking. And even on a powerful system, you get this obnoxious sort of grainy "pop-in" as you travel over a planet.

And, ultimately, you shoot for the center of the galaxy . . . which is the end-game. And . . . well, if you really want to find out, just search youtube for the end. It's not worth it.


This game is a brilliant concept and if this were Early Access, it would be worth a lot of hype. Unfortunately, it's a full triple-AAA priced published title. And . . . it's just lacking. Lacking in everything.

The curiosity of this game would be worth $20 USD on sale at some point. As it stands now, it is difficult to recommend this game to anyone at full price. I may return to this game, someday, but only if they release a ton of additional content to it over the coming months.

I like Sean Murray. He seems sincere. I'm sure that he had the best of intentions with this title and there are no doubt stories to be told of how influences from partners drove them to the state the game is in right now . . . but when it comes down to it, this is an issue of "is what I'm getting worth sixty bucks?".  At the moment, not really.

At release this game was a train-wreck but over the years Hello Games has managed to make it into something truly remarkable. There's so much to do in this game that I doubt i'll ever finish doing anything in it.

I really like how they did the lore in this game, theres 2 main quests that gameplay wise are mostly fetch quests, but are amazing dialogue/writing-wise (same goes for the sidequests) then there's also tons of POI's in the game that give little bite-sized pieces of lore that you can piece together the more you find.

Hello Games is still giving the game a ton of love, adding massive updates every couple of months or so.
In my experience the Expeditions (limited time events for some exclusive rewards) do give a bit of FOMO pressure though.
(At time of writing this review, all of the updates and expeditions have absolutely no microtransactions; nor do any other parts of the game)

Some of the features can feel a little lackluster or random (i.e. faction standing), but the other 90% or so are great.

I've played the game for 24 hours at this point and I feel I should review it. It's worth noting - I feel like I've barely scratched the surface for this game.

Cons:
- Combat is infrequent and feels kinda awkward.
- The art style is a little cartoony.
- Base building is rudimentary and awkward. Please expand on this. (If you haven't already).
- What is an atlast pass and how does one acquire it? Lots of chests require them.
- Tutorial crafting of essential resources requires a bit of digging through menus. Either make it intuitive or make it arcane so I have to google and memorize it. Pick a lane.
+/- learning languages feels satisfying, while practicing languages is very tedious (but rewarding!).
- Alien non-sentients feel awkward, but unique.
- Having a unique UI takes some getting used to.

Pros:
+ Procedurally generated universes leave potentially endless content.
+  Biomes vary more than I'd anticipate.
+/- learning languages feels satisfying, while practicing languages is very tedious (but rewarding!).
+ There is a story that you can discover at your own pace. I'm very curious about how this plays out.
+ Discovering stuff is fun and rewarding. You can name your discoveries!
+ Space combat was awkward until I realized there's a hotkey to track enemy movement from your cockpit (It will automatically align your cross-hairs! I'm a terrible pilot!)
+ It seems like there's lots of free DLC, which is a very good selling point. I get the impression they're free seasons. I have fairly limited knowledge of how these work. I guess they're just free updates? Not quite sure "season" is the right word.
+ Bugs are minimal if present...
+ Hint: If your cavern fills in above you, dig up!

REVIEW AT RELEASE: 

3/10

With a lack of a tutorial, I actually had to Google the storyline of the game to figure out what I should be doing. Twice.
If I didn't have to do that, I actually would have likely given this game a higher rating. But they really just throw you into it, which some people are into, but I am definitely not.

If you like exploring, it's fun. If you like aimless wandering, it's fun.
If you like a structured storyline, it's not amazing.
If you get bored easily, it's definitely not the game for you. 

After playing for around 20-30 hours, I found that it really is just scanning, mining, jumping to a different planet, and managing your inventory.

EDIT: After trying to play more, the CTDs and stuttering are just ridiculous. Textures are terrible. I actually upgraded my graphics card so I could run at high rez textures (GTX 1070) and it still looks like LOD textures from Fallout NV. 

I thought perhaps more gameplay would open up after you jump a few star systems. It does not.

This game has for some reason managed to entertain me for what is now more than 80 hours, and it has done so in very different ways over its patch cycles. 
I already liked this game when it came out, as I hadnt really paid attention to the hype around it, so there was no preconceptions that couldve been dissappointed. At the Start, this game straight up enchanted me. 
It wasnt the gameplay loop, that although accessible and intuitive from day one, has remained one of its weaker points, it wasnt its super crisp, bloomy visuals (which I love nontheless), or the amazing and unique soundtrack composed by 65days of Static. No, what enchanted me for the first 40 Hours of playing this game, was its very unique quality, something I havent really been able to experience in any other Space-related game, any other Survival Game, or quite literally any game, for that matter: What enchanted me from the moment I took to Stars was the feeling of somber melancholy, of sad sublime, the absolute and crushing solitude that only Space can give you. As the games environment is procedually generated, a massive Universe spawned from a set of rules and a starting Seed, it really hammers down the metaphor of an uncaring cold and dead universe, not material, but digital in this case, in which desolate loneliness is the emotional Axiom. I havent been able to find this feeling in any other game ive played, ever. And I treasure the memories I made immersing myself in it. Later on, as the game evolved, its character become more lighthearted, warm, and the generation of its environment became more "realistic" and earth-like, and lost a bit of its surreality. I enjoyed the improved COOP-Mode, but that magical feeling of crushing insignificance in the face of an uncaring universe never came quite back. 
I wouldve given this game an 8/10, but it has changed. And while I think the countless free updates this game has gotten have objectively made it a better game, more accessible to a larger audience, and with more stuff to do, subjectively for me, it has lost a bit of the unique appeal it had to me. As of know, I still enjoy playing with friends from time to time, but ill never find myself resting at the silver beach of a purple ocean, with golden formations of Stone floating in the Air above, gazing at its surreal landscape elevation, and feeling the loneliness of a lost astronaut in a binary universe of LED-lightened Smoke, and Silicon Mirrors. As of now, id give it a 6/10

I don't really understand why people like this game...  it's very repetitious, and the combat is terrible.  If you want space combat, play Freelancer, and if you want resource-gathering and base-building, play Valheim or Subnautico.  I played for 12 hours and kept expecting it to get better, but it just never did.  It's worth mentioning that the UI is horrible.  I thought Borderlands 2 inventory interface was the pinnacle of intern-written UI's designed to make everything more frustrating than they need to be, but NMS takes the cake.

Hmm, probably also worth mentioning that there nominally is a plot, but it seems half-assed.  I mean, I'm mentioning it, but just to notify you that it's not worth mentioning.  Just, "Go to point X for reasons.  Now go to point Y for reasons.  Now there's a voice in your head that wants you to go to planet Z.  Then it wants you to go to planet W."  In other words, don't buy this game if you're hoping for a story.

...and just in case that wasn't enough, there are lots of aliens in space stations, but you can't communicate with them.  You can randomly find obelisks that teach you one word from a random language.  You can also ask aliens to teach you a word from their language (then you can no longer interact with them).  After 12 hours of begging every alien in every space station to teach me and hitting every obelisk I could find, I got to the point where I could read less than 1 word per alien dialogue sentence.  Maybe at 100 hours I'd be able to communicate...  but would it be useful?  I'm guessing no.  In the theme of recommending other games that do it better, if you want to communicate with aliens and have an interesting story, go play Star Control 2 (aka The Ur-Quan Masters), which happens to be free!
Honestly its the best survival game.

Revised Review from 2016 launch purchase (after doing all Redux Expeditions).

This game has come a massively long way from what it used to be in all the right ways (exploration, combat, building/crafting, lore, and accessibility). Despite the disastrous launch and merited negative criticisms, the development team and content designers have crafted a sprawling game with a sense of scale, awe, and space sci-fi atmosphere that few other games can replicate. 

The addition of expeditions has been a greatly refreshing and interesting experience for easing the player into the expanding the universe lore and getting them acquainted with in-game mechanics.

This is my ONLY recommended space exploration/crafting game and I can't think of any other game that can compete with this value. Neither Elite Dangerous or EVE online, both of which seem dry, worn out, and overly complex for the average person. 

Lacking is the rough combat that's still rather basic and isn't explored fully by deep combat-oriented achievements or objectives. I would also welcome the addition of player-crafted structures being populated within the planets until it becomes its own sprawling metropolis interconnected with other crafted/generated hubs, something similar to Dwarf Fortress and other crafting/exploration games like it.

Buy NMS, relax, and think about the beauty of the cosmos and creation in the comfort of your home.

9/10 (Nearly perfect game)

New review:

Its so much better now. There's now a separate slot for your suit/ship/freighter modules and your storage. There's a lot more storage now as well. The resource grind has also lessened a lot. Some hazard protections can recharge on their own, all modules have more than one refueling method, and the rewards for quests/looting are now much higher. Planets are now more varied and they all have many different points of interests. The team has also promised many more updates this coming year--supposedly the biggest year for No Man's Sky yet.

Some things I would like to see improvement on:

- Colonies/Settlements should have more NPC interactions. As of right now, the roaming NPCs in your settlements don't really do anything. The "mood" bar for your settlement is more or less meaningless and they increase/decrease based on your dialogue choices in random events. I would like to see an improvement where mood management is much more fluid--where you can talk to each NPC in your settlement and increase their moods through interaction and resource allocation, and have that reflected on the overall mood meter in the settlement's stats. Hello Games should take notes from other colony sim games. They can make it so an NPC's mood is increased if they have a home allocated to them, if they have good food, or if they have decorations in their home. That would elevate the settlement system immensely.

- They have unfortunately made the aesthetic too cartoonish in my opinion. The game used to look a lot more bland, but that also added to the game's realism. Now, everything in this game is overflowing with vibrancy and saturation. Even the little things like freighter rooms have started to look more cartoonish and less realistic/analog. The expedition command room have gone from an analog-looking computer terminal to a bright hologram-riddled mess.

- The render distance is atrocious. Even on max settings, there is still so much pop-in and low-res textures.

- They need to improve on the space station NPC interactions--which make up like 80% of your NPC interactions. The ones next to the trade terminal all have the same 4 dialogue options; and you can't just click one, you have to hold it down for it to register. They are extremely tedious and repetitive as a result.

- They need better tutorials. Like every minute I have to reference the fan wiki to find out what I'm looking for. 90% of the blueprints are unlockable via the Anomaly. The game does not tell you this. I have played for 30 hours on a new save and just recently found out that the components/modules I was missing were all unlockable via certain NPCs in the Anomaly.

Some other things every new player should know are:
- Freighters are the big ships that you can build in and house all your other ships.
- You can not pilot the freighter.
- You can only own one freighter.
- Frigates are ships that are bigger than your regular ships, but are smaller than your freighters.
- You can not pilot frigates.
- Frigates don't have modules or inventory.
- To get a freighter, you have to save one from a pirate attack in a random space-event. Your first freighter is free, but DO NOT claim it if you don't like it. Because you can only own one freighter, if a better one comes along, you will have to spend millions to exchange your old one for your new one. It is more efficient to just hold off on claiming your first free freighter until you encounter one that's B-class or above.


{Older review:

Really addicting but also extremely stressful. Resources are drained every second and every time you simply want to reposition your starship. I'm over here trying to find specific rocks to use as material to make other things, yet I'm constantly worrying about not having enough sodium or oxygen to refuel my life support or my hazard protection--all whilst stressing over whether or not I have enough inventory space. They really need to work on improving that. You can only store your items in your exosuit or in your starship if you haven't unlocked the storage container blueprint. Super tedious and annoying.}

Probably the best gameplay loop of anything I've tried in a long time. Resource gathering, basebuilding, exploration, and upgrading are all fun, and the degree to which you can customize is amazing. It has all the depth that I wish Elite Dangerous had. Now, if it just had a 6DOF flight model and realistic scale galaxies and star systems, this would be my favorite thing of all time.

All in all, I'd say it's well worth the price. I was a huge skeptic of NMS when it was first announced/released and held off on trying it for years, but I can definitely recommend it now.

Can be a lot of fun. Extremely wide range of things to do and collect, with an explorable universe orders of magnitude larger than any other game I know of. Each planet is not only fully explorable, but also can be built on and mined out (kind of like Minecraft except the building and mining is clunkier). The biggest problem is that the game can feel rather shallow - a large portion of content is generated from a random selection of attributes (for example, the color, body style, fins, nose shape, etc. of a spaceship are drawn from a pool of predetermined parts). Once you realize that many things only differ superficially based on these random changes, things start to feel much less interesting. Still, it's at least worth your money if it's on sale, especially if you like casually exploring and base building.

I struggled at first with playing because I kept getting frustrated & dying, but once I understood the game more and played with friends who had resources, it was much more enjoyable & fun! I like that the game offers both solo & multiplayer so if people want to get a feel of understanding the game solo, they can, but if they need help in multiplayer, they can do that too. I'm definitely the type of person to need in game help via resources or even chatting to explain what things do or how to do them, so the game is really enjoyable when I play with friends. I know some people would want to figure things out solo, which works just the same. The graphics can be a bit intense if you have a potato computer, but otherwise, really cool visuals with all sorts of environments, flora, fauna, minerals, materials, and more! Each system & planet is unique which is really fun to explore, plus the materials you gather are more or less accurate to real life, with raw materials refining into others and crafting useful parts. The quests are pretty engaging once you get into it too, and work with any play style. I personally liked playing on controller more than keyboard because the controls become somewhat simplified and it's easier to navigate when flying/attacking/etc, but either way works. Basically, fun exploratory/open world space game to play solo or with friends!

I loved this game at first but it just annoys the hell out of me now. It's not the game itself although it does get super repetitive after a month or two. Once you've seen one toxic planet or whatever you've pretty much seen them all. It's just variations on a theme and there's not much diversity. 

BUT what really annoys me is the insane amount of bugs. Refiners eating my resources instead of actually refining them into what I need. Game crashing while loading and freezing my PC. Just loaded the game to find all my ships and weapons are black with green stripes (none of my stuff is actually black with green stripes) and looks horrible. Multiple reloads haven't solved the problem so I have to quit and wait another 10 minutes for the game to even load. Yes, the game takes a good 10 minutes to load on my gaming pc and always has. Every other game loads fine. 

People say the devs work hard on the game but the fact remains that it hasn't EVER delivered what was promised at launch and, at times, barely functions or won't load at all. I had to load the game three times the other day before I could get past the title screen without crashing. 

I could not possibly recommend this game to anyone and I personally wouldn't buy another game by Hello Games ever again. Massive disappointment. I also notice the game now costs £10 more than when I bought it a year or so ago. Thank god I got it when it was on sale and didn't pay full price.

The "Single Player" gametype in the store page is misleading. Online services cannot be switched off, and you're always playing in the online world.

Edit: After painstakingly blocking this game off my firewall, it's really disappointing just how shallow it is. Random generation can work wonders if all of the content can be accessed be every player, just in different paths, but playing NMS means that there is some content that has either been lost to time (expeditions and twitch drops) or will never be seen by the player. Skip it. Play X4 if you like flying ships, or Starfield if you prefer exploring planets.

Edit 2: quick update after Starfield launched: don't buy it.

I have to be honest, when this game was first released, it was a massive disappointment, and even saying that is an obvious understatement. Yet, Hello Games has definitely sought to redeem itself with the progressive updates that have breathed new life into a game I thought was long dead and buried. It did take the developers quite some time to get on the road with making this game in the image it should have been released in, but the free updates and no paid DLC have placed Hello Games on the track towards redemption. I will update this review as this game continues to progress, but for now, I can recommend this game due to the rich updates and the newfound or rediscovered passion the developers have shown.

Missions feel glitched, needlessly slow at updating, or just all around inconvenient. I had to google several of the mission types, because they didn't give very accurate directions in how to complete them. Sometimes these missions would take me into a different galaxy, which can be inconvenient, but not as inconvenient as trying to figure out which galaxy you're supposed to jump to. I kept looking for a golden cone-shaped waypoint like what appears next to the mission you select and it took me a good 20min, and a little googling before I figured out I was supposed to warp to the galaxy with a plant-shaped waypoint/icon. Then I needed to look for the right planet to scan plants on, which was an entirely different issue. 
Main missions were boring to me. I had no real desire to read the dialogue as it was all very confusing and bland. The aliens themselves in this game seem very annoying to interact with as well, since they all react pretty poorly to meeting the character, but their dialogue also says otherwise. They also seem pretty un-phased whenever I, a complete stranger, enters their research facility on a lifeless planet in space. 
The multitude of different stores for different categories of items in the game feels unnecessary and borderline MMO-like. There's a store for your tool, ship, land vehicle, exosuit, and general goods to buy/sell along with a couple vendors that gives missions, and planetary charts in exchange for nav data. It is extremely excessive.
The multiplayer is hit and miss. I bought this game at the same time as a friend of mine. Once we figured out how to connect to each other, the game got a bit more fun for the both of us, but the portals we would to go to each other's bases seemed to only show up for the other in a list of portals to use whenever they felt like it. There was even one point where my friend was being attacked by a lot of pirates in a different galaxy, but whenever I warped to him, there were no pirates. None I could see, at least. They were completely invisible to me, but not him, as he panicked and flew around me. Yes, we were in the same online session. On the planets we would both visit, either of us would experience storms while the other wouldn't. Opposing temp readings as well on the same planet, and ships in the sky only one of us could see. So even though we were connected in the same multiplayer session, it felt like we were in different instances. Very inconsistent gameplay.
Other parts of the game you can unlock like settlements, and freighter expeditions seem very grindy.
If not for my friend still playing, I probably would have put this down a while back. We're still trying to find a place to build an underwater base. But if you've been to 15 planets, you've probably seen them all at that point. They all have the same 3 boxes to loot, the same 5 buildings scattered about, and the same minerals to mine/extract. After a while, it doesn't seem like there's anything worth doing or reason to explore any farther.

No Man's Sky is an open world sandbox experience that promises a near-infinite amount of creatures and planets to explore within more than one galaxy. That sounds great, but the real question still remains: is it fun? 

PROS:
+ Tons of exploration. In fact, this game's primary reason for existing is exploration.
+ You can discover new solar systems, planets, moons, animals (both land-based and aquatic), plant-life, and lots of minerals and rocks.
+ Planets and moons can have very different weather systems, including storms and other environmental disasters. 
+ If you're really inventive, you can take the time to name your discoveries instead of using the randomly-generated names that the game creates for you. 
+ You'll meet alien life (the majority of whom will be one of three races: the Gek, the Korvax, and the Vy'keen) and learn their language and culture. 
+ Space combat is fast and usually enjoyable.
+ You can build and decorate multiple bases on different worlds. 
+ All sorts of ships, ranging from small, nimble fighters to large, bulky haulers with lots of inventory space are available. 
+ There are numerous exocraft available, each with their own benefits and drawbacks. 
+ You can eventually purchase a freighter, a massive ship that lets you park all of your personal starships, in addition to being a mobile base (that can be built and decorated, just like planetary bases) that can jump to systems far further away than your ship ever could. 
+ You can modify the components of your exosuit, multi-tool (which is essentially you're mining tool and your gun), ship, and freighter.
+ Graphics look decent. Despite numerous updates to the game over the years, the core engine was still released in 2016.
+ Different game modes, including creative and custom, exist for players who want a more relaxed experience or wish to make some aspects easier and other aspects more difficult. 
+ Controls include mouse and keyboard, gamepad (or controller, whichever term you prefer), and flightstick. I have no idea if HOTAS (hands on throttle and stick) works in NMS. 
+ You can play NMS as a normal game (using a monitor) or in VR. 
+ Cooperative gameplay is available.
+ Compatible with Windows 10/11 (and technically Windows 7, although Steam no longer supports Win7 and I heard co-op functionality doesn't work on Win7 either), Linux via Proton, and Mac OS. 
+ Steam Cloud (so you don't have to worry about backing up your game).

NEUTRAL:
+/- Your character is an adult human of undetermined sex. In other words, you control a silent protagonist and there's nothing physically obvious to indicate "this is a male body" and "that is a female body." 
+/- The game's building mechanics are very weird, especially when it comes to properly sealing bases on planets with inhospitable weather. Properly placing items within a base is a major chore as some snap into place, but most just have to be "eyeballed" and as anyone who's ever hung up a painting or rearranged furniture can tell you, this can quickly become very annoying. 
+/- No survival game mechanics. While I'm glad we don't have to manage food, water, and sleep, some gamers love it, so I figured I'd add this bit of info here for the survival game fans out there. 

CONS:
- While procedural generation means you'll find a ton of different lifeforms and biomes to explore, it also means that many of these same combinations are haphazard and make very little sense. In particular, the animals have some of the weirdest combinations I've ever seen. 
- You can't change anything about your ship's appearance. No matter how screwed up the ship looks (and many of them look unbelievably bizarre), that's how it'll always be and you can't do anything about it. You can't even change your ship's color, which is odd because you can change your freighter's colors. 
- In combat, if you even accidentally graze a ship when fighting off pirates, you'll now be treated as a pirate yourself and attacked by that ship and other ships near it. Fortunately, you can reset this by landing on a freighter or on a station, but even so you shouldn't become "public enemy #1" if you accidentally hit someone once. 
- The controls are extremely clunky. There are often numerous steps to do things (such as calling your freighter or scrambling a pirate scan of your cargo) and even then, there's very little consistency as sometimes some buttons will do "this" but won't do "that" yet at certain times they will. This is especially noticeable when some buttons do double or triple-duty. A good example would be the times I've hit "X" on my controller to lock on to an enemy fighter only for the game to tell me "you can't land here."
- Messages relating to everything constantly appear in the lower right-hand corner of the screen. Not only is that annoying, but it also covers up important screen information in starships.
- Milestone messages appear so frequently that it comes a detriment. When a milestone message pops up, it narrows the screen and then slowly tells you you've taken thirty steps or some other nonsense. You can fast forward through this by pressing TAB on the keyboard, but it's still frustrating to see it pop up when you're doing stuff. 
- Cooperative gameplay in NMS barely works. You can join someone else's game just fine, but that's about it. Want to complete missions together? Too bad. The best case scenario is only one of you gets credit, but more often than not, missions won't function properly or at all. You'll often see different things as well. One of you might see a pirate capital ship attacking while the other won't see anything or one of you will be building a base that looks complete, but the other person will see gaps (that they can fly or fall through) in the floor and walls. Also, good luck finding each other if you start in different star systems. Sure, the galaxy map will show your co-op partner's icon, but because the map is three-dimensional and absolutely massive with no way to orient yourself, you're unlikely to see the other person's icon at all. 
- There's a huge amount of important gameplay information that's not explained in-game and instead relies either on trial-and-error or necessitates asking people on a forum or using a wiki. Games should be self-contained, in that all the relevant information should be accessible to players from the game itself. 
- The game ultimately becomes busywork, with the vast majority of missions repeating themselves or most of your time being taken up by scanning plants and rocks. I realize this is a common drawback to sandbox games, but even so, there's very little to do that you haven't done a million times before and you don't even have interesting NPCs to keep the game going. 

VERDICT: So is No Man's Sky a fun game to play? Yes, but with quite a few caveats. If Steam used a one-to-five star rating system, I'd give it three stars because NMS is a good game overall, but there are lots of problems that negatively impact the experience. 

I'd only recommend NMS if you primarily enjoy single-player sandbox games centered around exploration. If you really want a good co-op game or prefer an RPG or a space combat action game, I'd suggest passing on NMS entirely.

No Man's Sky is good now, they said; it's actually multiplayer now, they said. 

I finally caved during this past Winter Sale and bought NMS for myself and the homies as a game for all of us to play. I heard it was god awful for so long but then people started saying good things and I'd debated trying it for years. Now, here we are. I wanted to like this game. I really wanted to like it. 

Here's the problem, the teensy wittle tiny problem: its still not fucking multiplayer. After like 12 major updates, each adding new systems and features, this games tutorial is as long as Persona 5's. And if you're playing w friends, you each must complete every step, alone. Half of it is base building and, even if you are all grouped and whatnot, you each have to build a base, you cant collectively build a commune. This means you each have to gather the enormous amount of materials needed to construct everything, and this, coupled with the fact that bases cannot be built in each others territory, essentially means the game forces you apart. Gather materials together? It'll take way longer because you all need the same things and because your bases have to be pretty far apart some of you got a commute to get back. Go adventuring together? Well only one of you gets credit for the kills, the resources for scanning new discoveries, the valuable rare resources you stumble upon. Yes, now you can see other players, go to their bases, etc, but it's still not multiplayer.

Once you have unlocked every system in the game, NMS feels like a mobile game. Log into the game to tend to your settlement on its hour timer, send your fleet on missions on its 4 hour timer, harvest your crops on an 8 hour timer, do fetch and kill quests to raise reputation with a few factions, and gatcha roll warping to new systems and exploring to see if you can find any rare ships or multitools, not with real money, but with resources you constantly have to collect. 

NMS is a single player crafting MMO, if you go into it for that experience, you'll probably like it. Don't expect anything else.

I wanted to like this game. The exploration of a stylized, star-system-filled galaxy has always been a draw for me in gaming. The promise of seeing new things every time you venture off the planet or rocketing away from whatever space station you start from was a compelling idea. You ostensibly can create for yourself real estate portfolios busting at the seams with any mood or notion you woke up with and build an empire of custom property and fleets of warrior/diplomatic/entrepreneurial spacefarers. You can have access to the cultural richness of a wide array of alien races; each species with their own values and each individual with their own personalities and motivations. You can fight, you can embrace, you can betray, you can get them ducats, you can meditate on the meaning of existence while pointing your ship in a direction and punching the throttle. A universe of possibilities.

It is not a common state for me to believe the marketing claims of any product, especially computer software, especially especially video games developed over the last decade, but I played until I couldn't stand it an longer. Over 100 hours and not accomplishing much at all. Bare in mind, it was not the length of time and minimal progress that made me sour so much towards NMS, I play games fully and over long periods of time regularly. It was actually two things that broke me. 

One, of all the time I spent in that universe, nothing surprised me or gave me any sense of awe after the planet I first spawned on after starting a new game. Even that got old at an uncomfortably swift clip. The core game mechanics seem to revolve around activities: finding new life on planets, completing missions, completing tasks (in my mind these are the missions that are completions of essentially chores), and piloting your ship from planet to planet to fulfill the latter 3 things. each of these things are highly repetitive; quickly, and in the slowest possible ways, becoming a tedious slog. Moreover, you need money and nanites (no real difference except they are used to exchange for different things in an awkwardly arbitrary way) for acquisition of items and resources, all of which are randomized in their respective locations...every time you want them and even if it's the same location. It's been expressed many times before, but the problem lies in relying so heavily on procedural generation. Not just for the planetary features or the organisms that live on them, but also for all of the NPC interactions, side missions, and inorganic items you come across or produce. It forces the game to come across heartless and brain dead, ending up with no purpose or intent for the amnesiac (truly original) you control to do literally anything in the worlds of NMS.

Two, and the most obvious, is the S-tier (a purposeful pun) levels of jank in the game. I refuse to outline the specific bugs from the tome of examples I've created because after describing what I was dealing with to a coworker a couple days ago, having to live through those bugs again, I was left with a severe headache afterward. However, the last time I loaded the game, the ship I was piloting, just before I hopped out to save and then exit the game, was missing its entire cargo. It wasn't even the valuable, high-unit items I cared about. It was the time and effort I put into amassing the things that would keep me from having to return to port so often. Items whose purpose was to relieve the tedium to the point of being bearable, and that took me days to accumulate, were taken from me, leaving me knowing that I would have to do it all over again to return to a flow where inventory management wasn't my lord and master. A brutal flashback of my first problem overwhelmed me. It was quitting time for good. I had heard the bugs in this game used to be worse and the thought of that makes me want to alleviate my headache with a power drill.

This game's only purpose seems to be keeping you playing it. Not with an intriguing story or novel gameplay, but through the same compulsive obligation we feel from unfulfilling jobs; made worse, and even longer, by the excess of immersion-breaking bugs. Also, I believe "sandbox" , since the developers don't make the game, the players do, should come with features, hopefully more than one or two, that are unique. NMS fails at that, too. It is an experience whose only inspiring takeaway, at least for me, comes from the beautifully composed screenshots you can take with the in-game tool, and since the depth of the game is what has just been laid out, if you have seen any of the screenshots, you've played the game.

--------------------
Question
--------------------
Since this is a technologically advanced reality, where the hell are the maps? The planets you haven't visited or scanned are called "unmapped planets", so maps exist, but they don't use them? (I know about the galactic map, but again, you can barely tell what's going on there and you still can't go to specific planets on it which wastes even more time...long press...)

You can figure out, in this universe, how to beam inventory 200 meters to and from your starship hold, but you can't figure out how to access your vault without physically opening it? A game that 80% of is inventory management and no sorting of inventory? records of inventory were some of the main reasons writing on Earth was invented at all, and in the game's universe, that's beyond their ability? How do the developers think computers even function?

Online Co-op is basically a lie. It runs so poorly, with drop-ops happening every minute, that it is impossible to play this game together. Even in single player the game runs terrible for a modern game. Pop-in is horrible, the game stutters way to much, and the UI and controls for keyboard are basically non-existent. So many problems plague this game from the second you start playing. People say this game has gotten better since launch? How is that possible when it's still feels like a Beta build 7 years later. Do not buy this game, just buy any other space exploration game and you'll have more fun.

I was planning on writing this review a few hours ago, and at that point I was planning to write a glowing review about how engaging to story was and how expansive the general game play was, but I put it off, and during that time, I finished the main quest line which up until that point had honestly been quite enjoyable, but as soon as I finished it I was transported to another galaxy (as intended) and all of my stuff was broken (as intended). The only caveat is that I had a special ship (which was only a B-tier, so it wasn't even that good) that required specific materials that I didn't have and would have taken hours to find, and a significant amount of RNG to boot. This truly put into perspective for me how much of this game is actually just mindless grinding for menial loot. I think over the past few days I have spent hours simply sitting at trading posts and space stations waiting for a good ship to come through but nothing has happened. That was particularly egregious to me, so I took a break then went back to the "normal game play", however, this normal game play was actually just more grinding, more fetch quests, and more RNG. On top of the more central grindy aspects of the game, simply existing in the game is a grind, you have to replenish your core life support, as well as many different specific environmental options based on the different planets. Then on your ship you have a limited amount of launches to use, as well as replenishing the fuel in your hyperdrive and your pulse engine, but this is one of the more of the reasonable ones.
On top of the incredibly mind-numbing grind of this game, the quality of life is simply nonexistent. The usage of the inventory screens can be acquired but is still slow and at first feels very unnatural. The movement feels deathly slow without the ability to melee jetpack which is possibly an exploit, yet is the only thing that makes moving on foot bearable. The ship battles are unfortunate at best, as I always end up simply holding down the auto-lock feature and pressing my mouse to shoot the enemy.
This game is incredible! I would recommend it.

So far I've been completely derailed from the main quest because I found a crashed solar sail ship on a backwater planet and decided to make my own sidequest to fix it up. Then I got lost in a cool underground cave complex.

Apparently multiple players have coordinated to populate a specific area of space as a player-run civilization, so I will try to visit that area as my next goal. Plus I get to be a chonky turtle lizard person.

10/10 experience so far and I've barely started.

A success story: truly the best space exploration game from the ashes of a terrible, awful launch.

NMS is a game meant to be played over a long period of time, and just casually making stuff, like a nicer base, starships, frigates etc. while exploring the galaxy for however long you wish for. Its story is rather short but also drawn out in the same time, and the related quests are very repetitive to get there. However, once you finish the main story, you just get to enter the free roam again and do as you wish.

Because of this VERY slow burn, this game is not for everyone. And it is also not for me as well. I liked the exploration, I like the settlement building and managing, new planet and biome exploring and more, but there is no reason for me to stick to this game for longer, which is something I realized very late on. I wasted a lot of time mining materials and money, just to not have anywhere to dump it on unless I wish to make everything extremely rare (S class everything grind), which again, was not in the picture for me, because I didn`t care if I had everything maxed out, I enjoyed where things were. 

I don`t have much else to say about the game. Exploration is interesting enough, and it keeps you engaged for a nice 30-ish hours while you explore new stuff, after which is it just becomes a grind fest. 

There are a few things I really did not like about the game:

 1. There is almost no danger in the game. Very few dangerous plants and animals that are way too easy to spot and kill, a few rebel enemies and only one faction that truly *rules* over the whole universe. All of them, even the most dangerous enemies are not that hard to kill, or to evade.
2. A lot of stuttering problems. While it never crashed, it stuttered A LOT of time during the loading period of large areas, and this stuttering continued on for quite a while afterwards, making it almost permanent. 
3. Variety. No matter how randomized things are, you will start seeing patterns very fast. Most of things look different, while having the exact same role as the other 99 similar objects (being plants, ships, tools or other).

Overall, NMS is not a bad game, but it certainly deserved much more options. 6.5/10

I first tried this game in VR. Let me just say it wasn’t perfect and it was challenging to get it in a working state. But it was to be expected, many reviews here informed me about it. But those reviews also convinced me it was the right time to buy this game. Even if VR wasn’t perfect, I fell in love with this game in VR. After a few hours, I had to switch to a flat screen because I couldn’t play as fast as I wanted.

Regarding the game itself, it simply has so much for everyone. You have space ships, space fights, you have a playable character (not just a spaceship), your character can fight, you have vehicles, you can  build bases, you have progressions (suits, weapons, ships, vehicles, etc.), you have customization, you have so much more… Yes, there’s a lot of grinding but in this game it feels relaxing to me. The planets are so beautiful! I can jump in, do 1 or 2 missions, mine a little here and there, warp to another system, discover new planets, etc. In one word, amazing!

Now for the DEVs. You have done a wonderful job. I love it and I’m obviously not the only one! But please don’t stop there. This game could be a reference in VR if you want it to be. With the visuals you have, you could easily achieve that. On a flat screen, I can play the game in ULTRA everything. In VR it’s playable with everything set to minimum and with GPU settings carefully chosen. Almost everything was blurry, the quest panel doesn’t move when you turn your head so it ends up in your back most of the time. Looting is challenging to say the least, you move closer, you go left, you go right, you go back. In my case it was to a point where I simply left loot behind… If things improve in VR I’ll be the first to try it again even after 100s of hours played (one day or the other...).

I just finished my first galaxy, and while I'm not sure I'll "complete" another, I'll at least stick around to complete some of the sidequests. At this point, I can say that I recommend this game for what it is. It's a repetitive, resource gathering, base building, space exploration/adventure game. It also has a general vibe of existential loneliness to be ready for...which is part of the core story, so I'm not just making that up! 

What the game gets right is progression and rewards. You will slowly gain more powerful ships, suit tech, multitools, exocraft of various types...all of these help you explore more of the universe. You can even gain your own fleet of capital ships to send out on resource gathering missions.  Quests (including handcrafted ones) make good use of the procedurally generated worldscape, which is a stark contrast from a certain other game that just came out. 

Overall, I'd say to expect 50-80 hours of enjoyment here.  It's true that some have played for thousands in a similar fashion to Minecraft. But just like that game, you're eventually going to see and do just about everything you can.

This game is awful for new players. Started the first quests and lost track of the ship. I couldn't find it and was stuck. Looked online and it said I needed visor. I don't know how to get and install a visor, so I restarted thinking maybe the game with show me how later on. Restarted followed the quest got mapped in my head so I didn't lose the ship this time. I took of in the ship and went through the flight quests. landed on a planet and it told me to hit F for the visor scan... Right so tutorial quest fails again. Apparently you need a visor installed, however you don't get one to start. The game doesn't show you how to get one. This game sucks for new player as the dev doesn't care how to teach you anything. I just have to keep tabbing back and forth between the internet and the game to understand how to play it. The tutorial is missing key functions of the game making it stupid to try and start playing. This is probably a great game for those who are continuing players, but it sucks for anyone interested in starting it new.

Want to explore planets? Go for it. 
Want to build up bases? Sure.
Want to become an outlaw space pirate? No problem.
Want to just explore the vastness of outer space? Lets do it.
Want to go underwater exploring? Yep can do that to.

These are just some of the things that you can experience and more the sky is the limit.

There are some negatives after awhile the planets feel kinda the same even though it does a good job of varying them. However the cut and paste buildings you run into all have the same layout just maybe different colors and bits and bobs inside. That does not detract from all the fun one can have. Highly recommend this if you want a more slow paced exploration game with some survival elements. Haven't tried the multiplayer so I cannot comment on it.

I feel like generally No Man's Sky is in the best state that it's ever been in, and I enjoy playing it. A lot. There are hundreds of hours of content, with much more to come throughout 2024, and I genuinely recommend this game to anyone who likes either sandbox or space exploration games.

It is a fun change for an mmo player to be given the chance to scratch around in this sandbox.  Yes there are bugs, but frankly not as many as the big AAA games I have played.  And for those of us who like to see what is over the next hill, or next galaxy it scratches that itch nicely.  It is a casual game, multiplayer kind of patched in but certainly not perfectly - but it's Gud Enuf to check off that box.  
My only real complaints are the startup for first time players.  The OMG where am I and wtf do I do before I die yet again.  Enjoy that adrenaline push, it wont happen ever again.  And building is a bit fidgety and limited, especially for us on the pc.  All the cool things we can't do that those with a controller can is annoying.  And the setup of the build menu is really hard to get used to and inconsistent in its presentation.  But those are small complaints, unless I am in the middle of a build........
On the whole, am glad I got it, feel the goodening of Sean Murray & HG was accomplished and it is a game now worth buying, especially if you can get it on sale.

Update after many more hours.  Still enjoy this game a lot.  Been thru 3 expeditions and they do get me out of my comfort zone.  there are bugs and glitches but for some reason they mostly don't effect me too much.  The constantly worrying about saving is probably my biggest gripe (2023 no longer an issue).  Losing hours of play can be pretty disheartening.  Other than that, it's a great game.  Just buy it.
4000+ hours in and it's still a great game.  Yup, a few bugs, but not really an issue.  So many upgrades to the game since I started and all for free.  Now there's almost too much content at the beginning.  My favorite sandbox until Light No Fire drops.

I love this game.  It's both simple and challenging, and the devs change things up often enough to keep me coming back.

I was originally reluctant to try it, because the notion of an endless procedurally-generatred universe didn't sound too appealing; but reading more and more enthusiastic reviews eventually led me to take the plunge and I'm glad I did.

I am especially fond of the Community Expeditions, added in the past year or two.  Thanks, devs, for a wonderful game!

This is my second review in my two years of being a part of the Steam community and playing many games.

While this game may not be the best, it also is not the worst. It gives off a similar vibe to playing an adult version of Minecraft. The idea of time travel and the specific upgrades needed to travel in different light years resonates with those of us who enjoy the reality of the Galactic Universe, akin to the Interstellar levels.

Getting this game at 50% off is a great deal, especially considering that the developers have not charged anything for the numerous updates over the last 7 years. The game is not difficult to understand, especially for those who are dedicated to understanding how survival, real life physics, and mechanics are applied within the game, making it easy to pick up and play.

It is also very friendly to mods and can be customized to how realistic you want the game to feel. Apparently so real that you could even play it in VR... ( I still have yet to try with my oculus but I'm looking forward to it) 

Overall, the developers have gained a fan in me.

P.S.. I'm glad I didn't buy Starfield.

very space

It's better at being a space exploration game than Starfield. However this is like comparing two expired bottles of milk and saying hmm I think this one will give me milder case of diarrhea when consumed.

- The basic gameplay cycle is not fun, as it's just an endless cycle of holding down mouse1 on rocks and plants. 
- The "main" story is not fun as it's a bunch of fetch-quests with a lot of pretentious text. No, I don't have hidden masochistic tendencies and would prefer not to have to click on "submit" or "cry out" thank you, maybe some of the people who wrote this garbage should consider visiting a psychologist instead. 
- The combat is not fun as the enemies doesn't even have basic collision detection and will freely clip through objects or spawn behind/below indestructible terrain and make the engagement impossible to finish.
- The exploration is not fun because either you are on ground and cannot see very far or you are in your spaceship and the game instantly toggles LoD mode and de-renders anything further than 50m away from you meaning that either you are hoovering over the ground or cannot see anything at all. The unique planet is maintains a "cool" factor for an entirety of 15 seconds until you realize there's nothing significant mechanics wise there and you can't enjoy the visuals due to above issues.
- The UI is extremely bad and I feel like the people who designed the UI did not play the game at all. Many of the keys cannot be re-bound at all. The default hotkey for changing tabs on freighter inventory is E and one of the default keys to interact with an inventory item is also E, so half of the time you want interact with an object you end up switching inventory tab instead. Navigating is entirely manual as the game lacks basic QoL things like having more than 1 custom marker/highlighted landmark. You can not set waypoints on planets to go to so you end up wasting time spinning around in space to find the planet you want to go to. You cannot set any sort of proper filtering for systems. There's no sort or move multiple function on inventory. If you run into a sudden encounter that requires one item and you have the materials to make the item but not the item itself the quest just fails. Because your choices are Give item (you can't) and Decline (fails quest)
- The base building is a downer as there's very few objects with mechanical significance and rest is static decorations. The part snapping is unwieldy as there's a minimum range of snapping meaning you have to step away to snap something to a nearby wall or platform.
- The game does not respect your time, as ships, tools and upgrades are all RNG generated stat wise to artificially pad the time a player has to spend. This is some shit mechanic you have on Pay2Win MMOs where you can swipe for better chances, except there's no Pay2Win here, you just lose (your time spent) by default. There is no option to auto disable the "now entering XXX" or "reached XXX milestone" that locks any interactions while its useless waste of time animation is playing meaning you need to manually cancel it each time (which isn't instant either)  

- The game is unpolished and full of bugs. Are you fighting sentinel ships in planetary zone? Can't finish encounter because the Carrier is now invisible. Driving your vehicle on bumpy terrain? You just insta-died for no reason. Trying to dock to a station or freighter? Your ship is trapped the building geometry, repeatedly takes damage for bumping into it and then you die. Trying to generate items with base placeables? It's inventory just reset and your stuff is lost. Shooting things on land? Your tool just suddenly stops shooting or pressing reload does nothing or the tool just lowers itself down for no reason. Destroyed the enemy dreadnought ship? Encounter starts again and continues forever as 2 enemy ships keeps respawning endlessly. Trying to scan all fauna on a planet? Too bad there's 2 (two) different underground creatures and somehow underground creatures are only coded to spawn caves that happens to be near PoIs except only one of them spawns and you can never get the second one. The first person view of ship and land is makes me feel claustrophobic but the 3rd person isn't even properly aligned with the camera meaning you're often unable to highlight/scan what you are looking at without switching back to first person.

But yeah still a better space game than starfield.
Approaching 500 hours since 2018, and this game still amazes me every day.

Added TL:DR: Yes! I wholeheartedly recommend this game! It is excellent and definitely worth playing if you like this sort of experience.

I would say that it's insane how different this game is from when it first launched and how crazy good it is nowadays, but to be honest, the game speaks for itself. The developers could have cut & run, but they didn't and holy heck this game is absolutely amazing for it!

I never thought that, as a veteran MMORPG player, that I'd get that feeling of euphoria upon seeing another real person in the same game world as me again, but well, NMS gave me that feeling once again, and I am eternally grateful for that moment. That and the game now has bases, story-lines (as in multiple), a huge amount to see and do including setting up settlements, upgrading them, becoming their leader and even creating a fleet of ships which never gets old.

So yeah, in summary, I very much approve of this game! :D

No Man's Sky has a certain charm to it, I find myself constantly returning to the game. Each time I find new things, a strange planet with impossible features, animals that are colossal and tiny. I could write a huge list of all the things I've found on my travels and it's just a small insignificant amount compared to what has been archived over the years.

And one thing that really stands out to me is that if you found it, it's your discovery. You can name and upload any animal, rock, plant, planet even the star system itself if you found it first. It's like you're leaving a mark in the universe that maybe someone will find someday and see you where there.

The game also has very fascinating lore if you pay attention to it, I'm not going to talk about it at all though it's best discovered on your own. Music is great to.

Stop hesitating, go roam the sky's of no man and leave your mark in the universe

No Man's Sky, an ambitious space exploration game, has evolved significantly since its launch. Initially facing criticism, the game has undergone numerous updates, transforming it into a rich and immersive experience. It offers vast, procedurally generated galaxies to explore, each filled with unique planets, wildlife, and ecosystems. Players can engage in various activities such as mining, trading, space combat, and base building. The game's multiplayer aspect allows for shared adventures in the vast universe. Its redemption story is a testament to the developers' commitment, making No Man's Sky a remarkable journey worth embarking on, especially for those seeking a boundless and ever-evolving space exploration experience.
minecraft in space

If you enjoy exploring, basebuilding, crafting, bit of space fighting? I think you'll really enjoy this game, I sure do. Ingame tutorials are excellent, and online too. The first hour or so is pretty intense as there is so much to learn, but once you've got your base, know how to buy stuff, fly in space, you're well on your way to really enjoy this one.

I'm fairly sure this game is as good as it's being hyped up to be. But I just won't be able to enjoy it in good faith. And that's cuz 10 minutes in, the thing BROKE MY GRAPHICS CARD. Which makes no sense, the thing should have been able to take it, but...oh well.

I barely got to play the game, and yet I had to send it back for a refund because it broke my computer and forced me to pay $300 for a new graphics card. And I can't forgive Hello Games for that. They'd have to pay me back every penny of what I lost before I'll play this again.

Don't let this bad review discourage you from playing this game, I'm sure it IS actually good, but because of what happened I need to vent, and will likely never set foot into this game again.

I wish that one of these reviews mentioned that this game does not allow you to invert the camera x-axis, only the y-axis.  For most people this isn't an issue, but for a significant subset of gamers, mainly those who have been playing 3D games since the 90s, this limitation of the camera controls renders the game unplayable.  It's very hard to re-train your brain on something you've done for decades.  Most developers understand this, and allow inversion of both the x and y camera axis, or they at least allow this to be achieved using Steam to alter the controls (this game inexplicably overrides the Steam controller settings, the only game I've seen do this).  If you google this issue, you see numerous discussions begging Hello Games to make this simple addition, but after several years it's clear that they are content to ignore this subset of gamers.  Attempts to email the company for an explanation have been ignored.  So I guess what I'm trying to say is f**k this game, f**k this company, and do not buy if you need inverted camera controls.

Amazing game. To give my honest opinion about this game would take hours on end, so let me list the 3 main positives and the main negative:
Positives: 
-Great Graphics that do take a while to load in but once loaded in can be breathtaking at times. I would recommend for new comers to try and find these worlds to then share them to others in the form of coordinates
-Amazing story that had me locked in and on the edge of my seat at times. I got to love and know many of the characters which made me come to love the lore just as much
-The amount of things to do in this game will keep you playing this game for hours and hours. There are so many maps and story lines to keep the average player entertained for at least 50 hours before they begin to get bored in the time period that you grind No Man's Sky.
Of course with the positives come the drawbacks of this game however some are to be expected:
-The Repetition is the only main drawback. When many first come to look at this game, many critics online mention the amount of repetition in maps, layouts, and planets. I am here to say that the Critics are only partially true. Fauna and Flora do repeat often depending on the planet type but not entirely, so a couple plants may pop up more then once but other different types you've never seen before are there as well. Also even 100 hours into the game, you will have those breathtaking moments with "Redacted" Planets and Paradise Planets. Other than that, ship types as well as buildings, derelict freighters, frigates, etc will repeat as well but maybe that's because the building style is so good? idk
Conclusion: 
No Man's Sky is worth the buy and the 50 initial hours you will put into this game. As long as you can handle the repetition will this game fully thrive and show you some amazing moments. Only feedback I have to the developers is to make the ships more complex, not to the point where we have to play mechanic for an hour, but so that each ship while looking similar might have different engine components or singular pipes that we can customize to maximize stats. Overall, please buy this game and get an idea of its wonder for yourself

It's a game I've played on many different platforms almost since release. It can absolutely be regarded as the biggest comeback in gaming history and hello games should be truly proud of what they've accomplished. Over time no man's sky has evolved into my all-time favourite game. I've recently moved over to steam deck with it and it runs perfectly. I've invested probably thousands of hours into this game over the years and it still never ceases to surprise me.

However it does have some very small issues. The combat and especially the PvP can leave you wanting more. A PvP/combat update is sorely needed. It can be a little janky in 3rd person. And there's a graphical bug where the right wing of the hauler class starships are always black unless you get within like 1 metre of it then it renders in. But if the wing leaves your FOV at any time it goes back to black. I've experienced this for years on the PS and still experience it on the steam deck and I have no idea why it's not been patched coz I've seen it in the game for years and it's the only reason I don't use haulers which is a shame because they're my favourite ship. 

Despite all that all it's flaws are completely overshadowed by what an absolute work of impeccable art this game is. It will lead you on an endless journey through an endless universe with endless things to discover, mysteries to solve, bases to build and relationships to forge. This is a game game you can truly get lost in as a wanderer of the stars. I don't want a no man's sky 2, I don't need a no man's sky 2. I just want them to continue updating this absolute masterpiece of gaming.

Overall score I'd give it is 30/10
