No Man's Sky stands as one of the most well known and infamous redemption stories in gaming history. What we have today is NOTHING like the bare bones tech demo we got almost eight years ago. It still has issues like bugs, desyncs, weird design choices (the elimination of certain menus...why?), etc. However, the game is so filled with things to do and offers such a colorful universe to explore that it's truly difficult to hold Hello Games' past wrong doings against them. Despite all the toxicity from the community, they really managed to pull it off in the end and give us something special. I honestly cannot wait, like truly excited, for Light No Fire. See you all there.
The amount of content and game tech in this game is staggering. This is truly a game like no other, and the fact that it still receives updates is amazing.

Simply beautiful. Easily one of, if not the best games I've ever played. This game is proof of a community and Dev team that genuinely care about the game. Something that can be played at one's own pace. It can be as relaxing as it is exciting. Thank you.

If you enjoy space exploration, combat and research. Well then this game is for you.
You can study plants, animals and even planets and then, the best part, you can name them whatever you like.
Research not your style? Well you're in luck!
You can fight waves of pirates out in space, Defend settlements down on the planet, you can even fight the authorities!
Combat not your thing either? Guess what! There's more!
You can explore all the different types of planets and moons out there. So are completely lifeless, abandoned. While some are crawling with life.

If there is one thing I've noticed with No Man's Sky it's that you can create your own path, build your own base and so much more.

Please consider buying the game, trust me... You most likely wont regret it and might even thank me.

[h1] Review [/h1]

kinda hate how games turn out these days, especially this one, but nonetheless, its a good game.


[h2] Expectations VS Reality [/h2]

the reason i first bought this game was because of the way it gave you the option to exlpore a whole galaxy, read about interesting fauna and flora, build habitats wherever, and progress your tech and become the ultimate astonaut. 
and while thats entirely possible, its not what the game strives to be nowadays. its beginning to turn more into a: get big ships with good stats, make a money farm and become a rich guy flying around focusing on becoming the most overpowered guy around. 
that being said, i have to mention:

[h2] Incredible Support [/h2]

as everyone and their grandma knows, this game has had, probably, the biggest comeback in gaming history, with updates coming out every year since the release, still at the time of writing this review, 7 years later. the thing i find incredible is how its all made by a small team, under 50 people! 
every update this game gets makes it a more enjoyable experience, and at this point, im sat thinking how they continue to make these updates of great quality, but apparently, its one of steams top sellers, which i find jaw dropping.

[h2] Core [/h2]

at launch, reviewers described the gameplay loop as something like this: hold down your mouse button to pick up rescources, deal with a full inventory, get an upgrade, leave the planet, go to another planet, repeat.
and now it looks more like this: hold down your mouse button to pick up rescources, leave the planet, take part in a space battle, get a giant ship, go to another system, encounter a broken big ship with lore and interesting loot, land on a planet, encounter one of many different POI's, get an awesome new ship, get some random new item you didnt know existed, get attacked by pirates from space, kill those pirates until a big ass capital ship spawns and shoots everything thats ever been at you, panic, escape, and so on. and its barely ever repeated, because of the amount of different stuff there is.
that being said, holding down your mouse button is as boring as ever.

[h2] Settling Down [/h2]

one of the main reasons i bought this game was the idea of settling down on a planet and buidling whatever you wanted. and im glad to say that this game does that incredibly well, and i can say that atleast 50% of my time is spent browsing the immensely well varied oppurtunities it gives you when doing so. you can do so much, create so many feelings, you can even place 20 floors the same place as a design choice. i could go on and on about how much i love this system, but id want anyone to experience that for themselves. 

[h2] Variation [/h2] 

another thing that done well here is the variation. for example with vehicles, which there are six of, which all feel different, like the mech that makes you feel safe and strong, or the fast and agile nomad, or the underwater nautilon, which all have great designs aswell. this is just one example, as there are many different suit upgrades as well, which can work as builds themselves, or the many ways to upgrade and customize your ship, freighter, exocrafts, bases, and you can even tame every single animal you see to ride on, from a wolf, to a dragon-like bird, or a long necked dinosaur, which all are gene-customizable aswell, allowing you to fine tune them however you want. all these variations are exceptionally well done, and are worth experimenting with, to truly make this world - or galaxies - your own. 

11/10 would hold down mouse button again

What a beautiful and rich game! I read some reviews that complained there was no main quest-line after the initial one and the game felt aimless. I didn't even know that was a thing!!! I was out looking for that perfect planet to build a nice base on, and got a great freighter that I can build in instead! There is scavenging, and ship to ship fighting, ground fighting, you can manage your own colony and become it's overseer. I mean there is so much to do. And like I said it's beautiful. [h1]An Ode To Exploration[/h1]
Carl Sagan once said, "Exploration is in our nature. We began as wanderers, and we are wanderers still." Exploration, wanderlust, and discovery are at the heart of No Man's Sky. I can't speak for what this game was at launch - but now, as we enter 2024, this game stands as a love letter to the explorer within each of us.

[h2]Out Among The Cosmos[/h2]
No Man's Sky has a plot, but it is as nebulous as the incomprehensible gas clouds photographed through the Hubble.

Instead, this is a game for explorers. It's for the player who love games like Minecraft because they are eager to discover the next beautiful vista. 

Hello Games, the developer of No Man's Sky, claims there are over 18 quintillion planets available for players to explore. That is 18,000,000,000,000,000,000 - an unfathomly large number, and one that, as it has been claimed, would take literally billions of real life years for a single person to fully explore.

Of course, these planets are procedurally generated, so to call them "unique" is a little bit of a stretch. However, at over 50 hours into the game, I'm [i]still[/i] discovering truly new types of planets, and the vast majority have been undiscovered by other players. So, while No Man's Sky suffers the formulaic sameness that other procedural games do, it still feels like a vast, entirely unexplored universe.
 
[h2]Ready At Last To Set Sail For The Stars[/h2]
No Man's Sky offers a wealth of content, and provides players eager to explore a massive universe a seemingly infinite playground for discovery. If you want an in-depth space sim or combat-heavy looter shooter, you'll find this game lacking. But, if you want to find yourself warping from star system to star system, discovering new planets, establishing bases, and seeing what the universe has to offer, then there are truly no games that compare in scope to No Man's Sky.

I don't really like the game play, it seems like its not user friendly and it always seems like I need to be in or near my ship to do anything significant. The flying is absolutely horrible, the base building is horrible, and the overall learning curve for the game is too much given that the tutorial portion was not helpful at all. The multiplayer is just playing along side friends doing your own thing, so its a far stretch to say this game is multiplayer. You can play solo and it won't have any impact on your multiplayer game play and I am truly disappointed with this purchase. Even at 50% off, I still do not recommend buying this game.

Overall, the game is beautiful and the planets are full with vibrance and wonder, but at the end of the day...the game play is what matters most and this game is just terrible for players. I plan to ask for a refund and I hope that I did not play too long because I really tried to give this game a chance, but I really did not like it. I would rather play Space Engineers because it does everything No Man's Sky is trying to do much better.

100% in under a hundred hours. Unimpressive, I know, but enough for me to put together a valid review. 

The Good:
The game play of No Man's Sky is built around exploration. There is a LOT of things to explore and creatures to discover. Almost 100 hrs in and there's still aspects of the game I am yet to explore.
The survival aspect as well as some of the random encounters had me on the edge of my seat at times.
The lore is pretty interesting if you have the patience to piece everything together.
I like the space battles.

The Bad:
There are multiple intelligent alien species but the interiors of their space stations all look the same.

The Ugly:
A lot of these issues will probably be fixed with time, I'll do my best to update it accordingly.
The space battles, while fun, get kind of janky at times. Plenty of times I've taken on sentinel/pirate capital ships and the battle was cut short because I somehow clipped into the ship and got stuck inside. 
The building system, while limitless in its potential, has frustrated me beyond any of the other mechanics. The base-building UI is horrible and the cost of building materials is disproportionate.
Annoying tooltips that you can't turn off are the Navi of No Man's Sky.

I was impressed with all the things this game allows you to do. And a friend and I had been playing for about a week and while some of our experiences overlapped, we'd found completely different aspects of the game that we'd focused on. I think this is one of the strengths - that there are many ways to play the game and so it appeals to many different types of players.

Generally, yes.  Sort-of.

After nine years the game is still somewhat buggy and really geared towards single-player play.  Co-op is possible but it's really a sort of pick-up co-op without the option to share a lot of resources.

Navigation is also incredibly painful with poor wayfinding and waypointing.

That said, playing this on modern hardware is rewarding both for the entirely acceptable visuals and the scope the RNG has to get you some really great worlds and visual.  Not as adept as other space sims, though, but considering the worlds are all living and not sterile corpsicle-worlds like some other games I'd say there's a fair tradeoff.

GRAPE

If you like Minecraft and you like Space/Sci-fi then you'll most likely love this game if you give it a chance. 

I say, "give it a chance" because I personally found it a bit rough around the edges as a new player at the end of 2023. The interfaces and systems weren't very intuitive (especially the galaxy map) and I was feeling a bit lost and/or confused pretty frequently in my initial hours. However, now that I am used to it all I feel a bit silly as it all seems to make plenty of sense now. Beyond that, the game also is still pretty buggy (especially in multiplayer mode) and I find myself wishing there was a lot more variety in assets/points of interest. For example, almost all the space stations look identical inside. 

At this point, my review is already starting to feel like nothing but negatives so you may be wondering why I am recommending it? Well, it's been one of the strangest experiences I've had with a game... In that, I feel like I shouldn't like it as much as I do... because there are a million obvious things about this game that I can criticize... yet despite it all, this game is a blast to play for many of the same reasons Minecraft is. As a new player there is that sense of wonder. What is out in the cosmos? What sort of cool planets might I find? What  treasures await to be discovered? There is also the base building aspects for which they have tons of assets to unlock and play around with. There is also a great sense of progression with all the tech that can be attained. And to highlight one last there, the main story line went surprisingly deep and left me in many moments of deep meta physical contemplation. 

In conclusion, my opinion is that this game shares many characteristics to Minecraft and in many ways it is even better. I feel it has a better sense of progression and a fairly juicy main storyline. The tech available in the game feels a lot like a Minecraft tech mod. And at the end of it all.... just like in MC, you'll have to find your own reasons to keep playing because it's ultimately just a big sandbox and there is no "end" or "purpose" to any of it beyond just doing whatever you feel like doing.

I was one of the many who were disappointing w/ this game on day 1 when it came to PS4. But it's been amazing to see it's development blossom into the game it was originally intended to be. All DLC and overhauls have been free, there are no micro-transactions and most likely never will be, the developer hasn't sold out to a parent company, and they are still updating the game frequently. Of course, these ideals SHOULD be standard among devs, but even these were standard this game STILL would stand out. It's not a case of have a low bar set and being amazed by devs that actually care.

There are many things I still do not like about this game (the lack of NPC interactions/conflicts, lack of enemy AI, wonky first person weapon animations, meh story, etc). The resource grinding/crafting is particularly tedious IMO, though it's gotten better. It is my hope that, with time, the game will improve upon these issues. Perhaps a NMS 2 could be on the horizon, as I do believe the developers have done more than what was necessary to bring their original vision from years ago to life.

To me, what stands out in this game is the seamless exploration. The ability to feel like you are covering vast distances in solar systems within seconds/minutes is amazing. To point at a spot on a planet, and land there manually, is something of a rarity among space exploration games at the moment (*cough* Starfield *cough*). The hiccup here comes back to resource grinding. Travelling between stars can be tedious, but again these are issues that may vanish in the future easily.

This game has exceeded it's original vision, but it's still a 2016 game. It is my hope that a completely revamped NMS entry will come in the future, Until then, I have a blast playing every now and then. After playing Starfield, I gained an even GREATER appreciation for the space travel in this game. It's not perfect, and something HAS to be done about spaceship dogfights in general for game like this, but even in 2016 it was a hell of a lot better that Starfield, a AAA title that spent YEARS in development.

The movement is just bad, my character keeps turning on it's own, without my input. It's extremly annoing, same happens in Dying light, why is this a permanent feature. Why do my character keeps turning 90 degrees every time there's wall or even small rock in front of me. Just can't with this, give me an option to remove this "feature". Until then, this is not worth it.

Fundamentally, No Man's Sky lacks a reason to engage with it. There's a base building mechanic that only exists to build a base. You explore just for the sake of exploring. The systems don't really feed into each other and give you a real, vital reason to pursue them. There's a main story but it's written as if the writer was trying to strike a mystical, mysterious tone a la Homeworld but just comes off as obtuse, as characters needlessly speak in these odd half-sentences.

Compare this with something like Subnautica, which gives you vital reasons to engage with its systems. You build a base to get the battery charger to power your devices, to build the Seamoth to let you explore deeper and farther in the pursuit of escape from the planet. In No Man's Sky, you have nothing but a vague mystery to propel you forwards while your base building doesn't really feed into your goals.

The game also commits a cardinal sin - stingy inventory slots. There is no reason for this. None. Inventory management is not a fun part of any game. No one fires up Steam for the joy of sorting their inventory or curtailing their exploration because they're out of inventory slots. But No Man's Sky makes you do this chronically and further pushes you to burn game time pursuing inventory upgrades. I don't feel like a space explorer when I'm running around in pursuit of one more inventory slot.
Had a rough launch but over the years has grown into an enjoyable game.

Dear NMS Devs. If you read this just know your game is amazing and I love that you beat Bethesda in making a good space game. And I love most of the mechanics of NMS but ONE, EXOCRAFT TO SENTINEL COMBAT. I enjoy the effort of making the sentinels shoot at you in your exocraft and damage you, but I really wish there were way more exocraft weapons, and more exocraft. An idea I have on an exocraft would be the Skystalker Gunship Helicopter. I wish this were in the game due to the fact that if your in a spaceship to shoot down on Sentinels, the Sentinels don't shoot back and it just spawns interceptors, plus your ship automatically moves forward unless its interceptor which makes hover firing annoying. As for the weapons I really don't care as long as there are more of them that are not straight from the spaceships. I also wish there was a tank because I understand its an exploration game but using the Roamer for Sentinel combat is just not the same experience. As well, I like the stage five Sentinel Battleship you fight if you do it in a spaceship and I wish there was a land version of bossfight or something because the big walker things are a bit underwhelming. My final request is that an atmospheric jet be added so that you can have better maneuvers in a planets atmosphere and not be super slow in the atmosphere like a spaceship.

most definitely worth the price. there are 16^16 (over 18 quintillion) planets to explore, spread among 255 (+1 that you cant get to) galaxies. i think that a large but finite number of places to go is better than an infinite universe because with infinity, it doesnt actually feel as good to find something rare or discover something, because there would always be an infinite number of places just like it. 16^16 isnt truly infinite, but it is large enough that there will always be new places to go.

This is one of the most amazing games ever - but the way the developers screw over their customers with update 4 the inventory update - I'm forced to say a big "no" to this game. If you're prepared to play their new (pointless) "creative mode" - then sure, go for it (surely they can't screw that over in the future?). But if you want the "story mode" then forget it - because after countless hours of gameplay (like me 208 hours) - you'll find this developer Hello Games will, with future updates, screw-over everything you worked towards - all your efforts will be wasted efforts on the next update which will destroy everything you've achieved. Apparently this appears to be a pattern with this developer.

After reading about the horrendous history of this game and the amazing recoveries, I can't believe the devs Hello Games would even consider doing what they have done to their current player-base with the update 4.0. I guess the profits are so great now they just don't care. I guess beyond the price of online worlds, the dev's still control the interfaces to their worlds - to the customers detriment. 

If you're prepared to play a "galaxy" game seriously for hours upon hours or months (or years), and then be gutted by some random update that destroys everything you've worked towards - then this is the game is for you!

Otherwise steer clear of this - unless you want a casual "creative mode" experience (& we can only hope Hello Games won't destroy that save in the future as well - but who can say - who can trust?)

I played No Man's Sky at launch during the YouTube gold rush and really found it to be horribly disappointing especially as someone who was singing that it would change the future of gaming.

It's been about 8 years since launch and I recently decided to take a chance and try the game in VR. No Man's Sky alone could make a VR headset worth buying. It has been so polished, improved, and overhauled that I am thrilled to say its finally what I wanted, and it has even gone above and beyond so far. 

As I am early still, but if you want a game that will take you to another world, there is no better VR experience than No Man's Sky. 

I can only sit excited to see their next project!

No Man's Sky is a stunning testament to the power of dedication and continuous improvement. Over the past decade, this game has transformed magnificently, evolving from its initial launch to become an expansive, ever-engaging universe. Each update has added layers of depth and wonder, making the gameplay experience richer and more fulfilling. The developers' commitment to enhancing every aspect of the game – from graphics to gameplay mechanics – is evident. It's rare to see a game not only rebound from its early criticisms but soar to such impressive heights. Whether you're exploring distant galaxies, crafting on unknown planets, or engaging in epic space battles, No Man's Sky offers a universe of possibilities. It's a journey worth embarking on, a game that truly gets better with time.

Not sure if the white noise of the RP messages is done on purpose or not. Either way, that's where my disinterest starts. There are some pretty basic things wrong with the game tho. Like remapping keys might break some functionality. Add ships and fauna that just break immersion by ignoring collision with the world and even your base. Subtract a planetary map (galaxy map, yes, local map, no) and a reasonable amount of storage space. (Why are game makers so cheap with storage?) 

I will say that the game landscape is very beautiful, the UI isn't too confusing and the player can Fly Around A Star System! That's pretty frikkin cool! Also, building. HG nailed that. Very nice system of construction.

But that tutorial starter quest is like an entrance exam for an elite school. (What is this, EVE?) I had to go off-game to figure it out. Not good for new players. The tutorial is supposed to teach the basics of the game. Instead I was figuring out how to make that ominous red light bar stabilize. (Just find a cave, new folks. You're welcome.)

HG Apologists, just go play your game. I'm not looking for a refund. I got the game on sale and I ain't sore. Just want to warn folks like myself.

OK, 7 years after having bought and returned the game on its original release back in 2016, I have to update my review because Hello Games have worked their hearts out updating the game and adding aspects of gameplays and quite a few QoL features that make this game actually fun to play now. Yea, it can still be a bit grindy, but compared to the initial release, where you could literally get stranded on a planet because your ship decided to land way up in a tree so that you couldn't ever get back in your ship, or it would fly inside a cave that you could never get out of, they've managed to breathe new life into the game and make it an enjoyable experience.

I played an expedition last night and had a lot of fun doing it, (It was the "Cartographers" expedition).
I'm bummed that I missed out on the three other Expeditions earlier this month, but hopefully HG will keep making the expeditions available to play again.

I want to say from the bottom of my heart that developers need to take notes from this game, from the colors to the details to how modular you want buildings to be, this game is amazing. Yes the launch was horrid, but I still saw the potential from this game. I come back about 4 years later to this game, and it feels playable and enjoyable. Thank you Hello Games for creating a masterpiece.

May be of help if you are new:

You can choose which slot to open when expanding.
If sentinels won't stop following and the timer isn't there, reload the game.
If your starship accelerates on its own, reload the game.
If you are unable to scan a planet even if you're looking right at it, idk what to do.
Sometimes epic or threatening music won't stop, reload.
If the task persists even though you've finished it, just wait. There is also a button that resets a mission in another system if you've previously started it somewhere else and left.

Some other minor things, but the game is very good. I can imagine some people losing interest because of too much freedom. I fought it, I thought about it, planned my actions, then the game became much more interesting.

Don't spend hours looking for a perfect planet, you will end up hurting your brain in the process.
Once you hit couple of million credits, start spending them on materials in trading terminals, just buy everything that you find yourself using often. Currency is not a problem in this game, even without farming you will feel filthy rich.

I have to give them credit where credit is due. 

They fixed so much from release to now. They poured their entire soul into a game that they could have easily abandoned and I'm so happy they did.

Gets a lot of love from the creators. I personally have a love hate relationship with it however, I just find that the basic premise behind the game doesn't stick in a small way. What I mean is, It is too vast; things are too spread out. It tries to do a lot in a huge universe but fails in the small things which most people find satisfaction that sticks, hence why games which have linear experiences still work. One thing that I found always annoyed me was the water textures on each planet, it feels like an afterthought. Or the lack of audible communication in English (or applicable language). It feels like the game keeps me at arms length, audibly. Perhaps a text to speech in game bot for translation would be good and simple to program in? (no need to voice over, just robot text to speech). Also maybe if they added some simple primitive 'tasks' to provide purpose to traversing around the universe; I understand there is quests and all that, but perhaps like hunting a species of alien / beast, with only clues on habitat / traits provided. Just plain & simple tasks to drive you to explore.

You may not realize it yet, but No Man's Sky is the start of something revolutionary in gaming. 
Not the game itself, but the technology involved in making it. 
NMS is a "create your own fun" type of experience, and if you have trouble with not having any structure in your games, you will struggle to like NMS. You will have trouble finding MEANING in this universe, so you will have to set out and create your own meaning.
-Do you like conducting expeditions to other star systems?
-Do you like constructing bases on world and extracting it's resources?
-Do you like growing exotic alien plants and selling them for profit?
-Do you like being a pirate and stealing from other fleets?
-Do you like taming alien creatures and genetically altering new ones?
-Or maybe you like visiting different planets for fun

Positives:
- Incredibly expansive galaxy with near infinite numbers of systems and planets each with a unique environment and inhabitants
- Simple yet expansive collection and crafting mechanics
- Large array of space ships
- Freedom to build a unique and individual base

Negatives:
- No major structured quest line
- Little multiplayer interaction

Opinion:
This game provides a phenomenal experience exploring the vast uncharted expanses of a foreign galaxy while investigating new planets, discovering unique vegetation and lifeforms, as well as trading with other intelligent beings, learning their unique languages along the way. Whilst it may not be for those who desire a structured and quest orientated play style, it certainty provides one of the best experiences in its genre.

I'm gonna give highlights for those who don't want to read my rambling, first...

- First and foremost, the game is about discovery and exploration. If you don't enjoy aimless, wandering gameplay this probably won't be for you. Same goes for your enjoyment of survival crafting.
-Survival elements are the next big ticket item, but it should be noted that a *lot* of the difficulty stuff can't be adjusted to meet your desired gameplay.
-Resource gathering, money making, and base building are all core components too. The base building is pretty optional though, with some small exceptions.
- This game is very very "zen", and is often a slow burn. I spent several hours last night just gathering resources and cataloging planets, with a loose objective in my mind.
- Over the years I've played on my PC, Steam Deck, ROG Ally, and an M1 Pro Macbook. 
-- By far the best experience I've had is on the M1 Pro (total eye candy). 
-- ROG Ally is a great experience too, but I found the Steam Deck to be very inconsistent performance wise so your mileage may vary. 
-- PC is obviously dependent on your hardware. An Intel Mac will likely be a poor experience since the game targets Apple Silicon, and I'm not even sure if it can run on non Apple Silicon chips. 

I actually preordered No Man's Sky way back when, and on release I actually enjoyed it! However I couldn't recommend it to anyone at the time, because it was "a mile wide, but an inch deep". At that time it was just a walking and inventory management simulator.

Since then this game has become next level. I feel that the mis-managed hype pre-release wasn't done from a place of maliciousness, and Hello Games is a studio that just really likes working on NMS and are proud of their work. This game truly is a labor of love, and the quality is out of this world now. The community around this game is also super welcoming.

Alright, let me spill the space beans on No Man's Sky. I remember when this game first dropped, and oh boy, it got roasted harder than marshmallows at a campfire. But you know what? Fast forward to now, and it's like Hello Games flipped a switch and turned this thing into a cosmic gem.

First things first, the universe they've built here is downright mind-blowing. I'm talking planets, moons, and stars that make your jaw drop. It's like a sci-fi dream come true. If you're playing with online features you have great community to interact with planets where cities have formed by the players but there are still a few things I would like them to improve on such as more NPCs are needed, it's an unending space with very few interactions on planets it feels lonely when you want to play offline. I won't be surprised if they might just do that with the next update as this game is one of the best games I've played. 

This game is experiencing rapid growth and expanding across various platforms, enhancing the overall gaming experience for a broader player base. Personally, I've enjoyed playing it on the PS5 and have made significant progress. My only regret is the absence of cross-platform save support, a feature that could add even more convenience. The game's increasing diversity and widespread appeal are a testament to its potential, surpassing our initial expectations. Kudos to Hello Games, the real heroes of game development, for not just patching things up but executing a complete cosmic makeover. They've fulfilled players' wish lists with features like bases, freighters, and seamless multiplayer experiences, showcasing their dedication and turning them into the Santa Clauses of the gaming world. May the game's success continue long into the future.

And the story? Oh, they've spiced that up too. Quests that mean something, community events that get the hype train going, and the mysteries of the Atlas – it's like playing through a space opera now. I love it.

But here's the kicker – they've been listening. No Man's Sky runs smoother than a jazz solo now. It's like they fine-tuned everything we griped about. They're not just making a game; they're crafting an experience.

So, if you're still thinking about the No Man's Sky that made headlines for the wrong reasons, snap out of it! This ain't your grandma's game anymore. Hello Games flipped the script, and now it's an intergalactic party that keeps getting better.

No Man's Sky went from zero to hero, and I'm strapping into my virtual spaceship for the long haul. If you haven't been back in a while, trust me, it's time. The universe is calling, and it's one heck of a ride that just keeps getting sweeter.

I had hankered after this game for some years, and only just had the time and finances to pick it up. There was so much hype when it first came out as part of the new genre of generative video games. The hype is, obviously, difficult to live up to. However, this game did that for me. I wanted something stylish, open, and expansive—all three were delivered. The plot, while a little derivative (without giving too much away, I think we are all a bit tired of the "meta-" prefix), is enjoyable to run through. I have not yet explored the online features of the game, owing to an extremely poor internet connection, so I can't comment on that. The variation in worlds, adventures, and technologies is excellent. It's not skyrim, but it also isn't aimless—the ratio of guidance to exploration is impressively navigated.

This game provides a worthy escape from the everyday, I could hardly put down my controller.

No Man's Sky: A Phoenix Risen from the Ashes
Rating: 5/5 Stars - A Masterpiece Reborn

Back in 2016, I had dismissed "No Man's Sky" as nothing short of a disappointment. It felt like a hollow promise, a universe vast in scope yet shallow in substance. However, what unfolded over the subsequent years is nothing short of a miracle in the gaming industry. Today, I am here to set the record straight: "No Man's Sky" has evolved into a masterpiece that stands as a testament to the developers' dedication and love for their creation.

A Universe Reimagined: What was once a barren landscape of repetitive textures and unfulfilled promises has transformed into a vibrant, ever-evolving universe. Each planet I visit now bursts with life, unique biomes, and captivating flora and fauna. The sense of exploration and discovery is genuinely exhilarating - a dream come true for any space exploration enthusiast.

Engaging Gameplay: The addition of base building, multiplayer elements, and a plethora of missions have given "No Man's Sky" the depth it initially lacked. Whether you're constructing your own space haven, engaging in space combat, or simply exploring the unknown with friends, the game now offers a rich, engaging experience.

Visual and Audio Masterpiece: Visually, the game is a feast for my eyes. The improved graphics engine renders breathtaking vistas, while the procedural generation ensures that no two experiences are the same. The soundtrack, too, is a sublime companion to your space odyssey, enhancing the sense of wonder and isolation in the vast cosmos.

A Developer's Love Letter: Perhaps the most commendable aspect is the developers' commitment. They didn't abandon ship but instead worked tirelessly to deliver the game everyone hoped for. This level of post-launch support and dedication is rare and praiseworthy.

In conclusion, "No Man's Sky" is a shining example of how passion, perseverance, and listening to your community can turn the tides. It's no longer the game that many of us once called "crap." It's an odyssey that continues to expand and surprise. It's a journey that I am delighted to be a part of, and I can't wait to see where it takes us next.

"No Man's Sky" is not just a game; it's a journey of redemption, a beacon of hope for the gaming community, and a universe waiting to be explored. Don't miss out on this unparalleled adventure.

The game is a great space sandbox. Hunting for sentinel ships, flying around and building different bases it's really engaging. Nonetheless, some bugs are really annoying and they ruin the experience for me. For instance: 
1) The oxygen harvester bug, it burns the fuel but generates oftentimes no oxygen at all. 
2) NPCs sink into the ground regardless if it's a planet or freighter. 
3) Stuff magically disappears in refiners on my freighter with a tiny chance to reappear if I'm lucky. 
4) Stellar collectors or whatever they called often do not collect anything, especially, if the multiplayer option is on.
5) A bug with the pirate freighter. If you destroy it and save a civilian freighter you get no reward. If you leave pirate frigates the civilian freighter is getting attacked again by pirate spaceships.
I am just in love with this game, a recommendation for everyone who just wants to chill and build a base on his own planet lost in space

I am a researcher in medicine with experience in biomed and chem eng research, and I was looking into possibilities for using NMS as a learning tool by integrating medical knowledge into the gameplay with monetary rewards to gamify learning. It is a great game, but because mod functionality is blocked for the macOS version but allowed for the PC version, it makes it hard to experiment with a gamified learning solution that is cross-platform. A solution to this would be an interpreted public API like how Minecraft has, which would also help reduce the risk of crashing for the windows version. But functionality of any nature other than that which HelloGames has made is not up to anyone else to determine, so allowing mods for PC is currently the only allowable option.

The game universe is a limitless field of stars for me to explore.... or almost a starfield, some might say.

Only better. 

Everything is proceduraly generated. No two planets are anything even remotely alike. Life is vibrant and the environments and the universe itself are gorgeous. And ships, ships, ships! Little ones, big ones, titanic freighters, space stations, anomalous space objects, derelict freighters..... It's got sci-fi tropes by the truckload. And even some sci-fi pop culture references sneakily inserted in ways just different enough to make them legally distinct, yet respectful homages.

Everything this universe has to offer is yours for the taking! And fortune favors the bold! GET IT!

Easily one of the best space sim/ survival/ exploration games out there.  Stunning graphics, endless variety of environments, robust base building system.  Only flaw, for me, is that the story lines are somewhat lacking.  They really feel like more of an afterthought than an integral part of the game. They just don't draw me in.
That said, I have still put hundreds of hours into this game and will likely continue to play for hundreds more.

If you can get this game for free, that's the right price to pay for it. Lets start with that unskippable forever intro, you know, the things that game devs learned not to do in the 1980's. You spend half an hour in game before it even lets you do anything and all the while it's a nausea inducing circling motion. Then the "intro" on how to play seems to be built by two coked out squirrels who don't know how to play the game either. I've been told there's fun in here somewhere but so far I'm not finding it.  I keep TRYING to play it, but by the time that intro is FINALLY over I've lost all interest and moved on to other games where you can actually do things.

No Man's Sky has come a long way since its original release. Going from playing on PS4 to PC has been really interesting, and honestly one of the best experiences with the game that I've had. 

They've added customizable playthroughs, so you can change your difficulty settings on a whim whenever you want, with whatever mode you start in. You can also lock your settings in, making so you can never change them. You can swap settings at any time you wish to if you don't feel like giving full effort, then swap back to previous settings after you're finished. You can also have the choice of swapping certain rules, all manageable by your command! It's also not just limited by mode, but by a variety of settings. Enemy strength, free purchases, even lowering the cost of things. These are just a few of the settings you can choose from, not to mention the full templates you can go through as well. Custom game modes are extremely fun!

You have new freighter updates, create very real-ish ship interiors and decorate them how you want to! Show off your findings via holographic images. Through the creatures you've encountered, having a full museum onboard. You can now collect a ton of ships too without having to get a freighter first! You can even just possess a singular freighter for mobile base and create your own farms on it like never before! The new interior designs make for a great way to farm plant matter to create into craftable items to sell in the market.

You can hire your own fleet, having a flurry of military patrollers shoot down incoming threats, or summon your squadron to help you. You can even sell ships to NPCs and immediately recruit them into your squad to have a totally unique ship!

There are many more updates to talk about! It is a good game if you like space games, but there's also pets, collecting, farming, survival, etc. If you like those things, then you'll like this game.
This game is a great games with endless maps to explore however they made it too difficult to find a planet like planet earth.

I noticed I still had a negative review for this game from launch. I needed to fix it.

No Man's Sky is a tale of a developer who was made to launch earlier than intended, but kept going to make the game more and more amazing, without charging extra.

This is a love letter from developers who care, and the game far exceeds what it was originally pitched as. A half decade of love was put into this after launch. Without extra profit from DLC sales for each new feature, just a desire to make an amazing space game.

Highly recommend.

Well I'm a fan of space games, but I try to give an honest review.
This game is so relaxing and challenging at the same time.
The stories of the missions gets boring over time but it can provide like 60 hours of interesting game play.

the variety of the items and spaceships and other devices and vehicles is so much and as a collector makes a good challenge for you to find all kind of them.
the combat system becomes so easy when you have a paralysis mortar.

BUT BUT BUT

the bugs in this game:
- you may put some items in the refinery room in your freighter and then you summon it to another location what happens is the items will disappear, you lost them for good. they may or may not reappear after some time.
- there is a maximum depth you can dig, and some times some buried items spawn beneath it and you cant dig them.
- some elements like trees and volcanoes  are for decoration when you are riding your companion and you can easily glitch trough them.

I've been meaning to leave a review for awhile now, 700+ hours and I think it's about time! 
I'm a 52 yo grandma (but don't freak out! I play a LOT of games and have for years!) That being said, I love this game. My husband introduced me to it and we've played it a lot together but I also enjoy playing solo. I come back and play every time there's a new Community Expedition. There's so much to do and so many different ways to play the game. You can just go your own way, build a base or do the main quests or missions. I'm an over "achiever", so I've completed all but one of the achievements on the game (including making it to the center of the galaxy on permadeath, which impressed my husband to no end :-D) and will complete the final achievement one day (Surviving a god awful number of hours on an extreme planet). So, go play, explore, discover and just have fun!

This game is fantastic IF you like a sandbox that gives you plenty of room to do your own thing! It is very short on a linear story line that you can speed-run in a few hours, wrong game for that, it also is not a substitute for COD or GTA.  This is a laid back casual game which expects you to be able to 'drive' your own adventure.

It has an excellent build mechanic that can be used to build all manner of things. You can build on ANY planet and there are SO MANY! Also you will get a freighter that can be your mobile base / city or a hub for your fleet and squadron. There is so much to do here that sometimes it is hard to decide what you want to do next. Multiplayer still has issues, but this started as a solo game and it is not that easy to just bolt on multiplayer. 

TL:DR
They give you the shovel and bucket, it is up to you to design and build the sandcastles / adventures.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

If you love collecting rocks and scanning things, this is the game for you. I bought this recently on sale, many years after initial release, so I imagine the game has improved quite a lot since then. But I can only recommend this game as a mostly single-player experience. Multiplayer seems like mostly an afterthought, with large amounts of de-syncing. It is not a good feeling when you search for a resolution for a specific bug and the community replies to just turn off all multiplayer functionality. Additionally, ship combat and flight controls feel weak but I guess this is okay for the target audience; if you're use to flying your ship like a mad-man in Elite Dangerous, you'll be disappointed. I would even say that the flight controls in Freelancer (2003) feel more responsive. Base building is kinda lame when it comes to terraforming, you'll see all the terrain regenerate and clip into your structures but some of the community insists that this is okay and "working as designed". So as I've seen other suggest, build upwards to overcome this. Finally, getting the frigate so early feels like it defeats the purpose of a planet-side base. When I can just build a max level refinery on my frigate, why bother going through the phases at the base, plus having to power them. The games strengths lie in its exploration and rock collection.

One of my favorite games and one of the best ever made I think. I've played thousands of hours of other base building and/or survival games and this one is just outstandingly wonderful. You truly are given a universe to explore in what ever manner you choose, search remote corners no one has ever seen before, build towns, fortresses, mining empires, or be a pirate and rain shiny laser death across the stars. I have over 600 hours logged at this point and I'm sure many can relate to a 100-200 of those being AFK-time but I'm 90+% sure I've got less than a day of that for this game. I have lost many nights playing this game only to realize it's morning because birds have begun to chirp.
Very fun, has come a long way from its early days. Plenty to do and accomplish, and one of the most satisfying and immersive space sims I've played.

This game is so well made. It's not really one of those games where you are trying to do something in particular, and that's the joy of it. There are missions and things to do, but getting side-tracked is the entire point. I have loved simply flying around from planet to planet discovering new things and then getting bored and traveling across the galaxy to another planet that's filled with hostile sentinels and getting involved in a full on fire-fight. You can really play this game however you'd like, and though other might not like this level of freedom, for those who do it's incredible. The community (from what I have experienced so far) is so great and wholesome! I went to the player hub and sent a chat message out asking for help with a mission. A veteran player (since the launch back in 2016) helped me out, and after I told them this was my first "team mission" and that I was new to the game, they welcomed me to the game, telling me some tips, giving me advice about upgrades, and after the mission even gave me a few items that would help me along the way and said I could come back to him anytime for help or with questions or to just have a fun time!! I know this isn't going to happen for every new player, nor is this how every member of the community behaves, but out of all the game communities I have ever joined this one has by far been the most welcoming and rad. This game isn't like what it was in 2016, it's better, and it keeps getting better with every free update.

SIDE NOTE: if you’re curious if this game runs well on MacOS, I play it on an M1 Macbook Pro and I get 30fps with high graphics and 60fps with medium-low graphics. It doesn’t even drain my computer’s battery or set the gpu on fire (metaphorically, of course). Very well optimized, very well made, very well executed, 10/10

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Back in 2016 this game had potential and thus this game was filled with hype and anticipation. In fact No Man’s Sky was probably one of the most anticipated games of that year. However, we received a buggy, glitchy mess on release with almost zero content. The game was beyond disappointing. Even back in 2017 when I think I got the game it was just barren and lacked content. This was a game that I would have never recommended to people, a 1 out of 10. And that’s not even mentioning the reputation of the studio. There is a good saying that reputation takes years to build but moments to lose. And I think this saying fits perfectly. Hello Games lost their reputation in just moments because of the horrible release of No Man’s Sky. However, since then the developers at Hello Games have continued to pour their hearts and souls into the game and it has paid off. The game has become a masterpiece and the studio have rebuilt their reputation after years of hard work. The game is ripe with content after adding new releases year after year free of charge. And with the recent release of the Echos update, it has really shown how much of a masterpiece this game is. I think the best part of this game is that it isn’t all too confusing. One of my main issues with Star Citizen is that I can’t play it while being half asleep or I suppose high as a kite. But with No Man’s Sky there is still a structure but it's much simpler to understand. To top this off the game runs extremely well on the Steamdeck and there aren’t any DRM problems when playing offline. Thus, it is my most played game when on the road. All in all, this game for me is an easy 10 out of 10. The exploration, music, and game mechanics all make No Man’s Sky an incredible experience. And I think that No Man’s Sky is probably one of the best examples of a comeback that a studio has been able to pull off. And with the recent information surrounding their next title Light No Fire, I have no doubt they will be able to pull it off.

Introducing - the twelve time winner of the Steam Labor of Love award...No Man's Sky!!

And nobody batted an eye.

We get it already. You made good on what would have been a career-ending error for most. No Man's Sky went from being the industry's biggest lolcow of the year to becoming the belle of everyone's ball. And now we all have to hear it year after year, after year. 

Can you just move on now? Like, go make something new, yeah?

I'm sure I'll receive twelve clowns for this. I'll see myself out.

Pretty good game.  I'm 300 hours in and have plenty of things I still want to do.  There's multiple story arcs I haven't even started and huge variety in the ships you can find or buy.  Gathering resources is a little grindy early on, like pretty much all survival games, but there are ways to automate it once you get a bit further along.  If you like exploration and survival games like Valheim or 7 Days To Die and also like science fiction settings, definitely try No Man's Sky.

I definitely recommend this game. TO ANYONE WHO LOVES EXPLORATION. It saddens me that the game has gotten so many bad reviews from people who were very obviously not the target audience. From the absolute get-go it's been made clear that this game is mostly about exploring and discovering things. Sure you can trade and do other stuff but it was pretty obvious to me that that wasn't the true focus and intent of the game.
Another thing I keep seeing is that the price tag is too high for what you get, but you're also paying for any future updates and content. But I guess they'd rather prefer a game that costs 60 bucks and also comes with a dozen DLC to buy. If you're the type of person who can't live with having to play the game with less content until more is added, then you shouldn't pre-order or buy things at release.

Anyway, I love this game for the same reason I loved Minecraft. It's essentially endless and I keep finding out new things that surprise me. The Atlas "storyline" is also pretty amazing so far and I'm actually really glad they put it in there. Kind of gives me the option to change things up a bit if I get tired of hunting for that 1 species that's eluding me on a planet.
The game is visually beautiful, comes with an incredible soundtrack and offers enough gameplay variety to keep you busy for dozens of hours. And this is not counting future updates and added content.

---------

Update many years later (2023). Picked the game back up again after a long hiatus, it's basically a completely different game now and it's still ridiculous amounts of fun. I still recommend the game... but not with the same glee as I did 7 years ago, despite almost 300 hours of game time. Approach the game as an exploration game with base building and minimal quests. Think of it as Minecraft in space, and you will likely love it. Below I will explain in more detail.

SPOILERS START HERE

SERIOUSLY STOP READING IF YOU CARE

FINAL WARNING

Since you're still reading, I will get down to it. The main quest ending is absolute dogwater. The main quest sends you on this massive undertaking with amazing build up and interesting lore but the payoff is just not there. If you read that and you still want to experience it, for the love of god make sure you store all your technology before the last jump. And then KEEP IT STORED as you approach the final part. The level of frustration it caused in me to jump to the core and pop out the other side with ALL of my tech broken, which I then spent 90 minutes fixing, only for the game to send you on one last portal jump which, of course, breaks ALL YOUR DAMN TECH AGAIN. I used all my resources to fix it the first time. Portals usually break only 1 thing, I was not expecting a full system failure twice in a row, I can't afford to fix my fully kitted out exosuit, multi tool and starship all over again. And the kicker is that the endgame is basically the same stuff you were doing before. I might as well have just not gone to the core. So I recommend the game, if you see it as exploration and base building with minimal quests. Spare yourself the pain and just watch a youtube video of the ending though.

honestly the decisions lately by HelloGames is now designed for hardcore player who has being playing the game for several years.  their choice to do the expeditions in short form for a week is great if you watched a video and know what you are doing.  from what I hear they use to short these expeditions for 2 weeks to reply them.  I wouldn't recommend this game in its current state since lately the decisions have focused more on the new game with multiplayer Light no Fire.  If you wish to solo this game and know what you are doing this is a great game for you.  If you have the time watching a lot of videos before doing these weekly expeditions and not make a huge mistake in the game like I did mid way through the expedition in a week by knowing the game inside and out to fix this fatal error.  I would recommend this game for you.  For casuals and those without a lot of time including wishing to do multiplayer I would hold off on this game now until they recognize doing expeditions in a week isn't a great idea.  Two weeks for expeditions would be much better to replay them not a week.  So whoever is reading this make sure you watch a content creator fully before these expeditions if you don't know what you are doing or returning after a long while.  Honestly I wish they made these expeditions 2 weeks not 1 week.

I’m running with an I5 (4460), 16 gig of ram, an MSI Armor GTX 1070, a stock lenovo mainboard (it’s a modded of the shelf build) and I’m using a 50"4k TV for a monitor (so the refresh rate could be better if I were using an actual monitor) and the first thing I did was change the resolution to a borderless 2K and bump up the max FRP to 60. (LOL wish I’d waited a bit before changing the resolution though. After the restart the planet I ended up on wasn’t nearly as hospitable!) Out side of the very odd and rare momentary shudder, I’m running into zero problems with the game and getting a typical framerate of 50fps. To be fair, I haven’t tried to Alt-Tab in/out of the game so I can’t speak to that issue and as far as the “freshness” of my drivers is concerned, I haven’t updated them in a few weeks so I don’t know if their current or not.

My biggest problem is the game itself. After about 8 hours I feel pretty comfortable saying this is the most frustrated I’ve ever been being this bored. I’m all for not being spoon fed a tutorial but there’s a sharp difference between that and being tossed into the deep end with zero advice and instruction. So in no particular order:

Interface

It too me several tried just to figure out that you had to hold the button down to make a selection! There is at least one icon on the screen that I have absolutely no idea what it means (If anyone knows, it resembles the outline of a backpack and it’s near where the jetpack icon shows up.)

(BTW it took me 4 or 5 hours to discover that while you’re scanning an object if you press the right thumb stick you get multiple levels of zoom.)

On a tangent, I’d LOVE to be able to set way points! I’ve literally lost track of a destination more time that I can remember. And why can’t I make a map of a planet? (And then use said map to “autopilot” to and from known locations!)

Flying

**I HATE FLYING IN THIS GAME** It’s a good thing that you can’t crash into the ground or I’d be dead sooooooo many times already!

Landing

Anyone figure out how to land exactly where you want to yet? I have landed right next to the landing pad of so many outposts that it’s no longer funny (landing/taking off from the landing pad supposedly doesn’t cost any fuel.)

What am I doing again?

IS there a way to pull up what’s next to do in the early stages of the game? I wandered to 3 other planets before managing to check off the next box on my initial to do list because I had no idea what I needed to to and missed it when it showed up on the screen the first time.

SOME KIND OF HINTS!

I wasted a perfectly good (and charged!) hyperdive (my first one to boot!) trying to swap ships (after finding a better (well bigger anyway) one crashed on a planet. (For reference, you have to transfer material to the damaged ship first, then repair the damage. (Of course, doing that transfers control to the damaged ship abandoning your old ship, but you can always just return to your old ship and reverse the process to reclaim it.) (Why CAN’T I swap engines/weapons/shields between vessels? After all I installed and repaired them in the first place didn’t I?

All in all, it’s not rally a bad game it just suffers from a lack of direction, a sense that you actually need to do something. Now I haven’t made my first warp jump yet, (I need to recharge my hyperdrive...again...) so maybe that get better once you’re out of the initial system but as for right now my impression of the game is...Meh.  

As it stands now, there's nothing that stands out about it enough to warrent reccomending it to others.

_____________________YEARS LATER_________________________________________

Hello Games has established themselves as one of the best developers in video game history.
best played at 11pm honestly
Absolutely amazing game. Had a rough start, but has a well earned community and consistently provides great content.

I played over 1000 hours easy accumulated between different platforms, so yeah it's definitely worth it as a game an I started when the game came out so I have seen the evolution of the whole game getting better and better .

Now to be objective and honest in my review, I have to admit that I never enjoyed the combat on foot in this game, even after improvements they made, it's just not very fun IMO because it really feel like it's kind of added on top and not part of the core game play and more precisely, I just find it hard to aim and the weapons are so so. But I have always played with controller so maybe with mouse  or VR it's good ? It just wasn't for me. Combat in your ship is actually decent but feels a bit too simplified and too easy unless you are overwhelmed  but still there is no real strategy  until you attack way bigger ships , only then it's a bit better.

Also the creatures in the worlds are still a bit too weird for me, some are really good and you actually feel like you want them as pets or mounts, but many just seem weird in an illogical way, they don't fit their environment and how a creature would evolve in this kind of place. Even for a science-fiction setting. 

The first main story is not amazing ( The Artemis quest) , it doesn't matter too much until you realise that some NPC who give different quest are locked until you have done the main story. When it's the first time you play it's ok , but when you make a new game it feels like a chore to have to go through again. Once you pass the Artemis quest , it's ok but it's a long quest and I wish I could just skip it. Now you can totally play the game without doing it but then you can't unlock what's after and that's the most interesting to me. 

I also wish there was a lot of random quests that are not necessary linked to anything and not mandatory but it would give me more incentive to explore to try to find this kind of quests, just for fun and push the feeling that there is always more to discover.

Last  point, I wish there was more diversity on the planets themselves , and not only one  type of environment all over. it doesn't make you want to explore more of the same world and what they could offer it it was at least a little more diverse.
It would not work for all planets or moon as for some it's kind of logic that if the whole planet is desolated, you won't have a forest on the other side, and I agree with that. But it would be nice to see some planets with like an icy pole, and desert on the other side  or some other mix.

Overall, I know this looks like a negative review, but it's only a list of things I wish would really improve, the game itself is great and I can only praise VERY HIGHLY  all the efforts and love that Hello Game put into it, and I respect them so much for not trying to empty your wallet like most of the other greedy modern games. Just buy and play , no BS, no cash shop.

This game is worth it at full price, but again it's very often on sale and it's great so more people can experience it or buy it again on another platform like I did about 3 times and no regrets after. We all know this is a rare feeling nowadays with modern gaming...

I found the game extremely tedious at first, not understanding all the mechanics and intricacies required to understand how the game works, I even complained about it and gave it an initial bad review, but after many hours spent on it and watching a few youtube videos that explain stuff, I realised that this game has one advantage over many others: You don't just play it from point A to B in a few hours, you can spend a LOT more time on it than most games and do all sorts of creative things in it. I therefore change my opinion after about 40 hours of time spent on this game so far. I like when you get value for your money

This game has done so much to overcome its train wreck of a launch. NMS has over time worked hard to bring the game within inches of the over hyped expectations.

They went from a literal scam of a game to a *meh* game and we are supposed to cheer them for that

1. [b]Gunplay[/b] - I cannot turn off mouse acceleration completely. I can reduce it from the menu, but I cant turn it off. Which would be a major dealbreaker if there was any significant gunplay. Most of the bullets I shot during my playthrough was shooting at doors. Where are alien invasions and raids on your base/ship/frigate? There are these big behemoths in the trailer, do you fight them? No, you either shoot at literal doors or some wild defenceless animals. Terraria and Minecraft are also not combat focused games but their core combat loop is much more polished.
2. [b]Ship combat[/b] - Put a paperweight on your S key and left mouse then go grab a sandwich. Pump in sodium into to shields to recharge them for some reason. You cannot have frigate to frigate combat or seige space stations. There is no war mechanics or raiding. Literally all other space games I have played handled it better.
3. [b]Sentinels[/b] - No mans sky equivalent of GTA wanted levels. The justification for their presence is weak sauce. Something... something... Atlas. Whenever they show up I just dig a hole with terrain manipulator until the heat goes away. In space its harder because you have to time your jump just right or it will be jammed.
4. [b]Story[/b] - Something... something... simulation. Too much reading I couldn't be asked. The campaign is just filled with busy work. I neither felt invested nor had fun.
5. [b]Base building[/b] - In most sandbox games, bases have both form and function. Here there is only form, no function. Yeah, the base protects you from the elements but so does digging a hole. The frigate in mid game renders that poinless as well.
6. [b]Exploration[/b] - Exploration in games like minecraft or terraria feels epic because the game developers put effort into making exploration worth it. Here there is just drab planet after planet with some hazardous environment which makes exploration more of a hassle than actually worth it.
7. [b]Language learning game[/b] - When you first contact with aliens you only see giberish and you can ask them literally ONE word of their language then it is added to your collection. This serves no purpose and is a complete waste of time, just avoid.
8. [b]Too many things to recharge[/b] - In minecraft you just need to worry about hunger and health. Here you need 6-8 different things topped up with different fuel at all times. I know there is a gamemode which gets rid of that, but I will still rage.
9. [b]Intergalatic loading screens too long[/b] - Whats the deal with that?
10. [b]Flora and fauna scanning[/b] - You get a pittance for scanning wildlife on a planet. Avoid this mechanic, waste of time.
11. [b]Factory chains[/b] - Just mine gold from asteroids and buy what you need. Its grindy and brainless. 
12. [b]Procedurally generated content[/b] - You have no idea how many times I went in the same building in different worlds in different systems. I am sure there are less than 10 models which are not even randomized.

Overall this game looks like it was built by people who were more interested in ticking boxes of failed promises than actually creating a real game.

After several years of playing this game I can say its been enjoyable, its by no means a perfect game, but it has become its own version of a masterpiece. 

My favorite stuff right now has to be the expeditions, which allow you to jump in and play quick sessions with an end goal. 

Other than that I love that it is a very customisable experience, whether you want to interact with others or not, harder or more lenient settings, its all up to the player.

Of course the game has its flaws, some of the controls are a bit annoying for some, and although you have options, the mechanics or physics can be frustrating for some players. For myself is the space combat.

Of course there are workarounds for almost everything in game and you can basically skip things you do not find enjoyable if you wish.

Overall, a very good game, they get an A from me.

I am just amazed. 

I've always wanted to  try it out and now I did. And I am just 50 hours in... and o my god. 

This game is big. The precissiongenerating is absolutely nuts. When I first zoomed in the map my jaw dropped. 
First of all i couldn't believe how open the game is. I was a bit disappointing that It doesn't have natural HOTAS support, and the flying was kind of flunky. Yet now I know that's just the starting ships with no upgrades.

The base construction is extremely good developed, I still don't feel like close to unlocking 50% of it and I can do so much with the teraforming tools. 
While playing I was thinking how can a developer like Bethesda fail so much with a lot more money to spend... 
The combat looks cheesy at first, but with proper difficulty setting is quite the challenge and get's more sophisticated. You will need specific updates to fight elites. The Whole ship upgrades and freighters fighting is absolutely insane. Even the derelict missions are quite creepy and fit the whole "lost in space" idea. Loved everything about it. Hunting special ships is now a never ending side quest for me. 

The resource/materials gathering and building and combining makes me regret skipping school. It gets quite interesting as I unlock more and more complicated recipes. Money flows and gets spent too fast and it feels overall really dynamic. 

The moment I found a teleport things changed as well, now it feels like way more connected with the whole community. It's a feeling one should just experience that himself/herself. 

Now about the story. I was definitely not expecting this. When I started it, it was arcade-y for me, did not think there's much worth in it. And even in that case the game sort of forces me to pay attention to small details. I ended up so invested in it that I stopped doing anything and focusing in the story mission. I am on the last day from the last quest but I will not share the spoiler. It's just I don't know what happens next and I am scared to rush it but, i surely end up doing it anyhow. It's just crazy and unexpected good. 

I don't think it will be the case but I hope the game goes way past the end of the story while managing to keep the sense of purpose in it. Just overall 10/10 in every aspect. I am so picky, and I just can't find anything big I can beef about. My HoSaS system is gathering dust and I really don't care about it at the moment. Just one more quest at 5am...

Thank you Hello Games
I FORGET TO GO TO MY COLLEGE CUZ THIZ AWESOME GAME :V

If you put in the time to understand the steep learning curve, enjoy sandbox survival experiences, and love space, this game is up your ally. i started the game back in 2016 and only played a couple hours. it was very boring. but in the many years that followed, Hello Games put SO MUCH love and dedication into this game and it shows. Don't get me wrong, just like in most sandbox survival games, you kinda make your own fun with the tools and ingredients you obtain (think Minecraft), but there is also quite a lot of content that is just genuinely fun that you will stumble upon, be it intended, or unexpectedly :) 

it does miss a few opportunities i feel would have varied the experience a little more. and its highly possible they are working on it. Such as getting more planets with different gravity. Having every planet except airless have the same gravity i feel is a missed mark. it may not add a lot to the core game play, but i feel it would add to the experience a little. as well as any form of ship customization. i do note that it would take away from the rarity of some ships, but even just letting us change the color would be nice. we can already upgrade the class and the inventory size, but we cant adjust the color, but we can adjust the color of the freighters?? it may be coming an update though, so just a nitpick. the last complaint is the "tutorial". i feel like it does explain stuff, but not really in a "new player" fashion. I was having to walk my friends through majority of the first half of the game, as they had no idea what to do. they began to catch on around hour 2 and saw where to look and how to read the UI, but learning that i feel could be improved just a little. again not a huge complaint but just something that could be improved to retain new player attention. 

All in all, you have to give it the time to learn the systems, learn the UI, and finish the "tutorial" but then the game really is fun for as long as you want it to be, and with all the twitchy shooters out, it is a relaxing breath of fresh air to come into this game and just enjoy slowing down and smelling the roses a little. 

Highly recommend as a Minecraft alternative or a casual chill-and-explore game.
