No Man's Sky was sold on lies and deception. Pre-release information was censored by Sony to prevent leaks about the game. Now that the cat's out of the bag, we have various avenues we can take to point out these deceptive practices.

Report Hello Games to Consumer Watch, they distribute your claim to multiple organizations to protect consumers from fraud.

https://ssl.datamotion.com/form.aspx?co=3438&frm=citacomplainform&to=flare.fromforms

The above link is the direct link to the appropriate form for reporting Trade Fraud. If you would like to view the parent site yourself, you can do so here:

https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/consumer/get-more-help/if-you-need-more-help-about-a-consumer-issue/

There are a few peices of information you will need to file a complaint properly.
- brief details of your problem, eg when you paid for the item or the service, how much you paid, how you paid for it, whether you did so in a shop or online
- the seller or trader’s name and address
**the following corporate details are publicly available data**
Trader: Hello Games Ltd. Sean Murray, Managing Director. 
Address: 79 Walnut Tree Close Guildford, ENG GU1 4UH, United Kingdom 
website: http://www.hellogames.org/
email: hello@hellogames.co.uk

- what you’ve done so far to try to solve the issue

- Supporing evidence, such as the reddit compiled missing features list here:

https://www.reddit.com/r/Games/comments/4y1h9i/wheres_the_no_mans_sky_we_were_sold_on_a_big_list/

Most of the complaint form is optional to fill in, as indicated by the asterisk.

Steam not giving you a refund?

Report steam to Federal Trade Commission in the US as promoting false and misleading advertising.

https://www.ftc.gov/faq/consumer-protection/submit-consumer-complaint-ftc


AUG 19 2016 Patch v1.03
70 Hour Review

At around the 30ish hour mark you will find you have collected most, if not all of the tech upgrades. Shortly after this your suit, tool and ship will likely be maxxed out in terms of functionality and power. After this point, having more inventory upgrades or a bigger ship is somewhat pointless due to the fact you do not need to gather resources aside from maintaining charge on your gear and jump fuel to reach the center. The fact that after 30ish hours you will have seen most, if not all of the content available means that the subsequent time spent is simply a grind to jump to the center of the universe, which at maximum jump range will likely take 600 to 700 jumps. Assuming you stock up on materials to craft jump fuel periodically along the way this is a monumental and completely unnecessary grind. Top this off with the game as it is calculating your jump range max at around 1650 LY, but due to launch changes increasing the universe size 10x, your linear jump distance to the core only shows 10% of that jump range distance gained when you actually jump. Since I did not realize these things during my first review I must change my recommendation to DEFINITELY NOT recommended, unless you like simply exploring planets repetitively with no new content, no real purpose or goal. I may come back to review again after the development team adds the excessive amount of content they showed in previews for the game prior to release but cut out of the game without informing the players before launch.


AUG 14 2016 Patch v1.03
15 Hour Review

Space and planetary exploration that doesnt force the player to feel rushed or constrained. This game as it is now is more suited to adult players - in the sense that it doesnt hold your hand or have you riding on rails like other games built for children often do. A decently enjoyable semi casual experience despite the rocky launch. I suspect future patches will take this game to new and exciting places! Looking forward to playing again. This review will be appended with additional reviews in the future.

No Man's Sky is a colossal disappointment, showcasing the epitome of unfulfilled promises in gaming history. Seven years post-launch, it remains an exercise in tedium and monotony. Despite the developers' lofty pledges, the game still lacks the fundamental element crucial for any gaming experience: fun. The universe is vast, yet barren of engaging content, with repetitive tasks and uninspiring exploration. The once-hyped features are mere illusions, leaving me with a hollow sense of disillusionment. No amount of updates can salvage the fact that No Man's Sky is an enduring testament to unmet expectations, rendering it a virtual wasteland of boredom

incredibly polished game thats been fleshed out over the course of years. theres SO much to do, it could be the only game you need- but i'm not really at a point in my life where i WANT to only play one game, so i'm doing an expedition or two and then moving on.

the main story has a lot of cosmic horror spookiness, and that's due to some amazing writing, possibly one of my favorite instances of cosmic horror in games

theres a little fomo with the time limited expeditions, but i'm sure theyre super cool for dedicated players! unfortunately tho it feels like they're made specifically FOR dedicated players, because if you're new, you'll be pretty lost and have to look up how to get a bunch of the required materials.

my one big gripe is that the game starts to feel a little samey after a handful of hours, so you have to find your own fun or you will burn out FAST. there's great base building, missions, customization, and progression with new tools and ships and upgrades, but the moment to moment exploration gameplay just didnt hook me, and i fell off after like 4-6 hours.

it seems like an AMAZING roleplay game where you can really feel yourself building familiarity with the world, but for me, i just dont feel like that's worth my time because i'll only stay engaged with new content, and that new content (expeditions) basically requires a new save

also, WEIRD performance drops, like really severe. it gets fixed if you restart but man it TANKS frames after a while.

basically very close to a casual space sim roleplay focused mmo, which i would have loved in middle school

In an era where developers back out of games Days after launch for "failing financially" it is refreshing to revisit no man's sky and to see the dedication the developers have spent to investing and growing this title over the years.  In the past decade we have seen that passion and dedication win in the long run when it comes to games with rocky launches.  Although we as gamers are extremely critical of titles entering the space, I feel we are also extremely forgiving and love to see passionate developers more than anything else.  

We all love a good comeback story. No man's sky is a testament to this. So is cyberpunk 2077 just to name a few.  Hell let loose has had a very tumultuous few months since the new development team took over, but it seems the new development team is listening to their consumers and slowly regaining their respect and trust.

No man's sky should be celebrated not just for the brilliant game play they have produced, But for their love, passion, intensity and dedication to the game as well.  The gaming industry is under threat by con artists, scamers,  venture capitalists and people who have no real vested interest in creating a work of Art, but only to produce some **** that is just good enough to get you to spend your money and nothing else. 

So yes in short by this title. Not only are you getting the game in its current state, but it seems guaranteed that you are getting the game in all of its future configurations as well.  The number of updates to this game that had been free of charge are absolutely astounding.

There are plenty of games in early access with far less active development teams.

NMS is a good game.  There is plenty to do and the game is kept updated with additional content for free after 7 years. 

Is it flawless?  No.  In fact I can point to the main storyline as it's most glaring flaw.  Without spoiling it, it makes the whole exploration of the 16 galaxies seem without purpose.  The game can be grindy at some points, but once you get into it you find ways to mitigate this very quickly even from starting a new game.  And of course, there is very little reason to explore unless you are looking for something in particular (which is usually a smaller detail).  But the star cluster you start around is just as good as the next (more or less).  And lastly the multiplayer aspect is ho-hum.  Good to have it.  But not the best implementation.  Has issues with things like terrain resetting or weather popping around to sync up both players.  Which means if you are underground and someone comes around, suddenly your digging is refilled.

That all being said.  The game's tech (proc gen) is probably the best I have ever seen.  It is fast and seemless.  And it does look good (even when viewing what you've seen already).  There are plenty of activities to do.  Newer features have built up the experience quite a bit and each...ahem iteration ... has gotten better.


After a while planets become very much the same thing arranged in different order.  

You can only have one frieghter in a system making multiplayer grouping silly.  And things are gererally easy to acquire if not just handed to you for little or no effort.  

It can be a better game, but it needs to be a game first.
Its worth it guys. If you have played astroneer an looking for a similar game like it this one is it!

No Man's Sky beckons the bold and the curious to partake in a saga of epic proportions. In this vast and wondrous realm, boundless exploration awaits you, traveler. Behold as one embarks upon a journey across the stars, encountering magnificent worlds and creatures beyond imagination. With the spirit of a true adventurer, one may chart their own path, uncovering ancient lore and forging alliances with strange beings.

As the sun sets upon alien horizons, the heart is stirred by the beauty of this virtual realm. Each step taken in this cosmic odyssey reveals a tapestry of wonders, resonating with the spirit of exploration and the thrill of unearthing hidden marvels.

With every starship launch and planetary landing, one is transported to a realm where the spirit of adventure knows no bounds. Let the echoes of ancient secrets inspire your odyssey through the cosmos, for in this place, the legacy of exploration and wonder lives on.

If you really like exploring, if you are a "I wonder what's on the other side of that hill" kinda guy, you might find NMS entertaining enough. The best feature the game has is the universe of RNG planets with RNG fauna and flora, it's not infinite thou, eventually you'll struggle to find something that feels really new.

BUT...

There is no challenge. The game is just a grind.

If you fought the enemies on a planet and beat em once, you have seen everything the game has to offer land combat wise. The AI is too simple and buggy. The battles on space used to be a little more challenging, but only cause the ship maneuverability is awful, and enemy ship AI is capable of doing stuff you can't (like very sharp and fast turns). Since now they added a "hold this button to dogfight automatically" mechanic, they essentially removed almost all the challenge to fighting in space. There wasn't much challenge to begin with anyway, most space fights boil down to "do you have enough nitrate to keep your shield charged?".

The points of interest on a planet are not diverse/random. Once you've seen one of each you know them all, as they are always the same. This has been the case since release, and they never did anything to introduce variety to this aspect of the game, specially considering that the players are required to visit multiple of these. It just makes the grind more tedious and the shallowness of the gameplay more obvious.

The UX is horrible. After so many years in development I still don't get why they haven't fixed it yet. Maybe they like making players miserable. For some reason almost everything requires you to hold a key, not tap it. Everything requires multiple steps and multiple windows. There are no filters of any kind anywhere, and eventually everything fills up with just too much stuff.

On a related topic, the crafting system is awful. There's no way to craft multiple items at once, and every craft is holding down a key, then release, the hold again, etc. Then imagine having to do this for recipes with multiple crafting steps... You end up just buying the items you need instead... is so much faster.

Base building mechanics were initially very simple, very intuitive, now they are a convoluted mess with an awful UX. The first iteration of base building had simple modular bases, you just put a room and a door and you had a base. This modules are still available but only later in the game, instead players have to build their first base out of wooden planks like a primitive life-form. Kudos for including a build camera, all base building games should have this feature.

For reasons unknown they also added an electricity system at some point, which really serves no purpose other that be a nuisance, specially cause every modular building piece requires electricity now... maybe it was a way to push people to start using the other system? Well... at least there's an option to disable electricity if you want.

The game was not made for multiplayer, it's a singleplayer experience through and through. Having someone play along side you can be helpful, as you can share resources, but you both be mostly doing your own stuff on your own... there is not much stuff to do together. Also, the multiplayer is really buggy, lots of desyncs (experiencing different stuff though being right next to each other), personal quests sometimes bug out when doing it along someone else, some stuff can be looted by everyone some cannot, etc...

Story wise the game is actually well written, if I remember correctly there was a big name in scifi literature involved with the game originally, but the delivery is really bad. It's just text dump after text dump, and the game being so grindy just make you skip most of it, as you just want the reward and the text is in the way. It also doesn't help that some of it is garbled until you become proficient in some of the 4 different languages, which you can only learn one word at a time.

Being an angry feminist eager to ruin the sky for men and claim the far reaches of the galaxy as the sole domain of  women,  I admit I cackled as the outrage cries of thousands of gamers flooded review websites and forums during the weeks that followed the launch of No Man's Sky.

"Finally, the sky shall be ours and ours alone! Muahaha!"

Unpestered by solitude and under the influence of a moderate dose of psychedelics, I roamed the vast emptiness of space, scouring systems for paradise planets to name after famous lesbians. 

However, even as I spread my feminine hold over the galaxy, Hello Games seemed determined to make peace with the men who'd left in droves, and diligently worked month after month, year after year, patching, repairing, expanding, and delivering. The men began to slowly return, suspicious at first, and eventually with great enthusiasm.  

While I may have been forced to cede interstellar territory to Men for Whomst the Sky was Not intended, it's hardly been a bitter pill to swallow.  Incredible development progress has been made over the past 7 years, and it's impossible to deny that the game is much better today than it was before, even if you (like myself) were dating an indie game developer in 2016 and thus had incredibly measured expectations for a dev team of 15 people in the first place. 
 
I was refused a boarding pass for the hype train, due to vaguely understanding the limitations imposed on individual developers by the mere fact of only 24 hours existing in a single day, and an awareness of the impact of artificially imposed launch deadlines that fail to respect non-linear development progress. 
For that reason, I didn't feel the game was  ever a failure... But having played the game years later, with the massive (free, by the way) expansions and the improved graphics and the DLC and the community that grew along with the base game, the original launch sucked balls b comparison, and I'd be a loon to suggest otherwise.

If you were on that hype train and haven't come back to it since the initial launch, you ought to consider revisiting.

No Mans Sky, as a result of the development team's continued devotion to their craft and confidence of  concept, had by 2020 certainly met or exceeded the expectations of its original audience, even if the sky now has a bunch of men in it.

It would appear that I am part of a small minority of steam users who are not suffering from random crashes and are able to run the game at max settings without any performance issues. I have to admit that the scenery is quite beautiful, but unfortunately beauty isn't everything. At the time of this review I have clocked about 1.6 hours on steam, and I am seriously debating at requesting a refund and purchasing this game again when they've fixed all the issues. 

Now to get to my issues:

I started the download a few minutes after 1 PM EST, which lasted a mere few minutes before being completed. 

I launched the game and was immediately thrown into action as soon as the splash screens ended. I received a neat notification that I had discovered the planet I was stranded on. My first instinct was to simply walk around and look at the gorgeous scenery of my newly discovered planet when a pop up notification alt-tabbed me out of the game. I tried to alt-tab back in, but was unable to resume my gameplay. Using the task-manager I performed the "End Task" action and simply restarted the game.

 Upon re-launch of the game I was thrown onto a completely new planet, once again receiving the notification that I was the person to discover this planet. Since I hadn't really done anything with my initial launch I simply shrugged it off and started playing again. After an hour and 25 minutes of gameplay, I had explored a good amount of the planet's surface while simultaneously getting credit for having discovered a ton of species and fauna I had come across (One of the flying species required me to climb a mountain and wait for it to fly by in order to scan it). I could track my exploration progress by pressing the ESC button, which showed me how much of the planet I had discovered as well as my status as being "online". At this point I alt-tabbed (unfortunately I had forgotten what happened earlier), and was unable to tab back into the game. The only option I had at this point was to force close the program and re-launch the game for a third time. At this point I was a bit worried since I wasn't sure that I would spawn back onto the same planet, as my earlier experience with restarting the game threw me onto a completely new planet. Luckily, I was not thrown onto a new planet but instead was spawned back on the same planet. However, all my progress had been lost. To ensure that this wasn't a simple connection glitch, I decided to "Quit to Desktop" and launch the game again. Unfortunately, even after restarting the game and re-connecting to the online servers my past progress did not show up in-game. 

I cannot stress how frustrating it is to lose all the progress I had made because the alt-tabbing feature doesn't work properly. It said that I was connected to the online servers my entire game play session, so I am unable to understand why my exploration progress was lost to begin with. Does it not upload our discoveries to the online server upon us getting credit for them? 

I feel like a player losing all their progress is a potential risk in playing an early access game, but I honestly did not expect to have such an error occur in a finished product that was pushed back twice before being released. 

At the current state of the game I cannot recommend it, but if you do decide to try it out be sure to stay away from the alt-tab buttons and manually save your game by jumping into the cockpit of your ship.

---Updated Review---
A friend recently recommended that I re-install the game and check out all the new content added to the game. I have to say, I am completely blown away at what the game has turned into! It feels like an entirely different game from the last time I played it, which technically it is since so many features have been added that didn't exist when the game came out. While there are still some issues while playing multiplayer, the overall experience is amazing and it's clear that the developers are very passionate about their work (it really shows!). I feel like the minimum I could do to show my appreciation of their incredible work over the years is to update my review, if you're into open world survival/exploration type games I highly recommend you check this game out. If you already own the game but haven't played in a few years, re-install the game and check out all the new content that has been added!

I have decided not to remove my original review to reflect my experience during launch, other game developers can definitely learn a lesson that even with a very rocky start you can still make a gem of a game.

No Man's Sky is a thoroughly enjoyable, relaxed, casual sc-fi survival game that has a heavy emphasis on exploration and travel.

The game world consists of a near infinite number of procedurally generated galaxies, each of which contain a large amount of star systems that subsequently contain a number of exoplanets.
This structure doesn't aim to emulate existing star systems in our own universe like for like, using an entirely procedurally generated formula that produces random results constantly.
This structure is applied to every aspect of the game, from space to planetary surfaces, and although there are certain objects like Space Stations and buildings on planetary surfaces that seem to have a more standardised formula, there is usually some aspect attributed to them that will make them unique from other locations.

The core gameplay loop that the game is designed around is essentially to hop from one of these exoplanets to the next while scanning, mining, acquiring goods, taming creatures, fighting drone like enemies named sentinels and biological horrors, creating bases and crafting and other similar more traditional survival mechanics.
The crafting mechanics the game offers are abundant, although not at the very top of it's class in the survival genre in my opinion.
There is typically a limited amount of data you can scan, resources you can extract etc. per planet, so you are incentivised to go to other planets to acquire what you would not have access to on one planet alone.

Although the player has the ability to traverse space, it is clear that it's purpose is to act as more of an intermediary location from the planet to planet exploration.
Each star system typically will have one Space Station, which is essentially a giant trading hub that possess's features only attainable there.
There are also a number of random encounters that you may come across in space, from pirate fights to traders looking to trade.

The game does have combat mechanics, both on planet via your multi-tool, which has weapon functionality that you can craft, and in space via your starship.
The quality of the combat is satisfactory, it doesn't feel particularly impactful but is fun nonetheless.
It didn't come across as tedious or as an unwanted, tacked on feature to me which I feel is adequate for the function it serves in the context of the game.

Despite using an entirely randomly generated world, No Man's Sky does have many narrative elements to it, although it is more of a secondary function of the game behind the survival mechanics.
There are multiple different alien races with their own history & lore. 
There is a main quest that offers an interesting narrative that I was satisfied with upon completing.
This main quest also acts as a great way to introduce the game and it's abundance of mechanics to the player when first playing.
There are also some smaller side quests in addition to in game achievements and titles that you can earn for performing a number of actions such as harvesting a certain amount of plant etc.
All of these are the main progression based aspects of the game which act as a nice goal to have while playing through the exploration based mechanics of the game.

Given that it is an exploration based sandbox game at heart, these progression focused areas add specific goals for the player but tend to only last for a small portion of the early to mid game of a playthrough.
Other goals that have trended among the community currently or in the past include starship hunting, rare planet or biome hunting, or trying to travel to the center of the universe.
The fact that this list is as long as it is and many veteran players continue to  play this game in new ways constantly is a big indicator of the quality and scope of the sandbox this game provides.

The developer, Hello Games, have continued time and again to release huge patches and updates filled with new content all for no cost to the player.
These updates are big enough in scale to be reasonably compared to a typical paid DLC expansion that you would receive from most major triple A studios.
Each update typically has a particular theme associated with it, with the majority of content added within it following this theme in some way.
For example, one of these past updates was known as 'OUTLAWS' and consisted of improved space combat, outlaw systems, the ability to recruit your own squadron of pilots etc.
Another common game mode that is introduced with new updates are Community Expeditions, which are essentially time limited journeys that give you a number of tasks to perform in a variety of locations in return for rewards not obtainable in a regular save game.
I find these Community Expeditions in particular to be very enjoyable, the guided structure and quick time frame makes them both challenging and entertaining.

The game also boasts a variety of standard game modes available to the player constantly, the basic most common being known as Survival, in addition to there being a more building focused Creative mode and even a hardcore 'Permadeath' mode where, as the name implies, your save is wiped upon dying.

No Man's Sky is also a sort of semi multiplayer game, with the ability to play both single and multi player in the same world depending on whether you have the relevant setting enabled.
The community in general in this game is very strong and positive, a lot of the Community Expeditions mentioned above are often completed with teamwork amongst the community, and there is also this very impressive, massive community hub in game known as the Space Anomaly that is summonable on command in space that allows you to see worlds and creations of others instantly.

I was initially skeptical about this game upon hearing all of the controversy surrounding it when it released back in 2016, however I picked it up in a Steam sale for about half price about a year ago and am now very happy with this decision. 
I would happily pay the current full price of €58.99 today given the amount of potential play time and content available.
No Man's Sky ranks in my top 5 survival games of all time and may be the very best exploration game specifically that I have played.

MY OVERALL RATING: 85/100

My original review of this game, shortly after its release, was the following:

[Shakespeare may have played this game:
"It is a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing."]

In late 2023, shortly following the viewing of the VGA, I chose to finally revisit this title, and potentially reassess my opinion.  In short, I concluded that the game isn't idiotic, and may very well have deep meaning to somebody, but I couldn't bear the process of digging deep enough to discover if it has meaning for me.

Sadly, I have concluded that No Man's Sky remains a game that I cannot recommend.  It is more than content-rich - it is a vast, VAST sandbox of immense potential, if you enjoy what the game offers.  I will admit this: the moment one lifts off from a planet, that first time, and seamlessly transitions from the surface of a planet to outer space, it is magical.  However, the rest of the game failed to meet that moment.  The pace was absolutely purgatorial for me - and I LOVE crafting survival-style games, and I found the effort of scouring the surface of a mildly hostile planet for various elements to be almost immediately tedious.  The game is a constant presentation of little challenges, and does provide the feeling of accomplishment when you deduce the means of overcoming them...  but some of that challenge is, unfortunately, baked into the odd method of interaction with the menu and controls.  I found that I strongly dislike the menus and the means of selecting items, crafting, and nearly every other interactive element.  This may change for a veteran player, but to me, I couldn't stomach getting that far.  The act of discovering a space station for the first time, rather than feed the joy of discovery, felt like a confusing let-down.  Meeting additional aliens, and starting the process of learning their language, one word at a time, was to me a "Groundhog's Day" scenario of nightmare repetition.

It's almost a stupid thing to say, but there's no way I got close to experiencing all that this game has to offer - the truth of the matter is, nobody can.  The game is too big for that.  The barrier I cannot overcome is this: after re-familiarizing myself with No Man's Sky circa 2023, I didn't want to even try.

It's not for me.

Don't get me wrong; this game is incredibly impressive from a technical standpoint. But it's too much of a toy or dollhouse, and not enough of a game. 

Yes, sure, you can collect lots of outfits, and you can make a base, and you can even tame pets. But if you're looking for something that has more direction and focus, that challenges you, that asks you to overcome obstacles, or entices you with an engaging narrative alongside meaningful exploration, then this game might not be for you.

--

In detail:

The game is really easy. And by that I mean, there's really no meaningful challenge, anywhere. The game never asks you to figure something out. There's combat, but it's very easy. There are puzzles: Easy. You have to worry about oxygen and radiation, but the solutions are obvious and simple. You have to collect resources, but it's trivial, just time consuming.

There's a story. It's text-only; no voice over, no animations, and the writing could be better. So far, it seems to serve as just a tutorial for the sandbox. It lacks weight, focus, emotion. This is unlike, say, Subnautica, a similar game that I enjoyed more, which grounded me in a character on a mission from the opening scene, all the way through the ending.

Exploration. It's painfully obvious that each world and everything in it was created by an algorithm. I like other games that feature procedurally-generated content, but the extent to which No Man Sky relies upon it is unmatched. Better designed games create spaces specifically for humans to explore, in ways that lead to surprise, enjoyment, feelings of danger; gameplay! I didn't feel so moved by No Man's Sky's worlds.

Space has no verisimilitude. There's no gravity, except when your boots are actually on the ground. You don't orbit a planet. You don't need to think about your path through a solar system. You just point your ship at where you want to go, press a button, and you're instantly there. There are no gas giants, or anything other than terrestrial worlds. Our own solar system could not be modeled in NMS.

Base-building. Don't get me wrong, I love base-building games. But this isn't supposed to be a base-building game; it's supposed to be a space exploration game. The goal of the game (to reach the center of the galaxy) is directly opposed to base-building. 

In fact, when playing the game, and seeing how fully featured ancillary features like base-building, creature taming, and space-suit customization were, I found myself feeling that they'd sunk all their development time in the wrong things. No Man's Sky feels like it's being led by something other than it's listed design goals.

--

Conclusion: For me, I found myself falling asleep playing it. I don't hate sandboxes by any means, but this just lacked enough of a challenge or narrative for me to sink my teeth into.

All that said, this game really is incredible, technically. One wonders what they could do to bring a gamer like me on board. I love survival sandboxes like Oxygen Not Included; I love builder games like Subnautica or Factorio; I love games about space, like Stellaris. I'm in the developer's wheelhouse. Just... Make it a better *game*!

I have enjoyed the game so far. I have played roughly 100 hours.
  Things I like:
1. Once I got a hang of the game it is pretty easy to progress.
2.  The different types of worlds and the endless amount of them.
3.  There are different paths to follow in story
4. Many ships to choose from
  Things I think need improvement:

2. I also enjoy running my settlement. It is also a little slow. I can build something and then I have to wait for the settlement to decide what to do next. If I am the overseer I should just be able to do it myself.
3. I find NPC's in floors pretty often. So, there are some bugs. However nothing that makes the game unplayable.

UPDATE #2 (Dec 2019)
This game is still seeing major updates and new features and is an entirely different game from that garbage state it was released in. Compared to my last update where I said that it wasn't worth $60, maybe 40. I am going to change that slightly with how much has changed since then. Is it worth 
$60? Previous No; Now Maybe,
$40? Previously Eh maybe; Now Probably
$30?Previously Probably; Now Almost certainly 
$20? Previously Definitly; Now No change.

The game came out in a terrible state but now has been worked on above and beyond their original promises that they failed to deliever originally.. 

UPDATE #1 (some time early 2018) 

This game launched as a buggy unfinished mess, with a lot of lacking promised features or fake ones. But since then it has been three years and a lot of updates, new features, and fixes have been done, even to the point where a new major patch with a lot of content added will come out here in the next week even though the game is 3 years old at this point. I would honestly say while the game is still very grindy, if you find the game on sale, it might be worth looking into since the poor reviews mostly comes from people who bought it at launch, hated the state it came out in and never gave it another go since. Is it worth $60? No; $40? Eh maybe; $30? Probably; $20 definitly; If Steam had an option to filter out reviews by date to get more accurate representation I would say look at reviews from the last 6 months and not ones from 3 years ago, there has been vast updates and fixes, but since they don't just realize that 52% is from people who got a lot of hype and then got something launched years to early and then never came back when the game was more feature complete. Initial Load times are a little long but once you are in the game the far and few between load times (only when you switch galaxies) are not bad.

#####Original review##### (August 2016)
Has a lot of performance issues for a lot of people, while my performance isn't what it should be I am lucky and it is atleast a playable performance for me. Hopefully the issues for most people will get fixed sooner rather then later but it seems to be 50/50 as to wither or not you get a playable experience or unbearable framerate issues and for that reason alone I would say wait for them to fix it or wait till its on deep discount because you shouldn't be rewarding devs when they release something not fit for purpose for half their consumers.

With that out of the way lets get to is the game good or not and wither or not I would recommend it after it gets some fixes. I feel this game is very much like Spore where most people will be disapointed it didn't live up to its hype and for people who didn't listen to hype it will depend on if you like games that would be best described as Elite Dangerous crossed with Rodina crossed with the survival genre of having to constantly be gathering tons of resources to craft into things, that has a "Inventory Full Simulator 2016" feel to it as well where you have very little inventory but in the few places you can sell stuff most of what you have you need to craft things so end up either selling stuff you need hoping its common enough to find again, skiping looting, or constantly flying back and forth between the vendor and where your exploring, mixed with the Final Fantasy X "find all the words for each language throughout the game to figure out what gibberish they where speaking the first time you encountered them" (yes I know in FFX that it was 26 letters hidden around the game and not hundreds or thousands of words, but still point is having to find a way to translate the language they are speaking right in the begining)

All in all I am enjoying the game, but I also enjoy games like Elite Dangerous, Rodina, and I didn't find Spore to be that bad (sure it wasn't that good either, but it wasn't that bad), its got the beautiful exploration of Rodina mixed with the Elite Dangerous "well I can sell it hear but I will get 20% less money then if I sell it 3 systems over, but it costs resources to fly those 3 systems so do I really make a profit flying that far?" mixed with finding all the words to be able to get what the alien races are telling you. Its a niche game (not as niche as ED, but still definitly not for everyone) that if you don't like exploring in games, if you have to have something to do you will not enjoy this game, but if you like exploring everything with very little to no main objective to head towards (that you are aware of) then you will love the game.

The upgrade system is interesting, though it is annoying perks like sprinting take up inventory slots which you start off thread bear with anyways. The constantly having to recharge things as often as you do feels like survival game crap that while things should need recharged you shouldn't need to do them near as often as you do.

My biggest gripe with the game is that while the wild life is pretty cool when you come across it, the planets seem way to barren, you can explore a planet for an hour and only run into one creature, I don't expect the planets to be sprawling with creatures, but I would like there to be enough to where you can not go 30 miutes without seeing any lifeforms at all, atleast enough to where you see atleast one other living thing once every 10 miuntes to make the planets feel less barren.

#####END Original Review#####

Top 5 in my favorite games of all time. An absolute gem. As a newbie, the first couple hours can be a bit of a drag, but after that, everything just opens up like mad. If you're unsure about buying the game, trust me, it's WELL worth your time. It goes on sale frequently, so I would wait for that, but if you're itching for it right away, it's well worth the price of admission. Hello Games to this day is STILL putting out free content and updates all these years later and from what I can tell, they're not going to stop anytime soon. Get it. You won't be disappointed.

I've tried to get in to this game four separate times since buying it. Each time, it was after hearing someone say "Oh yeah, that game really did get good after a while, you should check it out again." Each time, I have the exact same thoughts - the game is boring. Almost indescribably boring. It actually puts me to sleep. 

That could be good if you really want a "chill" game, but to me it only feels "chill" because it's literally nothing. I'm not DOING anything. The only reason I go anywhere (outside of the occasional randomly generated building with a static npc in it) is just to be burdened with the process of going there in the first place. 

Taking off and leaving orbit requires fuel, and jumping to another system requires a different fuel. Landing and getting out shows you pretty much the entire planet right away; the terrain and flora/fauna are mostly the same outside of the occasional cave or sea. The entire planet has the same weather.  There may be a hut or two somewhere you can trade with a minecraft villager at, if you're lucky. Aside from that, the only reason I even have to get out is to get more fuel for my thrusters. While I'm out, my life support systems start complaining about needing more fuel, too. After punching every tree, rock, crystal and randomly generated spore creature in eyesight of the ship and stuffing it in to the status bars shackled to my ankles, I get back in my ship and take off, having accomplished nothing except knowing the Gek word for "stupid."

The actual spaceflight stuff is nice, although it's not exactly sim-y. Pretty simple and basic. The incremental tech upgrades to your ship(s), suit and laser tool are probably supposed to be the main source of progression and a reason to keep going, but that's not helped by how tedious the menus are to navigate, especially on a gamepad. Tedious just feels like the word here. 

Even if I can go out there and build a big compound or run my own frigate or discover that we're all in a simulation or whatever, I can't shake that feeling that when I head out towards to a new planet, there's not really anything to do or anything to discover unless I'm doing it just to inconvenience myself.

WARNING: this game has horrible load times, and an extremely long tutorial, and in general is extremely grindy. You will not be able to get a good idea of the game within the 2 hour refund period, and they will reject your refund for being longer. DO NOT PURCHASE unless you are 100% sure you will like the game.

In addition:
- lots of bugs, many of which softlock or hardlock the game
- all procgen feels very repetitive once you've seen like 20 of each thing
- all the buildings are identical, feeling even more repetitive
- they tried to shoehorn in a story which feels very disconnected and antithetical to the game's design
- tutorial takes forever, far longer than your 2 hour return period
- everything is locked behind the tutorial for some reason
- cant customize your ship despite it being made of modular parts. you cant even paint it.
- every single task in this game boils down to collecting materials, which is a huge grind
- sentinals act like gta cops, and since they just keep coming, your only option is to hide, which is extremely annoying, especially if you're in space, and they can be triggered by anything
- every planet looks the same all over, once you've landed, you've essentially seen the whole planet
- there are 0 towns or cities, just repetitive buildings
- building could be fun, if it there were more decorative blocks, but there's only like one variation of everything
- $60 is way too much for this game, it should start at $30 (which they put it on sale for constantly, so they know that's the real price). but I still think $30 was too much. I'd be happy if I paid $15.

I'm not one of the players who played during their disastrous launch, so I can't say how much it's improved. But I did play around 4 years ago, and it still feels pretty much exactly the same. I'm sure people who already own it are happy to get free updates, but the game still feels like it isn't complete. I think even if this version was what they launched with, people would be upset. I wish they focused more on refining the features they already have and fixing the gamebreaking bugs instead of adding new fancy features. 

Don't listen to all the reviews who gave it a thumbs up just because it's better than it was at launch. It is still not a good game.

But that's really where my gripes end. All that stuff aside this game is a great space exploration sandbox that gives you a lot of neat tools to do whatever you want. Piracy is really fun. Commanding a fleet of starships is cool. The ship combat and base building is also really satisfying. If you're willing to play for a while to get access to all the cool stuff then this game is for you. If you don't care about all that stuff and just want a really chill space exploration game, this is a must buy.

"As vast as an ocean, as shallow as a puddle". After seeing how public opinion had been turned around on this game, and all the content they were adding, I finally decided to give it a chance. And as I feared, I played it for less than 4 hours and got bored. What a shame, it has all the elements to succeed, cool art style, fun flying in and out of planets and exploration mechanics. But I didn't feel like there was a purpose at any point. Just exploration for the sake of exploration. An empty, albeit beautiful, but meaningless sandbox without what I would qualify as a story! Compare it to Breath of the Wild, which I loved, I don't mind exploring huge maps, grinding for cosmetic items and working on my base. But I still need to know my purpose in this world and what the main objective that I'm working towards is. My time is valuable to me, I love gaming but also am not interested in a huge grindy timesink with no real purpose. Hopefully, they've learned their lesson for Light No Fire! (Although given the initial presentation at the Game Awards, talking first about a huge open world and big mountains and rivers, it doesn't seem like it.)

You should buy No Man's Sky.

No Man's Sky is one of my special games. 

This is my story of the game.
I discovered the game in late 2019, right after the launch of the Beyond update. I had very little access to gaming news back then (so I had no idea about the controversial launch), I had very little experience with many open world games in the past, the only exception being Minecraft. So when I went to my grandparent's house (they have an XBOX 1) and got to test it out, my mind was completely blown. Never in my life had I even imagined it possible to have a game that contained a literal universe that I could travel seamlessly!
Of course, the game immediately went on my christmas list. My parents bought it for me on the PS4, and I played the crap out of it. For months, it was exclusively the game that I played with little exception. I was enthralled by the universe, and exploring it was a dream come true.
I loved building empires, getting ships, finding weird planets no one had ever seen before! It was something truly special.
The thing that really got me was the updates. Oh My Gosh. I thought the game was amazing when I was playing it back then. But then huge update after update released. I clearly remember learning about Living Ship and thinking "This can't be real". Exo mech came out, and while it wasn't as spicy, it was still cool. Then there was Desolation, which was incredible! 

Soon, I got my first PC. After a few months, I decided to get No Man's Sky on steam. So, I purchased it one night, woke up the next morning, and Origins dropped. Origins was one of the best updates to ever come to the game in my opinion, and to say the least I was stoked.

While I don't play the game consistently, it is one of those ones I can always come back to. I recently have played 10-20 hours every year, and it's great. Last year, I played the game, and I got to get myself a then new solar ship, play around with sentinels, etc. This year I came back to the same save and got to get a sentinel interceptor, and got to enjoy the incredible Echoes update. Every year, there is a massive amount of content added, and it is truly a blessing and a testament to the legendary comeback this game had.

with that out of the way, here are some pros and cons:
PROS
-Updates
-SEAMLESS SPACE TRAVEL ITS SO GOOD
-Base Building. That's always great to see in a game
-Graphics/artstyle
-Soundtrack. Could be swapped with Risk of Rain's and no one would notice *HYPERBOLE*
-Story and lore---OMG it may not be on the level as stories in like the Ori Games or Hollow Knight, it is surprisingly good. Like I came back to it after like 2 years fully expecting it to be not as good as I remembered, but I was quickly proven wrong 9/10 story
-gek

Cons:
-The procedural generation is, inevitably, limited.
-that grind... This game has hours of content, which is good, but sometimes it feels soooooo grindy
-The multiplayer is great, but somewhat limited. The universe is not perfectly consistent between players, so dont expect to be building cool shared bases with your buddies that you can both edit offline :(

7/10, I recommend this game! :)

No Man's Sky is a game that lets you explore an infinite universe of planets, creatures, and mysteries. With the latest update, 4.0, the game has become even more immersive and enjoyable. Here are some of the features that 4.0 brings:

- More storage: You can now store up to 10,000 items in your inventory, and up to 100,000 items in your freighter. You can also upgrade your storage containers to hold more items and access them from anywhere.

- New item icons: The game has redesigned the icons for all the items, making them more detailed and colorful. You can easily identify the type, rarity, and quality of each item by looking at its icon.

- Sweet graphic additions: The game has improved the graphics and lighting effects, making the worlds more realistic and beautiful. You can see the sun rays, the shadows, the reflections, and the weather changes in stunning detail. You can also customize the graphics settings to suit your preference and performance.

With all the free content added since release, such as base building, multiplayer, VR support, and more, No Man's Sky is a must-have for anyone who loves adventure and exploration. You can buy the game on Steam, PlayStation, or Xbox, and enjoy the endless possibilities of the universe.

If you are an exploration buff, then this game is very addictive.  There's always one more thing to pick up, one more thing to get.  Over 300 hours in and I have not finished the main quest.  I am starting to call the main objective "ArteMISS" because I keep putting off finding them.  Most things lead to new solar systems, and I have to go to every planet.  There's exploration, discovery, base building, and combat, all on the ground and in space.  You can explore, be a pirate, or be a farmer even if you want.  Something for everyone.  It helps if you're a fan of space sims.  No RPG elements, just finding new stuff and improving your equipment.  Leagues beyond what the game was when I first tried it six years ago, I just hate I took this long to find all the good stuff Hello Games has done.  Hats off to them for giving away what everyone else charges $ for as DLC nowadays.

You see, hello games has a very strange strategy to game design, namely they don't fix bugs, they label them as features and call it a day.
Well, that's not entirely true, they do sometimes "fix" bugs, but they appear to look for the worst way possible to do so.

Star ship mining laser overheats so fast that it's not usable for mining?
Call it a phase gun and pretend the overheating is intended!

People abuse bash-flying to get around planets too fast? just reduce jetpack fuel by 95%, it does nothing to fix bash-flying, but at least it'll be more annoying to do.

People complain the game is too easy? 
make a hard mode where every planet is deadly, so being exposed to the elements kills you in about 5 minutes.
and spawn the player a 10 minute walk away from their ship every time they die.

Clipping into space stations when you make a sharp turn as you boost into the landing animation?
let's just not let you turn the starship when boosting, does nothing to fix the floppy pathing that is the root cause of the clipping issue, but it makes it harder to do (it also completely ruins space combat, but we'll ignore that)
https://twitter.com/siriusblack9999/status/1731756310163775763

Freighter telepad softlocks you if you try to hover over because it teleports you to the same position relative to the destination, which happens to be inside the wall above the destination telepad?
don't fix the fact that you're softlocked when you end up in a wall because wall hitboxes are two-sided
don't fix the fact that teleports don't autosave, so you can spend literal hours playing without ever autosaving if you teleport between locations
don't add a way to un-softlock yourself (EDIT: turns out i didn't check the options menu well enough, because sure enough, there actually is an unstuck button!, too bad it only works on freighters)
don't fix the relative positional offset in the teleporting that causes this particular softlock
naah, cause those fixes would make sense, hello games style is to just shrink the teleport hitbox and call it good, never mind that the "biological horror" creatures that were introduced in 2018 also have a habit of pushing you into walls, softlocking you, which still hasn't been addressed.
https://twitter.com/siriusblack9999/status/1732550287087550727

And don't get me started about the shitstorm that is sentinels... at least they've finally been somewhat buffed, so it's no longer 5 waves of 1-3 enemies per wave, followed by "oops, we didn't think anyone would make it this far, now no more sentinels will ever spawn as long as you stay on this planet".
But they're still completely and utterly broken.
If you aggro sentinels, then sit in your spaceship and do nothing, after 30 seconds, you'll get 2 stars
30 seconds later 3 stars, 30 seconds later 4, 30 seconds more 5 stars, and if you then get out, they de-aggro entirely
https://twitter.com/siriusblack9999/status/1731822518930227210
they forget you exist when you're standing inside a building, even if you're actively shooting them
https://twitter.com/siriusblack9999/status/1732097526101311922
and shooting a space station gets you 3 stars instantly, but landing in a space station de-aggros and despawns them (useful for farming freighters)
https://twitter.com/siriusblack9999/status/1731757951151661481

oh, and they thought a virtual joystick would be a good control scheme for VR
no, not the joystick on the VR controllers,
you use the VR controllers to grab a virtual joystick, and moving that virtual joystick then controls the ship with zero feedback at all, so you better have a steady hand or you're going to start doing backflips in VR, great for people with motion sickness.

No Man's Sky has transformed from a promising concept into an absolute masterpiece of exploration and limitless potential. As a dedicated player since its early days, I've witnessed the game's evolution, and I am truly astounded by the commitment of the developers at Hello Games to continually improve and expand upon their universe.

The sheer scale of No Man's Sky is mind-boggling. From the moment you step onto your first procedural generated planet, you are immersed in a breathtaking, diverse cosmos. The sense of discovery is unparalleled, as each star system brings new wonders, unique landscapes, and a wealth of flora and fauna waiting to be catalogued. The exploration aspect alone is worth the journey, and the recent updates have only deepened the well of possibilities.

Beyond exploration, No Man's Sky now boasts a robust multiplayer experience, allowing players to seamlessly connect with others across the galaxy. The addition of multiplayer not only enhances the cooperative aspects of the game but also introduces a social dimension that enriches the overall experience. Teaming up with fellow interlopers to embark on epic space adventures adds a whole new layer of excitement and camaraderie.

The crafting and base-building mechanics have also seen significant improvements. Building your own planetary outpost or constructing a massive freighter fleet has never been more intuitive or rewarding. The customisation options are vast, allowing players to truly leave their mark on the universe in creative and unique ways.

One of the most commendable aspects of No Man's Sky is the dedication to community feedback. Hello Games actively listens to its player base, addressing concerns and implementing changes based on user suggestions. This commitment to improvement has fostered a strong and supportive community that feels genuinely valued by the developers.

In conclusion, No Man's Sky is no longer just a game; it's an ongoing cosmic adventure that continues to evolve and captivate. The dedication of Hello Games to their creation is evident in every update, and the result is a space-faring experience that is as boundless and awe-inspiring as the universe it seeks to emulate. Strap in, fellow travellers, because the journey through No Man's Sky is an odyssey of infinite possibilities, and the stars are yours to explore.
The game has come a long way in 7 years, it has finally become the game we were promised so many years ago, kudos to the Hello games team for sticking by its labour of love and making it special

[strike]7.5/10[/strike] 9/10

Original-ish review:

The Good:
It's just plain fun.  The core game is quite simple, there are a lot of things you can do at any given time depending on your mood, and to appeal to a wider variety of players. In my case, one daughter likes to just go exploring and finding new creatures/planets.  Another just plants in place and starts base building...while Daddy's out in space blasting pirates. 

Patches continually add new things that add new spins or overall TLC to the game.  While there is still room for improvement, I have revised my review and expect it will eventually get a solid 10/10 in the future.

The bad:

1) The game lacks cohesion:

Having completed the game, I enjoyed it overall, but I think it might be better to rework existing things to better mesh into a longer overall story.  Or to not progress certain main story elements until certain related parts are done.  As is, you just go from place to place without really integrating all elements. 

As is, there's really no reason to have certain upgrades because there's really no gate or progression between them.  Hyperdrives for example: As soon as you get one, warp to the newly unlocked star type, mine the next mineral up, upgrade to the next hyperdrive, rinse repeat to max.  

It should be using additional components that are more involved: Rare resources that require planetary searches, underwater-only resources, materials gained only from fighting the menacing machine/"horror" enemies or something you get from derelict freighters in space).  Something like storm crystals are an excellent example of how they "Gatekeep" in that you have to have a good handle/patience on surviving in hostile storms to get them. 

2) It can get repetitive quickly:

My biggest issue now is  how uniform planets are overall.  I hope we can eventually see worlds reworked to have multiple biomes on a single planet, and for more general points of interest or pull to just exploring an individual planet.  Essentially I would love to see a player be able to spend their entire play on a single planet and continuously enjoy new experiences.  As an example, other sandbox games like Conan Exiles show how a world can have a lot packed into a small space.  Of course, that game is a handcrafted world and not procedural, but it's a good goal.  Things like enemy humanoid encampments or ruined cities would be interesting.

Similarly, there is a need for more creature types, more variety in parts and ideally more alien races, even if they are merely minor.

3) A lot of options that don't REALLY matter:

The different exo-craft, space ships etc ultimately are just aesthetic choices.  There really should be a more obvious cap or difference between things like cargo space, speed or maneuverability.

Things like the shuttles being efficient for fuel/launch fuel, ultimately being the ONLY option for free takeoff would be interesting.  Or having fighters have pitiful cargo max space, or the inability to have a warp drive...but also an inherent bonus to all weapon mods.  As is they are all essentially identical.


The Verdict: 
With as much love as this game has, I'm confident any problems will be ironed out, and perhaps the core story/progression loop might get a TLC.  A solid game but still needs a little more love.

I cannot recommend a better Open-World space exploration game. Though I only have a few dozen hours on steam as of writing this, on Xbox I have hundreds upon hundreds of hours spent in this masterpiece. I was there at the beginning of it all, in 2016, No Man's Sky was only a concept, one small step. But I've watched the game grow and become something so unrecognizable from the launch. It has become one of if not my favorite open-world game, and I find myself constantly returning to it, if not grinding it. The music, the atmosphere, the U.I., the lore, and the game-play, all concocted into something absolutely intoxicating. The developers have mastered their design, and seeing it constantly improve and seeing the endless, empty galaxy be filled with life, is something beautiful. 

Even in my career as an aspiring astronautical engineer, No Man's Sky is almost solely responsible for creating my dream to invent magnificent machines that can take me to the stars. Much of my designs are inspired from this very game. So I can not adequately thank these developers enough for making something so breathtaking.

Great-looking game, I know it was said to be pretty bad at launch, but I'm glad I bought it. I was looking for something with exploration and an RPG feel that's different from other RPGs. The worlds are beautiful to behold, there's a LOT of things to do. I'm glad they added a 3rd to 1st person ability to the game, as I'm not too keen on playing this type of game in 3rd person. The space exploration and battle aspect are pretty cool, also. I tried playing this on my Xbox-One/s, but there's so much going on, that the frame rates are absolutely abysmal. You definitely need a current-gen system, or a fairly capable PC to play, and there is full controller support for most game pads in production today (though I prefer a Dual Sense controller for space and Starship flight, and KB/Mouse for on-foot). All-in-all, this game is great if you like 1st/3rd person shooters/exploration games. It's definitely something worth checking out.

No Man's Sky, the poster child for redemption arcs in the gaming world. Remember the disaster that was its launch? It was like promising a gourmet meal and serving a bowl of soggy cereal. But credit where it's due, Hello Games didn't abandon ship. Instead, they rolled up their sleeves and embarked on a journey to redeem their creation. Fast forward, and we've got a game that's light-years away from its initial state.

The procedurally generated universe is a double-edged sword. On one hand, it's vast, awe-inspiring, and practically infinite. On the other, it occasionally serves up planets that make you question the sanity of your spacefaring alter ego. But hey, that's the charm, right? The freedom to explore, build, and shape your own narrative is a major draw. Base building is a welcome addition, giving you a reason to claim your slice of the cosmic pie.

The multiplayer aspect breathes life into the galaxy. Teaming up with friends or encountering strangers adds a social layer that was sorely missed at launch. And let's not forget the ongoing commitment to improvement. Hello Games deserves a nod for not abandoning ship, for steering No Man's Sky from the brink of gaming infamy to a respectable position in the space exploration genre. It's not perfect, but it's proof that sometimes, second chances in the gaming world can lead to stellar outcomes.

As a newer player to the game, I did not have to go through the horror of the earlier versions of the game. That said, I have thoroughly enjoyed the game so far. I haven't felt rushed to finish the game or a felt a need to catalogue every little thing, resources are both plentiful but also require a little effort so as not make it an idle simulation. The early game was a little difficult regarding the core concepts as it didn't explain it well but after a restart, it was much easier and enjoyable.

For me, it feels like it's a game you can either grind or take a leisurely stroll and you won't feel like you are missing out on anything important.

I highly recommend this game for children, casual players who wanna chill, and people who wanna experience visual journey across the NMS universe.

The game poses very little challenge ("Min-max" is not needed to thrive and "grinding" would reward only convenience but not progress) also it provides no meaningful experience (Most quests revolves around "go and fetch" since they are generated randomly). Although, the game could be tricky in some aspects such as refining system which no hints given whatsoever or such as adjacency bonus for modules placement.

Story and NPC behavior: The main story is linear and decent. It covers deep theme but somehow the storytelling just couldn't cover its complexity content. It's worse for the side story since most of them are only texts (at least show pictures or something). I still fail to see relationship between individuals in those 18 quintillion planets (I barely visited around hundred of planets within 10 galaxies & I don't expect to see difference in other place). For example, individuals live in one star system show no connection whatsoever to the individuals lives in nearby star systems. Heck! Even individuals live in same star system have very little interaction to each other. FeelsSoullessMan.

Combat: Could be overwhelming if you are not prepared, but once you're good then nothing's threat.

Survival: This one I find very fun because it involves your knowledge about the NMS universe.

Exploration: 10/10 Eye-opening, but expect natural formations instead of handmade structures. I still hope they put grand waterfalls somewhere in the universe. :(

Base building: It has satisfying snapping points (Few can be irritating to placed) for main structures but very limited to available stuff given by dev unless you use glitch such as wire glitch and other shenanigans like expanding base radius from 600u max radius to 2000u max radius then the creativity become infinity.

Management: Very basic without delegation of authority. I find it annoying because the player need to do everything just like Fallout 4 settlement once again.

Roleplay: IMHO, it's very weak because NPCs have limited interaction with the player and the barrier to be anything you want in game is very low thus not meaningful.

Multiplayer: It's functional but since you can (and would) do everything by yourself, it becomes questionable for my taste. Still, you can meet other players and interact with them with words or gestures even doing missions together.

Overall, if you have 100+ hours to spend (You can at least experience everything given by the game once). Get NMS for amazing visual experience, it's really eye-opening. They are still updating this game time to time even after being released 7 years later and all of them are free.
Very in depth game. Easy to lose yourself into it.

2019: The developers have been making great progress with this game, they have redeemed themselves and turned this game into a real finished game that is absolutely god tier

2023: It's been four years since my last review the developers absolutely pour their hearts out into improving and adding to the game, bringing more then they originally promised; this game is and will always be one of my most favorite video games. I am really happy to see the devs continue to work hard at this labor of love.

No Man's Sky has truly evolved into a virtual reality masterpiece, seamlessly blending the limitless exploration of its open world with the immersive experience of VR technology. From the moment you step into the headset, the universe comes alive in breathtaking detail, offering an unparalleled sense of scale and wonder. The freedom to traverse procedurally generated planets, seamlessly transitioning from space to the surface, is made even more captivating by the immersive nature of VR. The multiplayer aspect adds a social dimension, allowing friends to embark on epic journeys together. With ongoing support and updates, No Man's Sky continues to expand, ensuring that its universe remains a dynamic and evolving playground for exploration enthusiasts. In the vast sea of virtual reality experiences, No Man's Sky stands as a shining example of what is possible, offering a truly mesmerizing odyssey through the cosmos.
I never played before the game got good, but now I would say it's one of the best VR games on the market.

Below is original review. 

The game has come a long way from when it first released. Today it is a very complete game with more than enough stuff to do for almost any player. 

Flying ships is good, simple but effective. 
Flight combat is simple, almost to simple. Flight combat is waaaay to simple. No where near enough ships, style of fights and tactics to justify the number of weapon systems. I am not expecting Elite Dangerous or Eve Online. However something more here would go along way in the future. Right now it is just serviceable. 

Ground exploration has an EXTRMELY good loop. It is a very simple loop but extremely effective. fight something, scan, move on, explore. 

The variety in planets is pretty extensive, you see patters over time but they did a great job at making things different enough to where you dont feel like its the same planet, at least so far not one has been quite the same, even if it is the same type. 

The game feels like an overly simplistic version of what Star Citizen wants to be. The difference being No Man's Sky exists today and is fully playable (some bugs abound) and is an honestly great game now. To my knowledge there are no plans to stop making it better.  So the best could be yet to come.
After 26 hours I have only (18,446,744,073,709,551,616 - 4) planets to explore

What can I say but it is the quintessential adventure through space that I've always dreamed of; absolutely breathtaking in VR. Impressed by the creator giving free downloadable content. Though released in 2016, I think that it has many many many more years of awesome game play to come.
Totally worth a buy nowadays.

After a million games, No Man's Sky is by far one of the most games that I've invested my time with. All the mechanics for me are enjoyable.

A great space exploration game. Character model is greatly modular with no effect on actual gameplay. Difficulty settings are greatly custom to any liking seemingly, allowing for a peaceful, no-worries experience or great battles. Unfortunately, while freighters (large/colossal ships) are able to be 'controlled', there is no option (that I know of yet) to actually command a warship into combat or for general purpose. Other than that, the game is beautiful and I love it.

So far the game has been very immersive for me, with a mix of searching, flying, building, fighting, exploration, quests...
The graphics are a treat, and the level of being able to fine tune the game-play is unique.  If what you're looking for a fast-paced shooter that never lets up, this game may not be for you, but it's probably a good one for just about everyone else. I've had nights where I've been up till nearly 2 a.m. playing, and I haven't had a game pull me in like this in a long time, not since the Hawken PC gaming servers were shut down.
I think I'll be a Traveler for a long while.

Okay i had i come back to redo my initial review. The devs showed what "labor of love" means. Look how many great updates they released for free on this 7 year old game, and theyre still going. No pay to win, microtransactions, or other BS. This game exemplifies the words space/flight sim and exploration. If those things interest you, this game is a must. Base Building, resource gathering/management, tons of upgrades, tons of alien races, infinite universe with infinite planets, NO LOADING SCREENS (suck it starfield). Thats right...seemless planet to planet flight. What are the cons? well its hard to get into. The intro takes forever, there is little direction, the story is hard to understand unless you look it up on the internet, and whats the point of multiplayer really? Otherwise its a pure gem.
its a great space servival game lots to do and great graphics and colors i love it

I love this game so much, and would definitely recommend it to anyone who has a spare 60 bucks you're gonna spend on a game. Thanks for reading!

Great game full that never gets you bored

I bought the game on sell a week ago. I have put almost 100 hours into this game now. Hello deserves some positive feedback. The game is beautiful. Just land on a lush planet and stand in the grass and take it all in. Then jump in your spacecraft and go star hopping. Find the perfect balance of economy/resources/beauty in a solar system and build a base on land or water if you choose. Upgrade all of your equipment to S. Play with your friends. Ride animals around a planet while you farm resources.  I have to say that I have enjoyed everything but my favorite part of this game is the soundtrack... The music in this game is a masterpiece plain and simple. Every time I log on it seems like I hear different music or a different take on previous songs. It is vast and so so good. From the drum and bass when you are fighting a sentinel to the piano piece that I first fell in love with, this soundtrack is far above so many other games. I know they have glitches. I lost a freighter and a base myself. I had to have a little patience at the start but they kept releasing updates. They keep working and it looks like they really care about this game. Just catch a sell and spend 29 dollars. 

SO, I can recommend this game. 
Soundtrack  10/10!!!

Technical  5/10

Overall  7/10

Update. 
 
I just want to add that all of the updates since this review have done nothing but make the game far more enjoyable. I am still in love with the soundtrack and the overall beauty of the landscapes on planets.  I have been farming activated Indium and have billions of credits. I am very pleased to see that the latest reviews are very positive. Hopefully they will overtake the ratio of early bad reviews and the overall tag will be positive. Please, please, please buy this game. A true gem that I feel will be talked about for many future generations. 

Edit 12/05/2023
I was just wanting to come back here and add to the ever-growing saga which is NMS. The game which is always getting updated and asking nothing in return. I came here to give my take on the Starfield vs NMS debate.  NMS did not ask to get thrown in with Starfield. They existed well before the game and will well after. If anything the comparison has helped NMS because it easily shows its strengths lol. I really wanted to like Starfield but wow did that not happen. Such a missed opportunity. 

Buy NMS. You will thank me later.

The solution to this [b]MAIN STORY QUESTLINE ROADBLOCK BUG[/b]: Use the construction research terminal in your base instead of the one on the space anomaly and the quest trigger will proceed as normal and you may speak to Nada to continue the game.

It's a great game for a couple of hours. There's many major flaws in the games content and design.

Fighting goes like this:
-  any dog fighting consists of pressing a button and auto-locking onto a target to kill.
-  using mouse is bugged and doesn't work properly
-  you can turn on a dime or stop (shouldn't work like that in space)
-  you cannot escape sentinels (just quit and rejoin)

Resources:
-  gathering money is simple, yet tedious and a waste of time.
-  repetitive
-  you'll see 80% of the content after scanning and running around for a while
-  dig a hole, for Rock and STONE, go to the next deposit, dig a hole
-  it's a pain in the butt when you're missing a simple resource which causes you to waste 30 minutes to do a simple "rinse and repeat"
-  missions are also "rinse and repeat"

To keep a solid player-base, this game will need to come up with some hardcore overhauls. The controls and events just aren't up to the standards of good indie games of 2023.

I can see his game when he hosts but it wont let me join just says failed, if I host it says "No connection to matchmaking server".

Some of the things I have tried below:

I am connected to the internet
the network multiplayer setting is enabled
the program is whitelisted on the firewall
I have verified the game cache
I have deleted all but the save games from "C:\Users\Admin\AppData\Roaming\HelloGames"
I have tried deleting the "TKGAMESETTINGS.MXML" file
I have reinstalled the game on another drive
I have restarted the pc
I have turned off the PC power cycled the router and restarted the PC.

This was a wasted weekend trying to work out why it wont work.

I myself never got to play this game on release, so while I was looking forward to it, I didn't have nearly as much disappointment as the gaming community did that day. This basically meant that I got to walk in with an open mind, unmarred by the game's past. And I have to say, I have really enjoyed my time. 

The first thing to note is that yes, while the game does have a story and missions, this is ultimately a sandbox first and foremost. If you do not enjoy games that give very little to no direction, then you will dislike the game once you finish up the story. If you don't mind the sandbox though, there is quite a lot to do. There are a lot of interesting planets to visit and creatures to discover and tame, quite a few ways to get some action and combat, you can get a capital ship and completely forget about building a regular base, making a mobile station instead, or you can help build a settlement and manage it over time, as it continues to generate revenue for you. There are daily and weekly missions that I myself don't engage with that often, but some of them are pretty fun. There is just a lot to do, if it tickles your fancy.

This game really is not for everyone, but if you're looking for a way to have some good relaxing fun, I really do recommend giving this game a try. It's pretty easy to loose hours into it once you find something you enjoy doing.
