I just wish it ran well on PC. My rig is more than capable of handling any game, but this one was built for consoles and the developer appears to have no interest in whether or not it will run on a PC. That's too bad because the game is addictive and engaging. Just too bad it that I didn't try 9 ways from Sunday to get it to play without crashing within the necessary time frame to give up and get a refund.

Gameplay: The game is incredible. Exploration is fun and kept me chugging through the issues that made me not recommend it. Overall, I think the game is enjoyable and I wish it was functionally better made and possibly better thought out from beginning to end. At this point, I think the game was piece mealed.

Issues: 
Bluetooth Controller Disconnects- This from what I've been seeing is a wide spread, long term issue. I'm using a Xbox controller and it works fine for about a day (6 hours approx Total Game time). Than after that it will do what everyone says and disconnect repeatedly. This is in and out of active use. So I can be in combat and the controller will DC for 1-3 seconds or I could be on the phone. This is not acceptable in the modern age of gaming where Bluetooth compatibility is normal. Their should also be a warning if the case that BT isn't possible for controllers to curb any player issues at this point since the concern is 2 years old at least.

Aiming- The ability to aim in certain situations can get you killed and be a complete pain in the a$ $. It's usually in water, steep hills or when the camera takes a sharp first person zoom due to terrain shifts. During combat this can turn your health to zero if your not in open territory, constantly moving. If you stand still for a second, and get caught by a terrain shift or on a mountain range? The aiming has a big chance to screw up and blind you. 
In water, you simply can't look all the way up. So how you swim is how your view is and that doesn't change even when you stop. So your eyes technically always look forward and upward view is always limited by comparison to lower. Doesn't make sense when you come to a complete stop in water and try to look up or stand on the shore and are supposed to have full upward view. Another words, building in the water is minimum annoying and for me, rage quit frustrating. 

Conclusion (if you got this far)- The Exploration, mining, characters and story are my favorite aspects, but the combat, controller support, and technical support behind the game are just bad. It seems like the game was built for Consoles and we got what was left on PC.

On the other, it's also clear that the game has some fundamental/foundational issues that content updates may never truly fix.

In conclusion I'm glad I picked this up instead of Starfield.

No Man’s Sky was a project ahead of it’s time when it launched. It was nothing close to the titan of a title it is today. This game provides support for some of the most advanced VR equipment out there, such as omnidirectional treadmills and locomotion sensors like KatVR for realistic running. Or full blown ship support on a Yaw 2 gaming chair motion simulator. Can be modded to work with BHaptics equipment and is one of the very best titles out there to play in VR while using Woojer products. The latest update has brought a resounding amount of bug fixes. This is easily the best VR spaceman game out there. My entire family loves it and we own 5 separate copies of it.

I have a stroke and my right arm is paralyzed.  I thought it would be impossible to play.  I play this game with only one arm and have learned to adapt and survive.  It gives me a sense of accomplishment when I succeed.  I started out focusing in core upgrades.  Then I started mining oxygen and learned how to build power generators to make it sustainable.  I ignored the story for the first two weeks.  But slowly I incorporated it into my game play.  I incorporated ammonia into my mining operation.  I started with my mining tool to get cobalt and refined it into ionized cobalt.  This allowed me to make mass quantities of ionized cobalt by combining oxygen and ionized cobalt.  Then I combined ammonia and ionized cobalt into large quantities of herox which i sold for 6-7 million units a day.  I created 3 core bases and survived a battle to gain my first freighter.  NMS is so huge.  My best moment was a salvage and discovery job for a freighter that was infested with poisonous living jellyfish.  I felt i was on a ghost ship for hours.  I would highly recommend this to anyone and encourage you not to cheat.

Completely new player here.
I've no idea how the game was before ( yes, I saw the vids in u2b ), but now, it def worth buying and playing.

Linux users, don't worry, game runs like a charm with Proton Experimental (I'm currently runing the game with it, and it works. Tested out 8.* also -> no problems as well ). So big thank you to VALVE !

System used : Lenovo T14 Gen3 AMD Ryzen 5 Pro ( Integrated 680AMD GPU ) with 16 gigs LPDDR5
Ingame scaling  is on 60% ( to avoid internal action and menu lags ) -> works perfect & smooth for me, no hickups, no tearing, no problems ( even inside the anomaly station ).
Res used : 1920x1200 borderless ( full screen wasn't showing good results for me )
P.S. You might wanna crank up the CPU on a Performance, and switch off Night Light just in case.
Steam is installed as a flatpak ( isolation ) on a pure Debian stable with kernel 6.0* with no problems in functionality.

Ground combat could be improved with more different types of Sentinels ( not just floating toasters, cyberdogs, cyberspiders and Robocop on steroids :D )

Also, more random event space battles ( something like the Freighters saving, but with Living ships. Maybe saving them from another aggressive specie ? :)  )

These are just silly ideas, which you can ignore ofc, they're nothing else, but ideas, the game is great !

In any case, Thank you HG for the amazing product, keep up the good work, you have our support, as long as the rumors regarding Micro$oft are not real.

Todd Howard, I want No Man's Sky.

Todd: But we have a No Man's Sky at home.

No Man's Sky at home = Starfield.

It could be that I haven't been playing this game for very long or perhaps I'm spoiled by other games of a similar caliber being just simply better or more enjoyable but the whole experience just feels so incredibly empty. I don't see the point in making a base with my limited tools and building materials, and I don't see a point in going to other planets if it's just going to be much of the same everywhere. This game is a space sandbox game, and I'd like to compare it to two of my favorite games ever in the sandbox and space genre: Minecraft and Outer Wilds respectively. 

Minecraft is similar in its infinite generation, and that itself can get repetitive and boring after a while but it's also a game that 1. has multiple, truly new environments to discover (traversal comes easy as well) whether that be the biomes, dimensions or landmarks, and 2. has a sense of autonomy, creativity and freedom concerning choices whether it be your own movement, customization or playstyle. I sense none of these things with No Man's Sky, the game just feels rigid and while at first going to different planets seemed cool at first I realized that it was just the same thing over and over again. 

Outer Wilds shares the theme of taking a spaceship and exploring. Both games have NPCs, both games have a learning curve for ship controls and management, and both games have different planets to go explore beyond the one you start on. The difference is that No Man's Sky's NPCs are boring and add nothing positive to the experience of the game. Flying the ship was genuinely fun at first, the thrill of that first initial launch into space and exploring new places was definitely amazing but quickly waned when I learned that there was nowhere really worth traveling to in the first place (and don't get me started on the dreadful combat AI of the enemy ships, fighting them is just so unfun) and to me ship management wasn't too tedious to warrant overly scathing remarks but it just wasn't for me. No Man's Sky's counterpart in this comparison (Outer Wilds) is better in all of these ways. It provides a sense of wonder and mystery (which is helped by a great soundtrack), has actual characters that have personalities and help you on your journey, and flying the ship (which at first can be clunky while learning the basic controls, and the game will stop at nothing to make fun of itself for this which is amazing) is a blast. 

If you're reading this and you're looking for a space game related to space that is truly compelling in its story and experience, go play Outer Wilds. Cheaper and just flat out better. If you like a good space mystery and enjoy puzzles, you'll enjoy it over No Man's Sky every day of the week.

There's so much here it's kinda hard to get good coverage.  A warning, many of the games mechanics take significant amounts of time to progress on.  At 12 hours of play, I'm scratching the surface.  A lot of what's here is beautiful, interesting, complex, and fun.  There's definitely a lot to explore.  I'm starting to realize there's significantly more variation in the game than is readily apparent early on.

Recommended if you have copious amounts of time you can spare.

This is a testament to the entire game industry. It shows that if you try a new idea and flop at the start that slow and  steady improvements without charging the customer for them can and will repair your reputation and the over all acceptance of said idea.

As to the game, if you like having choices and no real clear objective beyond multiple systems of progression this is the game for you. Yes you can put on perma-death and make it a super difficult survival game but that more to the fact it's not really meant to be one. The game is best when you just enjoy seeing what's over the next hill, on that moon, in the next system. You collectors and base builders will have some fun but there are better games for those play-styles. No this gem works best as a scratch to the relaxing low risk exploration  type. The modifications you can do to your equipment allow for the lizard brain enjoyment of watching number go up [or down in cases of cool-downs]. Overall it's a great game to relax with alone or with some friends. Eventually you'll exhaust the barrel of it's tricks but by then I'd say you've gotten your moneys worth and that's coming from someone that pre-ordered this game and was very disappointed at launch.

I have a real love hate relationship with NMS. The game is incredibly fun but holy shit can it be so annoying sometimes. the constant stopping what you are doing to mine x resource for your suit or tool, or whatever and no EXPLORE IN AN EXPLORATION GAME is so dumb. Studies show that players who are stuck doing "tedious tasks or walking in nothingness" have a significantly higher chance of just dropping the game outright. I love this game so much. The lore is addictive and impactful, the gameplay itself is relaxing and itches my love for exploration. The races are fun to learn about, the option to learn their language is awesome to me as a linguistics student. My favorite race is the Korvax! A hyper-intelligent hive mind hellbent on the quest for knowledge? Sign me up; super cool!

The world generation can become repetitive over time, but I enjoy charting each planet. I think that there needs to be more ways an ecosystem can generate (more parts for animals & plants.) I start to see the same animal with minor differences after around ~7 hours. While single player exploration works perfectly, I have so much difficulty attempting to play with my friends due to bugs that it has become unplayable in a cooperative, open-world environment that doesn't involve missions. There needs to be some serious reworking here.

However, aside from that, I'm giving this game a 7/10, deducting points for my inability to play with my friends or family. I'd say to those interested, give it a shot. The updates make it worth it, but don't expect an action RPG. This is about the attention-span equivalent of playing Minecraft or Spore. You gotta make your own adventure in this one.

I was so hopeful that this game had turned around into a great game, and yes it has gone back and added many old, unfulfilled promises. But to me it's still not a fun game for one main reason.

The game is NOT AT ALL designed for multiplayer. If you play with friends, you each have your own (identical) objectives to do and haveto complete them individually, barely being able to work together or even base together. At best you will walk past eachother and say hi but apart from that it's still a completely singleplayer experience that just so happens to have other players on the map. I got this game for the sole purpose of playing with some friends as it would be far more fun than playing alone, but you might aswell just play alone. 

Personally, even playing alone is boring to me. Considering the fact that I got the game for a multiplayer experience without really knowing what to expect, it would be unfair not to mention that the game and each of its planets look very beautiful and the game has many interesting, unique and enjoyable features. On the other hand, the whole game just feels like a boring, aimless grind, there's no real difficulty and it's just not very thrilling or entertaining. So often you will go to a new planet that was basically the last one in a different colour palette, so exploring can quickly get boring. That's just my personal opinion and you might enjoy singleplayer for the amount of content and the hard work they've put into it, although I warn you: DO NOT GET THIS GAME EXPECTING A FUN MULTIPLAYER EXPERIENCE.

[h3]The Good[/h3]
 - Looks good with consistent style and a great engine, lots of great variation in the look and feel of celestial objects
 - Great choices on procedurally generated weapons (multitools), ships, upgrades, etc that make unwrapping your next upgrade a mini thrill each time or offering excitement when spotting a striking ship or tool
 - Lots of things to "do" in that you can explore quite a few different paths of self-established tasks ranging from exploring systems, hunting for multi-tools, ships or upgrades, commanding a fleet, searching for lore, farming plants and animals, building bases and mining operations, etc
 - I personally love the sound design (with a small gripe on the animals - millions of species and they pretty much all sound the same).  Everything sounds like it fits, and while I feel like this is a bare minimum requirement, the vast majority of titles just totally miss the mark here so this is a plus

[h3]The Problem[/h3]
There's really one [b]BIG[/b] gaping problem with this game that constantly left me questioning if I was having fun, and finally determining that I was not: 

[h2][b]There is no [i]challenge[/i][/b][/h2]

There is no real challenge.  No challenge that requires technical skill.  No challenge that requires aptitude.  No strategy or tactics required.  No resource supply management needed.  Nothing even behind a grind-wall. 
 You spend about 5 hours in game and you will easily be well equipped to handle the most difficult combat scenarios and a few more hours, reach the most distant and exclusive star systems with absolutely nothing standing in the way.  No tough space encounters.  No big bad groups of enemies.  No "bosses".  No challenges to ever come.  The only thing it demands of you, is your time.  And it won't reward you; you have to do that yourself

 - On-Foot Combat is point, click and hold fire, drop the enemy.  Rinse & repeat until your sentinel "wanted level" resets, or you just get tired of being pestered and dig a tunnel and sort your inventory for a few seconds to de-aggro.  The first 20 minutes of the game you might have to think about certain encounters, but every encounter has an easy escape either burrowing under ground or summoning the Anomaly, and nothing is lost if you avoid a fight other than wasted time
 - Starship combat is hold back button, click and hold fire, drop the enemy.  Enemy ships do not obey the same physics laws your ship is restrained to and perform the exact same silly maneuver - fly straight at you shooting, zip away from you in a straight line, then do a 180 and repeat
 - The only "puzzles" found require you to to do kindergarten math (addition or subtraction), or 2nd grade pattern recognition.  
 - All encounters are the same formula: Go here, kill or avoid (doesn't matter which), collect, return (optional)
 - You can set up mining systems on planets to get a regular flow of great resources to manufacture other useful elements or useless-except-for-selling items.  I've set up about 8 of these, in anticipation of something greater.  I've never returned to any except for a copper mine on my starting planet to refine a bit more chromatic metal.  BIG missed opportunity here since the building setup works so well and fits perfectly with the procedurally generated planets & moons - but it doesn't get you anything you need or even want.  There's nothing that requires you to pump out big resources that would be illogical to manually mine yourself.  No advanced [i]usable[/i] items that can only be crafted instead of bought; only sold for unit that you will be drowning in that don't buy anything useful.  No challenge that requires a good resource infrastructure to overcome.  It's just... there- in case you wanted to pretend you needed it.
 
The list will go on but it won't serve any more purpose here as further points require more experience with the game itself.  But to the reader:  If you like [b]pure[/b] casual, [b]pure[/b] exploration, [b]zero[/b] challenge - then yes definitely buy.  I know there are explorers out there that just love to explore for the sake of exploring.  This allows you to do so and does so [i]damn[/] well.  Guaranteed you will be visiting and naming star systems, planets, moons yourself, the first one to do so, and others may discover these in your wake.  You'll find interesting features, ships, fauna, and share them with a community that loves the unique things generated here.  And you'll have some well thought out and written lore to explore to keep it at least a little bit interesting.  

But that's a pretty niche audience.  Personally I was hoping for a [i]game[/i], where your performance matters and your actions directly affect whether you succeed or fail.  Even if it was buried somewhere in the Anomaly with nexus missions.  But (spoiler):  It's not.

Proven dedication means there is always something new to see right around the corner. While not the most thrilling or unique experience, gives enough direction to have a good amount of fun adventures. Probably won't wow you a lot, but will show you some neat tricks.

UPDATE at 446.4 hours in 2021 (77.8 hour review below):

This game is just so good.  There's so much to do.  Even since adding the VR, they've added Expeditions, Settlements, the Variety Update, and so much more.  I'm currently playing an Expedition save that I just continued because I wanted to start fresh.  I recently got all of the achievements, which I basically never do because the game is just that good.  I only play games in VR these days, but I can play this game in VR or 2D.  This game still just gets better and better and almost every developer out there gives up on their games after a while.  This game just won't quit.  I love it and don't know what I'll do it if it ever goes away.

OLD REVIEW:  I played this game when it got its first decent update after grabbing it on sale a couple years ago.  I enjoyed it, but it was repetitive and resource management was a pain.  But I always found visiting new worlds to be magical.

Then, the Atlas Rises update came out, and the game finally worked in a way that made it incredibly enjoyable.  None of those hours reflect here, though, because I played them on Xbox One.  Resource management was finally possible and the game was incredibly playable.  Still hard not to run out of space, but the game was way more fun.

NOW, the VR update is out.  When I so much as heard that I could walk on alien worlds and meet new creatures and build bases IN VR?? well I almost wet myself I was so excited.  The prospect of doing what I wanted to do as a child was incredible and I can't believe I've had the opportunity to do this in my lifetime.  I bought a Valve Index just to play this game and I'm incredibly happy with both.  Getting to manually fly a ship through the cosmos and build a base on alien worlds has been everything I thought it would be and more.

Hello Games, you didn't have to stick with this game.  You could have taken the money and ran with it.  But, you proved that you're the Labor of Love we all hoped for and which has delivered many times over.  Thank you so much for such an amazing game!  (Now I just wish I had an even faster PC to play it on haha...it's a little pixelated on my GTX 1070, but I still think the magic of VR is so wonderful that it doesn't diminish the perfect of this game at all.)

UPDATED at 533.8 hours in 2022:  Yup...still fantastic.  And the expeditions?  Incredible.  Always gives me a reason to come back.

I've left my original review in place for comparison,  but after seven years and a significant amount of development it no longer applies, so I'll update here:

In the seven years since the game came out, Hello Games has fully owned the disastrous launch of No Mans Sky, pouring an impressive amount of time and effort into making the game what they imagined it would be. 

Listing all the changes here would take far too much time, but suffice it to say that after several overhauls of the generation code and inclusion of new mechanics like base building, vehicles, entire new factions to work against the game is nowhere near what it was before, and in a good way. Choices abound for what you as a player can do, and it's easy to spend a significant amount of time focused on one aspect of the game before moving on.

Having said that, the core gameplay loop ("fly to a planet, land, scan as much as you can, fly off to the next") is unchanged from the original version of the game, and while it's enjoyable enough to pull you through the storyline it can wear thin quickly. I've come back to No Man's Sky after major releases and restarted from scratch, but after a while (and that amount of time seems to be growing shorter) the core gameplay loop wears thin enough that I feel compelled to move on. That's not to say that No Man's Sky is a bad game, or that the core gameplay loop is bad- just that it's a level of repetition that may not appeal to people who need new or exciting mechanics throughout a game.

Original review:

On paper, No Man's Sky seems like an ideal game for those with an interest in space and space exploration: procedurally generated, with planets and animals and cool things to see and experience. A chance to boldly go.

Unfortunately, the reality of the game falls far short. While the player is able to fly a ship and explore, the similarities between systems, planets, and ships means a sense of 'been here before, done this before' sets in quickly. There is very little purpose to the game other than grinding for slightly better gear, which helps you grind even more. In and of itself that would be fine, if not for the fact that exploration fails to deliver anything awe inspiring or even vastly different to what you'll find in the first few hours.

Pros:

* Relatively beautiful - while the graphics are not the best, it does offer beautiful sights and interesting looking planets compared to other 'space exploration' type games.

* Atmosphere to surface flight - This was a selling point for me: to be able to go from orbit to surface without loading screens or loss of control.

Cons:

* Enjoyment is lost in a sea of blandness - Your options when on a planet consist of flying to a point of interest, walking to a point of interest, interacting with a point of interest, or shooting the ground. You *can* 'hunt' animals and Sentries, but with the rewards for doing so nearly nil (aside from a few 'blueprints' you'll get in the first few hours anyway). Planets seem to blend together, with nothing really standing out or inspiring the player to stay or explore further.

* Bad ship controls - The game is, ostensibly, an arcady space game, so some exceptions can be made for shoddy flight controls, but the amount of hand holding takes any sense of adventure or excitement out of flying. Single button presses to land or take off, inability to actually hit the ground, and guns that only affect a specific set of objects makes flying in No Man's Sky about as enjoyable as riding a city bus.

* The Grind - Grind in a game is ok: it can give use a goal and a sense of accomplishment when we finally get what we were grinding for. However, as in the case of No Man's Sky, if the grind is *all* that a game is it leads to frustration and the sense that a game is pointless.

* Static universe - NPC's don't move or really react to anything outside of conversation, NPC ships follow a preset flight path and don't flinch if you fly at them, even animals don't seem to react outside of the generic 'hostile' ones (that just charge at you). Instead of a living, exciting universe, No Man's Sky delivers a universe that feels as though the creator of it decided that physical presence is quite enough, and that he shouldn't bother with making his creations alive.

All in all, No Man's Sky could be defined as a 'good start': an interesting idea, a decent base to build a much more interest ing game on, and a solid technical demo. What it *isn't*, however, is worth $60. Nor does it seem likely that the creators of the game are going to build on to it and deliver us an amazing experience: instead it seems like what you see is what you get.

If it falls to $5 or under, it may be worth picking up for the minor enjoyment flying the ships brings, but any higher price than that and the value falls off sharply.

Seeing No Man's Sky continually getting updates is great. It's impressive how Hello Games keeps making the game better over time.

Update for 2023: The ongoing updates continue to be impressive, particularly considering the age of the game.

Original review: I pre-ordered No Man's Sky over two years ago and have been following it through the various updates and enhancements since.

I'm pleased to be able to honestly state that the game has become an interesting, engaging, and entertaining experience.

Whether it is exploring the innumerable, and highly variable, worlds, building bases on land, sea, and in space, forming a space fleet and having it assist (albeit limitedly) in space combat, or seeking out resources and upgrades for your equipment and vehicles - there is now a wide variety of activities to take part in.

Still, not every activity has great depth and over many hours various aspects of the game can become repetitive and boring.  Thankfully the mechanics for advancement (e.g. upgrades) alleviate some of this so that you can focus on what you enjoy.

It is also great to see Hello Games continuing to support their product and I look forward to seeing where they take the game in the future.

NMS is my favorite "low pressure, just veg out, collect stuff or build stuff" kind of game. There's combat and fighting, but it's really not a huge essential part of it, and for the most part you can escape out of the combat situations. In space? Summon the anomaly. On a planet? Use the terrain modifier to dig yourself a hole and wait it out. It's pretty low pressure, and gives you a relatively simple story to follow, building up reputation and places to revisit along the way as you settle into areas you visit more frequently. It's my zen out game, but feels more productive than brainlessly watching TV.

After almost 100 hours of gameplay I can safely say this game is awesome! I appreciate the amount of love poured into this game since its original release and have been playing it on and off since then. The updates from the developers have made improvements to both the singleplayer and multiplayer modes. There's nothing like traveling between planets or warping between galaxies with no loading screens and it really makes you feel the scale of space and the distance between two planets. Their are literally billions of planets to discover. The scale of each planet is mind-blowing and every planet is jam-packed with unique creatures to scan, random outposts, upgrades, and materials to mine, loot and sell.

There are always bounties available to complete that might send you off to scan specific flora or fauna, kill certain creatures, hunt down pirates, or collect different resources. As you build your wealth you can buy bigger and better tools, ships, and upgrades. Every ship I've come across is available to buy or trade assuming you have the resources. 

I could go on and on about this game but if you haven't tried it I highly recommend you do!

For anyone thinking about getting No Mans Sky, I would highly recommend it. It's an amazing game with many things to do, the story line is a good length, although I can't say for sure how long it is because I did a lot of side missions on my way to the end. What I can say is that it took me about 90 hours including a lot of hours living ship hunting, sentinel ship hunting, hopping systems looking for ship upgrades, grinding nanites, and much more to be able to beat the game. The story isn't that hard, but I think it is quite interesting even though it can feel a bit repetitive at times. Overall, if you have the extra money to get it, you should, but other than that, just wait for a sale cause they happen pretty often. I think NMS is an amazing game with many things to do even after one completes the main storyline, and that the devs are amazing people for maintaining the game for the last 7 years. No Mans Sky is, I think, by far the only game deserving of the Labor of Love award because of how much content it is still receiving even after many years of release. If you don't know of any other games that may be good for that award, definitely vote NMS.

This game is so hyperfocused on being an [i]experience[/i] that it completely forgets what it means to be a [i]video game[/i] - whether through coherent game design, engaging mechanics, or not crashing/softlocking every two fvcking hours.

Trust me, I've been playing since 2018, and it has almost always been like this. The majority of updates are content islands with little in the way of connectivity - just a series of random rides in a cosmic carnival with almost nothing to do with one another, dashed with tiny tweaks to existing content. Mostly to the base game they're still trying to fix, of course, as Hello Games almost refuses to acknowledge or expand on what new they've added, instead opting to work on something completely different every single time. This, naturally, leads to even more potentially game-breaking bugs and optimization issues being introduced, and thus the cycle repeats. The amount of technical debt this game has accrued is [i]exhausting[/i].

I have to give them some credit; over 2022 they have put out a LOT of quality of life to make the game feel a little better. But it's all on an extremely shaky foundation: while being a little less tedious, the extremely dull basic gameplay loop has not changed in any meaningful way in YEARS. And any side content they've added in the meantime can be thoroughly completed in just a couple of hours, if they're not just dangling a shiny new ship to grind endless star systems for, anyways. I can count the number of updates they've done to address these issues on one hand.

To Hello Games, though this likely falls on deaf ears: Please focus solely on reworking and debugging the game as it currently exists instead of pumping out new content nonstop. You've accumulated SO MUCH goodwill with your dedicated fans, I'm sure we'll live if you take a bit to work things out.

To you, the reader: If you're looking for a space sim with any more depth than a murky puddle, keep looking. Sorry.

Between the massive, uncharted galaxy beneath your feet and the innumerable beautiful vistas waiting to be discovered, it’s hard not to love No Man’s Sky. You have the freedom to travel absolutely anywhere at anytime within this stunning, sprawling, and gorgeous procedurally generated universe; the only limit is your own courage to step into the unknown.

No Man’s Sky’s storyline is mysterious and intriguing. You begin your journey entirely stranded on a strange and hostile world, with nothing but your spacesuit to protect you. With enough luck (trust me, you’ll need it!) you will survive your first few minutes and discover a wrecked spacecraft nearby. The spacecraft responds to your suit’s input, as if it belongs to you, although you have no memory of ever owning this ship… Soon it becomes apparent that you must repair your ship and set sail into the black to find answers to these peculiar questions.

Gameplay is very flexible to whatever style you like best, anywhere from casual to professional. Don’t be discouraged at the beginning when the learning curve is steep, this will quickly change as you learn to survive the harsh environments. As you continue onwards you will have the opportunity to upgrade your suit and trusty multitool to match new challenges, while making old challenges a piece of cake. Tasks that used to be a fight for survival when I started is now a relaxing walk in the park. Exploring exciting new planets in the game is a great thing to help you unwind after a long day.

And perhaps one of the best parts of all; No Man’s Sky is still receiving frequent updates with amazing new content even after four years from initial release. This game is light-years from where its journey started and guaranteed to travel even further!

No Man’s Sky is a beautiful modern take at the Sci-Fi genre. It’s fun, relaxing, and even better with friends. If you love creative exploration space games, then don’t hesitate to give No Man’s Sky a shot! I definitely recommend!

No Man's Sky, developed by Hello Games, has undergone a remarkable transformation since its turbulent launch, evolving into a testament to the power of dedication and a genuine labor of love from its developers. This expansive space exploration game has grown into an unparalleled universe that captivates players with its sheer scale, diverse planets, and continuous stream of updates.

The initial release faced criticism for not living up to the lofty promises, but Hello Games didn't shy away from the challenge. Instead, they embraced it, pouring years of hard work into transforming No Man's Sky into the thriving, vibrant experience it is today. The dedication to improvement and innovation is evident in the numerous updates, each introducing substantial content, refining gameplay mechanics, and expanding the universe in ways players could only dream of.

The sheer scale of No Man's Sky is awe-inspiring. The procedurally generated galaxy offers an astronomical number of planets to explore, each with its own unique ecosystems, creatures, and challenges. The addition of multiplayer functionality further enhances the sense of shared exploration, as players can now embark on interstellar journeys together.

Beyond the vast exploration opportunities, the game's narrative has also evolved significantly. The introduction of meaningful storylines, engaging lore, and the overarching mystery of the Atlas Path adds depth and purpose to the seemingly boundless universe. The narrative improvements, coupled with enhanced graphics and a refined user interface, showcase the developers' commitment to delivering a top-tier gaming experience.

While No Man's Sky has faced its share of hurdles, the ongoing support and transparent communication from Hello Games have fostered a community that appreciates the journey as much as the destination. The game's evolution from a contentious launch to a beloved, ever-expanding universe is a testament to the transformative power of a dedicated development team's labor of love.

In conclusion, No Man's Sky stands as a shining example of redemption in the gaming industry. Hello Games' unwavering commitment to improvement, fueled by a clear passion for their creation, has turned No Man's Sky into an unparalleled space odyssey that continues to redefine the boundaries of exploration and innovation.

A beautiful space exploration game with over half a decade of free expansions. Its appealing visuals and music, a hands-off approach to player progression and many fun sandbox features will easily keep you playing through the relatively repetitive gameplay loop.

When I first started playing this game, I was stunned by the sheer vastness that isn't captured in any other game. In my first hundred hours or so I never even left the Euclid Galaxy (apart from the endings of a few expeditions). And it's always fun to dive back in every once and a while, and feel like that lone explorer again. Or roleplay as the captain of a ship like the Enterprise while you're aboard your freighter. And it never ceases to be fun to explore new features added every new update.

Unfortunately, you almost always get bored eventually, which is why nowaways I usually only boot up No Man's Sky when a new update is released. Of course I'm probably going to reach the center of the Euclid Galaxy in Permadeath mode soon, perhaps 100% the game.

Even after my advanced time spent in this game, No Man's Sky is still a reliable screenshot generator. Since photo mode allows you to move that system's local star(s) relative to you, you can always create a beautiful sunset or eclipse photo with any background. But that feeling of being a lone explorer always seems to catch me again. To pull me back into my memories of this game. I may go through the entire story of No Man's Sky one more time, just for the fun and nostalgia. I miss Apollo.

Thank you Hello Games, for putting the universe into perspective for me. A lonely speck of dust in the infinite cosmic void. In a good way.

[h1]This game has been the most violent roller coaster I've ever seen.[/h1]

It started with an explosion.
Everyone was on fire. There was screaming, and stuff was melting. Everything quickly became a large, heaping, pile of rubble.

Then slowly, with some large updates, it started getting built up.

Base building, farming, exocraft, a 30-ish hour story.
It had become a frame of a decent roller coaster.

Then suddenly, NEXT appeared and added a nice body to it. It took what we had, and overhauled it. It was still rough, but now it worked well!

And for the past 3 years, they've been buffing out the dents and scratches, and adding new trinkets and doo-diddles. And they've been adding more segments, and expanding the existing segments to make it more fun!

Fleets, Multiplayer, VR, More varied generation, More Planets, Balloons that drip blood. More structures to explore. Freighter battles. Pirates. In-game music creation. 16. Settlement management. Abandoned Freighters with [b]REDACTED[/b] inside, a brand new race of robotic nomads.  Large graphical improvements across the board. And promises of more to content to come!

[b]Now it's a pretty dang respectable roller coaster.[/b]

Also now you can ride the roller coaster with your pet.

No Man's Sky is an interesting case study in an absolutely atrocious launch followed by a long period of penance and regular updates. After it came out, it was synonymous with a terribly thought out release, and yet the phrase "do a No Man's Sky" now means to bring a bad release to a suitable state through continual effort. Was that effort worth it though? I think so, though that comes with some reservations.

For lack of a better term, it's an "ambient" game. While there is combat in space and on the ground/in vehicles, this is not the focus of the game. In the same way, there is a story as well as several quest chains that flesh out the universe, the story is not what you play the game for. It's largely a very relaxing game, and a lot of it is simply flying planet to planet system to system finding cool shit, building bases, and looking for interesting star ships to buy. It's not a high stakes space game, and if you go in with that expectation you will be very disappointed. It's a relatively slow sunset drive, not the Indy 500. This is also not a game that emphasizes player skill, or builds, or meta knowledge, or anything similar really, which leads to a common complaint about it, which is that it is "a mile wide and an inch deep". 

This is true, to an extent. While some updates, such as the update to Sentinels (the primary enemy the player will face on the ground) have added depth to aspects of it, many parts of the game are still extremely simple. There is some content that due to a lack of variety as well as a lack of reasons to engage with it that despite promising more activities and more time you will deal with one or twice at most (I'm looking at you underwater locations). Exploration can yield some truly amazing planets, but often it can give you nearly identical ones. Despite this, I would still recommend the game, though I do feel the price when not on sale is a bit steep for a game that released 7 years ago (albeit one receiving continuous updates). The game frequently goes on sale for half off, which I think is a very fair price.

TLDR: Very good game, enjoyable but not exciting, criticisms of depth are valid but the game remains enjoyable and the developers seem to be willing to go back and add depth to old content. Solid 8/10, but buy when it goes on sale.

So first of there are a few things about the game that may be pros or cons depending on the kind of games you enjoy so i'll list them separately in this review in a subjective list. With that said here are the things about no mans sky that i find important to state

Subjective:
         Light/non-existent story
         VR Supported
         Heavily Stylized slightly cartoony aesthetic
         Resource grind game
         Procedural generation
         Make your own fun style of gameplay

Pros:
       Lots of planet variation
       Minimal Loading Screens
       Plenty of things to do
       somewhat decent ship variation
       decent base builder

Cons: 
       Plenty of Pop in
       Procedural generation clipping issues (some times things are generated in weird/problematic ways)
       No real Unique Characters/ backstories outside of main quest
       Simplistic Combat
 
Very Grindy game with no real plot ( it has one but it is a glorified tutorial), but for what it is i enjoyed it. i'm sure everyone already aware but the devs have been updating the game consistently adding new content at a good pace since launch. if you were looking for a starfield type narrative space game this is not it, it is closer to elite dangerous in structure, while being more minecraft like with resource collection and base building being the bulk of the gameplay.
Came a long way to be this good but the journey was totally worth it, 10/10!

I'm really enjoying this casual game, especially with the content from the numerous free updates!

The game is very beautiful, fantastic, and multiplayer makes it really fun to play with friends.
It's the perfect casual gaming experience in my opinion.

The freedom to explore and build anywhere on planets is truly convenient and fun.
Combat is simple yet engaging, so it's a good balance for casual gamers.

Unfortunately, the casual aspect makes the game rather grindy in its activities.
The tasks the player can do are shallow because they are built on simple core tasks: you always end up just going somewhere, gather or kill something to do the activity. Rinse and repeat.

That said, there are LOTS of small variations on everything, combined with the text-based narrative, it's brings enough depth to be fun for a long time.

The last negative point is that planets are single biomes, so landing anywhere and exploring nearby will show you almost everything there is to see. It makes exploring whole planets uninteresting. A quick local survey is enough, unless you really like the planet's combination.

I really like this game overall. Hello Games has created something gorgeous and amazing. It's definitely worth playing, in regular doses without burning yourself with grind.

As a person who waited until the NEXT update (2018) to start playing No Man's Sky, I must say I am impressed. As contentious as the launch was, the effort invested into the game since has made it very good for those who like charting and exploring as gameplay.

No Man's Sky lacks for diversity; as with any procedural generation, it could use an order of magnitude more primitives to really give it a feel of greater variability. Still, this is not a failing, as I see it, that is particular to the title. 

The sheer scope of the game though is astounding.

My review of "No Man's Sky":
I bought this game a few days ago. I noticed it when it was first launched and I waited a bit to see what the community says, I read both positive and negative reviews trying to avoid spoilers just to get an idea about what the game is about and if it's something of my interest. Following up the initial disaster of launch, and reading about the backstory of it I didn't buy it at the time. However I did look back and I checked it a few times, because from the trailers it had potential to be a nice game. I saw the surge of positive comments but what struck me the most is that this game was said to have no further payments once you buy it, and that there are no micro transactions BUT the developers, the studio is still working on it and updating it constantly, that really caught my attention because that shows dedication, passion and prospects...it means that someone really cares about their project and will do their best to develop it. I decided to buy it and give it a go. 
I am happy with the game and I absolutely do not regret paying for it. I have played 25 hours so far and I can see that I am only at the very basics yet I have discovered so much! If you consider buying it, from what you see in the trailers that is exactly what you can do in the game, and have an immense freedom. It might feel slow at times because of course mining for resources and going places it's normal, but the discoveries and what it offers besides the visuals, gameplay and freedom you have in the game it's absolutely a must have as a game if you want to just relax and explore!


For the developers: 
you have earnt my respect. What you have done and are doing is something that I never thought I will see again. Your dedication to this project and passion is such an example to the other big companies and studios, I was amazed to research about you and find your backstory and the number of members your team has and seeing the game you have managed to offer us it is something that I am amazed of! The move that you did after the failure at launch shows how mature you are, shows that you believe in your visions for this project. You have my support and in future, other projects you might be working on I will dive head first because of what you have done here! Thank you and keep up with your passions! You have proven to be far far ahead of companies like EA, Bungie, Activision and other big names like these, they should learn from you!




Edit (200+ hours after original review):
The game still is amazing, so much more left to explore and do. Base building is something I am yet to dive in, but have visited other players' bases and the possibilities are countless (you want to make a base on a paradise planet? how about a desolate low gravity moon? how about underwater? and a skybase? in a cave? on your mothership? want to just make a farm? or build something to have fun with friend? how about a monument for other players to visit? etc). I am yet to find my own robotic creature and make it a companion. Finding S class ships never gets tiring.   SPOILER ALERT (stop here if you haven't finished the main story!!): I have yet to visit more galaxies, beyond ofc Euclid galaxy, I reached and scratched the surface of Hilbert dimension and Calypso galaxy, but what about the other 252 remaining ones? Mindblowing. 
So yes, the game is more than worth it.

Improvements/suggestions: 
1) they could add some PvP elements to the game, such as the Nexus PvE missions you get, they could make some PvP ones, so once you accept the type of mode you want to play in the Anomaly, you leave it and you get warped to another galaxy (for example Calypso where planets are more chaotic and full of storms) could be one, where you have to fight others. Or something like a PvPvE where 2 teams fight to get access to some space curiosity or space station, or fight other players and sentinels to capture X amount of Monoliths... or fight to capture a portal, open it to go to next location for "round 2". At the moment there are no PvP elements besides just players deciding to kill each other randomly and anything at this point could be good.
2) space battles with your own fleet. If I engage with enemies in space, whether pirates or THAT pirate fleet that is trying to destroy the civilian one, and I call in my fleet, they just stand there watching me destroy everyone else, but it would be nice if the big ships would get involved too.

What's not to like about a sandbox in outer space, you play this game however you like. Endless possibilities to focus on, you could spend hours creating a base, or hunting for ships, or ... anything you'd expect from a space exploration game!

Great game. Although it started out rough, No Man's Sky turned into an amazing game, with new content being added in regularly. Absolutely recommend if you enjoy a kind of chill space exploration game. There's combat, and base building, but the main focus is exploration. If you're into space sims at all, you should check it out.

This game is amazing! Truly all that needs to be said, you can easily lose track of time playing No Man's Sky! The game is a bit of a grind in the first hour you play it but after that it's so much fun. They have regular updates to the game that add cool new editions to you're own journey! The number one thing that I like about No Man's Sky is the fact that everyone that plays this game has their own story! You will always start on a planet that is undiscovered, and since the game world is a literal scale to size galaxy, you will be the only person to see what you see on you're own play through. You may come across a planet or two that someone else has discovered, but your main journey and own choices (unless they're mandatory for a quest), will keep you going to undiscovered planets. Few games if any can create this unique sense of wonder that No Man's Sky does.

I hope this review helps if you're using reviews to make a decision to purchase. It's definitely worth the money since the game is so big you can't go to every planet for just a second and see them all in a whole lifetime. If you get the game I recommend documenting it as a fun little YouTube let's play to show others interested in the game your discoveries. Since you and your friends will likely be the only people to ever see them. I was going to do something like that myself in the near future cause I thought it would be fun! Thanks for reading!

I was very iffy on this game. I have found many survival games to be repetitive and mundane lacking a loop that remains interesting. The changes from launch and the disposition guided me to pick this up this year and I was astounded. No Man's Sky is easily the best survival game in approach-ability since Minecraft and Terraria. The story is great as it isn't just dumped exposition, but in the style where you have to work for it and it feels great to progress. You can still tell that the overall game is incomplete but the way it is so makes it irrelevant.  I'd love to see a conclusion or maybe a road map to a concluding point, but its great even if it doesn't get one. All my played hours are in the past 8-10 months that I have owned it (452hrs as of writing this) and this isn't even in my preferred gaming genre. I would say buy it on sale, but BUY IT! Unless you despise exploration and open world and non linear story telling, this is an amazing game.

The worlds in this game actually feel alive. I've run into sandworms, weird alien bugs, even tamed some weird creatures as a pets. The resources are incredibly diverse as well, so survival feels more engaging.

And quests are amazing you get storylines instead of just "collect this" repetitive tasks. It pulls you into actually caring about the lore of the different races you meet. And the base building, oh man! I've built myself a dope underwater dome with cuboid rooms, hydroponic farms, the works.

After sinking dozens of hours in over the past month, I can confidently say No Man's Sky has risen from the ashes like a phoenix. The continuous free content and events keep things fresh too. If you gave up the game early like a lot of people did, I can't recommend enough to jump back in. It's a genuine miracle in game development. Kudos to Hello Games for not abandoning the game!

When Nomansky released, it was bad under a very thin layer of good.

Many years later it is still bad, but now the bad is under many, many layers of good. The amount of content and different systems is great, there are a lot of things to do, explore and obtain.

However, these layers, each usually coming from some specific major update, are often very disjointed. They interact with the "base" game of flying and walking around, but not with each other. So the game has a lot of "width", but not much depth.
Once you've done every questline (of which there are now quite a few) all you have left is same 10 biomes with same 8 terrain archetypes to explore. Same starships with like 20 archetypes and 50 optional components. Same animals from 10 archetypes and slight variations in colors and bodyparts. Same derelict freighters, same missions and so on.

Still, exploring through all that width is fun so what the hell let's give it a positive score

~No Man's Sky: A Galactic Odyssey of Infinite Possibilities~

No Man's Sky has undergone a remarkable transformation since its initial release, evolving into a sprawling universe of endless exploration and creativity. As an avid gamer, I found myself captivated by the immersive experience offered by this ambitious title.

The exploration aspect of "No Man's Sky" is nothing short of breathtaking. The vastness of the procedurally generated universe is awe-inspiring, with each planet offering a unique landscape, climate, and ecosystem. From lush, vibrant forests to desolate, rocky terrains, the diversity is staggering. The thrill of discovering new species, rare resources, and hidden secrets on every celestial body kept me constantly engaged.

One of the game's standout features is the building architecture, which allows players to leave their mark on the universe. The ability to construct bases and settlements on any planet adds a personal touch to the exploration experience. Whether it's a modest outpost or an extravagant architectural masterpiece, the freedom to shape the world around you is both empowering and fulfilling.

Crafting technology in "No Man's Sky" is a deeply rewarding process. Collecting resources, refining materials, and upgrading equipment provide a satisfying sense of progression. The game's crafting system is intuitive and allows for experimentation, encouraging players to tailor their tools and technology to suit their playstyle.

The ongoing updates and expansions by the development team have significantly enriched the game. Features like multiplayer, community events, and a narrative overhaul have transformed "No Man's Sky" into a living, breathing universe that continues to evolve.

While the initial release faced criticism for falling short of expectations, the dedication of the developers to improve and expand the game has turned it into a shining example of post-launch support. The dedication to the community is evident, and Hello Games has successfully turned "No Man's Sky" into a benchmark for the potential of ongoing game development.

"No Man's Sky" has become a masterclass in redemption stories within the gaming industry. Its vast, procedurally generated universe, coupled with the freedom to explore, build, and craft, creates an unparalleled gaming experience. If you seek a game that allows you to lose yourself in a limitless cosmos of discovery and creativity, "No Man's Sky" is a stellar choice.

Initially I got this game because I thought it was important to support developers who don't abandon their games and instead focus on fixing stuff. Hello games went through mud and dirt and came out on top. From overwhelmingly negative reviews to very positive rating and they are still not done with the game and provide regular free updates.

Then I started playing and by the time I realized I have completed story I have amassed quite a collection of rare ships and cosmetics. Game gripped me hard and I had an issue of letting go for dozens of hours.

This is one of the best space simulators ever. Nothing like it has ever been made by such a small team before, and it highlights what an indie studio is truly capable of. 10 out of 10 from me, this is my favourite game.

It's now November 2023, and I'm updating my review once again to say that this game deserves the Labor of Love award more than any other game ever released. As an aspiring indie game dev myself, I can't possibly imagine the talent and dedication put into making something this incredible. It looks like the kind of thing only a very large company with hundreds of talented individuals could ever produce, and I genuinely would not believe you if you said it was initially developed by just 6 people. The small scale of the team continues to astonish me, and the fact that they're still pushing boundaries and porting to new platforms is truly amazing.

No Man's Sky goes above and beyond anything I've ever seen before and likely will ever see again. It's been 7 years since release now, the game has been out for a while, and it sees more updates and continued support than games even released in the last one year (case in point, WWE 2K22 going offline just a year after launch). AAA publishers can't keep up with this tiny indie studio. If that is anything but a labor of love, I have no idea what it is.

Whilst the games basic selling point of the endless galaxy has a good number of hours to explore, the universe eventually felt empty. The economy was very basic and reacted little to my actions and not to all game world events (as there are no real game world events) -- e.g. attack of pirates of XX system means that YY product is in short supply -- such a thing does not exist. The prices of products today seemed to be exactly the price tomorrow. The NPCs said more or less the same thing over and over, the sentinels (the main 'enemy' you encounter) were just dumb. 
 Even the scripted main story was low on memorable pieces, I just couldn't bring myself to care about any of the characters since they had no semblance of 'life', just standing around in the same spot forever. Every space station is an exact copy of the one before, with different skinned NPCs standing in the same spots.

 The game universe is practically endless, but you could see it all in a few hours if you set your mind to it.

I first got No Man's Sky during the Singularity Expedition, just after it was released on mac. It was a game that I had an eye on for a while, but wasn't to sure about, due to it not being very popular when it first launched in 2016. So you can imagine the complete shock that I got when I opened it up for the first time, and found myself stranded on a strange world, with no ship, no communication, and nothing but a tiny laser to help me out. It was an exhilarating experience. The atmosphere was so different from any other game that I had played, and was simply amazing. I started the current expedition soon after, and loved the intriguing story line and narrative of everything that was revealed, the ATLAS being my favorite part.
I think that No Man's Sky is a wonderful game, full of millions of different things to do and collect, but every little thing has so much depth and detail, that it provides such a... I don't know what the right word is to describe it, but it is so much fun to play. The expeditions that are released every few months are also one of the best parts of the game, as they provide an extra story, with sweet new cosmetics, and are just so fun to play through.
10 ot of 10, one of my favorite games ever.

So many years later, game has just gotten so much better than it was at launch.

No Man's Sky went from being one of the infamous games of 2016 to a decently fun experience in 2018. From lies about gameplay, to actual teased features not being in the finished product, it's been a crazy ride.
I was on the band wagon for the game during the initial release, and I was just as angry as the rest of the community. The game has received multiple free content updates that have made the game very enjoyable. Who can say no to FREE content? It may not be exactly what was promised, but it's getting there and it's still growing. I say give it a chance if you have the money to spend, or maybe wait for a sale if you're really unsure.

In the tumultuous launch of No Man's Sky, initial purchase left me crestfallen as the promised universe of endless exploration felt hollow. Abandoning the game amid life's busyness, I rediscovered it years later, revamped and revitalized. The once-empty planets now thrive with life, and multiplayer functionality adds a communal dimension to the experience. The game's evolution from disappointment to redemption has been nothing short of remarkable. While the initial price tag failed to align with the early state of the game, the current iteration, rich with content and refined mechanics, makes it a more justifiable investment. For those yet to embark on this interstellar adventure, acquiring No Man's Sky during discount periods transforms it into a stellar deal, offering a captivating journey through a now-vibrant cosmos.

I think expectation's of this product ran rampant because those that love this type of free roaming game, hyped it beyond imagaining, so it's with some trepidation that I even attempt to write something, but I'm someone who's loving the freedom, the exploration, the language learning and all those little bits, that make this game stand apart from others.

So you start out, crashed on a planet, a little common sense and you know how to find resources and within a short space of time, your ship is repaired.  You gather a few resources and jump right in, flying around, finding lore and more about the planet.   A few hours later, your probably ready to jump to space, find the station, find a new planet or moon, rinse repeat, build, explore, improve, move on to hopefully reach the center of this universe. 

My journey is slower as I want to explore the starting planet and system, before taking the plunge, but there's no rush, I don't need to be first and I probably won't be last, but I'm enjoying the experiance.


It does have a few teething issues, I bounced into space when taking off.  Some sounds get irritating quickly and inventory space is a nightmare to manage, but these are little things.

If you want quick paced action adventure, then SC, ED or EvE would probably be more suitable, but for a relaxing jaunt around the cosmos.....  Sean and the team of Hello Games, did a wonderful job.

Ongoing progress..... so may add more thoughts at a later date.

Truly a labour of love.

Single player, i.e., keeping multiplayer on where random people might be in the same galaxy as you - really plays well!

But multiplayer in a group is still very bugged. Disappearing dreadnaughts, invulnerable sentinels, building bases together can cause unexpected issues, etc, etc.  The experience is more like parallel play: Few people playing by themselves, occasionally talking with each other and sharing resources, instead of doing things together.

100% recommend for the single player experience, but if you are looking for an exceptional multiplayer experience and don't want to be restarting your game every now and then, look elsewhere.

No Man's Sky has come a long way.

Being an original player, I am awed at the breadth and depth of content now available. From trading, to quests, to exploration, you can choose how you want to engage with the world.

Worlds are large and varied - sometimes beautiful paradises, sometimes desolate wastelands, and everything in between.

The crafting system allows you to build functional bases or profitable mining operations, making your permanent mark on that galaxy.

If you like space, exploration, or crafting, and haven't given No Man's Sky a recent look, definetley check it out!

No Man's Sky used to be a shoddy establishment. The buffet was limited, the service was lackluster, the building looked unfinished, and it did not live up to the promotional material.
If you had asked me then, I would have told you to stay clear of this establishment.

I am happy to say that No Man's Sky took the criticism to heart, and made an honest effort to improve.
It seems Gordon Ramsay's visit to No Man's Sky as part of Hotel Hell payed off, and the establishment has pulled off an impossible comeback.

Improved Buffet? Check!
Pets Allowed? Check!
Building Renovated? Check!
Easy Access Parking? Check!
Friendly Lounge? Check!
Streamline Check-in Process? Check!
Excellent Customer Service? Check!

Whether you stay for an extended period of time, or simply pop in for a quick visit, No Man's Sky offers immeasurable joy to all it's guests.
You have so many things to do: Befriend the Locals, Collect Rarities, Go on an Excursion, Ride a Jet Ski, Observe the Wildlife, Learn the Local Dialect, and much much more!
No Man's Sky is now worth the promotional material, and genuinely deserves the praise!

Now the big question:
What about Weapon Calibration?
It's Amazing! You can upgrade and tweak your multi-tool to your hearts content.

The only complaint I have is that the game sometimes stops responding and needs to be force-stopped. So make sure to bring a save beacon with you when going out on long planetary explorations.

A Stellar Odyssey with a Hint of Solitude

No Man's Sky is a visually stunning exploration game that fulfills its promise of an expansive universe. The vast array of planets, creatures, and activities ensures a captivating experience. Engaging in resource mining, trading, and space battles provides a sense of continual progression.

Yet, amidst the cosmic wonders, a touch of loneliness prevails. The multiplayer aspect, though present, lacks the bustling interactions one might expect. Encounters with other players are infrequent, leaving the universe feeling somewhat desolate.

The game's visuals are breathtaking, with each procedurally generated planet offering a unique and immersive environment. No Man's Sky has undergone significant improvements since its launch, with dedicated updates enhancing graphics and gameplay.

In summary, No Man's Sky is a visually enchanting journey into the unknown. While the occasional sense of isolation in multiplayer may be a drawback, the game's continuous evolution through updates makes it a compelling experience for those captivated by the mysteries of the cosmos.

No Man's Sky is a game that I keep getting back to. I pre-ordered it because I wanted a game where you can explore an infinite universe. It delivered on that part but was a let down on many others. 
After the post-launch hate rush had calmed down, the devs have introduced much of the promised content in to the game. The core story has been expanded, base building and exocrafts have been added. Preparations have been made for multiplayer. 
A lot has changed since launch and the devs are working hard to add new content. 

NMS is slowly turning into the game it was supposed to be.

[i] Edit 11/2019 [/i]

The developers keep updating NMS regularly with new features and many of those are community requested. Player feedback is used to make this game bigger and better. At this point in time Hello Games have more than redeemed themselves after the launch of No Man's Sky.

[i] Edit 11/2021 [/i]

The game is still being updated with new content. It is amazing to see how much love Hello Games has given NMS during all these years! I have nominated this game for the [i] Labor of Love [/i] award for multiple years in a row and this year is no different. Thank you for the great game!

[i] Edit 11/2022 [/i]

Yet again I nominate this game for the [i] Labor of Love [/i] award. Also wanted to add that this game is very fun to play on the go with the Steam Deck! I have now played NMS on a standard desktop, in VR, on a TV through Steam Link, and on a portable platform. PC gaming is amazing!

[i] Edit 11/2023 [/i]

7 years later and Hello Games is still releasing updates! No Man's Sky truly is a [i] Labor of Love [/i] <3

Great Game. And it still gets regular major updates!

[b] Once an "ultimate" review, but i can't keep up with all the big updates :D But let me explain, how YOU will enjoy No Man's Sky! Spoilerfree! [/b]
Whether you followed the giant s#!7storm during the release or never heard of this game, i will provide a solid idea what No Man's Sky is all about and if you would enjoy it. Playing it with the right expectations will prevent dissappointments, and grant really awesome moments. But first we need a level ground:
Did the company behind NMS advertise content pre-release that didn't appear in the first versions? [i] Yes [/i]. Did they realise their mistakes? [i] Yes [/i]. Are they working their butts off to provide the best gaming expierience they can squeeze out of the setting with big updates including frequent exchange with the community and adding most wanted features? [i] Hell YES! [/i]. But...but are there still bugs and unpolished parts? [i] Of course [/i]. 
[b] So, whats the gaming expierence all about? [/b]
NMS can be a lot, but at the core is the exploration of space, mostly planets, either in first person (VR too) or third person camera. It is up to you, to follow the main story branches or dive without a guide into an universe of fully explorable planets, striving to survive and interacting with 5 different alien races. Since the "NEXT Update" you can even do all that in multiplayer. Once you know the basics of keeping yourself alive and crafting, you can write your very own stories: Do you want to be a rich trader, using the different industrial specialisations of star systems for efficient trade routes, travelling yourself and sending out your fleet to different missions? You can. Do you want to join the space pirates with your friends, battling other ships or huge freighter in space, smuggling contraband? Break into production facilities to steal valueable technology information, even with upgradeable vehicles to aid your maneuver? You absolutely can. Want to side quest for eternity to help every living being you come across at the surface or in a space station, turning every stone, scanning every lifeform, unburrowing every old alien relic? You guessed it, you can! But, if you don't thrive for all that and just look for a quiet, lush place to build a nice homebase above or below water, feeding indigenous animals and enjoy the artistic pictures the light, clouds and terrains create infront of your very eyes, you got the right game! And if you change your mood, you can always switch from one of the above to another within a blink of an eye.
I could go on like this for a while, but to cut the long story short: NMS gives you an immense amount of freedom paired with magic moments, guaranteed no matter how you play it. Examples: You can finally buy that really expensive exotic ship you always wanted - Your friend got eaten by some serious horror creatures you awakened - You dive with your submarine to the bottom of a red sea to find ancient technology that is worth a furtune - Really otherworldy biomes twist your mind and fill your screenshot gallery as well as the trophy section in your home base. 
These are the kind of stories that make the game (paired with the aesthetics) a must-buy for every player that enjoys the space setting. Underlying is a nice "constant progress" engine. No matter what you do, it feels rewarding and gives you the ability to enhance your ship and land vehicles, your much needed inventory space as well as your weapons. 
That being said, you need some time to get going, it is easy to understand (you only "need" to consult the wiki for enhanced crafting to save yourself some headache), but at the start it takes time to gather ressources, fullify quest etc. Later on, when you are better equipped, the gathering part gets shorter and shorter. With enough credits in your bank you will have quick access to most materials, if you want to. Btw, there are no micro-transactions or paid DLC, all the great new contet is free. 
From one of the most hyped games, to one of the biggest disappointments in gaming history and the rock bottom of reviews, back now to an all-time classic, THIS is No Man's Sky for you! Don't judge too early if you run into a few bugs or die at first because you rolled a hazardous planet as your starting location! Learn, adapt, enjoy!
[i] Just keep your head held high, kiss your fist and touch the sky! [/i]

I love this game. Even though I've "completed" the game multiple times, I keep coming back to it from time to time. Definitely viable as a solo experience, but also a lot of fun as a multiplayer experience with both randoms and friends.

I love playing this, crossplay made it possible to connect with old friends I had left behind when I started maining PC. Don't get me wrong, it has plenty of bugs, as you can expect when most things are procedually generated, but the good side definitely overcomes it. There have been so many great and free updates, this game is a full on redemption story by now. Multiplayer makes it even better and the community is very helpful. If you have an ounce of explorer side in you or spacefarer in you give this a try, it can cater to every taste as well, combat, exploration, base building, survival, multiplayer.

The Company, The Game and You!

Like with most companies...it is about not telling the whole truth or "manipulating" the truth. It's about how we can "make" people think or imagine. I believe I heared him say there was no mp on Colbert Late night (i can be wrong though(YES, HE SAID THERE WAS MP[edit]), but this proves my point. It was left in the middle, they just didn't talk about it and that's how people believed there was mp for instance. [edit: he did talk about it. At first is was yes, than it was very rare to find each other, but now it is NO]

All everybody is saying (all opinions) is true. This type of game needs its player to imagine for it and give it a feel. If you are not a player like that, this game will really hurt your brain. 
I, for instance, just sometimes float above a planet and play some music and smoke some devils lettuce and that's it. Then i pick up my controller and find some words to learn. It might seem crazy, but that's how i can make this game very enjoyable. 

[THIS IS THE IMPORTANT PART]
So to conclude this essay ;) I want to say that this game is doomed to be a subjective experience. No story, no new gameplay, little to no action.... so basically you need to be the game...you need to give the game its story etc. [edit: if you can't or don't want to (and yes, you shouldn't have to), this game will suck]

Is this is good way to compromise, the whole love/hate relationship players have with this game? Or am I talking nonsense again....you tell me!

I recommend this game, if you are a cool, laid-back, sexy and super smart guy like me. Be imaginative and take your time. If you like story, high tier gameplay mechanics, action and other people....don't bother with this game. It's very expensive.

游玩时间不长，但这个游戏给我的视觉感受是极其震撼的，建造基地、探索未知星球、升级飞船装备、学习外星语言的过程是享受的，作为天文爱好者，希望未来的更新能够更丰富游戏内容，改善一些物理效果使它们更真实，比如黑洞吞噬、恒星爆发、三体运动等，把贴图改进为真正可以探索的内容，行星表面环境可以改善，因为太多的天体有相同的矿物、生物模型，且气候并不极端。另外添加一些天体比如中子星、星云、气态巨行星。最后剧情的世界观由于游玩时长不足我尚不清楚，但每个星系都有一个种族和空间站感觉很奇怪，我认为可以加入一些流行的太空科幻小说、太空科幻影视作品元素作为游戏内容。
[hr][/hr]
Although I didn't play it for long, this game brought me a very impressive visual experience. Building the base, exploring unknown planets, upgrading the spaceship equipment, and learning alien languages are all very enjoyable. As an astronomy enthusiast, I hope future updates will further enrich the game content, improve some physical effects to make them more realistic, such as black hole swallowing, starburst, three-body motion, etc. In addition, I hope to improve the map to explore real content and improve the surface environment of planets, because too many celestial bodies have the same mineral and biological model, and the climate is not extreme. In addition, some celestial bodies such as neutron stars, nebulae, and gas giant planets can be added. Finally, because I didn't play it for long, I don't quite understand the plot's worldview yet. However, I feel that each galaxy has a race and space station is strange. I think some popular space science fiction novels and space science fiction film and television works can be added as game content.
