Over seven years later and here we are. No Man's Sky is easily one of the worst launches a game could've ever had, from broken and missing features to a borderline non-functional PC port, NMS has seen it all. Despite that, with the help of major update after major update, Hello Games managed to 180 the whole thing, turning a smoldering pile of piss and rubble to a respectable survival with a keen emphasis on exploration that remains unrivaled to this day.

If you're wondering whether or not you should buy this game, just ask yourself these simple questions:

Do I like survival/crafting games?
Do I like space travel and exploration?
Do I like having nigh endless goals and objectives that interweave and overlap?

If you answered 'yes' to one or more of those questions, then I can whole-heartedly recommend No Man's Sky, doubly so if you have friends along with you.

No Man's Sky is a testament to the power of continuous improvement in the gaming industry. Its vast, procedurally generated universe and ongoing commitment to updates make it a unique and compelling experience for fans of exploration and discovery. Despite a few lingering issues, Hello Games has transformed "No Man's Sky" into a captivating and ever-evolving space odyssey that deserves a spot in the library of any sci-fi gaming enthusiast.

I love explorering, and I love building / tinkering.

This game finally is starting to itch that space minecraft scratch. Still on my first galaxy wandering around and it's so much better than before (bought it a few months after launch). I DID have huge hiccups getting it running due to shared libraries on steam and missing .dll files (?). That was unfortunate.

Runs great now, everything max 1440p (minus shadows, always turn them down), 90-100 fps on ryzen 5600x + 3070ti

Worth it on sale for sure. Was surprised to find a character creation tool on one of the space stations.
i love angering government robots and starting a police raid on my base

To all working on No Man's Sky, The Hello Games I simply say you are one of the VERY rare few in the gaming world that is shining the brightest and bringing joy at every level of your work and I go a step beyond and say that you guys might be the only Team that really pour your heart and soul into this memorizing experience and the love you put in your work can be felt as strongly at every level of your efforts. On behalf of the old guards of the gaming community, I salute and thank you as sincerely as I can. Please Never Ever stop. 
Keep on Rocking and Keep on being the Best you are. 
Sending love as big as the universe you have created. 

Edit 24th November 2023: 

To the incredible team at Hello Games,

In the vast cosmos of the gaming industry, your light shines the brightest. Yours is a rare commitment, a labor of love that permeates every pixel of the mesmerizing universe you've crafted in No Man's Sky. In a landscape often marked by fleeting experiences, your unwavering dedication stands out.

Allow me to extend a salute and heartfelt gratitude from the seasoned members of the gaming community. Your work is not just a game; it's a testament to passion, resilience, and a boundless imagination. Please, never cease to explore the uncharted realms of creativity.

Keep on rocking, keep on being the best you are. Your universe is not just digital; it's a canvas of dreams painted with the brushstrokes of commitment and joy.

Sending a love as vast as the cosmos you've created.

Kind Regards,

"When this game first came out in 2016 it was one of the biggest game disappointments of all time" You've probably heard that a lot. "Now its a completely different game is is really good" you've also probably heard that. I can confidently say after buying this game in 2020, not touching it for 3 years, sitting there, updating, and finally sinking my teeth into this for over 60 hours, its.....good. I would say it definitely has its target audience, its repetitive, which I like, its open world, which I like, its semi grindy, which I like. My point is that its not for everyone. However, if you plunge into the game like it did, even though it took me 3 years to do so, you will find a pleasant surprise i didn't know was there, a dev team that cares for their game, and despite a really bad starting sprint, tripping and injuring the cameraman which is its audience, it got up, it told the bleeding out cameraman he was going to be all right, and despite no one believing in this metaphorical runner that is Hello Games, it made it to the finish line, and made sure the cameraman was there too. It also keeps racing more races after it won, making sure to take us along for the ride. Updating to this day, and after all is said and done, I'm glad I got to witness it.
This game is the definition of a comeback story. True labour of love!

The devs can be proud of what they have achieved here. While there were many broken hearts at launch, today the game represents so much more than what was initially promised.

Being totally into space (games), I bought this game as soon as it came out. It was a super hyped game back then, and totally disappointed. Because it was so hyped, it sold tons of copies - leaving a freaked out community.

There were two ways go on from there: take the money and leave. Or keep updating the game so it keeps getting better and better. I know many developers / studios who would just take the money, or release much needed fixes as "DLC". (You all know who I'm looking to.)

The team behind No Man's Sky decided to continue working on it. And it's one of the games I keep returning to, only to start over each and every time because they have added so much new stuff. I've never reached the center of the galaxy. Hell, I even never came remotely close to it. I just start over to enjoy all the new stuff. This is a seriously devoted team.

In fact, I'm starting to feel guilty by now because I just paid full price for it on release. I should have been charged at least 3 DLC's by now. But they don't, they just... release new content to keep the game fresh. And despite not meeting expectations at the start, it has totally fired up hyperdrive and took off.

I felt I just had to leave a positive review to reduce my feeling of guilt for all the free upgrades. Keep up the fantastic work, team.

No Man's Sky is a Space Survival and Exploration game, where you can fight for survival on planets surfaces and fly many different space craft in space and air.  It worked on my HTC Vive system, looked good, played good, sounded good.  Has some in-game tutorial and instructions as you go along with story.    The devs have been good over the years since it's launch to make more Free content updates for this game.  There is limited time multiplayer events to play through for each expansion.  You have a Normal mode, Survival mode, Permadeath mode, Sandbox mode, and Community Event mode.  Has a Huge universe for you to explore.  Has 27 steam achievements.  Has Multiplayer mode, that is busy.  Has crafting system.  

It has VR support for 4 HMD systems. I tried it with my HTC Vive, worked ok, with the amount of control buttons the Vive has.  The last update had improvements on the VR support.  Plays good with Valve Index.  Playing in VR is comfortable and doable, but there is some situations that might cause motion sickness.

No Man's Sky is an action-adventure survival game played from a first or third person perspective that allows players to engage in four principal activities: exploration, survival, combat, and trading.  Has galactic sandbox of 18 Quintillion planets tallying up to 31,7000,000,000,000,000,000,000 km2, with procedural generated worlds.

Buy this game, if you like Space exploration and survival games.

Only major gripe i have - Multiplayer feels hollow or halfway;
Yes it exists in some ways but you cant interact or do all that much together.. 
like build a base together? nope. 
Can you visit each others bases? kinda.. it seems to not hold on to a list of places you've visited but there isnt a great way to save favorites because good luck remembering names. Even when you visit, its kinda meh as you can only interact so much.. its not like you can build a big farm together or even have bases all that close to each other. 

Beyond Base type things, its also kinda hard to sync up together to do missions together or get someone up to speed; feels like people meet up for one or two things and then everyone's missions kinda send them separate ways.. missions should be SYNC-able or if someone is starting a new basic/non-story mission you should be able to join and split profits or otherwise.. have a difficulty ramp or whatever. Space fights are kinda basic and, at least when i was playing, seemed to be just never ending-nuisance with no reward or challenge..

There are also some major mission glitches that happen from even being in 'online mode'.. like im going on a never ending LY jump train for way too long and the mission reset stuff never works.. seems to be tied to multiplayer things.

-----
Firstly, probably my favorite thing about this game is for the most part you can tweak all the "difficulty" settings on the fly.. don't feel like fighting a bunch of XYZ right now? turn down that setting for now.

overall good game - some refer to it as almost space minecraft in a sense. Sometimes you question UI/design choices because some things can be very tedious especially with a controller. Some mechanics are frustrating at times ie when fighting off space pirates attacking a freighter, if just one hint of damage is done to that freighter's storage (something the pirates fly around and past constantly - ya know theyre trying to steal it) then YOU get flagged as a bad guy by the local enforcement.. who werent even around to fight off the pirates anyways lol. I certainly prefer the way some other games do space things; the local planet has no map and are often quite barren (would be nice to have a dash of bigger civilizations), the local planetary system map is basic, and especially the galaxy map is pretty terrible and youd have NO way of knowing where you've been, where you could go (its limited "view" distance), etc. You can only easily go back to other distant places youve been by teleporting between space stations or bases, you cannot just see flags on the galaxy map far away they have to be pretty close.

Definitely not perfect, there are some glitches for sure and known issues that need to be sorted. multiplayer realllllly screws up a lot of missions and playing with friends doesn't really add much so i wish they'd focus more on fixing the hiccups there and providing team-specific tasks/quests etc. in some upcoming DLC. Oh and the only way to find friends is by going to a specific game space-station, landing, and then leaving for it to prompt if you want to go to their system.. you have no indication of where people are on galaxy map.

Oh and unlocking the alien languages is an absolute CHORE, not required but yikes..

Suggestions:
- Fix up multiplayer integrations more  - like base building etc.
- More base fun stuff like farming and elaborate builds not just walls and cosmetics
- Why so much planet mining but basically no space mining / space trucking (deliveries and trades or escort missions) - yes it exists a tiny bit but i want to go mine asteroids and capture space junk, resources, debris, and random alien tech..
- etc. to what i touched on above.

-> 1st Review (~200 hours played):
No Man's Sky has come a long ways from the first release. 

I have found it fairly addictive and have already spent ~200 hours on it.

[i]If you don't have tens of hours per week to spend on a game, then find another game. I find that No Man's Sky is most entertaining when I can play it for ~12 hours straight in each sitting and you will likely have a similar experience.[/i]

I have not tried the VR graphics, but I'm thinking about it.
The regular graphics are reasonably well done, however, as far as variety goes, I am starting to find each new world similar to worlds I've seen in the past and I can't tell much of a difference between the various Frigates or the various starships. Each class of Freighter (capital ship) seems fairly similar too. The carbon and dihydrogen crystals that can be found on every world are always the same. The red, blue and yellow plants that can be found on every world are the same (oxygen, boost and sodium plants). 

The gameplay is a repeating loop of flying the starship from planet to space station, using teleporters to warp from station to station and base to base, using the scanner to find resources, mining resources, setting up new bases to more easily access certain resources, selling various found and crafted items to any galactic market hub, buying things you don't want to mine or build, managing the Freighter and Frigate fleet, and exploring the various planets for structures, monoliths, crashed ships and to accomplish some of the rather few missions that you can pick up from the mission boards on Space Stations and at the Anomaly.
There are various other gameplay loops and details that I omitted as my main point is that you will very quickly become accustomed to these gameplay loops and will find yourself repeating them over and over and over again as you go about playing No Man's Sky.

I have greatly enjoyed base building even though I have yet to unlock all of the base parts.

I have greatly enjoyed the Expeditions [i](specifically 1 and 4 as I have yet to play 2 or 3)[/i]. 
I look forward to trying Expeditions 2 and 3 in the near future. 

One day I'll take a perma-death-mode iteration to the center of the galaxy(s), but that likely won't happen for many months (or even years) of real time.

-> 2023 Fall Update (859 hours played):
Now that I have completed Expeditions 1 - 6 (and attempted #7), unlocked most of the base parts and have played many hundreds of hours more (than the 1st review) I can add the following (as what is above still applies):
A. Trying to find specific versions of specific (frigates, freighters, ships, multi-tools) is incredibly time consuming, even with the NMS Glyph Exchange (and other similar websites). Certain characteristics (such as particular color schemes) simply can't be found. [i]It would be hugely helpful if Hello Games incorporated some sort of "Ship Yard" type space station in some number of star systems such that a Player could fully customize the appearance of their Freighter, Frigates and Ships. It would also be hugely helpful if the Anomaly (or some other place or set of places) had a "Multi-tool Customizer" or "Multi-tool Constructor" such that the appearance (and possibly Type) could be adjusted to whatever suited the player. These things don't yet exist, so you'll have to try to use a save editor, not that that is any easier.[/i]
B. Trying to "max out" or "max stat" (anything) is not fun. It is hugely time consuming, takes a lot of resources, and doesn't necessarily make a noticeable difference in regular game play.
C. Missing an expedition means not being able to attempt that expedition, possibly forever (at least without some sort of trick or hack). I have missed ~5 expeditions so far and will likely miss more as my work and life schedules don't necessarily allow me the time to play during the expedition's time limit. Players who join after an expedition is complete might never have a chance at it. [i]I am looking forward to Hello Games incorporating some sort of "Choose your Expedition" from a "New Expedition Game" choice when making a new character. If such a thing is added to the game then I'd be able to attempt the Expeditions that I missed in whatever order most suited me. [/i]

I still enjoy playing No Man's Sky, however, as the core game play loops haven't changed, I will soon become bored, again.

This is a strange game which will be either an instant hit for you, or you'll hate its guts. Fortunately, the former is my case

It just drops you somewhere without any specific instructions -- except for the first 10 minutes -- and you can ignore the plot altogether. No one would be there to force the "entertainment" for you, you will have to do it yourself. No one will force you or push you to do anything specific. If you prefer for your games to constantly push you and provide you with new and more exciting experiences -- this is not a game for you.

However, if you like sandbox-like games, if you like exploration and hunting for resources (fuel, crafting materials, even the oxygen you're breathing with), if you like when the no one forces the pace on you -- you'll find yourself at home. I think that if you're familiar with Russian-made "Space Rangers", old X-Tension and X2 games, you'll enjoy your time here.

Visually, it's very consistent and I really like the style of the environments and seamless implementation of the launches and landings. Sound-wise, it could be better (especially the sound of the player ship's engine), but most of the sound effects are mostly passable.

Also, it tends to run quite okay under Proton, so Linux games should be able to enjoy it as well. AMD GPU users might experience some issues with stability, but for the most part, those can be mitigated -- refer to ProtonDB for more details.

The rocky start of the game is far behind us at this point and we are still getting consistent free content updates. This already says a lot about the game and the studio. I would recommend giving it a go if you are even remotely interested in space/exploration games. The story missions and expeditions provide a lot of additional content to those who are not fully satisfied by exploring and discovering new worlds.

Edit: Original review was at about 20 hours in.

I was one of the No Man's Sky haters when the game first came out.  I was looking forward to this game, and I was really disappointed in the state that it was in when it was released. However, I watched the Internet Historian video about the game and although I had originally told myself that I would never buy this game, I decided to give it a try.  I mean, it was half off and I had heard about all of the progress that the devs had made in making the game something that was worth all the hype that it garnered years ago.

First and foremost, if you are not a fan of the Loot, Build, Loot, Upgrade game cycle, this really isn't the game for you.  but, if you are a fan of exploration and discovery, this is a great game.  

I have been obsessive about playing it and it is the first game in a while that I have been itching to play while at work.  I would say that if you are on the fence about the game, buy it.  There is so much to see.

One con: This game suffers from the same effect as Starbound.  Unlike Minecraft and Terraria, when there is so much to see, the changes you make seem to be less important.

With that all said, I love the game so far and am looking forward to learning more and building more as I go.

Edit at just over 100 hours: Still love it.

Edit at over 150 hours: I still come back to this game and absolutely love everything about it.

[h2]6/10 -- "Wide as an ocean and deep as a puddle" -- No Man's Sky has come a long way since the terrible release, it's now a reasonably decent game with potential hundreds of hours of fun to be had but there's still a lot of room for improvement, it's quantity over quality and quickly gets repetitive[/h2]

✅ [b]Review does Not contain spoilers. TL;DR at the bottom[/b]
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
[b]• Story: 5/10[/b]
The main campaign is OK but the story isn't the main attraction of this game. It's fine.

[b]• Community: 9/10[/b]
There is a fantastic passionate and friendly community around this game. 

Plus, there is an amazing mechanic in the game called "The Anomaly", without any spoilers, it's a mechanic in a singleplayer game but you can actually still interact with other players. 
Don't panic they can't grief you, they can't break or steal anything that you've done, or start screaming abuse at you but you can interact with random players if you want.
It's a hub where all players can visit and interact with each other, maybe go on a mission together, look at what other players are building, things they've discovered, maybe you want to trade or learn how to do something, make some friends to enjoy the game with.

Genuinely a brilliant mechanic but you can turn it off.

[b]• Difficulty: 3/10[/b]
Started off quite challenging on "Extreme Survival" the first couple of hours were challenging, however, progression was disappointingly easy. As in many games, there are upgrades you can find and purchase, in this game they are "Classes"; C being the worst, then B, A, and S being the best, plus random X-class which can be worse than C or even better than S, it's completely RNG.

The issue is the best S-class upgrades are available everywhere almost immediately, it's not difficult to get resources to purchase them, and you frequently find them while looting. 
Once you have a few good upgrades the game becomes easy, I started to install mods after only 15 hours of playing to make the game more difficult. 
I haven't come close to dying or felt challenged in 400+ hours, the devs could have easily made it so rare upgrades or ships only spawn in rare systems or planets, or for completing long and difficult missions but you can have multiple uber S-class upgrades within 2 hours of playing.

[b]• Settings / Menu Options: 7/10[/b]
Disappointed there's no option to completely hide the HUD so you constantly have mission reminders popping up and health meters always visible, you can scale them to make them a bit smaller but they are still always visible.
Warning to anyone playing on an OLED monitor, do what I did and every 10-20 hours of playing change the HUD scaling to make it a little smaller or larger so it's not static in the same exact place burning into the display.

There are however a lot of customisation options for how you would like the game difficulty, unfortunately on the hardest difficulty it's still not challenging but the amount of individual customisation for how difficult or easy certain things are in the game is very good, you can really configure things to your taste.

[b]• Graphics, LOD, & Lighting: 6/10[/b]
Pretty good, a few lighting glitches here and there, and sometimes the textures can be a bit stretched on large objects but overall the visuals are pretty decent.
The game can have some really lovely and beautiful environments, you will take a lot of screenshots.

However, the biggest issue is the LOD and pop-in, the render distance is Bad! Bad enough that I searched online thinking my game was bugged.
Entire volcanoes or huge buildings will suddenly render 100m in front of you. Passed 100m everything except large rocks and a few trees stops rendering so it looks very flat and empty.
Plus the rendering can be quite delayed, it can take a few seconds to catch up so you boost forward and then 2 or 3 seconds later plants and grass start rendering.

This was on ultra settings and a high-end system, it's a limitation of the game engine and it's very immersion-breaking.

[b]• Exploration: 3/10[/b]
Technically it's near infinite but the biggest problem the game has for me is the planet generation, once you land on a new planet within 2 minutes you have seen everything that planet has to offer. 
This is the biggest disappointment of the game, you land on this alien world but you have no reason to explore it past what you can see when you land, the game presses copy, paste, copy, paste... across the whole world and every planet only has 1 biome.

In less than 15 hours played I had installed a mod called "Better Planet Generation" which did improve things a lot but it's still limited by the game engine.
Planet Generation needs a BIG overhaul!

[b]• Mod support: 9/10[/b]
Thankfully mod support and community are very good and active, there are thousands of amazing mods, dozens of new ones every month and it's one of the easiest games I've ever come across to mod, for people that are new to modding it's just drag and drop. 

The only downside is the game is still frequently updated by the devs, which is great but every time a game update releases it can break mods and they need to be updated, so you have to be careful about updating your game and keeping your mods up-to-date.

[b]• Bugs: 8.5/10[/b]
Really good, well polished. A few little glitches or clipping issues here and there, occasionally you might get bumped through a wall but you can just load the latest save.

[b]• Replayability & Game length: 5/10[/b]
This is difficult because it's procedurally generated so replayability and game length would be infinite but all of the recipes and core gameplay don't change, all objects are just repeated with slight tweaks or variations, so for me, this isn't a game I would replay, just one big playthrough and that's it. 
There is a lot to do, I put nearly 400 hours into one playthrough but it gets repetitive quickly.

There are Community Expeditions that I run a few times a year where you can get together with random players or solo, go on a big adventure, and earn some rare and unique rewards. A lot of our players return to the game just to play these expeditions.

[b]• Performance & fps: 9/10[/b]
Very good, no issues with framerate even on ultra settings at 4K (2160p). With an RTX 3080Ti, my framerate never dropped below 60fps. 

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

[b]• TL;DR (Conclusion):[/b]
It's a good game that I could recommend playing. The game really has come a long way, it is now fleshed-out and has become a decent game potentially with hundreds of hours of gameplay.
The community is very friendly, passionate, and active, there's a great amount of support, mods, and open player bases, plus it's still constantly being updated by the devs.

But NMS feels like [b]quantity over quality,[/b] planet generation needs a massive overhaul it just feels dated and basic, reading online the biggest complaint players have is there is no point in exploring planets.
There are quite a few other features and mechanics that feel like the devs implemented them and then forgot about them, you put a few hours in and then you realise it's repeating and doesn't go anywhere.
It's one of the problems with procedural generation, for some things it's fantastic but it's literally repeating the same assets with little tweaks so it gets repetitive quickly.
Rather than adding new things a lot of the community is always discussing that the devs should go back and overhaul old mechanics and features, improve the planet generation, biomes, flora, and fauna, rather than adding new things, overhaul the old dated stuff that restricts the game.

It's worth playing, it's decent, however, it's an exploration game where you should be exploring unique alien planets but there's no incentive or reason to explore any of them after the first few hours.
It's vastly improved since the beginning but there's still a long way to go before this would be a great game.

I'm so glad I waited.

Many years ago, when I heard about the release of this game, I was stoked, as were most. I admittedly forgot about it for a bit until I came across it months later, and heard about how badly it flopped. I thought it was done and I'd never get to play it the way I imagined... but man, I have to say, what an epic comeback story this game is.
I saw that the game was holding on, and the developers were still working to redeem themselves. So, I waited. I waited until I couldn't wait anymore and finally, years later, decided to buy the game for my wife and I to begin together. Immediately, we were hooked.
Sure, it has its flaws. Multiplayer is amazing but complicated to set up and keep connected, but regardless of these issues, the game has so much to offer. I have been mind-blown by every planet I visit, every encounter I experience, and every new aspect of the game that I learn about. Finally, a game that truly makes me feel like the possibilities are endless, and I can play for hours with absolute determination towards a goal, or loft about with no goal at all. I love No Man's Sky, and I'm glad I waited for it to become what it is today.

So, a long overdue review update is needed.

I posted a review 2 years after launch and after putting 147 hours into the game I said the game looked promising in its 'beta-like' state, especially with the NEXT update injecting new life into the game back then. Now after another 5 years and 10 times more hours put into the game, [u]it looks fantastic and so far each update has topped the last![/u] I don't know when exactly it stopped looking like a beta, but I think that happened on Vers 4 when some QoL stuff was added along with the UI getting update for the Switch release.

Even before that, I started a serious run that so far has clocked in 800 hours of playtime! (after saying I couldn't stay interested for 30 hours at a time in the previous review) After pulling myself away from that I jumped in for as many Expeditions as I could when they cam up, giving me a taste of what the latest update had to offer. To be honest, the Expeditions are still hit or miss for people, but they are typically a great way for a new player to get a jump start into the game, if interested.

[u]Value keeps getting added to the game with no signs of slowing, and with no paid DLCs in sight[/u], so early buyers are still being rewarded (or compensated for the bad launch) to this day. That said, this game still has a lot of breadth but maybe not as much depth as some may like, but recent updates have made strides towards fixing that as well. They have made on foot combat and ship combat way more interesting over the past year or so (which were major sticking points I had early on), along with an injecting of new lore through the past couple updates.

This latest update, Echoes, is actually tempting me to either do a new serious run or restart my old one, which is saying something since I pretty much played things out after doing my 800 hour play-through.

Lastly, there are still bugs in the game, especially after an update, but typically you can avoid most of it after a week or two of waiting for the devs to clear them up. While they aren't elite code hackers, they are still very diligent and have gotten to know their creation over the years.

All in all, this game grown surprisingly well over the years, fulfilling and exceeding launch promises through the many updates, all for free and all with no signs of slowing.

I've played this game since nearly the beginning. Since two days after launch, to be precise, so I've seen the game change and grow over the past five years. And I'll admit... I liked it even at the start. Just the exploration element, the infinite universe, the vastness of it all... it was compelling, even if there was technically not much to do but follow the so-called "Atlas Path", which was the main motivation to warp between systems, along with reaching the fabled centre of the galaxy.

For this review, which is my first one ever, I'll give a brief listed summary of how the game was at the start, followed by what has been added since, just off the top of my head, without resorting to looking at the announcements. I'm not going to list pros or cons, I'll let you decide whether the effort spent on the game in these past five years is enough to entice you.

State of the game at launch:
- Limited inventory system with no stacking for crafted items and tiny stacks for basic elements.
- NPCs permanently stuck to chairs and almost nothing in the sense of actual acknowledgement of the player in terms of movement/gestures.
- Space stations with only two small rooms with NPCs.
- No way to expand ship inventory.
- No multiplayer (remember that whole debacle?).
- Buildings with sealed-off areas that required basically unobtainable passes.
- No visible player character.
- No way of warping between systems without having to spend warp cells.
- One save slot.

Features added since launch:
- Base building with a large number of different parts and part styles.
- Exocraft (extremely useful for traversing across land quickly).
- Actual multiplayer, with crossplay and friend groups.
- Freighters (acts as a second base with unlimited power and way higher warp distances than your ship).
- Customisable player character.
- Multiple save slots.
- Hugely expanded space stations with several NPCs and upgrade stalls.
- NPCs walk around, chat to each other, show visible emotions, and gesture while talking to you.
- Once two-room Anomaly now the huge multiplayer hub of the game, featuring community missions, team missions, stalls for earning nanites, upgrade stalls, and base showcases.
- Space station/base/Anomaly portals that allow you to warp between systems/bases without spending warp cells (though you do have to spend one to access them the first time).
- Planet portals that allow you to warp to specific systems with coordinates.
- Expandable ship and freighter inventory.
- Different inventory tabs for massively improved flexibility.
- Generous crafted item stacking and very large basic element stacks.
- Previously sealed-off areas now accessible thanks to easy-to-get passes.
- Artemis storyline serving as a thorough tutorial of the game.
- Crashed freighters on planets with loot.
- Derelict freighters in space with valuable loot.
- Possible random encounters while travelling between planets.
- Creatures can be fed, ridden on, and even adopted.
- Mission stall on space stations with randomly-generated quests.
- Guild stall on space stations to get good rewards for completing missions for them.
- Cartographer stall on space stations to obtain points of interest on the current system.
- Settlements that you can manage and grow.
- Regular "Expeditions" that are shared by everyone and always start from a fixed point and is always online... it's complicated.
- Huge archive buildings with upgrade stalls, NPCs, a rarity exchange service, and lore.
- VR support.
- Anomalous planets that look really weird.
- Third-person view (I never use it, hence why it came across to me only now).
- Hatch your own ship from an egg.
- Full manipulation of terrain, with digging and creation of new terrain.

...well, I am sure there's other, smaller stuff that I haven't listed, but that should be about it for the big stuff.

There is some stuff that hasn't really changed between then and now, such as the trading system, the ship controls, the multi-tools (though they did add a couple more "alien" versions), the general style of the ships, the looks of the three major NPC alien species, the ancient ruins and monoliths, amongst other things.

I will offer a couple of tips, should you buy this game:
First, do the Artemis storyline, THEN the Atlas one. This is to avoid possible conflicts between the two main quests.
Second, you can consider yourself truly free to do what you want once you've completed the Artemis storyline.
Lastly, try to pay attention to the lore. It's in various little tidbits, from ancient ruins, to monoliths, to derelict freighters, to crashed freighters, to abandoned buildings, to archives... it's rather deep and compelling.

In conclusion, I would say the developers deserve nothing but praise for their commitment to this game after its horrendous launch. They obviously messed up and have been trying to fix things constantly ever since. That alone should deserve some sort of reward, be it awards... or constant new players. ;)

UPDATE NOVEMBER 2023
Well, two years since my review, and still they are cranking out new features and updates. So what else have they added since launch?
This time, I've had a brief look over the patch notes of the major updates, since I admittedly haven't been playing NMS all that much.

- Reworked Sentinels, with new Sentinel types, lore, structures, Sentinel-based upgrades, and the ability of having one as a pet.
- Yet more types of ship, including your own procedurally-generated Sentinel Interceptor.
- Reworked piracy system, with outlaw systems and smuggling runs.
- Squadrons, where you can recruit other fighter pilots to fight with you when in space combat.
- Heavily customisable game modes to make your save as easy or as difficult as you like.
- Dynamic difficulty, AKA adjustable difficulty within a save.
- "Catalogue & Guide" section with introductions to the alien factions, faction milestone progress, and all discovered pieces of lore.
- Save renaming.
- "Wonders" section, with records regarding treasures, planets, fauna, flora, and minerals.
- Corrupted planets and Sentinels.
- An entirely new alien faction.
- Multi-Tool salvaging.
- Freighters can now be destroyed.

They're still going, seven years after launch. I don't think any other game has had this many updates and features added over such a timespan, which is why I find it odd that it has never won a "Labor of Love" award. It's one game that definitely deserves it.

Maybe for its 10th anniversary... ;)

Thank you Internet Historian -(๑☆‿ ☆#)ᕗ

If you want the aspects of a space sim and want them condensed into a tight package, then NMS is superb. Base building, trade and exploration are all there. Comparisons are made with Elite, even calling NMS "Elite-lite" but in my opinion the two games are pitching at different elements of space simming and so comparison is somewhat unfair. 
However, there is one point Elite and NMS share and at which both excel: they offer you a sandbox world and a set of tools to make your own story and play the way YOU want to. If you suspend the element of disbelief and invest a bit of imagination, you are going to have a metric luckfoad of fun in both of them.
NMS offers base building, somewhat simplified trading system, and a greater variety of (sometimes illogical) eye candy and planet environments to explore. It is easy to sink many hours into this title. 
On top of that, the support, updates and commitment shown by Hello Games to NMS is truly fantastic and they deserve every ounce of respect they receive for it. The game keeps getting better with every iteration. It is an excellent addition to the space sim genre and deserves a spot on your shelf.
Recommended!

EDIT April 2021: Again, blown away be a free update. Hello games just keep on giving. This game deserves your love even if only for the dedication shown to this title by the team. Totally thumbs up. EA - are you watching? This is how it's done!

EDIT November 2023: NMS keeps getting better. Every iteration brings something new. This has to be one of the best chillax sci-fi games out there. Definitely worth checking out.

This game fell flat on it's face on initial release, let's all just admit that fact. It was hyped beyond reason and when it finally became playable it was absolutely nothing like it was meant to be. However, they have updated this game SO MUCH that it's no longer recognizable from what it once was. This game is amazing beyond comprehension at this point. The base customization is insane, the frigate/freighter system is really cool, the amount of vehicles available as well as ship types is expansive, and there's so much more they've done with it. I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves exploration and open UNIVERSE. I downloaded the game again after about the third update and in that one weekend I spent over 30 hours just grinding through the new quest system.
The world is, your platform. Limitless potential.
It's a game that keep giving and for free! Get this if you are disappointed with Starfield.

The one with bioluminescent plants that glow in a wave with the wind at night is one of my favourites.

Dollar per hour I think you could definitely get your moneys worth on sale but it will very likely become a bit stale after a while. At that point you hope you've done all the main missions or focus solely on them and try to skim over everything else.

Update on 11/22/2023: Congratulations to the NMS team on a massive year sales-wise, learning that your game is still doing quite well has me with a massive grin on my face. I'm truly grateful that your passions outweighed whatever the burdens of launch brought upon you, and that this game is not only alive and well but continuing to thrive and grow and expand. Studios like yours give me hope for an industry that seems to be shifting more and more towards greed. I know this game didn't start off optimally, but where it is at now and where it continues to go with the consistent and substantial free updates has more than redeemed itself and in my opinion it belongs in my personal video game hall of fame. So. Wishing you luck on the labor of love award this year.

For the most part, they've fixed the complaints from this last update in the experimental patch. HG has implemented super-charged tech slots that allow you to get close to play styles that relied on 2 3x3 mods previously. Playing a new game, I can say that permadeath is still fun. The main ante-up has been that attacks can damage your equipment, although it seems to be limited to after your shield is broken. Ryzen 7 2700
32gb RAM
GTX1050ti
SSD

The above specs is not enough to run the game seamlessly apparently. The game stutters, freezes, FPS drops, and sometimes outright crashes. 

That being said, even after trying out all the fixes without success and endless frustration cos the game just won't run smoothly, I still didn't ask for a refund. Why? Because the game is everything that I want in a game. I love to explore. I love to hoard materials, I love to discover and build and collect. I enjoy the odd bit of survivability that's just enough to make you feel like you have to manage stuff to survive, but not enough to detract from the main focus of the game, namely exploration. 
I could do with some more customisation options for the ships, but for the most part, the game is in a very good place. Now please check the performance and stability. HG has done a lot of good upgrades over the years and I'm sure its  a matter of time before they get it right.

Edit: Run Malwarebytes before playing. Bitcoin miners will eat up all your resources. Game running smooth now. Sorry....

When it first came out, it was big. Lonely, but big. Then, we got updates. Then we got more updates. Then we got BIG updates.  Yeah, it gets better, and it's hella fun with friends.

Update late November 2021:
It has been a long run, and NMS just keeps getting better, and bigger. Some updates I'm not much into, but ... over all, it is getting even better looking.

Update mid November 2022:
Is this even the same game?  Massive updates. This last update has cause some re-thinking (not enough to restart a new toon). much easier to add / remove tech for buildouts. Less OP here and there. Visually, has gotten even better looking.

A year later, 2023:
Massive updates all year long. Continual re-thinking of the game. Don't agree with 100% of the updates / addtions, but there are folks that do, and that's a good thing.  Seven years in and still the game is updated, improved, and grows. Still massive af ....
After a disappointing release, the constant updates have left me in awe. Playing in VR is also absolutely stunning. being able to switch from VR to PC with the same save file is great.

(Sep 2021) Day 1 player, terribly disappointed, but stuck with it for the zen and now I'm glad I did.  Update to update, there was more interesting to see and do, but it's always reverted to kind of a zen diversion.  The expeditions are a really nice addition, and they should build on that.  For $30 it's got a solid base of players, plenty to see that hasn't been seen (though too much repetition--HG, we need an exploration / variability update to get more real oddness in here), and honestly it's a nice change of pace from time to time.  Are there bugs I still want to see squashed?  Sure.  Are there features that need tweaking or overhauls?  Yeah.  But this is a nice time to jump in if you haven't before.  You'll keep coming back to it as long as they keep updating, which may be a long time yet, and each time it feels like coming back to an old friend.

(Nov 2023) Two years and two months later, it's still chugging along.  It's become a bit hokey and goofy to say 'I played Starfield and now I'm back to the OG' but that's really true.  It's unclear how much sense this game will make to someone just coming to it for the first time, but the incremental improvements have continued to be interesting.

I was disappointed just like everyone when this game first released. I was so hyped to play with my best friend and explore worlds together. But it came out and everything wasn't as it seemed. Years went by and I didn't hear much about the game, until I saw Next. Actual multiplayer was being added. I was still iffy on the game as I was still soured by the disappointment. 

More time passed and more updates were added, but I hadn't really thought about NMS until I saw a video on YT. It covered all the troubles the developers had, and how they still persisted updating NMS. I still didnt buy it, but it was almost always in the back of my mind. 

Smash cut to the beginning of 2022 and i buy it from the Winter Sale. It felt great to play, like playing Minecraft for the very first time. And then within a month or 2 Sentinel dropped and added more content, and I kept playing. By that time I had convinced my bast friend to get it, and I was brought back to that time when my friend and I were hyped to play together in NMS. Finally it happened. And although there is still some stuff I wish was in the game, they're still adding to it. 

Just this year they added Sentinel (ground combat overhaul), Outlaws (space combat overhaul), Endurance (Freighter overhaul), and Waypoint (general overhaul). They still have pledged to add more and I cant wait to see whats next in store. They definitely deserve the labor of love award for 2022 for sticking with their game.

Edit: They've since added a death star-like trench run, enemy capital ships, a new race, and new ships. If you're looking for a sandbox space exploration game, this is still the game to go to.

Year after year, No Man's Sky continues to impress, becoming easily one of my most played and enjoyable games of all time. A true testament to how much love the devs put into their game. Each new update typically adds big feature changes and new exciting things to do, with 2023 perhaps being one of their best title update years to date! Though on PC I only have 40 hrs at time of writing, I have 300-400 hours on playtime on PS4/PS5 and I bought it on PC, merely to support the devs to show them that as a customer, I have just as much love for the work they do!

Update: I started playing again when the NEXT update came out. Holy crap, this is a totally different beast than when it first came out 2 years ago. I've put so many hours into it already. I was hoping that it would get fixed and it did in the end. There are some glitches and multiplayer isn't exactly fleshed out but damn, I trust that they will continue to make this game better and better.

Once I get the game that is shown to me in the trailers I will be happy. I want the build of the game that was demoed at all the conventions and all the interviews. We were lied too, I'm hopeful that Hello Games will update the game to reflect on what was promised and shown to everyone. I don't even care that it may never be multiplayer. This would have been a solid game if we had just gotten what was shown in the trailers. 

Factions? What factions? Epic space battles? Come on, Star Wars X-Wing vs. Tie Fighter had better flight controls that this game. You don't even see the outposts shown in the gameplay videos. Everything is just one big grind at some point. I was hopeful for something epic at the center of the galaxy.

I hope that this game gets updated. I really do.
If you need a game to play at your own pace and relax to, then this is definitely worth a try.

The game looks lovely and I found it ran well with no issues. Now that I have completed the story line  I have an issue, what now ? I want to explore the universe with a friend, find a world and build a base BUT this is the problem the multiplayer still does not work properly. You can explore and fight together yes but the co-op  base building does not work. I have given a positive review because I really enjoyed the game for nearly 200 hours it was honestly  great and I might still go back from time to time.
 Now if multiplayer was working 100% then I would be exploring and building with a buddy. If you like exploration , survival and base building then this is worth buying, seriously get it but if multiplayer co-op is of importance to you then give it a miss.

This is what I'd call "Labor of Love" game. It came out broken. But now? It's one of those games I sometimes go back to. By now it's worth to recommend it, even though it's not at the absolute top. Somewhere at 8/10 for me.

--EDIT--
Although it is not my absolute favourite game in general, it is, by now, the one on Steam (that I own). I've gone back to it at least once or twice a year. It's still an 8/10, because some things are stiff and scripted very clearly, but like GW1/2, there's just nothing else quite like it. That feeling of landing anywhere on a planet, fairly seamlessly, of unlimited exploration and freedom in a vast multiverse... the power to build what I want, where I want, even on a planet hell-bent of killing me. And in spite of there being some games with similar premise, somehow this is the one I fall back to.

--EDIT for 2023--

I waited for the price drop and that just so happened to coincide with the 1.3 update. Having heard of the lacklustre launch of this game I’ve been following its comeback with great interest and finally took the plunge. 

I can safely say I’m hooked thus far.

Landing on a new planet and never really being sure what to expect is a unique feeling I haven’t experienced in gaming for a long time. I think if you have a good imagination you will love this game. There’s a multiplayer element that’s not focal to the main game (right now) but just the knowledge that there are others like you out exploring this vast vast universe is in a strange way comforting. 

The game just looks stunning, the hardest part is trying NOT to stop and take screenshots every 5 minutes. 

If you liked Elite Dangerous but found it a bit too complicated at times this might be right up your street. It simplifies many of the elements that are in that game (landing/missions/crafting etc) and the planetary exploration is just leaps and bounds above Elite in my opinion.

I’m aiming to get the storyline completed and see where that takes me. Perhaps after that, the repetitiveness will set in, but if this game continues to be supported as it has been in the last year then I for one am extremely excited where we go from here.

Happy Travelling!

[h1] Once dead, now immortal. [/h1]

I mean, I was skeptical at first after so many stories about how much this game sucked. Amazing how much devs did to make it a one of a kind space simulator adventure. Starfield wishes to be 3% of No Man's Sky.

I've followed NMS from its inception. I was there when it was first released. I luckily waited and didn't buy into the phat heaping pile of steaming shit it was. I watched as the game I was excited about was eviscerated and put on horrid display in 4k by the community. Seeing terrible generations of the first creatures, simulated co-op, and barren landscapes in their infinitely vast...nothing space. When HelloGames realized they fucked up and the future looked as bleak as their planets, they flipped the switch. They came back and told the community they performed horribly and released a product they can't be proud of. They listened and gave the player base ACTUAL multiplayer/co-op. They added content update after content update to add life to the universe they created. Quite literally, breathing new life into the game. Honestly, one of the best wholesome comeback stories a developer/publisher could do. This game is unrecognizable to this day to what was initially released. I couldn't be more proud of the company and I will always give credit to HelloGames for keeping their promise and owning their mistakes. They never failed...they just delayed success dimwittedly <3

No Man's Sky is an amazing game which offers an amazing experience of exploring a massive galaxy. It did a complete 180 from where is was at release in 2016 and is still well worth the 60 dollar price tag since the developers are regularly putting out massive, high quality updates, with the current features pretty much surpassing what the developers initially promised from the game. The game from my experience right now does not seem filled with bugs, other than the periods of time right after a major content drop when new patches are needed. The multiplayer experience is decent, with the ability to play with a small group of friends in your party and to encounter other people at random in star systems and the nexus multiplayer hub. Probably one of the best features of the updates to the game are the base building tools which allow you to build your own base on alien planets with a great deal of creativity and a part list that is ever growing. Also of note is the ever growing roster of unique spaceships to hunt down and grow your fleet with new different vessels being added over time such as organic starships, flyable sentinel starships, and solar sail ships.

Quick Summary

Pros:
- Amazing experience of an infinite universe
- Great base building mechanic
-Good mix of flying through space and walking/driving on planets
- Everything is procedural which makes for plenty of new and unique ships, planets, and aliens
- A good mix of space sim and resource management survival
-Decent cross platform multiplayer
- Regular high quality updates that are 100% free
- Regular expeditions which provide a new time limited adventure to play through every few months

Cons:
- A bit expensive (maybe wait until its on-sale which it frequently is)
- grinding is needed for credits and resources (but not worse than most resource and building oriented games)
-Major updates often come with bugs when they are first released.
(Edit)
-Admittedly after over 400 hours the procedural generation can get less interesting, but for the price you can easily get at least 100+ hours out of the game, and expect to hop back on to experience every major update.

Get No Man's Sky if you have any sense of adventure and desire to explore the stars.

I'm not much of an explorer, more of a builder. But I had fun with the exploration trying to find good spot for making a production base. Also, this game let me own a whole fleet with freighter as the flagship and about 30 other escort that ain't just cosmetic. You can land on it, there's a repair quest sometime. You can send them on expedition getting resources. The game let me build huge factory and based too. The freighter interior is customizable and can be useful too. With processing machine, plant farms, storage, etc..

I wish they would remove the limit of number of object per save. Or let us change it in the config/setting to allow unlimited.
There's already a check that if the base is too complex it won't be available to multiplayer. But at least I want it for just myself. I've heard that this is so that the PC wouldn't run like a potato because the base was built too large, but let me try that out myself please.

This game should stand as the blueprint for developers struggling to handle a miserable launch and harsh criticism. Not that the criticism was unwarranted in this case, but the internet has a habit of piling on when the neg-train rolls by, which only makes it that much harder for a developer to stop it without derailing. [b]Hello Games[/b] did that, somehow. I still don't fully understand how the turnaround has been so successful, but it was a nice surprise.

I'm also surprised to see the Recent Reviews finally make it back to Mostly Positive from the orange-red death of Mixed. That's really hard to do. It'll be even more impressive if we can change the [i]Overall rating[/i] to Mostly Positive. I'm gonna do my part, and hope you do the same if you play the game and enjoy it.

EDIT 11/2023: Game gets better each update and over time, which is exceptionally rare these days. Nominated for GOTY in a year where I completed both new expeditions.

UPDATE: It Is now November 2022 and the Expedition Replays have started. This year was a bit rocky with the community, but it is still the best game I have played. The Waypoint 4.0 update changed a lot of fundamentals, which people hated. I think they were needed changes that benefit the game. The only thing that worries me is that this was the first update in a very long time that felt unfinished, like it was incomplete but they had a deadline to meet. More issues / bugs than normal were reported and also features added in after the fact in a patch ( super charge slots ) feels like they didn't have time to finish it so they released it knowing that within the month it would be done. Who knows what that means, but it was a stumble from an amazing studio. Maybe they have finally met the limitation of the size of their team, with working on a Switch version and PSVR2 while creating a big overhaul update. I just hope they get rest over the holidays and 2023 is back to amazing updates.

[h1]No Man's Sky[/h1]
...is an exploration and crafting survival game. Waking up on an unknown planet with no memory of your past and a crashed spacecraft with cryptic or fragmentary information, you set out to survive the environment and explore the Euclid Galaxy one planet at the time, as you define your purpose. This review takes into all updates up until Echos.

[h1]⚙ [u]Game Description & Mechanics[/u] ⚙[/h1]
Gameplay is focused on gathering resources and crafting objects. You begin with a basic multitool and limited inventory space, and learn to mine for crafting material to fix your equipment and recharge your life-support and hazard protection shields. As you progress, you'll learn recipes to more advanced components to build devices, refine basic elements, craft equipment upgrades for your multitool, exosuit and spacecraft, and even build a base (or multiple bases).

Much of [i]No Man's Sky[/i] revolves around exploring and cataloguing all you discover. Scanning each mineral, flora and fauna found on each planet will identify the resource it supplies as well as give you Units (trade currency) for each you scan for the first time, while uploading them to the servers will give you Nanites (tech currency). Units can be used to purchase material and components from the Galactic Trade Network, as well as better multitools, spacecrafts and frigates. Nanites are used to purchase equipment blueprints and upgrade modules. A third currency called Quicksilver, used for character aesthetics or decorative crafting items, can be gained from missions on the Anomaly, a multiplayer hub from which you can meet with players, show off your starships, go on missions together and visit each other's bases.

Progression is done in multiple ways. After the introduction (which also serves as a tutorial), you can follow the Path of Atlas which sets you to eventually reach the center of the galaxy. You may instead set your focus on the single-player campaign where you retrace the footsteps of another Traveler like you. Of course, you can ignore both options and advance at your own pace, finding alternative ways to unlock the game's content. For instance, you can unlock base building component blueprints from buried salvage technologies and from side-missions given to you by your in-base specialists. Once you have a freighter, your crew will give you missions for your fleet of frigates (which you send on exploration, trading or combat missions). Those seeking a bigger challenge can do all that in Survival or Permadeath modes.

[h1]☺ [u]What I enjoyed[/u] ☺[/h1]
It's hard to express just how much there is to do in this game! In the early game, your limited equipment and inventory space will force you to struggle through a slow progression, but the entry grind has a satisfaction of its own once you acquire additional cargo space to store spare consumable and specialized material, upgrade your multitool and exosuit with a variety of weapon modules, better shields, enhanced environmental protection and various specialized equipment. Once you accumulate a good reserve of Units, trading your spacecraft for a bigger, stronger or faster one will only accelerate the process.

Base building is also very satisfying if you're into this. You can build anywhere, and the base's size cap is very high. The base can serve as headquarters with additional storage space, a farm to produce rare material, a gathering place for you your friends (the base itself can be built as a team), build racing tracks for use with your exocrafts (land vehicles you can, of course, build and upgrade!) or a wondrous piece of art (complete with logic-based wired lighting and ByteBeat musical creations). Getting a freighter (from which you control your fleet and store multiple spacecrafts) serves as a mobile base of its own, part of which you can alter and build in to your liking.

It's a gorgeous game, the constant updates since launch brought improvements to textures, procedural generation algorithms, fauna and flora diversity, and overall graphical technology upgrades. You never know what the next planet will be like: A low-gravity barren wasteland? Icy mountains with orange skies and pink waters? A hellscape of erupting volcanos, firestorms, and lightning striking the ground? A poisonous marsh of giant fungi and carnivorous plants? A paradise world with glow-in-the-dark purple grass and green night sky? Or perhaps deep oceans of radioactive muck and meteor showers where the atmosphere filters the color spectrum to exclusive yellow tints? New creature types, from small to humongous, can be found on these, once again proceedurally-generated from head to toe, with actual per-planet coherence.

[h1]☹ [u]What bothered me[/u] ☹[/h1]
As mentioned before, it's a game about resource-gathering and crafting. This means a lot of grind, hour upon hour of mining and refining your resources. Want to build a huge base? Grind for building material. Want to make a lot of money? Grind for valuable resources. Want to survive a hostile environment? Grind for life support and environmental protection fuel. If you don't enjoy this kind of stuff, you will find it terribly tedious. The change of pace from story missions, base building missions and sidequest missions are limited as they can also feel very repetitive, even with the efforts made by the developers with the week-long community events.

PvP and PvE combat mechanics, whether on the ground or in space, are less than optimal. The ingredients all appear to be there: various weapon types and grenades for ground, various weapon types and missiles for space, the run/strafe/jump mechanics, yet somehow it still feels off and doesn't even come close to games dedicated to either types of combat. So while you "can" be a pirate and fight frigates, or you "can" be a hunter fighting predators and sentinels, it's barely worth the trouble and seems to have been included as an afterthought. 

The single-player campaign is somewhat simple and feels like a goose chase of traveling from one location to another, grinding, digging or building specific upgrades to continue to the next clue. Learning the alien languages, one word at a time, has little payoff. Most of the galaxy lore, given through snippets of history found in monoliths or conversations with stationary NPCs, will feel superficial to anyone who doesn't want to do the roleplaying in their head. If you can't set your own objectives, you will get bored after a while.

[h1][b]My Verdict[/b]: ★★★★☆ - [i]"Next on your list!"[/i][/h1]

[i]No Man's Sky[/i] isn't a space combat simulator, nor a sci-fi adventure: it is first and foremost an exploration and crafting survival game, somewhere between [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/346110][i]ARK: Survival Evolved[/i][/url] and [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/264710]Subnautica[/url]. However, a lot of people are looking for a game that does just that. You'll find a lot to do, it isn't even humanly possible to discover the entire galaxy (even if all players worked together in an attempt to do so). With all the updates so far and those to come, it definitely delivers!

[quote][b]P.S.[/b]: I was lucky enough to avoid the pre-launch hype, but I do understand the disappointment and frustration caused by Hello Games' marketing, promising features that wouldn't actually make it in the game until years from launch. And while I can appreciate the dedication of the team not to have run away with the money and actually delivering on their promises, I would beware about pre-purchasing their games in the future.[/quote]

—————————————————————————
[i][b]This was just my opinion.[/b]

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/CJsOpinions/]reviews[/url].[/i]

Relaxing game. Is it for everyone? I don't think so, it's story will provide some lore but nothing too engaging. For some it's gameplay may become too repetitive. This is a game where one creates, or rather has to create, their own experiences (old times Lego kids will feel right at home). 
Get lost exploring many gorgeous worlds, though arguably even with procedural generation the diversity could be improved upon. Set up cozy homes, imposing bases or simply both with the expansive building menu. Find your absolute dream ship and add it to your ever-growing collection or do some questing for a bit of action here and there. And once one is done with all that take a breather and just enjoy the great community in the multiplayer hub where there is always a friendly face to find that is willing to help newcomers out.
And if the time comes where starting it up just doesn’t seem too enticing, sooner or later the regular updates and Expeditions will pull you back in for another visit. Safe journey fellow Travelers.

Of course, always my Labor of Love choice.

Seven years... I cannot believe the progress this game has made. It went from false promises to  exceeding those promises, and even adding things I did not know I even needed before the update. This game is incredible. The gameplay loop is like no other.

It truly boggles the mind, now more than ever, why Hello Games didn't decide to simply release this game in early access from the get go. 
Instead of the backlash that happenend people would've seen vanilla NMS as the foundation for what was to come from the beginning, Personally I've always greatly enjoyed the game despite it's early flaws but I would certainly never say the backlash wasn't justified even if it was, in true internet fashion, wildly exagerated. 
For me, while vanilla always felt like an alpha version, it was still somehow enjoable enough if you went into with a certain mindset. Specifically with a couple of good beers, some beautiful music (at least after you had your fill of 65days' fantastic dynamic soundtrack) and maybe a slightly tired mnd. It could be a very relaxing, almost meditative experience like that. It was a walking sim on a galactic level if you will and a good way to end a stressful day. Just flying from planet to planet, looking around for rare metals and crashed ships and maybe get the occasional glimpse of the very weird but intriguing lore the game had on offer was sometimes exactly what I needed in my day. I've put a good 50 hours into ithe vanilla version, which is a lot for someone like me, and at least after I had increased my inventory capacity I can't say I was often frustrated or angry on my journey to the center of the galaxy. It was still a grind mind you but since there weren't really any high stakes, farming resources to get more money and scanning planets for hours to find that crashed ship with the bigger inventory that I wanted was simply a reason to explore for a bit more. 
I shut my ears to the backlash and tried my very best to enjoy what was there and ended up enjoying myself immensely.

Fast forward two years and that weird little alpha game that half the wold seemed to hate has become something else and something much closer to what was initally promised. While it is still a grindy and weird game, there's so much to do beyond that. There's good reasons now to spend hours of your time looking for that one damn resource you still need and there are plenty of interesting things that will inevitably happen on the way. You can set your own goals, like farming, decking out your gear, becoming the commander of an armada, trading, bounty hunting, base building, etc or you can follow the strange trail of the atlas to flesh out the lore, figure out who Artemis and null are and what the nature of this universe is while the story guides you through a clear path through countless systems. And if you need a break from what you're doing, just go do something else for a while.
There's so much to accomplish and all of it feels so much more fleshed out now; It's quite an incredible turnaround. If you're willing to go with the flow and learn how to work with the game and its systems it will likely be a very rewarding journey indeed. And if you're ever in trouble you can now even call for a friend in multiplayer.
And now, on top of all that, there's also a mostly fully featured VR mode.

All of that is just scratching the surface of what this gigantic universe has in store. No Man's Sky is a very odd and huge little game and even now it can be infuriating at times, but with the right mindset it's a relaxing, peaceful and very unique experience. I can't help but love it for that. And with their continued support through updates Hello Games have proven that they're not just in it for the money but that they're trying their damndest to make No Man's Sky a great game yet.
I think they're well on their way..

[h1]From Humble Explorer to Galactic Conqueror[/h1]

Embark on an interstellar journey in "No Man's Sky," a game that transcends traditional boundaries to offer an expansive universe brimming with alien planets, peculiar creatures, and galaxies stretching beyond the horizon. More than a mere game, it's a comprehensive cosmic odyssey. It begins with your struggle for survival on a treacherous alien world and soon escalates to navigating starships across the vastness of space, where new planets await and the potential for crossing paths with other adventurers is ever-present.

The ambition of No Man's Sky is unparalleled—a sandbox of galactic proportions set within a procedurally generated universe housing quintillions of distinctive planets. Each celestial body teems with its own ecosystems, creating a sense of scale and exploration that is virtually unmatched in the gaming landscape.

Stranded on an obscure planet with a broken ship and limited resources, you're faced with the ultimate test of survival. The game's beauty lies in its reluctance to coddle you; instead, it encourages a bold spirit of discovery, pushing you to learn, adapt, and eventually master the elements.

As you traverse the cosmos, you'll engage with diverse alien species, each offering unique languages to decipher, intricate trading systems to navigate, and rich lore to unravel.

Base building and crafting are cornerstones of your journey, providing a canvas for both architectural genius and utilitarian functionality. The crafting system is a complex playground that rewards ingenuity, allowing for the creation of everything from basic survival tools to elaborate starship enhancements.

Combat is a thrilling challenge, whether you're repelling space pirates in cosmic dogfights or outwitting mechanical Sentinels on unforgiving planets. The thrill of battle is a constant companion in the wilds of space.

Despite its tumultuous launch marked by bugs and unmet expectations, Hello Games has orchestrated a remarkable turnaround. Through relentless updates, they've woven additional layers of depth that have significantly enhanced the game's immersive experience.

To conclude, No Man's Sky is a monumental testament to the beauty of scale and ambition in gaming. It's a labor of love that has blossomed into an odyssey igniting the spark of exploration at every turn.

This isn't just a game—it's an adventure, a lesson, and a canvas for creativity. It's a homage to our innate curiosity and the eternal human yearning to explore the unknown. I give it a 9/10, for it has redefined what it means to get lost among the stars.

Remember, the sky is not the limit, only the beginning.
A Cosmic Odyssey of Redemption.

Even though there is a lot of controversy surrounding this game I still like it. It's the closest thing to what I want to play and the closest thing to one of my biggest dreams - explore the universe, catalog everything I find, befriend anyone I encounter, have my own base on a wonderful planet, have my own ship, fly FTL etc. 

To the people who cry that the game has no gameplay - the gameplay is what you make it. It's like one of those many survival games on Steam but actually done right. If you are into space stuff, sci-fi etc., this game is for you, if you ever dreamed of being a space explorer, this is for you. If you are looking for action-packed shooter, you probably won't find it here.

Mods fix lots of issues with the game which should have been fixed by the devs. They also enhance the gameplay and visuals significantly.
I recommend using the mods made by Lo2k on nexusmods for the best results.

Kudos to the developers for continually improving it with free updates, it's really great to see (they could of easily have left the game in the release state and ran away with the money). Does the game have flaws? Absolutely. Is it a perfect game? Of course not, no game is realistically. 

I think the key to No Man's Sky is finding your own way to enjoy it, whether it's through multiplayer, VR, base building or just lone wolfing it through space. I would say that if you're still unsure, try picking it up during a sale and give it a go as it's often very cheap these days. In summary, an enjoyable and relaxing exploration through space that has the potential to become repetitive to some people.

The game is constantly getting updated every year and is becoming better and better compared to when it was first released. I enjoy visiting different solar systems to scan its lifeforms and try to find either a planet or a moon to set my base in. However, since the galaxies are all randomly generated, a lot of them could look about the same which is understandable! The co-op and online part of this game such as updating findings / renaming found flora and fauna is a little bit wonky though, and may not register which could in frustrating. Overall, I recommend this game especially if you have someone to play with!!

Purchasing it about half a year after release, but not playing it more than a couple of hours back then, I finally managed to give it another try. Although it's still clunky and glitchy here and there, some mechanics feel a little tedious and some others might benefit from being a little less luck- or rather randomization-based, the game is one hell of an experience

Exploring planets and building a home for yourself feels a little like Terraria, exploring space and fighting pirates feels a little like Freelancer, experiencing the main storyline feels engaging and interesting, at least when having a hang for philosophy and maybe theology. And there's so much more:
Even if just travelling around, approaching a new planet, taking in the views of vast oceans or huge mountains or branching canyons or snowy forests or thunderstorms above volcanic wastelands can be entertaining for hours. Not even mentioning the (partly absurd) variety of planetary life that can be encountered everywhere...

What Hello Games has done is something the entire industry should learn from. Of course this is never going to happen industry-wide but they have my thanks for their commitment and their hard work. They deserve a lot and I hope they keep adding as cool stuff as they've added for these years for many more years!
Amazing game. Would tame a walking bush again. 10/10

Personally I was a tad skeptical about NMS prior to launch, however at the same time I did think it was an intriguing project and albeit it didn't necessarily deliver on all of the promises at launch, since then Hello Games have been quite tireless in bringing more and content and complexity to the experience.   

Although I'm not sure I'd necessarily quantify NMS as a game in the strictest sense, it is certainly something I'd recommend people experience. There is wonder and joy to be gleamed from it.

If you haven't played in a while or have held off on it. I highly recommend jumping in when there's an expedition event, as they're good way to learn about the games systems as well as fast track a starting character.
