I'm a bit lucky I got this game when Origins came out, and the game was finally where it meant to be at launch. So I can't speak to the experience of playing it prior to Origins. But I have to say, this is one of the best games I've ever played. I picked it up little ways into the COVID pandemic, and didn't know how badly I needed the escape this game offers. Just flying around, checking out random planets, enjoying all the open exploration of places nobody has ever seen, not even the devs. Then a ways in I tapped into the Galactic Hub community, and the value the game offers went up even more. It's just such a lovely way to escape, explore, and enjoy however much time you want to throw at it. If you spot it on sale, don't pass it up.

No Man's Sky is a lonely space exploring simulator. 

It does not have appealing, have limited customization options on starships and other vehicles, lack a meaningful communication system with NPC, and have numerous bugs. 

Still, with 25 major updates over the past years, a lot of contents are added especially the exploration aspect. Tons of new things can be explored and collected — and that's all of the game. If you like to explore, collect, and build, you may love this game. If you want interesting story, battle, and customization, it would not be the game for you.

Want to play space minecraft ? Then this is your next stop.

Fun and entertaining to play, recommended for peoples who like exploration.

No Man's Sky is one of my favourite games to play by far. It's always fun to come back to and explore the fantasy side of space exploration, combat etc.
The developers at Hello Games are an example of how to create and more importantly maintain and progress a great game. While they had initially released the game in an unpolished state, they consistently added the features they promised and added much more beyond that.
Anyone who's interested in buying and playing this game really just needs to consider if they:
1. like space games
2. like/prefer simplified realism or a fantasy take on space and the universe
3. either are into exploration, trading, taming animals, fleet management, flying/finding cool ships, combat, crafting, farming or building (I'm probably missing something)

All in all there is a lot of content in this game, I still haven't done everything! And even if you do finish every achievement, find the coolest ship/freighter etc. these devs have been AMAZING and have kept producing more content for the universe of No Man's Sky.
10/10 I keep coming back. 👏👏👏

No Man's Sky is by far one of the best games I have ever played, thus why it is my favourite.
I have played a lot, and will continue to because there are so many things that make this game such an amazing experience!

Firstly, the game itself is exactly what I love! Space exploration combined with base building and a nice story.
With the procedural generation, it makes it continuously exciting to explore and find the perfect systems, I love the variety there is on planets, and with what can be created.
Some bases can be truly amazing! NMS also has so many more wonderful aspects inside that keep enhancing this experience.

Next, Hello Games are amazing developers! With constant free game-changing updates, it keeps the excitement.
NMS had a rocky start, but Sean and his team have delivered tenfold, are continuing to do so and I cant wait to see where the game continues to go!

Finally, the community is by far the best. So many positive creators and members, it's a true pleasure to be a part of it! (If you need some NMS guides go check out Jason Plays on YT, an amazing and helpful guy!)

Therefore I would highly recommend this game to anyone interested in space/exploration/base creating/more! Also if you like Subnautica I'm sure you'll like this too.

logged about 300 hours on PS4 but haven't played in years. The release of Starfield and paired with recent watching of one of my fav movies (Interstellar) actually made me want to go buy NMS for a 3rd time. So I looked up the biggest updates that have come out since my exile only to learn that there is so much content that has been added and many aspects have been improved from quality of life to multiplayer interaction to planet procedural generation. I was stunned when I explored one planet where the only living "animal" on the surface was a floating, transparent orb....that I could milk....and keep as a pet......and named him Frank

Also there's something to be said about the extraordinary feeling of going from space to a planet's surface with no loading screen. I know there's a few other games that do it and it's been there since launch but it still  tickles my spaceman itch every time. I think the devs deserve some praise for sticking with this game for so long and pushing it past its potential.

i remember when a friend told me about this game like 2 years ago, i wasn't that interested and i've never thought that soon i'll buy it, and spend 243 hours on it ... And probably a lot more in the "bright" future. Honestly i didn't like it at the beginning but after beating the "main story" and learning the game's lore i started to like it. ...It's basically minecraft but in space.
After all these years, it's still one of the best games out there.

There are few studios who release a game and continue to work on it after 7+ years all with free updates and huge content releases. The game in its current state is well worth the price and the available content is got a lot to keep you busy. Opportunities for base building and expanding your reach to the furthermost parts of the galaxy and beyond. If you have friends it can be just as fun while you explore and build a base on a planet where you can "plant your flag" and call it home away from home. Explore, trade, fight pirates, battle robots, and build on alien worlds, and do it alone or with friends. This has it all. 

This game is more for PvE lovers; while it "has" PvP it is not widely played as is. If you are more of a PvE person and if you do purchase this game, there is a settings option where PvP is turned on by default and you can be harmed by another player(s). Not many people are aware of this and some players fall victim unfortunately to griefers who kill newbie players. Make sure upon character creation to turn OFF PvP. This will prevent player damage by other players and avoid griefer deaths. If you get past that, the game will be enjoyable and is worth the price and the time with all the free content the studios keep pumping out for this title.

This game works on Steam Deck too; so if you are a Steam Deck player; it is worth playing on the go, and it looks great too. :D
With every patch u feel the developers' love for this game. <3
To be fair after the updates the game is immersive and has a lot to offer.

Let me tell you my little story about No Mans Sky.

About 4 Years ago, Sean Murray from Hello Games promised me giant Sandworms on the planets in the game he was making. It was promised in one of their pre-launch trailers. I bought the game after some deliberation, mostly because I wanted to see the giant Sandworms. They where my trigger, my selling point.

The game released. It was all a fiasco and a horrible mess. There where no worms, small or large. And the game was missing many other things. I still played it. After all I had some fun, and got some nice screenshots. But it was not what was promised. This was worming me deep inside since then. A feeling of betrayal and broken promises. I did not write a review back then.

Since back when I played the game on launch, it got many updates. I was surprised and liked what I saw on improvements over the years. But it was not enough to bring me back to the game, or heal the deep wound inside, even if the game got a lot better, and some of the broken promises got patched in.

But now No Man's Sky got its Origins Update to version 3.0
Now Sean Murray delivered to me what he promised me.

[b]GIANT SANDWORMS ARE ROAMING THE PLANETS OF NO MANS SKY![/b]

I will have to return to the game now, and watch the giant worms.

Sean Murray, is forgiven.
The wound is healed.
The worms have arriven.
I fly again.


Thank you Hello Games.
You earned yourself my positive review now.

It took a lot of extra time, but Hello Games has turned NMS into the game most of us wanted way back when it launched 2+ years ago. It still has its warts and flaws here and there, but rather than those being front, center, and in your face, they've taken a backseat to all the things that have been added and improved upon. Improved crafting, improved travel options, improved visuals, improved diversity of just about every kind, improved stroyline/questing, structure building, underwater exploration, real multiplayer, etc, etc, etc.

If you like building/exploration/survival games and have never checked out NMS, I would highly recommend it at this point. Especially while it's on sale! If you already own NMS but haven't come back to it in a long time, it's definitely worth revisiting.

No Man's Sky is a phenomenal open-universe survival game. It is incredibly fun to play. 

Definitely Recommend.

I probably picked up the game at a fortunate time. The state of game is pretty good. so if you plan to get it, this is a good time.
The game is not everyone's cup of tea, there are a lot of exploring loops, but beautifully crafted, interesting and unknown planets, buildings, ships and many more things will make it worth. There are many times I just got off my ship in awe for what I discovered.
There are a lot of walking and scanning and buying and selling and similar mechanics and game is definitely a tad frustrating at times but all of the above become more organic as you play and they integrate in how you want to play the game in your pace.
Base building is a bit bare bone compared to similar games, but you can surely build something to your liking. Aaaah, [b]devs[/b] please [u]stop[/u] people from building in view distance of your base (ruining your view with an unfinished ugly structure or blocking the view).
Game probably doesn't worth full price to me, there are a large amount of quality of life things missing, but this means if devs keep improving the game, it can go places. 8/10.

P.s. 312 hours of game play later!
A new very improved base was built, and the new upgrades to base building are super good, it gives the player so many options.
A new settlement was acquired and "max" tier'd, when you are done with improving the settlement, it lacks follow up contents but Devs didn't disappoint so far, so I believe in them on this.
I never got around to do the expeditions, but thankfully Hello Games let us do them again. First of all, thank you very much Devs! Furthermore, first expedition is going great so far and I'm having a blast.

Update - after 560 more hours of game play and many more expeditions, game is still fun and chill. It recently got slower to boot up and crashes more at start up :(

One of the best "redemption arc" games out there. 

But wait there is more, because they went beyond that and keep giving us content and improvement for free(as of writing this).
Fun, relaxing, exploration game. Will definitely recommend.

The gameplay is simple and while most of the systems lack depth, the game provides a wide enough variety of things to do to keep you engaged. It's a good game to zone out to while you enjoy the exploration and I'll often boot it up every couple of updates to check out the new content. My biggest complaint is that the expedition game mode only runs for a short period of time and can't be accessed at all if you missed the window. It's usually only unique cosmetics and light story elements that you miss out on but I dislike the FOMO aspect of it. 

Above all else the game still receives regular updates that add new things to do. I'd recommend getting it on sale if you're interested in checking it out.

No Man's Sky offers that level of freedom that very few games offer. You can be a Bounty Hunter, Trader, Pirate, Explorer...
Heck, you can even become a Mayor of your own little settlement, defending it from threats and developing it.
Plenty of different and unique ships, planets, species and events make the world feel special and you can write your own story and even enjoy it with friends.
It came a long way from the first release and is almost a totally another game. 

If you love space, exploration, settlement building and combat, this game is definitely worth playing.

One of my favorite games of all time.  If you enjoy sandbox-style games with a sci-fi theme.  Exploration for exploration's sake then you might enjoy this game.  The fact that VR is being added to this game (freely) is why I am purchasing a Steam Index and significantly upgrading my machine.  I cannot wait to experience what new (free) updates are added to the game in the future.

I stand by my positive review of No Man's Sky now that I have had the opportunity to experience the VR version of the game via the Valve Index.  There are certainly tweaks that could improve the overall game experience including adding greater variability to planets, creatures, and spaceships.  Hello Games has announced another significant (free) update to the game which provide some quality of life improvements.  Would recommend to gamers who enjoy open world games, are not looking for linear (or much of any) story-telling elements, enjoy creative base-building mechanics, and a quasi-MMO experience with varying degrees of interaction with other players.

This game continues to improve.  Perhaps one of the greatest games ever made.

I waited for a long time to finally get into this game.  The early hype clearly did not pan out with the first release of this game.  BUT the devs never stopped improving and growing, and it really shows in the version of the game that exists today.  There is much to do, and much to explore, and much to build.  I quickly got hooked, and spent a lot of time just bumming around the galaxy.  My only complaint is that the starbases and buildings quickly become repetitive due to each of them having an identical layout.  That takes away from the feeling that you are exploring vastly different corners of the galaxy. Combat is also limited, but that is clearly not the main point of this game. When VR dropped, it was awesome to be able to pop my rift on an see everything from an entirely new perspective.  If you like exploring and building, buy now!

Update 11/28/20: These guys are still adding content to this game. I pick it up every few months, and the updates make it feel new and exciting all over again.  Even more enjoyable with the larger variety of tasks, and planets feel more rich and populated than in earlier versions.  Still buy it!

Update 12/1/2021: Still giving us updates! Still improving and growing. So many ways to play the game now. Truly a labor of love. Thank you, Hello Games.  

Have you not bought this yet??!! What are you doing? Buy it.

2023 and still going strong. I'm going to keep reviewing this thing forever until you buy it!

Old review:

Kind of reminds me of Batman:Arkham Knight release. Very bad PC port. Major stuttering, FPS drops... This is my first expensive game I decided to buy and im not satisfied. I should have waited for the pirated version and checked it out first...

Day 3 edit: 
Okay, so aside from these performance issues, lets talk gameplay. I still stand by my first review. The gameplay is dull. I was in awe for the first 3-4 planets. Then the repetition kicked in. The planets, as a whole, are different. Different color, different size, different "texture". The flora is pretty much the same. They are slightly different, after 10 planets you will be missing plants because you will think you scanned it already. Animals are what kept me smiling the longest. They are goofy, funny looking and derp-walking around, which is nice, but still after a while you can see the similarity between them. The only thing that is keeping me attached to this game is the language and the mistery behind the center. I want to gather as much alien language as I can and then proceed to the center. But every playthrough I literaly have to make myself play it, because when I start playing everything comes down to:
1. Shift... Q... Space... C... Repeate.
2. OOh, green question mark, and its only within 2mins of walking. *heads towards it*
3. Save, craft those pesky chips, discover some monoliths, signals, Drop ins, etc...
4. See first step and implement the second.
5. After 2hrs of that I get bored and rage ALT+F4.
6. After 15mins I come back because i didnt find those 2 remaining signals on that planet.
7. Play for another 1hr, 1hr and a half... For nothing. Rage leave the planet.
8. Travel to the Space Station, sell items, gaze upon couple of alien ships, realize i dont have money to buy that thruster let alone the entire ship. Get motivated.
9. Land on the next planet.
10. See steps 1-9...

-Update: Day 9
I give up... I'll be back when they, and if they implement some new features to the game. This is just plain boring for me. Repetition is not my genre.

No Man's Sky had a rough start, but Hello Games' constant iteration, improvement and dedication to making things not only right with the players, but excellent in every way, have more-than-earned NMS a full recommendation. If you like the core loop of explore-gather-build, there's plenty here for you to sink many hours in to. The Expeditions are a really wonderful way to dip back in and explore all over again with new goals, constraints and wonderful rewards you can use across all save games. Enjoy!

[UPDATE] 2 years after my original review, and with 800 hundred hours of play time, I can only say that the game has continually managed to surpass all previous expectations and work. Each expedition has greatly improved QoL, added significant story and lore elements, entirely new weapons and races, and just made everything that was great into something better, while polishing all of the rough edges, making them smooth and the game shine that much brighter.

Hello

No longer the 2016 disaster it released as, No Man's Sky is a go-to game for fans of Minecraft, Astroneer, and/or role-playing games with goals to work towards... with a sprinkle of Bethesda's charming "It Just Works" bugs. Highly recommended for the people who enjoy turning off their brain to explore the cosmos in a myriad of ways, as well as those who want to just be the lunatic with a laser. Grab a pet, some explosives, and go explore the universe, you fancy spacecase!
...or is that just me?

Now with a cool robot player-unlockable species!

Pros:
-Base building, pets, ships, weapons, friends, and more to collect, work towards, and search for in a "Just one more" checklist to improve your exploration of the universe.
-Fantastic, if not potentially seizure-risking, visuals from varieties of worlds with different atmospheres affecting the colors, to your usual simple pleasures of flashy pew-pews in space.
-Almost everything is optional, base building, questing, etc. are yours to chase as you please as the only real pressure to do anything is in the name of progress/survival if you so choose... BUT you skip the survival failure of having to feed/water yourself like a child with an instant metabolism!

Cons:
-The bigger the game, the larger the odds of a bug, so with great exploration comes great fails... NPCs or you go MIA as the floor decides it doesn't exist anymore, assets missed in QA squeeze into live play that aren't ready when a RNG spawn triggers, and the usual bugs any random-gen loading can cause. The support team rarely replies to issues, so be aware of your last auto-save as you play.(Exiting your ship triggers auto-saves.)
-You can build a base, customize your character, and install upgrades to your gear/vehicles as you choose but.... no customizing anything else. Your gun/tool, ships, etc. are reliant on finding the combination of parts you want and getting lucky. To some this is a hard pass, to others it's part of the exploration, but I'm gonna put it out there as a soft negative because of the split in opinion. PERSONALLY, I think it's a bit weak to have a canon scrapping system to get sellable parts, but not have kit-building options, for those concerned there are ways to narrow your search but it'll still be exploration grind.
-Although everything is mostly optional, there's a good number of faults within the "quests" that can be found if just the wrong action is taken, and co-op play tends to bug things out if you want to play story together, essentially making it "Multiplayer capable",  but not the best idea when doing lore-based questing.
-DO NOT START THE GAME IN CO-OP, something about the starting tutorial will lock up when done with a team active, it's best to play solo until you've reached the multiplayer hub, unless you want some of those tutorial quests stuck in your tab forever.

This has been the best game purchase I've made in a while. I was hesitant and kept my expectations low, but I have been absolutely blow away by both the game and how great the devs and the community are.  
The game itself is gorgeous and the drive to keep exploring and go farther and gather more things is very, very strong. Don't be mistaken, if you aren't okay with grinding a little, this might not be the choice for you, but somehow NMS manages to keep resource collection interesting enough that I look forward to hunting down that next copper deposit or rare relic. I also recommend finding someone to join up with, as co-op play adds another level of amazing.
All things considered, NMS had a rough start, but has most definitely reclaimed its crown. I can't wait to see what else the game has in store for the future.

This game and its dev team continue to deliver quality content. It has come so far from the point I first posted, its incredible. I don't play as often as I'd like, but every time I get back into things NMS is just as rewarding (if not more so) than when I left off.

[h1]Sometimes, in order to fly, you must fall first - and even then you may not fly as high as others hoped you would.[/h1]


Oh boy, this is gonna be a long one.

When No Man's Sky initially released back in 2016, I tried to refund it. I felt betrayed - Not only was it missing a lot of promised content, but it was also vehemently buggy and felt just half-baked. Planets felt dull and boring, animals were mediocre and didn't add much to the experience, and it all around didn't feel like there was much to even do in the first place.

Of course, my luck being what it is, my refund didn't go through, so I decided to just swallow the pill I'd been given and kept it in my inventory. 

Over time, the game began to get updates - Foundation. Pathfinders. Atlas Rises. NEXT completely turned the game on its head, almost completely redesigning the game from the ground up. Abyss. Visions. Beyond took what made NEXT so great and expanded upon it (and gave us VR support, which is always welcome!). As the list of updates grew, I found myself slowly but surely coming back to it more and more. 

I didn't realize it at the time, but [b]I witnessed this game dig itself out of its own grave.[/b] I watched this game go from the butt of every gaming joke at the time to an actually beloved title in people's libraries. 

Fast forward to now, No Man's Sky sits at a Very Positive rating, something I never thought I'd see when I saw it release. As for personal statistics, at the time of writing, No Man's Sky is the 3rd most played game in my library with 708 hours played. 

I've kind of hesitated writing this review as I can't exactly put it into words all that well, so I'll at least try. Let me start with the elephant in the room:

[h2]No Man's Sky has been massively improved in all aspects, but still suffers from feeling shallow - and I feel that no amount of content will improve on it.[/h2]


Maybe it's because I'm burnt out - 708 hours is a long time for a game like this, long enough for someone like me to do just about everything the game offers. Planets have improved terrain (though that's still kind of up for debate - I personally feel planets pre-NEXT had more unique terrain, but to each their own on that front) but I can't help but still feel that mediocre slog that I felt all the way back in 2016. There's much more to do now, but it feels like if you do it once, you don't really need to do it again unless you want to grind for certain items. 

Despite all this, I find myself just booting up the game and exploring, maybe catching the occasional photo or two. Kind of ironic, considering that's more or less what No Man's Sky originally sold itself to be - an exploration game at its core with everything else tacked onto it over time. It's like the video game equivalent of a warm blanket to me - Sometimes I just want to wrap up in it, grab a warm drink, put on a nice video and get lost wandering around a planet that feels all too familiar compared to the last.

Most of those 708 hours have been exactly that, and honestly for that alone it gets my positive rating. It's [b]far[/b] from perfect, but it has provided a kind of entertainment I don't think many other games have achieved in my eyes. 

Earlier in this review I said my luck was bad. Thinking about it, maybe my luck isn't nearly as bad as I thought it was - just took some time to come back around is all.
Just a laid back way to explore a universe, sometimes gets a little repetitive (like you have seen some things before on other worlds)

Visit wild exotic planets, brave harsh environments, mine minerals and resources, trade with locals, fly spaceships, drive exocraft, fight pirates, plunder derelict freighters, manage your own capitol ship and fleet, build bases and factories, search for answers to your mysterious origin. Play solo or with your friends, including across platforms. The developers continue to put out content patches for free. 

Edit: 2023 and Hello Games is still pushing content updates for this. Amazing.

Also, don't feel put off by the recent negative reviews. There were some recent changes to your inventory that reduced your potential stats. But honestly, the game is easy enough that it's hardly noticeable. If anything, my only major complaint is this game is on the easy side.
Every time I turn around, the game has more content and it just keeps getting better!

No Mans Sky was a disaster at release, a terrible unfinished game with nothing to do but walk miles on end. After waiting years and years the game is finally better and I am confident to say I enjoy No Mans Sky. Some may argue it is still a walking simulator, but the game itself has little to do with walking and more about exploration. This is what brings the game to life, not just the unique settings, but the unique creatures and objectives that are presented. Starfield, upon release, posed a significant threat to the game. But as more people were informed of its existence and reminded of the game, the player count reached a total not seen in months. I was even able to get my friends to play, albeit they don't enjoy the game as much as me. For those who are looking for a unique experience, look no further to No Mans Sky. It is the epitome of space exploration, and it keeps on giving. Honestly one of my favourite games on steam.

If you did find this review helpful, please consider buying the game. The developers rely on the money they get on each update to keep providing free content for the community, so the more people play, the more things can be added to fully fuel the potential of No Mans Sky. It deserves more recognition for the feats the developers have accomplished, and it would be a wonderful sight to see.

Edit: A year later, still playing the game, still having a lot of fun with all the new updates.

If you can see that planet, asteroid, space station, ship, or freighter you really can go there and it isn't just a backdrop. 

Pulse driving your ship into uncertainty, on the hunt for a planet you can call home, or that has a cool dinosaur, coupled with the massive ongoing support and updates Hello Games provides this game and its players to this day with is admirable and gives me a reason to revisit even when I think I'm content and have seen all I wanted to.

Sometimes the music is so chilled and symphonic when roaming space or the new grounds that follow, and other times you are fighting for your tiny interloper life against a walker and his mech friends by tunneling underground like a mole and the soundtrack is right there with you.

Only thing that's missing from the PC version are the really fun haptic stuff they did on the PS5 with the dualsense, I am always coming back to this game, I wouldn't call it a space adventure, more like a peaceful space odyssey. I'm not really into space games, so I wasn't remotely interested or hyped when NMS came out. And all the drama turned me off even more. I'm sure I would never touch this game if not for Internet Historian video. But the game was on sale, so I decided to check it out. And, oh boy, I'm glad I did. This game is so beautiful, creative, mind-blowingly big, so fun and so damn addictive.

[b]SPOILERS! (kind of)[/b]

Playing No Man's Sky is one big incredible journey, after which you're left with so many fun memories.

Like going through black hole into some new star system and land on some planet that is 90% water, or has raging blizzards every 10 minutes, or makes everything around black and white and red, or just full of geometrical shapes.
Or landing on derelict frigate where temperature is so low, your hazard support doesn't last for even a minute, so you have to hop from one heater to another while searching the ship for some loot.
Or buying ships in space stations just to scrap them and sell all upgrade modules for some sweet sweet nanites.
Or even better, randomly finding some amazing crashed S-class ship and slowly fixing it up, part by part.
I loved going to pirate controlled systems and just annihilating every single frigate I see for precious frigate modules/upgrades and also ridiculous amount of money. Or just buying all of the contraband and selling it in for the crazy profit in the next system.
Although, buying tons of parts for cheap in one system and selling it for +50% profit in another (effectively crashing economy of both) was fun too.
I loved camping in some building while destroying waves of sentinels, including the walker, cause they are stupid dumb-dumbs that lose me the moment door closes.
I hate multiplayer part in any game, but here it was so seamless and fitting, I didn't care at all. I even liked to go to the Space Anomaly, just to dump some valuable parts on some unsuspecting player and run off.

[b]HUGE SPOILERS FOR THE PLOT!![/b]

Story has one of my favourite concepts at it's base. That universe is just a someones dream, or, in this case, a simulation made by AI. And now AI is dying. But it's scared, so it just keeps building more and more new simulations. And how number 16 keeps repeating again and again throughout campaign and only in the end of the story you realise, that it's the number of minutes AI is left to live. But this 16 minutes could mean a second, or a year, or a millennium for creatures in the simulation, so instead of living in terror of universe just ending, it's better just to enjoy every moment left. I just find it so cool and beautiful.

And one of my favourite things about the game, something that keeps me returning to it every few month - community expeditions. I love them.

So yeah, this game is ridiculously fun. And they keep adding new stuff! Like, now you can become a robot apparently? It is truly a labour of love.

Thank you Hello Games for all the amazing time I had playing No Man's Sky and for all the future fun moments I'll have exploring the infinite!

The new base building, freighter ships, and vehicle mechinics really saved this game from being a total failure. Despite a extremely pre-emptive launch of the game by Hello Games, they managed to pull this game around to be a truly enjoyable experience. First, the game was only fun for a few hours, then adventuring from planet to planet for no reason got rather... dull. Now, however-- there's more to it than that.

The game is subliminally separated into three paths-- The Path of the Atlas, The Journey to the Center of the Universe, and The Path of Freedom, is what I call them. The Atlas path cannot be explained without Spoilers, but it's basically the main quest. The Center of the Universe pathline is often the most popular, being rather self-explanitory. The Freedom Path was once the one that was despised... but now that there's things to do, such as claiming a planet as your home, this game improved ten-fold.

Don't let the other reviews fool you-- this game is very fun, you just have to focus on the good bits and forget the poor ones.

EDIT: After many years, Sean is still nurturing this game to the best it can be. Keep up the great work, HG, you guys truly know how to keep the flame of the awesome community going ever-strong.

This game is primarily about solitary exploration of a randomly generated galaxy, with some basic combat, customization, story, and survival elements.

The only multiplayer it has that I'm aware of is that you can name things you discover, and other players will see those names. If you're looking for more than that, you'll probably be disappointed.

As far as bugs go, the only issue I've had is sometimes it won't start (I haven't had any in-game crashes that I can think of).

While this game is by no means perfect, it's absolutely worth it for me, as my primary interest was in exploring a randomly generated galaxy, and that's exactly what I got.

Update: 11/2023: This game has come a long way, having received over 30 major updates since release, all free!
The game keeps getting better and better. We luv you Sean!

Embark on an extraordinary gaming journey with No Man's Sky, a true masterpiece that has evolved over seven years of dedication from Hello Games. The once-controversial title has transformed into a shared cosmic adventure with seamless multiplayer, inviting you to explore a vast and visually stunning universe, especially in immersive VR.

Experience unparalleled realism with breathtaking visuals, enhanced by the introduction of living ships, Exo-Mechs, and creature riding. The universe feels alive and unpredictable, adding a new layer of depth to exploration.

The ongoing commitment of Hello Games is evident in free updates like "Beyond" and "Origins," addressing initial concerns and pushing the boundaries of what's possible. No Man's Sky is more than a game; it's a living, breathing universe—a beacon of redemption for the gaming industry.

Now is the perfect time to dive in and rediscover No Man's Sky, a genuine journey that transcends the stars. Immerse yourself in innovation, resilience, and a captivating experience that goes beyond expectations. Plus if you think $60 is just too much, almost every sale, No Mans Sky drops to a much cheaper $30.

-- Much Thanks to Mr.Chat for the inspiration

The game had the worst, shittiest launch for a highly anticipated game that I can think of (yep, including Cyberpunk 2077 in that list). 

However, the game has grown and changed in so many positive ways since then and the developers have poured so much time and effort into building goodwill and regaining their reputation. I couldn't sit by and watch the overall review stay at Mixed. I know this one review will doubtfully alter the overall, but maybe it will change your opinion.

I have spent over 200 hours in the game, with most of that time being after the major updates that have released. Yet, around 26 hours were from the early days--the Dark Ages of NMS, you might say. 

I stuck it out for a couple of reasons:
 [*] I wanted a space sim without supporting Elite Dangerous or Star Citizen.
 [*] I saw the potential in the game beyond the shit storm.
 [*] It also had the bones of a good experience.

My time could've ended there, remembering the game as an over-promised skeleton. Luckily, somehow, the developers have continued pouring resources into the game so that those bones now have muscles, veins, flesh, and even a heart and brain. You're not getting a mindless slog from planet to planet with a dozen variant creatures and plants; you're now getting a space exploration sim with a robust base-building sim within a massive universe full of unique creatures, planets and atmospheres, optionally centered around a Destiny-like hub where you can meet with other players, start planet-spanning missions, and grow your base/arsenal.

The game that was promised now is.
[h1] S P A C E [/h1]

I never played this on launch but of course I knew about the hype and the subsequent disappointment.  Well I am here to tell you to forget about all that.  NMS today is an absolutely fantastic game.  The sheer amount of content is staggering.  Want to build really really complex bases?  Check.  Want to build them underwater?  Check.  Want to be the owner of a huge space freighter that you can build a base inside of and go on expeditions with?  Check.  Want to team up with other players and go on missions?  Check.  Want to build several kinds of vehicles, a racetrack and then race them on alien planets?  Check.  Some of the updates are almost like devs realizing their childhood dreams/memories in the game.  It is important that you know that a lot of the game is about grinding materials and/or looking for that one special tool/ship you want by hopping to many many stations.  It will not be for everyone, but it will probably appeal to any MMO player or, dare I say it, anyone that liked Fallout 4 and everyone with a sense of adventure/exploration.  My final thought would be this:  Imagine turning the clock back 5 years, and the game of today released back then.  Here is what I think would have happened.  The whole gaming world would have been stunned.  The game would have gotten 10/10 reviews from every critic in sight and guaranteed "Overwhelmingly Positive" from players here on Steam.  It would have won every award there is to win and would have been lauded as one of the greatest gaming achievements ever.  You would want to play a game like that, right?  Well you can.  Unlike most AAA gaming experiences of today, No Man's Sky is worth every cent, a 100 times over. UPDATE: 1000+ hours and it is even more a labour of love than before.  Forget Starfield, just play NMS.

No Man's Sky was launched in a rough state very glitchy and very little content and replayabilty.
Since the launch this game has come leaps and bounds adding a immeasurable amount of content and fixes for various bugs.
I very much enjoy this game and have been recently. All my time in NMS has been spent in one single save. I have found the best way to play the game is to set your own goals once you have completed the main story and some key side quests as this allows you to unlock the basic things in the game that make it pretty easy to improve you 'economic position.' Some of my own goals that I have set is getting a fully fleshed out fleet and a pretty nice looking base and freighter if I might add. In addition I have made it my mission to collect some damn nice looking ships and an excessive amount of units (money).

The main pros of the game is the amount of things you can do outside of the main and even side quests, with a little imagination of course. Also there is a fair bit of questing you can do. The game is much more stable then it was back in 2016. The graphics are amazing and well optimised enough where it can run on lower spec machines. The game can also be played in different game modes like a 'normal mode', a 'survival mode' and a 'permadeath mode' as well as a 'creative mode' where you can basically do whatever you want.

The main cons of the game is there are still some lurking bugs, such as randomly falling through the ground, although very rare. Another issue is for me personally random frame drops or lag (this could be an isolated problem). There is (arguably) not enough to do. I say this because I have spent most of my time doing what I want to do and not main quests. The game can feel quite slow and the combat is not anything new or special.

Overall, I would recommend NMS to anyone who has played any sort of RPG/Survival/Sandbox game before like Minecraft, Skyrim or Fallout etc. This game also requires a bit of imagination if you want to do very much past the main quests. To conclude NMS is a very fleshed out game than it once was but still has some lurking issues and isn't for everyone.
Thanks for reading if you made it this far.

Note: This game does have a VR mode that I have not yet played on Steam.
Another note: Feel free to ask any questions! : )

First of all this game has a lot of controvercy. While the devs undoubtebly released it too soon, people should stop bitching about it towards the dev team per se, people tend to forget about stuff like investors that want a return & dev teams are often given deadlines.

While the game is maybe not quite up to 60$ standards there's no doubt that it very likely will get there in the near future.

For the people that say it's repetitive (and 99% of the people saying so don't even have 5hrs on the game) I can only say you haven't looked properly because I have now played almost 8 hours and not a single planet that I've visited has been the same & the animal species have been so oddly different that it's hilarious (sausage birds ftw >.< ).
On top of which they've already announced a patch to add more variation in the algoritm for creating worlds.

The second issue people land on is the fact that they can't even play it because it crashes or runs horrible. Watching most of the people say this with less than 20min spent in the game sort of tells me they're not really trying and are just impatient to get on the hatetrain. I have a rig that was top notch 4 years ago and my game runs fine on max settings (except shadows, cause fuck shadows).

TLDR: While the game might not quite be on the list for most people right now I would 100% keep an eye on it because i'm sure it will turn out amazing yet.

[h1] What a comeback	[/h1]

Almost 2 years ago after the disastrous launch I played the game for ~20 hours. After that I gave the previous updates a fair chance and I could tell just from the first big update, 1.1 a.k.a "Foundation" that Hello Games genuinely wanted to fulfill what was once promised.

You can say whatever you want about the lies that came out the mouth of Sean Murray, but you can't deny the fact that he and the small collective of people over at Hello Games literally worked their socks off to deliver NEXT and all 3 of the updates leading up to it for us to play.

[b] Without. Demanding. A. Single. Penny.	[/b]

Sure they owed it to us, to give us these updates for free and I 100% agree with that. But Sean and his team could've just taken our money and ran out the back door with it.
[u] But they didn't.	[/u]

Thank you Hello Games, for not giving up on what in many people's eyes was seen as a dead horse.

I think Hello Games has definitely redeemed themselves with the constant updates, but man do I wish this game had a sliver of polish to it.

Bugs run extremely rampant, from sentinel waves in multiplayer down to main story mission wavepoints just.... not working. The amount of bugs present in current build is too much I didn't know where to start with reporting them. There was a time I had to take a break because of how annoying base building bugs were when parts of my base would just DISAPPEAR.

One other criticism that I have with NMS is that Hello Games has their hands in a lot of cookie jars (those jars being features to the game) with absolutely no depth to any of them. Combat is about as deep as a 1 inch pond, and it gets boring reallllyyyy fast fighting sentinels over....and over....and over. Exocrafts are all pretty much the same except for the Minotaur, as well as the Nautiloid, ALSO both riddled with bugs that make you hesitant to use them. Quests at the space station are sooooo repetitive it makes me not want to pick any of them, and the level difference of the quests mean pretty much nothing.

I think No Man Sky is heading towards a great direction at this pace if HG keeps up with these updates that keep adding content, but please I beg of you, expand on the systems and functions you already have within the game. AND FOR GODS SAKE FIX GAME BREAKING BUGS, IM TIRED OF SPAWNING IN SPACE AND DYING.

I had pirated this game when it first came out because I was broke and curious, and at the time, it was worth what I paid.

Fast forward to now. I bought it about two years ago on sale and it was worth far more than the game at full price. I've sunk so much time into this game, both on Steam and on my Switch. 

What really pulled me back was how much HG expanded the game--and it's become massive. When I first played it, it was at best an inventory management walking sim. Now there's multiple stories, deep lore, fleets, pets, the Nexus, existential questions, capitalism, big ass freighters, frequent events and expeditions, and HG keeps updating and adding more content for free. I still wouldn't call it perfect but it's the game I want to play when I don't feel like playing games. Easy to shut off my brain for a while and explore the cosmos. HG really turned things around and it deserves the love it's now getting.

[quote]rawWwRrr's raTiNg: 🟩 🟩 🟩 🟩 ⬛ = ❤️[/quote]

Below you will find my original reviews from back when the game first launched. I was quite critical of the game's performance and content vs it's price. I've left it all intact below. 

Hello Games, whether due to a moral compass or as part of it's business strategy, has never let up on NMS. Once they tackled the bulk of the bugs from launch, they have added more and more to the game. Every few months there is a new content update, and never as DLC to buy or add. All the new content is released free already baked into the base game. They've been doing for the last six years and there is no sign that they plan on stopping yet.

So when you look at the Store and see that the game is still regularly priced at $60, on sale at $30, after 6 years, now you know why. It hasn't been like an Origin or EA title with a few updates or tons of paid DLC. 

If you want a space exploration game that can offer hours of enjoyment, NMS has a ton of it. Some of it the NMS community gets controversial about. And there is still an occasional glitch to the game. 

This is one of the few games where I'd say it's worth it even at full price. Having said that, I'm far overdue in flipping this review from negative to positive. I've nominated this in to Steam's game awards for Labor Of Love for a couple of years now. It's about time that my review reflects that.

-- rawWwRrr

[quote][b][u]OG August 14, 2016 Review:[/u][/b]

tl;dr: For $60, It's.... too unstable. Wait for an update.

I don't really want to recommend yes or no, but I have to go with 'no' in hopes of bringing about some improvements sooner than later. I am experiecing just about what everyone else has been talking about: 

* Frame drops
* Hitching
* Soft crashes (can still reboot with reboot switch)
* Hard crashes (can't reboot, must shutdown through power switch)

I did finally get a decent few hours of play time but only after I downgraded the graphics to all low, removed any post-processing, etc. And that still didn't solve any problems other than delaying the inevitable crash. 

The flight controls are funky but you get used to them after a bit. The worlds are pretty cool. I was able to jump around between two planets and a moon with a space station inbetween. The game is actually a lot of fun, but we need some updates to the engine so that it works better on the PC.

It was too frustrating having to repeat lost progress in the beginning. [spoiler]You have to fix your ship before you can really begin exploring the planet. The only way to save the game at this point is to enter the ship, then exit. Upon exiting, a save point is made. Once the ship is repaired and powered up, you can save the game progress at the outposts and whatnot scattered across the planet. So if you find yourself having to walk a long distance for a resource, make sure you can get back to the ship in time before the game crashes. [/spoiler]

I'm sorry, Hello Games. For now, it's not worth $60.

[b][u]OG August 21, 2016 Review Update:[/u][/b]

Update: I've since been on the experimental build and it's very much improved. I've got all the graphics settings maxed out at 1080p except for Anti-Aliasing. That is set to FXAA as Ultra SSAAx4 was causing huge FPS drops, which is understandable. I have even re-enabled the Steam Overlay. So far so good, many more hours of exploring and minimal crashes. 

There are a couple of bugs. Once I found myself falling off of a high platform after launching the game. I had exited the game while standing on it and clipped right through it when going back into it. I also had a moment where the reticle on the ship was off-center. Photo cannon would shoot towards the reticle but the phasers would shoot straight ahead. It wasn't until I warped out to a different system that it reset the alignment to dead ahead. 

The one thing I would really like to see improved upon is the hijacking of the UI during events and achievements. The screen letterboxes and temporarily removes many of the things you can do during the sequence. It really slows the pace of the game down and can cause some issues with hostiles while you're kind of frozen in place waiting for the game to allow you to continue. 

Another UI issue I find aggravating is how equipment slots can extend beyond the viewable screen, for instance when comparing ships or multi-tools. I often can't see the far left or right slots to get an informed decision about the entire object.

Lastly, the click-and-hold stategy to navigating the menus and configuration screens needs to be eliminated. It has a functionality to allow someone to stop just before making a mistake, or changing their mind, but anything in the Escape menus should be simple point and click. Save the click-and-hold to the gameplay.

That's about all I can think of right now. So far I've stumbled upon some ship-to-ship battles, took part in one, stumbled across some more interesting planets, and found a black hole. It's definitely a game with a lot to find. If it could clean up the UI a bit more, I wouldn't mind flipping my thumb from down to up.[/quote]

Decent singleplayer game if you're into it, but unfortunately the multiplayer is quite lacking. There's no real shared base building (instead, you can only help build another player's base, but can't [properly] access it while they're offline), and I've experienced (or have friends who experienced) sync issues and other unpleasantries while playing.
I understand if the developers don't want to deal with storing and hosting tons of player saves, but it should at least be possible to implement dedicated servers that you can host yourself, which allow shared base building and a proper, stable multiplayer experience.

All this is quite unfortunate, because the singleplayer sadly quickly became boring for me. The story isn't all too captivating from what I've seen so far, exploring and collecting resources can get "grindy" quite fast, and if I've got nobody to share my creations with, I'm not all too motivated to spend lots of time building a sick base (especially since the building, while ok, isn't world-class either).
In the end, because my friends didn't want to put up with the limitations of multiplayer, I ended up not really playing anymore. It's still a good game, and the developers are putting in quite a lot of effort even long after launch, so in general I can recommend it - just not if you want to play it for the multiplayer aspect.

When the game first came out, I heard all the negative stuff about it and how much it was hated. I was really sad since I really love exploration games a lot and especially space exploration games, so to hear how this game was awful, a scam and a lot of other negative things, it really saddened me as I thought this would be the perfect exploration game that I would love, and so then I forgot about it. Until last year.

A friend of mine started playing the game and told me how its good now and its fun and that I should get it. Curious I checked it out and see how many people love it now and how its really good. And so I had a few dollars to spend on steam, and so I bought the game. And I will never regret that decision!

The game at its core is very simple. Go around planets and find resources, find some things, trade, get new ships and a few other small stuff. Yes you can say that's all the game offers and a few more things you can do, but that's not what its about. Its about exploration, find new planets, find a new planet to call home even! The whole point of the game is to simulate a solo experience on exploring an entire galaxy while doing many other things along the way! The game is a beautiful one with every planet being unique. Now yes the planet types are all going to be similar or the same, and you might see a few of the same plants or animals, but that's alright! It doesn't really bother me at all but I know it does for others.

All the planets you visit are beautiful. Exploring them is always so fun and especially when its night time, just looking at the night sky and seeing the other planets in the distance just calms me and relaxes me and just, its breathtaking, that's all I can say.

To those that still think this game is horrible, a scam, worst game ever. First play it yourself and then you can decide on what the game is, as just saying what it is without ever playing it is just not fair.
Better than ever.

2021 edit:
The development team at Hello Games has demonstrated a commendable commitment to improving their latest title. Through a series of updates and patches, they have addressed many of the issues that were present in the initial release of the game. Furthermore, the addition of new features and continued support from the developer has greatly enhanced the overall gaming experience.

Based on the current state of the game, I am confident in recommending it to others. It is evident that the development team is dedicated to providing players with the best possible experience and that they take player feedback seriously.

Review at release:
As a fan of the gaming industry, I was highly anticipating the release of this particular title. The initial marketing and promotional materials, as well as statements from the developer, suggested that it would be a revolutionary and highly immersive experience.

However, upon playing the game, I was disappointed to find that several key features were absent or underdeveloped. The lack of factions and limitations in the gameplay, such as the inability to land on asteroids and participate in space battles, were major letdowns. Additionally, many elements that were promised in promotional materials, such as the diverse and exotic wildlife, were not present in the final version of the game.

In light of these issues, I would advise caution when considering purchasing this game. While the developer, Hello Games, has made efforts to improve the game and add new features, it still falls short of many of the promises made in the initial marketing campaign. It is worth noting that the game was, in my opinion, overhyped by its developer, Sean Murray, and I would advise to exercise caution when considering purchasing this game.

I've been playing this game on and off since launch way back when, and I thought it was time for a review. 

NMS has most definitely come a long, long way from what it was in 2016. I had pre-ordered for PS4, played on launch day, played like mad to reach the center of the galaxy and... yeah, what a shame.

Later on, I built a PC and kept an eye on the PC release, same song and dance, then the updates came and the game started to go on sale. "I think I need to give this another shot." I said to myself, and I'm really glad I did. The game still has its flaws and bugs, but if you're new to this game or thinking about grabbing it, this is probably the best time to play it (after you get it on sale, naturally). It has way more to offer now and feels like a completely different game compared to what it used to be.

QOL tweaks and starting out was incredibly streamlined and simplified. On launch you'd be grinding materials for hours and trying to navigate menus and figure what you were even supposed to be doing in order to just get off the rock you started on (and it was/still is usually a hazardous planet that forced you to rush around and take cover so you don't die to the elements). Currently, you get a bit more hand-holding and direction so you can get started, and once the universe opens up to you and your starship, it's an incredible feeling. 

Exploring each system, scanning the planets, interacting with the aliens, finding new ships, building your own bases, uncovering the story and finding weird things-- it's just so cool once you start to see how ambitious the game is and what it lets you do in the universe. At 200+ hours, I am still finding some new things, and the recent updates have just been adding more. You can play in a variety of ways and take on the story-lines at your leisure, wander around the galaxy, work the trade markets, be a pirate, etc. The game gives you a good amount of options to make money and I think it can appeal to a lot of different play-styles. 

The game isn't perfect, however. I'm still seeing bugs and issues I would assume should have been fixed since launch. I sometimes still clip through planets and space stations, suspended in limbo until I reload a save. Planets, while there are a few dozen different types to discover, become a 'once you see one, you've seen them all' type of experience. For example, every type of cold, hot, toxic, etc. type of planet will literally have the same style of plants, animals, and overall look and feel to them, with the only variety being how bumpy they are, or having one or two unique features like resource nodes and rock formations. The planet climate and features are also the same no matter where you are on it (i.e., North/South poles, equator aren't any different/ landscapes do not change dramatically). 

I know it's a procedural game, and I can't speak to how difficult implementing climate zones or terrain changes would be, but you don't have much reason to explore a planet for more than a few minutes unless you are looking for materials/wildlife, building a base, or working on missions. I find it really strange that a game focused on nearly infinite exploration would have that aspect be its absolute weakest point. I will say that for me, it took quite a while of playtime to start feeling this way, but I have still been having a great time playing the game to see what else the game can generate in terms of starship, creature, and planet variety. The recent additions like the Multiplayer hub, exocraft, customization, random interactions, and freighters has really made certain aspects of the game fun and fresh again. 

I could go on and on, but my thoughts in summation? Watch some streamers play to see if it's your type of thing, take a look at the Internet Historian video, get the game on sale, and understand the game is still a quirky indie game and very much an open sandbox to play in-- but still improving and getting better and better with each update.

Played since launch and - while it did get very boring an repetitive after 40 - 50 hours - I enjoyed my time with it.  The first couple of major updates improved the game in certain ways and I'd always fire them up for a few hours.

Ultimately what killed NMS for me was the samey-ness; all the planets, animals, plants, ships, started to look the same.  I had seen it all and the wonders of the 'infinite universe' wore off.  I was happy with my 60 or so hours in the game and felt I'd gotten my moneys worth.

But now Hello Games have just dropped what essentially feels like NMS 2 as a free update.  Take if from someone who played the game to death at launch - this update is fantastic.  Explorations is back and planets feel fresh again; there is now massive vistas, mountains that touch the clouds and caverns that run for miles and hide secrets.  But on top of that the core game has had a complete overhaul, there is literally hundreds of things to do - beside the main story missions - and the new crafting, base building and character creation is a great addition.

November 2018 and the game keeps getting better...

Open your eyes wanderer, your journey awaits. Once you've repaired your first ship, you are free to explore as you wish, fly through the atmosphere to explore, or just head out to the void. See a neat ringed planet in the distance? Point your ship and go, you see it, you can fly to it. Build a base on some sweet paradise you just found, or a barren rock, or purchase a freighter and have a mobile base you can call into orbit, or do it all, a portal system will allow you to return to your base(s) from wherever. There's even main quest lines and mystery destinations to help you progress, but totally optional. Just don't come looking for story time, it's a forge your own adventure kinda thing.

I literally cannot explain how good this is, it is simply a masterpiece.

I think it's easy to get lost in the game and find yourself going in several directions -- it can be overwhelming. There's lots to do, but at times it can feel a little bit hollow or cookie-cutter. I wish there were more meaningful stories to pursue in the game? I'm also a little bit bummed that it seems that I started playing the game way too late and can't access any of the expeditions? Maybe there's some story content there or some more unique things to see. I've played ~40 hours of the game and it seems like I'm sort of in infinite fetch quest mode? Another thing that is a bit jarring is when you're flying through a planet, you see the the procedural generation take place and pop things into existence in front of you. I'm playing the game on ultra settings, so I'd hope that the draw/procedural planetary tile generation distance was a bit higher. It would make the game a lot more immersive.

First off, i really wish there was a meh button as far as recommending the game goes.

So i was really jonesing for a space game about oh... 30-40 hrs of gameplay ago. So i booted up elite dangerous, but things took too long and it didn't run the best on my steam deck. Then i remembered i have no man's sky.

I hadn't played since the NEXT update i believe. So i see it's verified on the deck and install it.

Performance is not great, lots of stuttering and dipping down into the mid 20s if you travel to far too quickly on planets. Otherwise a pretty respectable 40. (some of the performance issues are my fault, it defaults to standard but i wanted a few things to be higher quality so i bumped textures and planet quality up.)

Tutorial still sucks and i wish it would go die in a fire. I don't know how many players that tutorial has cost em but i bet it's up there.

BUT once you get going it becomes a pretty relaxing and...enjoyable? experience.

I wouldn't say i'm ever having a blast but i'm not not having fun, if that makes sense.

It's a bit too grindy and after awhile the planets and creatures on them start to feel samey. Awhile in this case being 10ish hrs.

Oh also, this game is an assault on your ear drums. UNITS RECIEVED UNITS RECIEVED. I GET IT THEY"RE RECIEVED!

That and the game never freaking relaxes on the mission front. Sometimes i just want to fly around and do my own thing but that pesky pop up keeps rearing its ugly head and i feel like i HAVE to go do it.

Also, most of the mechanics are still pretty shallow. If you've done something once you've basically seen all there is to see.


So i get that that seems like a LOT of gripes but, it's seven years later and few games manage to do what this one does. Sure there's a few like elite or starfield i guess (I wouldn't know, i'm on a bethesda boycott.) but that's really it as far as space sims go. 

There's nothing quite like flying into space, traveling the unknown galaxy, finding a planet you like and completely destroying it in the name of progress.

I guess if i had to sum it up.

No man's sky is a game. Play it before bed or after work to while away a few hrs and relax. If you're looking for depth, look elsewhere.
Incredible game, well worth the money. I see myself sinking an untenable amount of hours into this game...

No Man's Sky is the gift that'll keep on giving as long as Hello Games continues to support it, not to discount their work in updating it to a brilliant little space sim. 

After a bad launch and almost a year of silence from the devs. this barren and often just ugly game became Minecraft in space, and unlike Mojang, has supplied it with nearly yearly meaningful updates since. the result is a decent economic simulation game, a solid Minecraft clone, a space MMO with drop-in, drop-out mechanics, and a totally competent singleplayer adventure, all while also containing an uncompromising VR experience. Nothing is removed from its VR experience.

NMS is one of the few examples too of games that are actually good investments. its legit gone beyond what the devs promised, even taking into its notorious launch state. Not only has it been worth its full price for some time now, i expect it to continually get even better.

The inventory management is the worst rubbish I've seen in a game like this.  It's unintuitive and overly complicated   You can't even directly compare items like installed upgrades.  Some items can be dragged to a new location while other need extra keypad strokes.   It's ridiculous.   I had to find out for myself outside the game.   Many info page links have different keys for similar actions like Q&E or A&D.  Why not have them all the same ??  In a huge game like this inventory management should be easy, not a learning curve itself.
Great game with an insane amount of content with free DLC being released consistently. Any fan of science-fiction or exploration should get this game immediately.

I did play starfield, but as every single defender of this game points out: 
"it's another kind of game" so i will not compare it to it

After like a million updates, game feels just as it did when i first bought it.

Planets still look and feel the same as they did in v1, combat feels the same, enemies feel the same, ships feel the same, AI of everything is still a joke, PG animals still look goofy AF. Still no giant animals like in that famous trailer. Space combat feels the same. Exploration feels the same.

Really wish they'd implemented any type of combat or something else than "mining" the now slightly different combat drones. and i'm not talking about turning the mining gun into every other gun (If you've ever played you know all these are useless except for the grenade launcher and regular rifle), i'm talking any semblance of a fight in this game devolves into: run for cover or create cover which will fuck up the AI and give you the "i'm stupid, please kill me" advantage, hide and shoot from cover, kill everything without getting a single scratch, repeat. Never heal, reload is always the same, why would you ever dogde or run if you can just create a whole fucking sniper's dream nest

It will get boring, really, really fast if you are on your own, as it's stands there's no PVP or PVE that's worth anyone's time, progression is mining the same shit forever just as it was in v1, same as money making. Getting a good ship is just 20 minutes away from grinding the same planets over and over again and selling it for 60 Mill. What you think GOLD will make you money? go dig up some bone, now that's the stuff that they want. That's the stuff that they've always wanted, since it's implementation.

There's no sense of danger even in hardcore, iron man runs, nothing to be obtained from the "lore" or quests. No presence will ever scare you or excite you, NPCs are as brainless as everything else, including story NPCs.

Planets feel bland, not empty, they are full of generic stuff for sure, but it's all so bland and "SAFE" that you can leave your character just standing there to go take a shit and come back and nothing will EVER happen to you. Every creature is your friend and is there mindlessly doing their biz. I've seen enemy creatures, but it's also the same type of creature in every planet, and only activates if you rob their eggs or mine around their territory, again sniper nest + grenade launcher, create your little floating island and kill every thing.

The only excitement i've ever gotten was seeing a giant worm leap in front of me. All the more disappointing when you find out, it can't actually crush you or your buildings.

Trust me i searched for the fun in this game, and it was just not there maaan.

I approached No Man's Sky with a sense of cautious optimism, armed with the knowledge that the Echo Update was a far cry from the infamous disaster that surrounded the game's initial release. And boy, was I pleasantly surprised.

One of the most striking aspects of No Man's Sky lies in the sheer immensity of its world. Spanning billions upon billions of procedurally generated planets, this game offers an almost limitless playground for exploration and discovery. What once seemed like an insurmountable task of endless repetition in the past has now transformed into a mesmerizing journey of unforeseen surprises.

The beauty of No Man's Sky lies in its ability to instill a sense of awe as you venture forth into the unknown. Time and time again, I found myself stumbling upon planets that defied my expectations, with stunning landscapes, unique creatures, and uncharted resources waiting to be claimed. The sheer joy of uncovering something that deviates from the world's original blueprint is truly an experience like no other.

The ability to build and customize your own base is where No Man's Sky truly shines. The freedom to establish your abode on a planet of your choosing, meticulously selecting the perfect site to suityour needs and aesthetic preferences, is a gratifying process. From carefully constructing each component to designing the layout, the base-building aspect of the game is a welcome respite from the hustle and bustle of intergalactic travel. It adds a personal touch to your journey and truly makes you feel invested in the world you inhabit.

While the game's missions may not be its strongest suit, they still provide ample opportunities for engaging gameplay and progression. Whether you're embarking on a perilous quest to rescue a stranded creature or simply exploring ancient ruins for valuable artifacts, the missions offer a sense of direction amidst the vastness of the universe. And although they may not be the main focus, they contribute significantly to the game's overall sense of replayability.

In conclusion, No Man's Sky with the Echo Update showcases the immense world it promised to deliver, and then some. The size and scope of the game are truly awe-inspiring, providing endless opportunities for discovery and adventure.
Seamless, fun and makes you want to keep coming back to explore more.

[h2]
Review:
[/h2]

The beginning of the game is a lot of fun. You find yourself in a strange world and have to find out why, for what reason and where you are. But after you have gone into space and visited some systems, you lose the thread. The main story gets lost in unimportant side quests, and even if you try to follow it you won't find any real sense in the main story. Here I think the story should be further developed and emphasized more. I think it's good that you don't have to follow the main story, but if you have a main story, it could be filled with more action, because the game itself already has all the features for that. (Or I'm not deep enough in the main story yet, because I don't really find it)

Another point that I often find disturbing is the grind. Usually the gameplay consists of: Fly to this planet. Mine this stuff. Inventory full. Thrusters empty. Mine the cloth to charge the engines. Fly to another planet... The grinding itself wouldn't really bother me, if you could search for minerals from the spaceship while hovering over the planet, or with the scanner of the multitool. Something like it is used in the game "Subnautica" would be interesting, where you can scan for only one specific substance.

A last point would be that I would not recommend changing the application while playing the game, because the game will crash. That's why I think it would be nice if Hello Games would intrduce autosave for every like 5min so that you can walk around without a Beacon on hand or spaceship nearby without fearing to lose the progress made in the last 20 min.

No Man's Sky has a vision that it brings you along with, one of constant discovery in a very romantic ideal of what 'space' is. Some people will get bored after visiting their second system while some people will find themselves constantly coming back for more because there isn't anything quite like it. A space-sim this is not, and maybe it'd be better to call it a charming and cozy sci-fi sandbox.

Great game for just relaxing, listening to podcasts/music, and exploring a virtually unlimited number of new worlds to find the perfect one for a base. There's a satisfaction that comes from getting better upgrades and slowly unlocking more and more blueprints as the list of discovered star systems, planets, flora, fauna, and minerals grows ever larger. While this is a relatively easy game overall--after the first couple hours you'll rarely want for much in the way of survival so much as space to store everything--I would argue that the charm lies in just how freeform the experience is. Whether it's building a seabase and exploring the vast oceans on one planet or adopting a giant mushroom creature as a makeshift pet/vehicle on another, there's always more to see and find. When it all feels like it has become too familiar, just abandon everything and hop into a black hole to get a fresh start somewhere else in the universe. Or hell, just make a new character. The early to mid game power growth actually makes starting new characters fun and the difficulty options can be individually tweaked to your liking making each playthrough feel potentially different.

Basically, this is a great game for those who are craving an experience which prioritizes the joy of exploration. It's always getting better (and definitely still has room to grow) and really just does a great job at making the player feel like an explorer venturing onto uncharted planets and surveying them properly for the first time. There may be the occasional generated outpost here and there, but it truly does feel like (and chances are very strong) the player is the very first to see the places they come across. The only other comparison I can make with this game would be like if a company looked at the idea of the uncharted worlds from Mass Effect 1 and thought to greatly expand upon it and make an entire game out of it. While there are often similarities in the vastness of what can be discovered, the sheer joy of exploration itself is what the point is and that means that No Man's Sky scratches a certain itch that few other games do and it does it pretty well.
