I love it.

while nms has definitely made a comeback and a half it's still no masterpiece. it still suffers from treating shallow procedurally generated content like it's all unique and stretching it over dozens of hours of gameplay. however, the only reason i just wrote all that was because i just got off from playing it for 91 hours. for the first 80 of them there was lots of new mechanics to discover, things to work towards, and worldbuilding to explore.

i love how nms's universe has enough sci fi tropes and realism to be familiar and make just as much sense to new players as lore-experts while also not letting real life technicalities such as life not being on every planet or celestial bodies being very far apart stop it from being unique.

the story is amazing and I was very intrigued by it's themes of surreality and self-questioning. but i was surprised by how right as these themes started to fully set in for me and the direction in which i thought the story was going to go became clear, it took a fast turn in order to abruptly end.

the use of strange visions and hallucinations wouldve been by far my favorite part of the story and exploration gameplay if they actually happened instead if being described like im reading a book or some nerd stuff like that. of course this isnt because of laziness, but because hello games is an indie developer and just couldnt afford to make a cinematic animated cutscene for each of them. making this yet another example of how this game sometimes feels like a proof of concept.

ironically, despite how surreal the game is, the space combat is exactly what i would imagine a space dogfight would be in real life. and while the game isnt as combat based as i thought it was going to be (and this is for the better) the occasional space battles were really fun and its a shame i dont see them mentioned in other reviews because of the focus of the gameplay being exploration.

even though collecting items from randomly generated structures by going to a waypoint on your UI seems terrible on paper, the aforementioned story and worldbuilding as well as how good the game's environments look encoraged me to do things like scan the same model of a rock 7 times on different planets, or learn languages i dont actually need to know because for some reason the game explains what the aliens are talking about after you read all their gibberish. so even though im against games whose main selling point is that theyre fun to look at, im all for games that can convince me that im living someone else's life (figuratively of course).

the only reason im not om my way to log another 100 hours on this game is because all of the gameplay aspects in some way revolve around resource gathering, which is by far the least fun thing you do in this game. in other procedurally generated open world games like minecraft or terraria resource gathering is made fun by consistently putting obstacles in the player's way, so that each time you go to mine iron it's a little adventure. in no mans sky, even with all of the difficulty settings cranked all the way up any obstacles can be easily exploited, have to be dealt with by waiting them out, or just arent there.

at first i thought the sentinels played this role because they attack you if you mine and you had to kill them to gather resources, but instead if you try to fight the sentinels they will endlessly come at you until you die or learn that you will always have to resort to hiding instead of having engaging gameplay. because of all that after 91 hours playing the game becomes a chore because you have to go through all that not-having-fun bull crap before you can have fun for a little bit.

i was willing to put up with this for 91 hours though because not too much grinding was necessary to have fun until now, and i dont feel like getting the best equipment will be worth it because whether your ship is the old and busted radiant pillar or the exotic new hotness they all operate the same.

nms still has some of the aura of overambition and missed potential around it since 2016 preventing it from being the true masterpiece it is supposed to be. as dunkey, the guy who ive based my entire personality on said "those first 2 hours were just amazing", nowdays that threshold has increased to exactly 91.4 hours. which is probably alot more than the average person plays an individual game.

I remember playing this game back before many of the major updates (on console) and I did sincerely enjoy it then. Now with all the updates, there's so much more to do and it's much more multiplayer friendly, without forcing it onto you as well.

Pros:
- Optional multiplayer, including missions you can pick up.
- Lot's of beautiful scenery.
- Easy to get the hang of.
- Can focus on base building and/or exploring.
- Creature taming. Haven't tried it yet, but it's a thing.
- (Nearly) complete terrain destructibility. Sadly you can't drill down to the planet's core, but you can destroy quite a bit of terrain. Maybe one day they'll allow you to destroy planets, but I guess that would be putting too much power into player's hands.
- Upgrading equipment. You can upgrade your tool or ship from rank C all the way to S if you're patient enough to farm what's needed. (Don't know about freighters yet)
- Steam Deck compatible.
- No micro transactions.
- Seriously, no micro transactions.

Cons:
- Repetitive fauna. While you will definitely encounter a large variety of creatures, once you travel to multiple planets, things begin to get very repetitive. It does make finding truly unique creatures more satisfying though.
- The grind. It's not that bad for minerals and the likes, but for quicksilver, you (as far as I'm aware) can only do 2 missions to earn it a day. The average reward I've seen is 400 and with so many items at 3000, it's a tad annoying.
- You cannot customise your ship's appearance.
- What is inventory space? If you want to get into the construction part of the game, be prepared to have no inventory space.
- Scan away from target. I encounter a lot of issues where there are multiple mission based scan targets and it will prioritise further ones to lead you to sometimes. I've been sent 20 minutes out from my ship once only to return to it on foot and find one not even a minute away from my ship because the scanner didn't tell me about that one.
- No cross platform play with Switch. I've seen many articles stating it has cross platform play with all consoles including switch, so I got it for my friend only to find out that the "cross platform" with switch is limited to base sharing. It was very disappointingly misleading articles and I should have done closer research, but of course google brings all the misinformation to the top. (This con only matters if you plan on getting it for a friend on switch or getting it to play with someone on switch)
- Let me destroy worlds!

Despite its cons, I still do greatly enjoy playing the game. It's a great pass time and I'm sure it'll be even more fun to play once I can get to play with my friend. It is very repetitive, but it still has its charm that I keep coming back to. Plus I hope to one day find that perfect alien life form to adopt as a pet. I wonder if I can create an invasive species problem on another planet.

Decided to try the game because I enjoyed Starfield but ran out of content in Starfield. Far superior game to Starfield. Excellent story-telling and background lore.
Excellent crafting and itemisation.
Good ground combat.
Good exploration (as good as is possible for endless procedural generated content)
A Multitude of engage-able side-hustles which remain relevant to game-play until (I assume) the very late game.
Passable space combat - the only real problem being that when using auto-tracking to chase pirates, the auto-tracker doesn't actually aim at enemies correctly for some weapons.

Firstly, I have to say these guys deserve their awards, this is an immersive game. But, and this is a huge but, lately the crashes have been so overwhelming that they have destroyed any enjoyment I get from it. They are either random or excruciatingly persistent. I can on one saved game just crash out immediately every time, or be at the end of a mission (that you cannot save) and get to the anomaly then CRASH!, of course with no save point that is 1 and a half hours just wasted for nothing. 2 bug reports sent to support but nothing over about a week and a half. Honestly, I've had enough but I guess I had my money's worth out of it. I may return to it some time but for me the game has become far too annoying. I understand it is a little unfair to give it a thumbs down, I would rather give it a MEH! or neutral vote at this time in the game's life but as I imagine this issue is down to the new 'upgrades' that thumb is pointed in that direction. If you don't have issues it can be an amazing and engrossing game, if you do get problems then have something soft and indestructible to release your frustration on rather than headbutting your expensive keyboard in despair.
UPDATE: 
I came back to the game some time ago and have to say the crashes (touch wood) seem to be a thing of the past. Loading times have become rather painful though, but I can live with that. The 'guys' have been busy bees and done quite a few updates since my original review which is impressive given that there has been no ongoing costs to the players like other games which charge big time for updates and add-ons. All in all the game has matured nicely and is well worth a punt if you haven't played it yet.

No Man's Sky's launch was marred by unmet expectations and a lack of promised features, leaving players disappointed. However, the journey of No Man's Sky since then is nothing short of remarkable. The developers at Hello Games committed themselves to continuous improvement, releasing a series of major updates that have transformed the game into a vastly more fulfilling experience.

The addition of features like multiplayer, base building, and a deeper exploration system has breathed new life into No Man's Sky. The once barren and repetitive planets now boast diverse biomes, flora, and fauna, enhancing the sense of exploration. The revamped graphics and improved user interface contribute to a more polished and visually appealing game.

Frequent updates, such as the Beyond and Origins expansions, have not only addressed the initial shortcomings but have also introduced a plethora of new content and quality-of-life improvements. The community engagement and developer transparency throughout this process have fostered a renewed sense of trust among players.

In its current state, No Man's Sky stands as a testament to the potential for redemption in the gaming industry. While its launch may have left a sour taste, the dedication of the developers to evolve and expand the game has turned it into a worthwhile and immersive experience, proving that sometimes, patience and commitment to improvement can truly pay off.

2023: Decided to play with my friends this time and actually almost liked it... until the godawful stuff started to surface a few days later. I'll just list it to get it out of my system. TL/DR is below the wall of text.

* Devs don't care. Most of the bugs from early 2022 are sill there. Some stuff got worse.
* Terrible console UI.
* "Variety" is a fake. Procedural planet generation does not matter because in the end, it's just the hazard type and flora/fauna visuals. Archeological digs are always the same dig. Crashed freighters are always the same freighter. Planetary POIs are always the same POIs. Pirate fights are always the same routine of "hold autolock and fire". There is a variety of things you can "do", but the "things" themselves are always the same and it gets boring fast. The game is shallow.
* Absolutely abominable galaxy map. ZERO redeeming qualities. Pure garbage. Impossible to tell star colour by looking at the f*****g star colour because the purely decorative "space clouds" change the hue of whatever is in them. And the star colour is actually important in this game. 10/10. Then again, why should it be good? The planets are not meant to be returned to 95% of the time, it’s a “visit and forget” game.
* Achievement vignette screens which wrestle control from you and get you killed. It's been like this since forever, apparently.
* Multiplayer is a lie. You can play "alongside" your friends, but you can not play "with" them. Aside from the random Nexus missions (which are there to let people grind and pass time), quests are not shared, so you cannot progress the story together. You cannot even fight the same enemies most of the time, because only the player who spawned them can see them. Brilliant. Want to take your friend somewhere in your freighter? You cannot. Want to give them your extra ship or weapon as a present? You cannot. Want to visit their settlement which is in a system you haven't been to? You have to trick the game into letting you do this. So technically, you cannot.

TL/DR: This is a CASUAL game which got big, from a small dev team. For all its advertised variety, it's very shallow, restricted, and feels fake. Probably good to play for an hour after work while having a couple of beers, but not much else.

2022: Feels like Spore Galactic Adventures but without the creative element. The interface and crafting system is in dire need of quality of life improvements - playing this for an extended period of time turns into an test of patience. The game makes way too many decisions instead of the player: which inventory window to open, which quest to mark as current, what the base walls should look like, the list goes on - and there is no way of changing this behaviour. Almost feels like No Man's Sky is actively resisting player control, which in my opinion is rather ridiculous in a sandbox game.

Original: With nearly 200 hours played, I can honestly say this is an awesome game. Sadly, it got boring once I beat the storyline. Since then, they've added quite a few updates so I may dive back in and see what they did to extend things. If they are done equally well, this should be fun.

UPDATE: I now have over 700 hours on this game. It has remained one of the best games of this type. Updates are free and I think the devs need some respect for this. In an industry that is constantly trying to gouge players for every penny, NMS has been true to their word about putting out quality updates for free. The game is great and their building of an online community has added a great deal!!
The respect they show for their own games is incredible.Thanks for that

Short story:

If you LOVE crafting, you are going to *like* this game. 80% of the game is resources gathering, 18% is crafting.

If you are looking for a space game, look somewhere else…

To be blunt: This 7 years old technical demo is a joke by today standards, and also as a video game...

Long story:

I played a lot of space games from Tie Fighters to Star Citizen, X3, Elite, just name it… But this one is really bad and is not about space at all.

Distances are very short: planets are tiny, and everything is packed together so you don’t have to wait more than 10 seconds of micro jump to reach your destination on another planet or on the same planet (unless you are on foot).

All planets are habitable, and they look all identical. Oh, yes, that’s true, one is red, the other is blue, one is hot, another is radioactive. Some NPC are round while others are square. Exploration is pointless: If everything looks the same, what is the point? I’d rather visit three planets in unfinished and unstable Star Citizen, than just harvesting forever resources in the million random planets of No Man Sky.

At least, in Star Citizen, there is an atmosphere and personality. Here everything looks cartoonish, the audio is boring, and I don’t feel I am exploring space like I could in Elite or X3.

Wait! There are missions, isn’t it? Oh, yes, if you want to do the 5 exact same mission: kill 10 innocent creatures, deliver a box in a randomly generated place, upgrade your suit by doing exactly the same things over and over. No thank you! Especially with the travel time of maybe 1-minute tops between specific location, it is like solving pointless mission by pressing fast travel button.

What about space combat? Should be cool with custom starships isn’t it? Oh, my: I don’t know how this is supposed to work, but either you try to do it manually, and fight against the controls, either you press an automatic button (I am not joking), and your ship aims automatically to the closest target, so you just have to press fire. Oh! Just got an achievement for killing 10 ships by pressing the auto kill button! I really feel like an ace now!

80% of the time you are harvesting planets, plans and animals by shooting at them. Mining in Eve Online is certainly much more meaningful and rewarding…

Oh, I forgot: What about playing with friends? I believe I haven’t seen in such a long time a game which so many network bugs. Incredible things, not just de-synch objects and quests, but also, my world was shifted by 10 meters compared to what my friend was living… So, as soon as we were in buildings, we could not interact and cooperate to do things properly. I was on one side of a wall, while my friend was on the other side… Good programming for a 7-year-old game!

I tried long enough. After 20 hours or so, I still didn’t see any interesting storyline. NPC are without personality. What is the point of learning a language when you don’t care about what NPCs are saying? At some point I learned enough to know that there are very few dialogs, and everyone is just saying the same boring things, like lobotomized cartoon characters.

I think you got the idea. I tried to have fun with my friend in a well-established universe and game. I wasted my time and money on that one…

Decided to give this game another try after getting quickly bored few years ago.

Game didn't start with my screen resolution and you can't access options from the start menu, and the game froze during world gen...

On my 2nd attempt my game finally loaded and could finally access graphical options to change the game's resolution to a proper one! Why the game doesn't let you do this without starting or loading a save is beyond me.

My spawn was a heavily radioactive planet, but I have managed to find a cave system filled hostile fauna that had sodium and oxygen! This part was actually really fun once I've dealt with the frustration of getting thrown onto a planet with my hazard protection almost instantly reaching 0.

I left the planet thinking the next location I'll need to go to will be a more manageable world, like last time I've played this game. 

No! It's on the same planet I just left! And now there is something new that wasn't last time I've played it! Pirates! And they are camping the location I'm supposed to go to!

Tried few times to fly further away and wait hoping they will go somewhere else, but no! They are still there!

How am I supposed to fight 2 pirates right after I was just told the basics of flying and didn't had any time to get used to it? And I've already have spent too much time at the beginning to just go thought it all again not knowing if the same might happen when I'll leave the planet. 

Didn't learn if the game is more fun now after the updates, but have learned it's more frustrating.
Good game, wish it had a better story.

If you still didn't get this game, just take a look on each 25 updates (even more to come I hope) 

1.1 - Foundation - Base Building, Farming, Freighters, Creative & Survival Modes

1.2 - Pathfinder - Exocraft, Multiple Ships, Ship Specializations & Class System, Online Base Sharing

1.3 - Atlas Rises - Story (Artemis Path), Varied Biomes, Mission System, Trading, Crashed Freighters, Terrain Editing, Portals, Mini Multi-player, Exotic Ships

1.5 - NEXT (Re-Release) - True Multi-player, Community Events, Multiple Bases, Third Person, Character Customization, Frigate Fleets & Expeditions, Refiners, Procedural Tech Upgrades, Space Station Marketplace

1.7 - The Abyss - Underwater Update & Quest-Line (Dreams Of The Deep), Submarine, Underwater Bases, Exocraft Shop

1.75 - Visions - Major Graphical Overhaul, Exotic Biomes, Lush Diversity, Rainbows, Trophies, Archaeology, Scrap, Storm Crystals, Hazardous Flora, Sentient Minerals, Shared Community Mission Progress

2.0 - Beyond - VR Support, Vastly Expanded Multi-player, Anomaly & Nexus, Major Story Overhaul With Improved Tutorials, Ambient Multi-Player (run into random people), Updated Tech Trees, Featured Bases, New NPC Characters, Better NPC Interactions, Creature Riding, Cooking / Feeding / Milking System, Base Power System, Industrial Mining, Sitting Down!

2.2 - Synthesis and Bytebeat - Starship Upgrades, Starship Salvaging, New Terrain Editing System, Protected Terrain Edits, Save Custom Outfits, Starship Interior Space Map, Significant Quality Of Life & Inventory Management Improvements, New Technology Blueprints, Triangular Base Building Parts, 297 Bug Fixes, Base Building Improvements including better Snapping, Storage Containers now have 20 slots instead of 5 & can be renamed, Personal Refiner, Own 3 Multi-Tools
Melody Sequencer, Envelope editor, Waveform editor, BPM/Key/Volume/Attenuation, Drum machine, Arpeggiator, Synchroniser, Link ByteBeats, Use audio to control objects

And the list goes on, the game that launched in 2016 over-promising features, delivered all and even more, to the point of running on PSVR2 and Switch, with crossplay for other platforms as well

The sheer amount of free updates, patches, content and new innovations just keeps channelling new life into the experience. Hello Games are an apparently tireless bunch.

Yes, there are some bugs and yes, it can also get a bit repetitive, but using No Man's Sky as an escape from today's life is cathartic. You can explore at your own pace, searching for that "perfect" home planet and build bases, meet other people in the Anomaly, set up mining bases, and more. Have a look at the community hub and see some of the amazing buildings people have constructed! You can even visit those with listed portal codes.
Truly a work of art. Be prepared for exploration on a scale you've never witnessed before. The crafting is fun as well.

TL;DR If you hate brain-dead build systems and lots of waiting, this game is not for you.

I decided to give this game a second shot after buying it early and quitting after 20 minutes.  I've gotten more than 100 hours in now, and while there is some charm in running through a variety of 3D worlds, the small frustrations have finally done me in again.  Actual 'playing' is broken up by long travel times, unnecessarily slow text display in dialogs, an awful "Let us do the thinking for you" build system, and an economy that is super-easy to game.  In an hour of time I might actually play for 20 minutes.  Add to it a UI that drifts as soon as you move the mouse as if to avoid your clicks, and it's enough to break a seasoned game player.  I can understand why people like it, and if it's on a deep sale I might suggest it, but overall I find it increasingly shallow, tedious, and frustrating to 'play'.
This is not a game, its just a mechanism to render graphic design. There’s fuck all of a story and I regret not getting a refund earlier. Now it’s too late, steam won’t refund.

One of those games where you get addicted and play continuously for days/weeks on end, and then drop it for a few months, then get addicted again when you start back up.

It's honestly a bunch of fun, so much to do and the possibilities are endless. I enjoy jumping from doing missions, to just exploring, to trying to find a cool ship/freighter, to fighting swarms of sentinels, to building nice bases.

If you're able to keep that childhood wonder and sense of exploration, this game will continuously feel fresh and exciting.
great game

No Man's Sky is a game that you should definitely play. It is a game that will make you happy. It is a game that will make you proud. It is a game that will make you say: "This is the best game ever!" No Man's Sky is a game that you will never forget. No Man's Sky is a game that you will always love..
YES. nice.

This game doesn’t need its dozens of shoddy farming, base building, management, and crafting systems, and functions best as the minimalist, dissociative survival road trip it was on its launch day. That original game is still here, sure, with some surprisingly good writing and art direction peppered throughout. Unfortunately it’s also plagued by ugly, paper-thin distractions added years after release, so it’s a difficult recommend.

Many open world games try to be “everything for everyone” but rarely do they hamstring themselves as hard as No Man’s Sky did in the pursuit.

This game is a fine wine, an artisan cheese, a Tennessee whiskey - just gets better with time. Every update address a concern, fills a gap, or offers something you never knew you wanted. You play solid for a while, can walk away, and 100% an update will bring you back before too long.

Edited 2 years and 200 hours of play time later to say my previous review holds true.

"No Man's Sky" is a thrilling adventure set in the vast expanse of outer space. The developers have managed to transform the game dramatically, turning a modest initial release into a massive and captivating project. Thanks to ongoing updates and the addition of new features, the game has evolved into a unique world full of possibilities and mysteries that continue to astonish players. "No Man's Sky" offers expansive cosmic landscapes to explore, a rich and diverse galaxy, and engaging gameplay that captivates and retains players' attention for hours on end.
space :)

It is hard to recommend No Man's Sky in 2023 (without context) though it has a better value proposition than Bethesda's Starfield.
 
While the amount of content on offer is great and there is a compelling game loop of exploration, the game is an aggressively disjointed game with an indie dev feel with many bugs and half-baked features. It would be one thing if the game was in Early Access but it was released in 2016. 

The space travel system, with no obvious loading screens, delivers on what most other space/scify games have been missing. That said, the amount of pop-in/graphical glitches and hitches keeps me at arms length in terms of immersion. 

Unlike Bethesda's empty worlds, there are generally a lot of points/objects of interest that keep me wanting to explore over the next hill. These points and objects lose their value to the player over time.

The language system is novel and appreciated but often feels a bit under utilized and disregarded when inconvenient.

One third of the game is spent in the inventory system shuffling around resources, recharging meters and flipping between other inventory screens. (Thankfully storage of resources becomes a non-issue rather early on) It feels as if most of this grind was added to make all the resources be more useful. 

The combat system is a cruel joke in almost every regard. The main antagonists being able to heal/repair throughout combat being insult to injury. The space combat is as simple as "hold down the fire button until the ship goes boom." However enemy freighter battles can be more interesting... if rare.   

Ship customization is basically nonexistent and requires the player to roll the RNG dice at shipping docks in hopes of finding their "perfect" ship. This feels like a major missed opportunity.

I almost forgot that I disabled both the sound and the music when I could no longer stand the screeching creatures and constant ships buzzing my character on the planets. 

There is too much content and various other systems in the game to cover in this written format but they all suffer in the same regards, they are half-baked, contain bugs and, generally, are not well implemented.

In conclusion, No Man's Sky might be worth a try when on sale and if you understand that there are serious issues with the game. There can be a compelling loop if you can overlook the numerous issues.

Many years ago now, I happened across this game shortly before it released and shortly before my birthday and stuck it on my birthday wishlist as a possible but risky choice. I did not get it then and I did watch the absolute drama that followed its release. I did actually like what I saw even with the failed ideas and everything else and then I saw them start to improve it. I picked it up on sale some time later and played until I hit a game breaking bug. This became a pattern for me as the game kept drawing me back in but then also kept breaking, but with each new iteration it was more stable, and less broken. Eventually, I stopped breaking the game.

There is something really magical about this game. It's still flawed and frankly it tries to do so many things now that no one system has all that much depth. The sheer number of ways you can interact with the game though are boggling now. There is a story which is frankly an existential crisis in the making. There are side stories which are basically tutorials for various systems. The main thing though is that is a giant sandbox. A whole universe for you to explore. You will see planets that no other person has ever set foot on or looked at and some of them are weird and janky but lots of them are amazing. You want it to be a space fighter? Hatch and raise your own living ship? You can do that. You want to build elaborate bases? You can do that. Establish a manufacturing empire? Become a trader? Become a smuggler? Tamper with the genetic makeup of creatures? Engage in epic firefights? Run your own village? Build a farm? Become a chef? Team up with other players to achieve your goals? Wander the universe entirely alone? Explore underwater depths filled with eldritch horrors in your submarine? Explore abandoned ships lost in space? Build racing courses to power around in your exocraft? All of this you can do and more.

And what do I do? I mostly just wander around scanning stuff, looking at all the weird and cool things. I'm still finding new things.

The relatively recent addition of entirely customisable difficulty across multiple different factors means you can pretty much tailor your experience to whatever is fun for you. Gathering materials isn't fun? No problem you can turn that off. Combat isn't your thing? Banish it. Don't want to have to fuss with making money? Sure, everything is free. OR alternatively if you want to ramp up the difficulty or the costs or the danger - you can do that too.

I will continue to keep coming back.

Amazing that they continue to work on this after the (well deserved!) backlash of too much hype, too little game at launch.

But ..

It's still a paper thin game. 
All planets are basically the same thing. The visuals are a bit different and fun for a few hours but then you kinda see past the varnish and realize they are all built from the same blueprint with very small cosmetic differences. And this matters in the long run. I don't have a problem with the lack of different biomes on single planets as this is probably programatically problematic AND prevents exploration. But the planets themselves are so boringly similar - except for some textures and color maps. Same ruins. Same platforms. Same ships flying. Same basic everything. Same same same. 
Speaking of which. All space stations ARE the same (except pirate stations that looks a bit different). And they are everywhere. With the same NPCs and same basic comodities. Same. 
Great for practicing language skills, mindnumbingly boring if you want to explore and discover NEW things. At least make the stations differnt per race or economic level or .. 

I mean .. It can be done. Elite Dangerous is gorgeous with a lot more diversity in the universe than NMS will ever have. (It's got other issues, though). 

I am sorry, I really want to like this. And I do. In small portions. Mainly the Expeditions (they should make them permanent and discoverable in-game).

But it's a shallow and hollow basebuilding game (not very good at that either, but people are amazingly creative) with a lack of depth and focus on what it should be and want to be. 
Exploration? Tech demo? Basebuilder? 
Now it's kind of bad at everything unless you glance at it quickly.

EDIT: My sentiment above stands, two years later. They add bits and pieces here and there to make it SEEM a complete "experience". Whenever I get back in I look for the changes that would make this truly enjoyable - and they never show up, unfortunately. 
It is a Dyson sphere of a game - on paper and scope huge, but in reality without depth and enough diversity in the long run to stay.. 
Some things are better of course.. Lots of textures and (nowadays) robots and actual wildlife on some planets. But it is still paper thin and gets old quickly. There is no point in exploring or trying to discovery anything. The lack of space stations in some systems in the early days was actually something I miss. TO boldly go required emergency drives or planning...
I search aimlessly for interesting things but, much like the persona you have in-game, you find yourself in an endless loop of disappointment and lackluster efforts - but every "expansion" adds a few shiny things to distract you for a short while.. Every single core feature is so barebones and lackluster you uninstall quickly. It is a shame, really.

Yes 486 hours. I was one of the people that preordered the game back in 2016 and kept it even after they offered a global refund some time later.

I must say Hello Games has definitely pulled NMS out of the gutter since the days of old. But the game is still just not for me. There are a few reasons.

A: The starship... everything. Since day one, in 2016 I have HATED the starship mechanics. Loathed them even. I have prayed to the Devs for them to announce in every update that they have overhauled the flight controls. NMS literally has the least realistic flight control mechanics out of all the space games I own.

B: I am rapidly transiting over to mostly VR gaming. I figured after nearing a year of VR I would give NMS another shot. I was disappointed to say the least. NMS is NOT optimized for VR. I have a decent graphics card that has been great with all my other titles. But not NMS. I noticed warbling in the background and refresh delays in my peripheral vision AT ALL TIMES. Not cool. And here I feel the need to once again talk about flight mechanics. Am I meant to be driving a bloody forklift!? The controls are literally that of a forklift. It felt just as clumsy as one. The instant motion sickness isn't necessarily the games fault, but I feel like realistic ship controls would have really helped.

C: This is probably the least important point I'll make here... but anyone who was psyched into preordering the game may understand. The planets, environments, and especially the fauna are BORING! In my opinion they have still failed to capture the wonder, diversity, liveliness, and beauty of the ecosystems shown in Sean Murray's original trailer. 

TL:DR
Im a bitter preorder survivor that has clung to the game in the hopes they'd make everything about the starship more realistic and less airplane with ball and chain. Now in VR its not optimized and a poor port.

I think it is hard to express how impressed I am with No Man's Sky, considering the public reputation it had when it launched 7 years ago. I heard the stories of how it was slowly redeeming itself as the years passed, but trying the game in late 2023 was worth the experience.

No Man's Sky is the ultimate casual experience for people who want a relaxing and expansive Science Fiction game. The game feels infinite, and worth exploring. The game focuses strongly on the experience of exploration, and being a traveler in an in-game universe that truly feels infinite.

The procedural generation running the game makes the game have a shockingly small installation size considering the scope of the game, and it makes a lot of the game follow predictable patterns. However, what I have found amusing, is when the game bugs out and planets that are procedurally generated becomes uniquely shaped by the bugs. Inverse mountains? Check. Discovering funny named planets? Check. Planets colliding with other planets, having two different forms of gravity? Check and check.

No Man's Sky is probably my best gameplay experience of 2023. After 300 hours of playing it intensely, I need a break... but I know I will come back for future patches, expeditions and the like. I did not finish everything there was to do, but I am happy, because that gives me worthwhile goals upon my inevitable return.

....and that is the beauty of No Man's Sky. When you've bought the game, it is yours to play forever, making it a game absolutely worth buying on a sale.

Decent game after all the updates
Starfield wishes it had an ounce of the fun and creativity this game brings. One of gaming's greatest redemption arcs.

Pros
- Beautiful and eye catching game, colourful, scenic, the space is amazing.
- Space travel is so cool, the "open worldness" of the game is hugely vast and spectacular.
- Great game-play and concept, can't get bored easily.

Cons
- The walking is bugged a little bit especially walking up through the mountains sideways. REALLY need to fix the movement in this game, feels like a game that just started its early access.
- I expected better graphics but not a big deal.
- Optimization is crap. Could hardly get 60FPS Ultra on my 1060 6GB.

Conclusion
Overall, worth buying. It's a great game to spend some time on and explore the vast cosmos. Needs some improvements and hopefully we will get that.

Okay so didnt know if I should buy this game or Starfield...  After reading a decent amount of reviews on Starfield which always seemed to reference back to NMS, and talking to most of my gamer friends, the consensus was to just buy No Man's Sky (Sorry Bethesda!! I still love you..). Now I got the game after the update (which I guess made it awesome) so I would say this - NMS imo is definitely the game to buy FIRST.  Its BA. Its like if Destiny, Borderlands, and Minecraft all banged and then the doctor asked ChatGPT for the name of this beautiful baby. Its not ultra hyper-realistic (which is what I imagine Starfield to be like) so its got a little more give in its universe to allow for some liberties to be taken and its content to be maybe not so dry ?? NMS offers a huge helping of both fantasy and realism, a proper scale in customizations and the ability to upgrade virtually your entire environment while still leaving certain aspects of the game to chance (multi-tool, sharship, freighter, etc). Here was was my gameplan and so far, so GREAT! Im going to let Starfield work out all the kinks for a while n then buy it on sale later on and by that time I should be ready to graduate from NMS haha. Although i just passed 100 hrs into this game and no signs of slowing down... would highly recommend!! this game is a blast thru intergalactic sci-fi and contains super nerd features like the ability to name your own planets as they become discovered in the NMS universe aka exacty the kind of space $#!+ I was looking for ;) Nice Job NMS **Also got it 1/2 off during a holiday promo add it if you see it tht low or more again

Owned and checked in on it since day 1 launch.
Still unremarkable in every way.

Flying a ship feels the same as every other ship.  
They differ only in backpack size and what you place in the backpack. 
1 doesn't go any faster or accelerate quicker than they other. 
There are no advantages/disadvantages to choosing one over another.
You can modify each one to have the same amount of backpack slots. 
You can not crash into the surface, your ship is a bumper car, the entire universe is filled with asteroids. 
Space environs are stale and pastel-washed mediocrity in literal infinite repetition. 
Combat both on foot and space feels as strategic and simplistic as the Galaga classic and equally as unfulfilling/boring.

Player movement feel like your character is running in peanut-butter.
Ship movement feels more like a camera panning around in space.  
There is no sense of speed as every single ship goes the same speed. 

Base building is ok but implemented without any reasoning within the game-loop.  It's an after effect.  Why build a base?  Whats it do?  What happens?  Nothing.  Nothing happens.   It's a place to keep a teleporter for if you want to revisit a galaxy you left. 


The story...vague.
Actually all narrative around this game is tediously vague. 
AI or NPCs are little more than self-moving text prompts you must ask for word translations. 
There is no engagement in this game.  
You are simply an observer to what is a mud-puddle pretending to be the Sky. 

It's like an illusion of a game. 
The illusion is only enjoyable until you notice why it's a trick.

Still no good. Yes, this game has too much potential, but no. Down vote for this game still.
Reason:
Too many main quest bugs: Game breaking bugs spread over your main story line, and for me I ran into 2 of those bugs. One for cannot locate Artemis, the other is I cannot end The Purge Quest. There were countless small bugs but meh, not as critical as those 2. Those 2 bugs directly made me to abandon this game, because, it wont allow me to play it. I CANNOT PLAY IT.

Another reason is for the online discovery service and single player network bugs: WHY THE F I HAVE TO WAIT FOR HOURS FOR THE ONLINE DISCOVERY SERVICE TO GO CONNECTED SO I CAN UPLOAD MY DISCOVERIES? Many times, I tried to reach some solar sys as fast as I can so I can rename the system, some good ones near the center of a galaxy, but I reached over there and found my online discovery service is disconnected. FINE, I waited, for 3 hours, then FINALLY the service is green again, just to find the system has been claimed by other players. This is pure b u l l s h i t. Why use such a broken service while the original goal of this online discovery function is to give the chance of the first discoveries can be renamed as a reward for those who discovered it? why not just shut the function down? while some players maybe lucky enough to connect to the wooden server HG have for online discovery service, other players just cannot do anything about it, since when discovery is only the race of who got the best connection but not who reached there first? PIECE OF JOKE.

EDIT: today I tried with my friend, he can still upload and overwrite my discoveries even when I uploaded them while it says I was connected to the online discovery system. And he was connected to the bloody fking piece of joke service also.

Im just so disappointed about this, so disappointed. The original goal was to allow the first player reached the system to get the right to name the system or other discoveries by his will, this is AWESOME. And means a lot. And I LOVE IT.
But the bloody online discovery service server just ruined ALL what the game could be. 

And when I play with my friends I love the online play function, it IS GREAT, but, then I want to solo play I turned off the online function and STILL, OTHER RANDOM PLAYERS I DON'T KNOW KEEPS ENTERING MY GAME, AND CLAIM MY DISCOVERIES.

Last is that for other language support for non-English speakers, there is just simply none, crappy translate, and none English speakers CANNOT name their discoveries with their own language. Only English letters accepted. For real?
 
EVEN in game, your game encourage players to learn the 3 different race’s culture and language. 


Bye. and gtfo.

I adore this game.
I know it's a meme to say, but sincerely, I bought this game for 50% off after trying Starfield and being disappointed.
In a world where procedural generation is often thought of as an evil cash grab, I think this game is one of many potential good examples to use procedural generation to create a genuinely engaging gameplay loop, and without microtransactions!

No Man's Sky really puts you in the shoes of being a space explorer, allowing you to discover new technology, new planets and new resources that open more possibilities to make your journey across space feel like a power fantasy of making any planet, no matter how dangerous, a place you can call home, and I love it.

Also the ability to find crashed and broken ships, lay claim to them, repair them and add them to your collection? Truly one of my favorite things about the game - any game that lets you collect different vehicles has an automatic win!
If there's one good thing to come out of Starfield's release, then it's that it made me truly appreciate just how good No Man's Sky really is.

I'm told that I should be thankful for not having played earlier iterations of this game.  Be that as it may, I do love this game in its current state.  I love it for its flexibility.  Depending on my mood, I can pursue main missions and explore the game's lore.  I can do some exploring.  I can craft a cool new base.  I can engage in unrelenting combat.  I can do this with friends or I can do it alone.  There's value in playing short pickup games of an hour, or in marathon eight-hour sessions that stretch into the wee hours of the morning.

Para mi es un juegazo que mezcla la exploracion espacial con la exploracion planetaria. Tienes misiones, comercio, combate... Los planetas estan muy poblados de criaturas y vegetacion (aunque no todos, ya que te encuentras algunos que estan congelados, deserticos, que son parte del planeta agua...). Hay multitud de elementos e items distintos (algunos por ejemplo para recargar herramientas o partes de la nave, como la herramienta de minado o el asistente de hipervelocidad). Hay muchas formas de conseguir estos materiales y no todos los planetas o asteroides tienen los mismos elementos. Por ejemplo si quieres Carbono tendras que eliminar un arbol (u otro elemento que te ponga el escaner que tiene carbono). Tambien puedes crear tu propia base e ir evolucionando el arbol de investigacion para tener nuevos elementos (como paneles solares, interruptores, portal de teletransporte...).

Me sorprende como desde el dia 1 que salio el videojuego los desarrolladores no han parado de meter contenido y expansiones totalmente gratuitas. Eso es algo que hay que remarcar, por supuesto.

En mi opinion, lo recomiendo si te gusta el genero de exploracion espacial y planetaria.

No Man's Sky is a difficult game to review. I cannot remember a game that is both so good and so bad at the same time. It's a science fiction Minecraft with a difficulty level that hovers around a match 4 game, yet it has an outstanding, even moving, storyline. The developers have continued to support the game after many years, but much of the support to the game consists of throwing in new systems on top of old systems with little heed for their interaction. The list of brilliant ideas in the game - planet exploration, fleet actions, language acquisition - is also the list of things that are infuriating about the game due to their implementation.

The plot is sort of the exemplar of that. The main plot is also, somewhat, the tutorial, which is a sound way to do things, particularly for a game with a sandbox-focus, and doubly so because of plot reasons that get into spoiler territory. But as a tutorial, it's pretty ill-formed, doing the thing where it teaches you concepts that you had to already understand to get to the point where you're supposed to learn them. Most (not all) of the plot motion consists of no player agency other than pressing a 'continue plot' button, giving question to why you have to put it in the first place. It was great, not novel by any means but getting into some great both old and new sci-fi territory, but it was painful to get through.

The things that I think that the game brings to the table that are somewhat unique and well-executed are the way multi-player works, which, even at best, remains somewhat iffy because multi-player is inherently so, and the sort of shuffling around components for different effects, which is fun, but tends to be only a midgame thing, or at least with slot expansions becoming more common it becomes a much different sort of task. 

It's the kind of game where you can lose two hours of your life to a Skinner box that feels like it arises more out of a lack of QoL improvements to the game, only to then trip and fall into a sense of wonder when something wild happens, only for it to be erased by that same amazing thing repeating itself. 

In short, buy it on sale.
